events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Manchester City and Fulham at the Etihad Stadium!
City are looking to maintain their perfect start to the season and return to the top of the table with another win here today. They've already beaten Burnley, Newcastle United and Sheffield United in the league, as well as adding the Super Cup to their trophy cabinet since the season started. As for Fulham, they started their campaign with a victory, beating Everton 1-0 on the opening day, before losing to Brentford and snatching a late draw at Arsenal last weekend. They come into this game on the back of a penalty shootout win against Tottenham, which saw them through to the EFL Cup third round in midweek.
MANCHESTER CITY (4-2-3-1): Ederson; Kyle Walker, Ruben Dias, Manuel Akanji, Nathan Ake; Rodri, Mateo Kovacic; Phil Foden, Julian Alvarez, Jeremy Doku; Erling Haaland.
SUBS: Sergio Gomez, Scott Carson, Matheus Nunes, Rico Lewis, Stefan Ortega, Josko Gvardiol, Oscar Bobb, Kalvin Phillips, Bernardo Silva.
FULHAM (4-3-3): Bernd Leno; Kenny Tete, Issa Diop, Tim Ream, Antonee Robinson; Tom Cairney, Harrison Reed, Andreas Pereira; Harry Wilson, Raul Jimenez, Bobby De Cordova-Reid.
SUBS: Adama Traore, Timothy Castagne, Calvin Bassey, Willian, Rodrigo Muniz, Carlos Vinicius, Tyrese Francois, Luke Harris, Marek Rodak.
There's no Pep Guardiola on the sidelines after his back surgery, and there are three changes to the City side that eventually got the better of Sheffield United last time out. Doku comes in to make his debut, with Akanji and Foden also being brought in. Gvardiol and Silva both drop to the bench, while Jack Grealish misses out due to a thigh problem. New signing Nunes is on the bench after joining the club on Friday.
Marco Silva is back on the touchline after serving a ban, and he makes four changes from Fulham's EFL Cup game against Spurs in midweek. Leno is back in goal, with Pereira, Wilson and Jimenez also coming in. Rodak, Traore and Muniz start on the bench, as do Bassey and Willian as they return from suspension and injury respectively. Joao Palhinha is not in the squad after his proposed move to Bayern Munich fell through on deadline day.
City have won their last 14 meetings with Fulham in all competitions – among Premier League/Football League clubs in competitive English football history, only the Citizens themselves have had a longer winning run against an opponent (15 against Watford).
The teams are out on the pitch now, with kick-off just moments away!
Haaland gets the game under way for City!
City are dominating all of the early possession here as they knock it around in front of Fulham. The visitors are pressing high, but they can't get close to them at the moment.
Walker decides to go for a more direct route this time, sending it long to Alvarez. It bounces off his shin out to Foden, but he is muscled off the ball by De Cordova-Reid, who looks to break.
Haaland drops deep to get on the ball and knocks it on to Kovacic so that he can make a run into the box. It's swept out to Ake so he can swing a cross in, but it's too deep for the Norwegian.
Robinson steps in to cut out a sloppy pass from Akanji, and Fulham have the chance to play out from the back. They neatly work it out to the right side, but Cairney's run is blocked off by Kovacic.
It's a great switch from Reed, and although there's too much on it for Cairney, the touch off his chest helps it to De Cordova-Reid. He curls a delightful cross into the box, and Akanji gets a vital touch to take it away from Jimenez.
After winning back-to-back matches at the Etihad in April 2008 and April 2009, Fulham are winless in their last 12 visits to City in all competitions (drawn two, lost 10). They have lost the last nine in a row by an aggregate score of 27-2.
Cairney has gone down in the middle of the field off the ball and he requires treatment on his knee. The medical team is on, and Silva is readying a substitute in case it is needed.
Cairney shakes his head as he makes his way off the pitch after treatment. He goes straight down the tunnel as Harris replaces him.
It's another sloppy pass from Akanji as he gifts the ball to De Cordova-Reid, and Fulham flood forward. The Jamaican cannot pick out Pereira's run down the right though, and the hosts soon have possession back.
Both teams have struggled to keep hold of the ball in the last few minutes, and Fulham win it back once more. Robinson drives down the left before trying to drill in a cross, but it's blocked by Doku.
Fulham are starting to enjoy themselves here and they're playing it brilliantly through midfield. When it's knocked back to Diop, he lifts it over the top for Wilson, but he gets sandwiched between the two City centre-backs.
City are just upping the pressure now and Rodri chips it over the top for Foden, who has space on the right. He drills it across the six-yard box first time, but nobody is in there for the hosts.
Doku does really well to get the better of Tete down the left and he clips a cross to the far post from the byline. Foden's first touch is a good one, but Robinson steps in to take it off him before he can get a shot away.
What a run from Foden! It's laid off to him by Alvarez down the right and he weaves his way towards goal through a crowded box. Leno thinks he's going to shoot so rushes off his line, but it's squared to Haaland instead, and Diop puts his laces through the clearance.
City have found their rhythm now and they're switching it from left to right and back again with confidence. Fulham are staying compact, though, and making it hard for them to work it through the middle.
ALVAREZ SCORES! It's been coming in the last few minutes, and they've finally opened up Fulham! It's a brilliant throughball from Kovacic into Haaland, and Diop just gets caught wrong side. The Norwegian unselfishly squares it into the middle to pick out Alvarez, who is left with a simple tap-in. 1-0 City!
Haaland has had a fairly quiet game so far, but he times his run perfectly this time to get in behind and sets up his team-mate.
REAM EQUALISES! Fulham weren't behind for long! They quickly work it upfield from the restart and win themselves a corner, which is swung into the box by Pereira. Jimenez peels away at the near post to strike it on the volley, and Ederson gets a hand to it. The ball bounces straight to Ream, who taps it in right on the line. 1-1!
Fulham win a free-kick this time, and Pereira delivers another set-piece into the box. City only half-clear their lines, and when it's put back into the area, Walker scrambles to get it away.
City are struggling to regain their momentum after the Fulham equaliser. They're still looking to use their wide players, but they can't find a way through the visitors' high press.
Reed sends it long once more, and Wilson makes a great run down the right and looks to have gotten the better of Dias. He breezes past him, but the defender recovers well to stop him from getting a sight of goal.
Rodri couldn't get back to stop De Cordova-Reid, and he just pushed the forward off the ball. He's shown the first yellow card of the game.
It's a really poor challenge from Diop as he stretches over the ball and steps on Doku's foot. He also goes into the referee's book.
Foden's free-kick is hit straight into the wall and Tete made the block, but is now down holding his head. He goes through the checks with the medical team, and he'll be able to carry on.
Walker picks out Alvarez in space and he looks to play Foden in behind once more. Robinson reads it well, though, and steps in to cut it out.
Robinson surges forward after intercepting the pass to Foden, but a heavy touch takes it away from him. He crashes into Akanji before he can slow down, taking the defender out, and receives a yellow card for it.
AKE SCORES! City have a goal right before the break! Foden whips a brilliant corner into the box and Ake has a completely free header on the penalty spot. He thumps his header back towards the near post and it bounces into the bottom corner. After a VAR check to see if Akanji, in an offside position, is obstructing Leno, the goal stands. 2-1 City!
It's a wonderful delivery from Foden on the corner and he spots Ake in acres of space in the middle of the box.
Akanji jumps out of the way of Ake's header as it bounces into the ground, and it's not until it clears the defender that Leno dives. It does look like he was blocking the keeper's view, but VAR doesn't see it that way, and the goal will stand.
Fulham are absolutely furious that Ake's goal stands, and they're crowding the referee as the protests continue. Silva is also venting his frustrations from the sidelines, and the referee is giving them a moment to calm down before the game restarts.
HALF-TIME: MANCHESTER CITY 2-1 FULHAM
City score just before half-time to take a 2-1 lead into the break over Fulham. The first 30 minutes of the game were tight, with neither side managing to create a single chance. Alvarez actually scored with the first shot of the game on the half-hour mark, tapping in Haaland's low cross. Just two minutes later, Fulham were level once more as Ream latched onto the loose ball after Ederson saved Jimenez's volley. In stoppage time, Ake thumped in a header from a corner, and after a VAR check to see if Akanji was blocking Leno, it controversially stood.
City haven't been at their high-flying best, but despite creating very little in front of goal, they have scored with both of their shots on target. They'll be looking to provide a bigger threat after the break. Fulham need to use half-time to regain their composure after the frustration of that second City goal. They've played well, though, and Silva will feel that they can get something out of this game.
Fulham get us under way for the second half!
Fulham are looking to make a quick start to the second half as it's played long to De Cordova-Reid. He beats Walker for pace before playing a one-two with Jimenez. When it comes back to him, his first-time effort from long range is fired high over the bar.
Walker gets his head down and drives down the right to get on the end of Kovacic's pass over the top. He knocks it down for Haaland, but he can't get it out of his feet before Ream gets across to him.
City are seeing a lot of the ball in the opening exchanges of the second half here, but they're struggling to get it into the box. It's played down the left for Haaland this time, but he's shrugged off it by Tete.
De Cordova-Reid isn't happy about something, and his protests see him get booked for dissent.
City are unbeaten in their last 46 Premier League matches when leading at half-time (won 43, drawn three), dating back to May 2021 against Brighton and Hove Albion, when they lost 3-2.
HAALAND SCORES! City pass it straight through the middle of Fulham as Rodri slides in Alvarez, who touches it towards the edge of the D. Ream sticks out a leg to try and cut it out, but instead helps it into Haaland's path. He's through on goal and makes no mistake as he slots it past Leno into the back of the net. 3-1 City!
Fulham look to make a quick response once more. It's sent long over the top by Ream for Jimenez, and he checks back at the byline to lose Ake and pick out Harris. He wasn't expecting it, and it bounces off him into Ederson's gloves.
The visitors have everyone sitting back in their own half as City continue to pass it around in front of them. De Cordova-Reid eventually decides to press, but they still can't get near the ball.
Wilson cuts out a loose pass by Akanji and knocks it out to Jimenez on the right before bursting into the box. The Welshman is screaming for it to be played back to him, but Ake gets across to stop that from happening.
CHANCE! Rodri threads it through the middle, and this time he picks out Haaland. His first thought is to play Alvarez through on goal, and his first-time shot from a tight angle is blocked by Diop.
City are still dominating possession here, and it's all in their own half as they knock it comfortably around Fulham's high press.
PENALTY TO CITY! It's a wonderful pass over the top to pick out Alvarez, who has acres of space ahead of him. He chests it down before running into the box and gets a nudge in the back from Diop, which sends him tumbling to the ground. The referee points to the spot.
Pereira isn't happy with that penalty being awarded and his protests see him become the second Fulham player booked for dissent in this game.
HAALAND SCORES! It's a brilliant penalty from the Norwegian! He puts last week's penalty miss behind him as he goes for power here today. Leno dives the wrong way, but he wouldn't have gotten near it anywhere as he rifles it into the left side of the net. 4-1 City!
Fulham can't get out of their own half at the moment, and City's high press is making things difficult for them. Jimenez tries to hold it up as he waits for support on the halfway line, but Dias steps in to nick it off him.
There's a double change for Fulham here. Tete is the first to go off, with Castagne coming on in his place to make his debut for the club.
De Cordova-Reid also makes way as Willian replaces him.
GREAT SAVE! Fulham aren't giving up yet, and Pereira bundles his way into the box before being shrugged off it by Dias. It bounces through the Jimenez, who hits the shot first time. It deflects off Ake's legs and Ederson stretches to tip it wide of the post.
City's first change is a double one. Rodri is taken off for Silva.
And Doku's debut comes to an early end as Gomez is brought on for him.
Silva tracks back to stop Wilson's driving run and picks up a yellow card just minutes after coming onto the field.
Haaland has reached 50 goal involvements (41 goals, nine assists) in just 39 appearances in the Premier League, breaking Andrew Cole's record (43 games) to become the fastest player to do so in the competition.
Fulham are making another double change here. Jimenez goes off for Muniz.
Traore also comes on to replace Wilson.
Fulham look tired as they chase City's passes around inside their own half, and they can't get close to the hosts. Foden sweeps it out to Walker on the right and he swings a cross into the box, but Ream beats Haaland to it.
Phillips is being given a rare chance as he comes on in place of Kovacic.
Gomez gets the better of Castagne, and the loose ball rolls to Phillips, who hooks it towards Alvarez at the far post. Leno watches it all the way to pluck it out of the air.
City may not be pushing forward with as much intent, but they're still causing Fulham problems here. Walker tries to push his way past Robinson into the box, but the American stands his ground to stop him.
City's final change is a double one. Alvarez is making way for Lewis.
Bobb also makes his senior debut for the club as he replaces Foden.
City are happy to just keep possession deep in their own half now as they look to see out the rest of stoppage time with their three-goal cushion.
Fulham committed a lot of bodies forward this time and it leaves City with space to counter into. It's threaded forward for Bobb, who is urged to shoot by the home fans, but he dawdles over it and the chance gets away from him.
HAT-TRICK! Haaland scores his third goal of the game! Fulham can't get close to City as they work it down the left and Gomez jinks past Castagne to pull it back from the byline. Haaland is left in space near the penalty spot and he hits the shot first time, drilling it low past Leno into the bottom corner. 5-1 City!
It's a great run by Gomez down the left as he weaves between the Fulham players to create space for himself to pull the ball back to Haaland.
FULL-TIME: MANCHESTER CITY 5-1 FULHAM
Haaland's hat-trick helps City to a 5-1 win to Fulham as their perfect start to the season continues. The game took a little while to get going before Alvarez scored with the first shot of the game on the half-hour mark. Just two minutes later though, Fulham were level as Ream latched onto Ederson's save to tap in from close range. On the stroke of half-time, Ake controversially put City back ahead after VAR deemed Akanji wasn't blocking Leno's view from an offside position. All three second-half goals came courtesy of Haaland, slotting in two well-taken finishes on either side of a penalty, which Alvarez won after being bundled over by Diop.
City make it four wins from four and they go back to the top of the table before the international break. They travel to unbeaten West Ham in two weeks' time. Fulham are now winless in three and will be looking to turn things around against Luton Town next time out.
That's all for today, goodbye!
summary: Referee: Stuart Attwell. Assistants: Con Hatzidakis, James Mainwaring. Fourth official: Anthony Taylor. VAR: Darren England. Assistant VAR: Neil Davies.

Bobb also makes his senior debut for the club as he replaces Foden.
City are happy to just keep possession deep in their own half now as they look to see out the rest of stoppage time with their three-goal cushion.
Team_10 committed a lot of bodies forward this time and it leaves City with space to counter into. It's threaded forward for Bobb, who is urged to shoot by the home fans, but he dawdles over it and the chance gets away from him.
HAT-TRICK! Haaland scores his third goal of the game! Team_10 can't get close to City as they work it down the left and Gomez jinks past Castagne to pull it back from the byline. Haaland is left in space near the penalty spot and he hits the shot first time, drilling it low past Leno into the bottom corner. 5-1 City!
It's a great run by Gomez down the left as he weaves between the Team_10 players to create space for himself to pull the ball back to Haaland.
FULL-TIME: Team_13 5-1 Team_10
Haaland's hat-trick helps City to a 5-1 win to Team_10 as their perfect start to the season continues. The game took a little while to get going before Alvarez scored with the first shot of the game on the half-hour mark. Just two minutes later though, Team_10 were level as Ream latched onto Ederson's save to tap in from close range. On the stroke of half-time, Ake controversially put City back ahead after VAR deemed Akanji wasn't blocking Leno's view from an offside position. All three second-half goals came courtesy of Haaland, slotting in two well-taken finishes on either side of a penalty, which Alvarez won after being bundled over by Diop.
City make it four wins from four and they go back to the top of the table before the international break. They travel to unbeaten Team_19 in two weeks' time. Team_10 are now winless in three and will be looking to turn things around against Team_12 next time out.
That's all for today, goodbye!"]
label: Exciting

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League clash between Everton and Arsenal at Goodison Park.
The Toffees have just one point to their name after four Premier League games, with a 2-2 draw at Sheffield United last time out their only positive result amid a torrid start. Everton sit in the relegation zone of the embryonic Premier League table after the international break, with Sean Dyche desperately searching for improvements.
Arsenal may have needed the international break to calm down from their last-gasp 3-1 win over Manchester United in their previous league outing. Declan Rice and Gabriel Jesus struck late in a controversial, VAR-filled encounter at Emirates Stadium, to record the Gunners’ third win in four top-flight games this term. The only blemish on their record came in a 2-2 home draw with Fulham.
EVERTON (4-4-1-1): Jordan Pickford; Ashley Young, James Tarkowski, Jarrad Braithwaite, Vitalii Mykolenko; Dwight McNeil, Idrissa Gueye, Amadou Onana, Arnaut Danjuma; Abdoulaye Doucoure; Beto.
SUBSTITUTES: Joao Virginia, Nathan Patterson, Michael Keane, Dominic Calvert-Lewin, Ben Godfrey, Youssef Chermiti, James Garner, Lewis Dobbin, Tyler Onyango.
ARSENAL (4-3-3): David Raya; Ben White, William Saliba, Gabriel Magalhaes, Oleksandr Zinchenko; Martin Odegaard, Declan Rice, Fabio Vieira; Bukayo Saka, Eddie Nketiah, Gabriel Martinelli.
SUBSTITUTES: Aaron Ramsdale, Gabriel Jesus, Emile Smith Rowe, Jakub Kiwior, Takehiro Tomiyasu, Leandro Trossard, Jorginho, Reiss Nelson, Kai Havertz.
Dyche makes only two alterations to his starting line-up that managed a point at Sheffield United last time out. Garner and Patterson drop to the bench, with McNeil and Mykolenko preferred for Everton. The introduction of the Ukraine full-back will likely see Young switch sides and start at right-back. Beto, signed from Udinese, makes his home debut for the Toffees, too.
Mikel Arteta opts for just two changes from his last starting XI, although one of them will catch the headlines for the Gunners. Usual first-choice goalkeeper Ramsdale drops to the bench for Raya to make his Arsenal debut, while Vieira comes in for Havertz, who is also named among the substitutes. Nketiah gets the nod to lead the line, despite Jesus returning to fitness and scoring late on in his last game.
Both of Everton's Premier League home games this season have been 1-0 defeats. Only three times in their league history have they lost each of their first three at Goodison Park (1958-59, 2005-06 and 2008-09), while among those only in 2005-06 did they fail to score a single goal. Can Dyche’s side improve? We’re about to find out as kick-off is almost upon us...
Referee Simon Hooper gets this game under way! Nketiah with the first touch.
Everton don't manage to get a foot on the ball for the opening minute as Arsenal probe through midfield. However, Young steps in to intervene inside his own area before the Gunners assume control once more.
An early corner comes on the right-hand side for the visitors as Saka crosses towards the near post, where Tarkowski rises highest to head clear and out for a throw-in.
A deft touch from Nketiah almost releases Odegaard but Pickford races off his line to smash a clearance long up the pitch. If the first five minutes are anything to go by, it could be a long game for the hosts.
Martinelli takes up an unusually deep and central position before failing to find Zinchenko with a simple pass, offering Everton their first real spell of possession. The Toffees show little interest in getting forward, though, as their defenders see most of the ball.
Saka looks to sneak in behind onto an Odegaard throughball but Branthwaite is alert and turns behind for a corner. The Arsenal and England winger whips it towards the far post, where Everton eventually deflect it behind for another set-piece.
OVER! Arsenal work a short-corner routine out to Zinchenko, who finds Vieira in space inside the Everton area. The Gunners playmaker aims to curl a right-footed effort towards goal but gets it all wrong and slices well over the target.
Arsenal have scored more goals from corners than any other Premier League side since the start of last season (15). However, their three set-piece chances have underwhelmed thus far.
Branthwaite sells Pickford short with a poor pass back to the Everton goalkeeper, who is caught late by Nketiah after clearing down the left-hand side. The Arsenal striker escapes without punishment, as do the Toffees despite their centre-back's lapse in concentration.
Branthwaite's long diagonal pass is easily dealt with by Zinchenko before Mykolenko covers well at the other end to deal with the onrushing Saka. This game is yet to truly settle as both sides are sizing one another up.
Saka makes a mockery of Mykolenko before Odegaard is crowded out by a sea of blue Everton shirts. A lunge by Doucoure on Rice offers Arsenal a free-kick in the middle of the pitch, although Nketiah is caught needlessly offside soon after.
White hangs a delicate right-wing cross towards the back post but Vieira miscues a volley and ends up clearing for Everton, who are pinned back inside their own third and struggling to find a way out.
GOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOALLLL! 1-0 ARSENAL! The Gunners deal an early blow to silence Goodison Park. Nketiah touches back for Vieira, who plays a killer throughball for the run of Martinelli down the left-hand side. The Brazil winger makes it into the area before curling a pinpoint right-footed finish into the bottom-right corner. However, the VAR is going to take a look at this one…
NO GOAL! The score remains 0-0. Martinelli's expert finish is ruled out after a VAR review. Nketiah had strayed offside in the initial build-up phase after Gabriel's clearance, proving the latter pass from Vieira to Martinelli as redundant. The first play of the ball appeared to come off Beto, but the VAR and the on-pitch officials have made their minds up!
There's still some confusion on the Arsenal bench surrounding their disallowed goal. Gabriel's pass forward to Nketiah appeared to come off Beto, although the Gunners striker was adjudged to be offside. Mykolenko also seemed to be playing Nketiah onside, but regardless, Everton remain level!
Martinelli, who has just had a goal ruled out, is forced off with injury as Trossard comes on to take his place.
Goodison Park is still subdued as tensions continue to heighten on Merseyside. Dyche's hosts are yet to lay a glove on Arsenal, who have just seen a Rice shot blocked in front of goal by Branthwaite.
Tarkowski is put under needless pressure by Pickford, forcing the centre-back to hook a clearance high into the stands. Murmurs are ongoing on the touchline as Arsenal are still unconvinced by Martinelli's disallowed goal, which by all accounts looked perfectly legitimate to stand.
Beto has the chance to drive at Saliba in an isolated situation but the France centre-back is far too quick and ushers the ball out for a goal-kick. The frustration for Everton continues.
Since the start of last season, Arsenal have kept more away clean sheets than any other side in the Premier League (11). They've also won a joint league-high 13 games on the road, while only Manchester City (17) have conceded fewer goals than the Gunners (18, excluding promoted sides).
Doucoure charges into the Arsenal area and throws himself on the floor under the challenge of Saliba. Referee Hooper shakes his head and shows no interest in awarding a penalty.
SAVE! Everton are growing in confidence in the last few minutes as the Toffees break through the middle. Gueye attempts a low effort from outside the area but Raya gets down well to make a comfortable first save on his Arsenal debut.
Odegaard hovers over a right-wing free-kick before clipping towards the near post. Mykolenko does his defensive duties to head clear as Rice lurks behind him.
Zinchenko and Nketiah are on different wavelengths as the Ukraine captain threads an aimless pass straight to the onrushing Pickford. This has been a first half devoid of good chances thus far.
Vieira stays down after a stray left arm from Beto. Referee Hooper comes over and has a quiet word with the pair before play resumes with a Gunners free-kick.
Mykolenko lunges into Saka with a late tackle but referee Hooper waves play on before deciding to stop the game. It won't be an Arsenal free-kick, though, as Everton restart with a drop-ball inside their own half.
Everton have won four of their last five home league games against Arsenal (D1), including each of the last three in a row after a 1-0 win in this fixture last season. They last won four consecutively against the Gunners between March 1910 and March 1913. The Toffees are yet to get going here, however.
Arteta's side are slowly falling into the trap of awakening the moody Goodison Park crowd. Rice needlessly fells Gueye and the hosts will launch a free-kick long.
Young hoists a long pass into the area but the Arsenal defence stand firm to head clear. However, Everton are soon back on the attack before McNeil sees a hopeful long-range effort cannon into Zinchenko and away from danger.
CHANCE! Odegaard and White exchange a deft one-two to the right of Everton's area before the Arsenal full-back smashes a left-footed attempt straight into the hands of Pickford.
Dyche's side have their backs against the wall as Arsenal manoeuvre possession and look for a gap in the opposition's defence. A wayward Zinchenko pass offers Everton some respite, though.
Zinchenko disguises a clipped over-the-top pass and finds Vieira, whose attempt to pull back towards the edge of the area is thwarted by Gueye. Half-time is approaching at Goodison Park.
Vieira ghosts in behind the Toffees defence but White's long pass doesn't have the required quality to pick out the Portuguese playmaker. There will be four minutes of additional time to end this half.
BLOCK! Gueye wanders down the left flank before crossing towards McNeil, whose left-footed half-volley is blocked with a last-ditch stop by Saliba. The Everton crowd appeal for handball, but referee Hooper is not interested.
Young hacks through the back of Trossard, perhaps taking a bit of the ball with a sliding tackle. Referee Hooper deems the challenge worthy of the first yellow card, though.
Saliba goes down holding his face near the halfway line after a duel with Beto. The France centre-back is suggesting he's been caught by an elbow, although Hooper – who was perfectly positioned – demands the Arsenal defender gets back to his feet.
HALF-TIME: EVERTON 0-0 ARSENAL
A largely uneventful first half comes to an end as Everton and Arsenal are goalless at the break in their Goodison Park clash. The Gunners may feel hard done by to not be leading after Martinelli – who was later forced off with an injury – had a 19th-minute goal ruled out by the VAR. The video officials deemed Nketiah to have strayed offside in the build-up to the winger's finish, despite Gabriel's first pass appearing to come off Beto.
The messages from both sets of managers may be entirely different at the interval. Arteta will fancy Arsenal's chances if his side can move the ball with more purpose in their attempts to break their recent Goodison Park curse. Dyche, seemingly content to pack his backline and sit deep, may want to offer the Everton home supporters some more excitement after an uninspiring first-half performance.
Referee Hooper gets the second half under way as Everton take the kick-off!
Only Manchester City (56) and Tottenham (54) have scored more goals in the second half of Premier League games since the start of last season than Arsenal (52). Meanwhile, Everton have only won one of their last eight top-flight games in which they've been level at half-time (D3 L4), beating Bournemouth 1-0 at Goodison Park on the final day of last season to clinch safety.
SAVE! Arsenal come flying out the blocks in the second half as Saka sees a low cross turned away at the near post. Rice then slips through for Odegaard, whose powerful left-footed strike is parried away by a strong two-handed Pickford stop.
Gabriel is shown Arsenal’s first yellow card of the game for blocking Beto after the Everton striker knocked the ball past him.
Young's free-kick delivery is poor and Everton's tall defenders have little chance to attack it. Onana is penalised soon after for a needless pull on White inside the Gunners area.
Zinchenko takes aim from range but Tarkowski stands strong to block the left-footed effort. A brief VAR check goes on in the background for handball, but it's decided that the centre-back stopped the chance fairly with his body.
It's all one-way traffic as Arsenal push Everton back into their own area. Zinchenko and Trossard both attempt crosses but have little success against the wall of blue shirts.
CLOSE! Saka whips a pinpoint left-footed delivery towards the back post, where Trossard redirects a header back across goal. Nketiah is there and ready for a tap-in but Tarkowski and Young just about manage to clear the danger in front of Pickford's goal.
Zinchenko clips another superb pass in behind the Everton defence before the hosts scramble to deal with Trossard's low cross. A belated offside flag renders the chance irrelevant, however.
Jesus has scored eight goals in just nine Premier League appearances against Everton, more than he has against any other opponent. Indeed, the Brazilian averages a goal every 71 minutes against Everton (eight goals in 568 minutes), the best rate of any player to play 500+ minutes against the Toffees. Surely Arteta will introduce the striker soon?
Chance! Odeegard releases Nketiah through the middle of the pitch but the Arsenal striker takes an extra touch, which allows Tarkowski to recover and block behind for a corner.
Saka's first corner is cleared as far as Zinchenko, whose tame long-range effort is deflected behind once again. The Arsenal winger goes short with another set-piece before Zinchenko has another strike blocked behind for a corner.
Tarkowski's block from Zinchenko's previous shot is briefly checked for handball by the VAR before no further action is taken. Vieira will take the next corner...
Is anyone else allowed to shoot? Another Arsenal corner goes short before Zinchenko sees yet another shot dealt with by the Everton defence. Pickford eventually claims the loose ball, offering the Toffees a breather for the time being.
Arsenal have won 100 of their 204 meetings with Everton in English league football (D43 L61), the most any team has ever beaten another. The Gunners will need to up the tempo in the final 30 minutes to better that record here, though.
Vieira clumsily hauls Gueye to the floor from behind and Everton will have another chance to cross from a deep free-kick. Dyche appears to be readying Calvert-Lewin on the touchline, too.
Young takes an age over the deep free-kick before clipping towards the back post, where Tarkowski has no chance of beating Saliba and Gabriel in the air. The Brazilian centre-back stays down after the aerial duel, much to the annoyance of the Goodison Park faithful.
Arteta makes his first change as the underwhelming Nketiah makes way for Jesus.
Dyche also alters his frontline as Beto's home debut comes to an end for Calvert-Lewin to be introduced.
Only against Brentford in February earlier this year (five) has Zinchenko had more shots in a Premier League game than today against Everton (four), while all four have been from outside the penalty area, his most in a single game in the competition. The left-back will keep trying his luck, too.
A fortunate bounce allows Saka in behind Mykolenko, who recovers to concede another corner on the right-hand side. The England international takes the set-piece short to Odegaard, whose hanging cross gets cleared by Calvert-Lewin.
GOOOOOOOOOOOALLLLLLLLLLL! 1-0 ARSENAL! Back-to-back corners eventually pay dividends for the Gunners. Another short set-piece routine sees Odegaard slide to the right of the area for Saka, who pulls back a pass towards Trossard. The Belgium international guides a first-time left-footed effort past Pickford with the help of the left post. A delightful opening goal for the visitors sends the away supporters into bedlam at Goodison Park.
Saka managed to find a bit of space inside the area after Odegaard's delicate pass before cutting back to Trossard, who finished in emphatic style.
Arsenal have now had a substitute score in each of their last three league games for the first time since December 2021.
A searching long clearance from Pickford seeks out Mykolenko, who wins a left-wing corner after a block by Saliba. Everton will have another chance here.
Raya claims Everton's set-piece delivery with consummate ease before the game is briefly paused as Odegaard goes down holding his face. Play restarts at the Arsenal goalkeeper's feet.
WIDE! Odegaard offloads for White down the right flank before the Arsenal full-back hoists an inviting cross towards the far post. Vieira attempts a first-time left-footed volley that is always going wide as Pickford goes untroubled.
Both of Trossard's Premier League goals for Arsenal have been as a substitute, as many such goals as he scored for Brighton and Hove Albion in the competition. The Belgian has the Gunners on the way to victory in the final 15 minutes here.
Gabriel picks out the run of Jesus in behind the Everton defence but Mykolenko recovers excellently to dispossess the Arsenal striker. Down the other end, Gueye wildly slices a terrible right-footed strike well wide of Raya's goal.
SAVE! A defensive mix-up for Everton allows Trossard to play it through for Odegaard. The Arsenal captain has just Pickford to beat but his right-footed strike is parried away by the England goalkeeper. Vieira's follow-up effort is subsequently deflected behind for a corner, which comes to nothing.
Goodison Park rises as one in a chorus of jeers after Vieira is felled near the left-hand touchline. It looks like Arteta is going to introduce both Tomiyasu and Havertz from the bench.
Zinchenko, who has peppered Everton's goal without reward, is removed for the more defensive option of Tomiyasu at left-back.
As part of Arsenal's double change, Havertz comes on for the impressive Vieira.
Dyche also takes the chance to change things up. Garner is on for Doucoure.
It will be 4-4-2 for the remainder of this game from Everton. With respective numbers nine and 10 on their backs, Calvert-Lewin and Danjuma will be tasked with breaching Arsenal's resolute defence.
Tomiyasu is adjudged to have got too tight to Garner and Everton win a free-kick just inside their own half. Pickford will launch this one high into the Merseyside sky.
Pickford's long free-kick causes a bit of carnage inside the Arsenal box before Trossard is the unlikely defender to hook a clearance down the pitch. The Toffees are running out of time.
Trossard and Havertz combine down the left flank but the Germany international's dinked cross misses his team-mates inside the Everton area. Pickford races to get the ball for a goal-kick, as the Toffees are entering last-chance saloon territory.
Jesus appears to kick out at Tarkowski off the ball. Referee Hooper awards an Everton free-kick, but strangely does not punish the Arsenal striker further.
Dyche rolls the dice for a final time. Patterson replaces Young at right-back.
Chermiti also gets thrown into the mix as McNeil makes way.
Pickford drives another long free-kick into the Arsenal area but Tarkowski is penalised for an aerial challenge on Raya, who dropped the ball in rather unconvincing fashion.
Close! Patterson drives infield and picks out Calvert-Lewin, who pokes a poor attempt towards the far corner. Raya watches it out for a goal-kick as the fourth official indicates there will be just four minutes of additional time. Dyche and Goodison Park are rightly infuriated.
A moment of hesitation from Gabriel almost allows Chermiti to profit but the Brazil centre-back just about manages to recover in the nick of time. Arsenal can ill-afford a lapse in concentration at this late stage.
Jesus goes down holding his head after an aerial tangle with Patterson and Tarkowski. The Goodison Park faithful, as has been the case for most of the game, are up on their feet and sounding their disapproval for referee Hooper, who awards an Arsenal free-kick in the left-hand corner.
Jesus wins a last-minute corner off Tarkowski on the right-hand side, and that will surely be that for Arsenal. Arteta will finally have a victory over his former employers as a manager.
FULL-TIME: EVERTON 0-1 ARSENAL
Arsenal end a three-game losing streak at Goodison Park in the Premier League as they eventually get the better of Everton with a 1-0 win. Martinelli saw a goal ruled out after a contentious VAR review in the first half, before limping off with injury prior to the break. It was the Brazilian's replacement Trossard who proved the hero, crashing in a 69th-minute winner to grab the Gunners' fourth win in five league games to start their campaign.
These are the sort of games Arsenal failed to win amid last season's title pursuit, which ultimately unfurled as a rampant Manchester City retained their crown. The Gunners have passed this test to move up to fourth in the table, just two points behind Pep Guardiola's league leaders before European football commences in midweek. Everton, by contrast, remain without a top-flight win this season and must bounce back at Brentford next Saturday.
As Goodison Park empties with frustrated Everton supporters streaming out, the travelling Arsenal faithful serenade their battling heroes. That is all from this live coverage of a hard-fought Premier League clash. Until next time, goodbye!
summary:
Newcastle United claimed back-to-back victories, easing past Burnley 2-0 at home, with Miguel Almiron and Alexander Isak scoring the goals. 
A slip from Dan Burn almost allowed Burnley to open the scoring after only four minutes, with Nick Pope thwarting Zeki Amdouni’s shot.
Newcastle took the lead on 14 minutes as Kieran Trippier won the ball and fed Almiron, who bent a beautiful shot into the top corner to score in back-to-back matches. 
Alexander Isak had a chance to double the lead, but after the Swede’s initial shot was blocked by Trafford, the striker was unable to finish the rebound.
With 15 minutes remaining, Isak was given another chance, this time from the penalty spot after Ameen Al Dakhil fouled Anthony Gordon in the box. The Swede converted to seal Newcastle’s fourth win of the season to go eighth with 12 points. 
Burnley have only one point and are above bottom-club Sheffield United on goal difference.
Newcastle report | Burnley report
Eddie Howe: "We recovered from a shaky start. We weren't at our best for the first 10 minutes. Once we scored we were the better team.
"We were keen to learn from our recent games; when we've had the lead we haven't pushed on. I'm delighted with this win because of what happened in the build-up, the high of beating Man City and coming back to a really difficult home game." See more
Vincent Kompany: "The first eight games, City, United, Tottenham, Newcastle, Villa, Chelsea and as a newly-promoted team I’m not that naive to guess it’s not this type of start.
“But we did really well against Forest, we showed a positive performance against United and today again.
“Against Luton, everybody knows, we just want to get a result. We think we can get results against Luton, we think we can get results in the future against teams like today.” See more
Referee: Thomas Bramall. Assistants: Simon Bennett, Dan Robathan. Fourth official: Matt Donohue. VAR: Jarred Gillett. Assistant VAR: Scott Ledger.

Goodison Park is still subdued as tensions continue to heighten on Merseyside. Dyche's hosts are yet to lay a glove on Team_1, who have just seen a Rice shot blocked in front of goal by Branthwaite.
Tarkowski is put under needless pressure by Pickford, forcing the centre-back to hook a clearance high into the stands. Murmurs are ongoing on the touchline as Team_1 are still unconvinced by Martinelli's disallowed goal, which by all accounts looked perfectly legitimate to stand.
Beto has the chance to drive at Saliba in an isolated situation but the France centre-back is far too quick and ushers the ball out for a goal-kick. The frustration for Team_9 continues.
Since the start of last season, Team_1 have kept more away clean sheets than any other side in the Premier League (11). They've also won a joint league-high 13 games on the road, while only Team_13 (17) have conceded fewer goals than the Gunners (18, excluding promoted sides).
Doucoure charges into the Team_1 area and throws himself on the floor under the challenge of Saliba. Referee Hooper shakes his head and shows no interest in awarding a penalty.
SAVE! Team_9 are growing in confidence in the last few minutes as the Toffees break through the middle. Gueye attempts a low effort from outside the area but Raya gets down well to make a comfortable first save on his Team_1 debut.
Odegaard hovers over a right-wing free-kick before clipping towards the near post. Mykolenko does his defensive duties to head clear as Rice lurks behind him.
Zinchenko and Nketiah are on different wavelengths as the Ukraine captain threads an aimless pass straight to the onrushing Pickford. This has been a first half devoid of good chances thus far.
Vieira stays down after a stray left arm from Beto. Referee Hooper comes over and has a quiet word with the pair before play resumes with a Gunners free-kick.
Mykolenko lunges into Saka with a late tackle but referee Hooper waves play on before deciding to stop the game. It won't be an Team_1 free-kick, though, as Team_9 restart with a drop-ball inside their own half.
Team_9 have won four of their last five home league games against Team_1 (D1), including each of the last three in a row after a 1-0 win in this fixture last season. They last won four consecutively against the Gunners between March 1910 and March 1913. The Toffees are yet to get going here, however.
Arteta's side are slowly falling into the trap of awakening the moody Goodison Park crowd. Rice needlessly fells Gueye and the hosts will launch a free-kick long.
Young hoists a long pass into the area but the Team_1 defence stand firm to head clear. However, Team_9 are soon back on the attack before McNeil sees a hopeful long-range effort cannon into Zinchenko and away from danger.
CHANCE! Odegaard and White exchange a deft one-two to the right of Team_9 area before the Team_1 full-back smashes a left-footed attempt straight into the hands of Pickford.
Dyche's side have their backs against the wall as Team_1 manoeuvre possession and look for a gap in the opposition's defence. A wayward Zinchenko pass offers Team_9 some respite, though.
Zinchenko disguises a clipped over-the-top pass and finds Vieira, whose attempt to pull back towards the edge of the area is thwarted by Gueye. Half-time is approaching at Goodison Park.
Vieira ghosts in behind the Toffees defence but White's long pass doesn't have the required quality to pick out the Portuguese playmaker. There will be four minutes of additional time to end this half.
BLOCK! Gueye wanders down the left flank before crossing towards McNeil, whose left-footed half-volley is blocked with a last-ditch stop by Saliba. The Team_9 crowd appeal for handball, but referee Hooper is not interested.
Young hacks through the back of Trossard, perhaps taking a bit of the ball with a sliding tackle. Referee Hooper deems the challenge worthy of the first yellow card, though.
Saliba goes down holding his face near the halfway line after a duel with Beto. The France centre-back is suggesting he's been caught by an elbow, although Hooper – who was perfectly positioned – demands the Team_1 defender gets back to his feet.
HALF-TIME: Team_9 0-0 Team_1
A largely uneventful first half comes to an end as Team_9 and Team_1 are goalless at the break in their Goodison Park clash. The Gunners may feel hard done by to not be leading after Martinelli – who was later forced off with an injury – had a 19th-minute goal ruled out by the VAR. The video officials deemed Nketiah to have strayed offside in the build-up to the winger's finish, despite Gabriel's first pass appearing to come off Beto.
The messages from both sets of managers may be entirely different at the interval. Arteta will fancy Team_1 chances if his side can move the ball with more purpose in their attempts to break their recent Goodison Park curse. Dyche, seemingly content to pack his backline and sit deep, may want to offer the Team_9 home supporters some more excitement after an uninspiring first-half performance.
Referee Hooper gets the second half under way as Team_9 take the kick-off!
Only Team_13 (56) and Team_18 (54) have scored more goals in the second half of Premier League games since the start of last season than Team_1 (52). Meanwhile,\xa0Team_9 have only won one of their last eight top-flight games in which they've been level at half-time (D3 L4), beating Team_3 1-0 at Goodison Park on the final day of last season to clinch safety.
SAVE! Team_1 come flying out the blocks in the second half as Saka sees a low cross turned away at the near post. Rice then slips through for Odegaard, whose powerful left-footed strike is parried away by a strong two-handed Pickford stop.
Gabriel is shown Team_1’s first yellow card of the game for blocking Beto after the Team_9 striker knocked the ball past him.
Young's free-kick delivery is poor and Team_9 tall defenders have little chance to attack it. Onana is penalised soon after for a needless pull on White inside the Gunners area.
Zinchenko takes aim from range but Tarkowski stands strong to block the left-footed effort. A brief VAR check goes on in the background for handball, but it's decided that the centre-back stopped the chance fairly with his body.
It's all one-way traffic as Team_1 push Team_9 back into their own area. Zinchenko and Trossard both attempt crosses but have little success against the wall of blue shirts.
CLOSE! Saka whips a pinpoint left-footed delivery towards the back post, where Trossard redirects a header back across goal. Nketiah is there and ready for a tap-in but Tarkowski and Young just about manage to clear the danger in front of Pickford's goal.
Zinchenko clips another superb pass in behind the Team_9 defence before the hosts scramble to deal with Trossard's low cross. A belated offside flag renders the chance irrelevant, however.
Jesus has scored eight goals in just nine Premier League appearances against Team_9, more than he has against any other opponent. Indeed, the Brazilian averages a goal every 71 minutes against Team_9 (eight\xa0goals in 568 minutes), the best rate of any player to play 500+ minutes against the Toffees. Surely Arteta will introduce the striker soon?
Chance! Odeegard releases Nketiah through the middle of the pitch but the Team_1 striker takes an extra touch, which allows Tarkowski to recover and block behind for a corner.
Saka's first corner is cleared as far as Zinchenko, whose tame long-range effort is deflected behind once again. The Team_1 winger goes short with another set-piece before Zinchenko has another strike blocked behind for a corner.
Tarkowski's block from Zinchenko's previous shot is briefly checked for handball by the VAR before no further action is taken. Vieira will take the next corner...
Is anyone else allowed to shoot? Another Team_1 corner goes short before Zinchenko sees yet another shot dealt with by the Team_9 defence. Pickford eventually claims the loose ball, offering the Toffees a breather for the time being.
Team_1 have won 100 of their 204 meetings with Team_9 in English league football (D43 L61), the most any team has ever beaten another. The Gunners will need to up the tempo in the final 30 minutes to better that record here, though.
Vieira clumsily hauls Gueye to the floor from behind and Team_9 will have another chance to cross from a deep free-kick. Dyche appears to be readying Calvert-Lewin on the touchline, too.
Young takes an age over the deep free-kick before clipping towards the back post, where Tarkowski has no chance of beating Saliba and Gabriel in the air. The Brazilian centre-back stays down after the aerial duel, much to the annoyance of the Goodison Park faithful.
Arteta makes his first change as the underwhelming Nketiah makes way for Jesus.
Dyche also alters his frontline as Beto's home debut comes to an end for Calvert-Lewin to be introduced.
Only against Team_4 in February earlier this year (five) has Zinchenko had more shots in a Premier League game than today against Team_9 (four), while all four have been from outside the penalty area, his most in a single game in the competition. The left-back will keep trying his luck, too.
A fortunate bounce allows Saka in behind Mykolenko, who recovers to concede another corner on the right-hand side. The England international takes the set-piece short to Odegaard, whose hanging cross gets cleared by Calvert-Lewin.
GOOOOOOOOOOOALLLLLLLLLLL! 1-0 Team_1! Back-to-back corners eventually pay dividends for the Gunners. Another short set-piece routine sees Odegaard slide to the right of the area for Saka, who pulls back a pass towards Trossard. The Belgium international guides a first-time left-footed effort past Pickford with the help of the left post. A delightful opening goal for the visitors sends the away supporters into bedlam at Goodison Park.
Saka managed to find a bit of space inside the area after Odegaard's delicate pass before cutting back to Trossard, who finished in emphatic style.
Team_1 have now had a substitute score in each of their last three league games for the first time since December 2021.
A searching long clearance from Pickford seeks out Mykolenko, who wins a left-wing corner after a block by Saliba. Team_9 will have another chance here.
Raya claims Team_9 set-piece delivery with consummate ease before the game is briefly paused as Odegaard goes down holding his face. Play restarts at the Team_1 goalkeeper's feet.
WIDE! Odegaard offloads for White down the right flank before the Team_1 full-back hoists an inviting cross towards the far post. Vieira attempts a first-time left-footed volley that is always going wide as Pickford goes untroubled.
Both of Trossard's Premier League goals for Team_1 have been as a substitute, as many such goals as he scored for Team_5 and Hove Albion in the competition. The Belgian has the Gunners on the way to victory in the final 15 minutes here.
Gabriel picks out the run of Jesus in behind the Team_9 defence but Mykolenko recovers excellently to dispossess the Team_1 striker. Down the other end, Gueye wildly slices a terrible right-footed strike well wide of Raya's goal.
SAVE! A defensive mix-up for Team_9 allows Trossard to play it through for Odegaard. The Team_1 captain has just Pickford to beat but his right-footed strike is parried away by the England goalkeeper. Vieira's follow-up effort is subsequently deflected behind for a corner, which comes to nothing.
Goodison Park rises as one in a chorus of jeers after Vieira is felled near the left-hand touchline. It looks like Arteta is going to introduce both Tomiyasu and Havertz from the bench.
Zinchenko, who has peppered Team_9 goal without reward, is removed for the more defensive option of Tomiyasu at left-back.
As part of Team_1 double change, Havertz comes on for the impressive Vieira.
Dyche also takes the chance to change things up. Garner is on for Doucoure.
It will be 4-4-2 for the remainder of this game from Team_9. With respective numbers nine and 10 on their backs, Calvert-Lewin and Danjuma will be tasked with breaching Team_1 resolute defence.
Tomiyasu is adjudged to have got too tight to Garner and Team_9 win a free-kick just inside their own half. Pickford will launch this one high into the Merseyside sky.
Pickford's long free-kick causes a bit of carnage inside the Team_1 box before Trossard is the unlikely defender to hook a clearance down the pitch. The Toffees are running out of time.
Trossard and Havertz combine down the left flank but the Germany international's dinked cross misses his team-mates inside the Team_9 area. Pickford races to get the ball for a goal-kick, as the Toffees are entering last-chance saloon territory.
Jesus appears to kick out at Tarkowski off the ball. Referee Hooper awards an Team_9 free-kick, but strangely does not punish the Team_1 striker further.
Dyche rolls the dice for a final time. Patterson replaces Young at right-back.
Chermiti also gets thrown into the mix as McNeil makes way.
Pickford drives another long free-kick into the Team_1 area but Tarkowski is penalised for an aerial challenge on Raya, who dropped the ball in rather unconvincing fashion.
Close! Patterson drives infield and picks out Calvert-Lewin, who pokes a poor attempt towards the far corner. Raya watches it out for a goal-kick as the fourth official indicates there will be just four minutes of additional time. Dyche and Goodison Park are rightly infuriated.
A moment of hesitation from Gabriel almost allows Chermiti to profit but the Brazil centre-back just about manages to recover in the nick of time. Team_1 can ill-afford a lapse in concentration at this late stage.
Jesus goes down holding his head after an aerial tangle with Patterson and Tarkowski. The Goodison Park faithful, as has been the case for most of the game, are up on their feet and sounding their disapproval for referee Hooper, who awards an Team_1 free-kick in the left-hand corner.
Jesus wins a last-minute corner off Tarkowski on the right-hand side, and that will surely be that for Team_1. Arteta will finally have a victory over his former employers as a manager.
FULL-TIME: Team_9 0-1 Team_1
Team_1 end a three-game losing streak at Goodison Park in the Premier League as they eventually get the better of Team_9 with a 1-0 win. Martinelli saw a goal ruled out after a contentious VAR review in the first half, before limping off with injury prior to the break. It was the Brazilian's replacement Trossard who proved the hero, crashing in a 69th-minute winner to grab the Gunners' fourth win in five league games to start their campaign.
These are the sort of games Team_1 failed to win amid last season's title pursuit, which ultimately unfurled as a rampant Team_13 retained their crown. The Gunners have passed this test to move up to fourth in the table, just two points behind Pep Guardiola's league leaders before European football commences in midweek. Team_9, by contrast, remain without a top-flight win this season and must bounce back at Team_4 next Saturday.
As Goodison Park empties with frustrated Team_9 supporters streaming out, the travelling Team_1 faithful serenade their battling heroes. That is all from this live coverage of a hard-fought Premier League clash. Until next time, goodbye!"]
label: Normal

events:
Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the Premier League fixture between Sheffield United and Brighton at Bramall Lane.
Sheffield United currently sit in 20th place in the Premier League table, but they will be hoping to continue their momentum after picking up an impressive result last time out. The Blades defeated Luton Town 3-1 at Kenilworth Road, ending a seven-match winless streak (D2 L5). Chris Wilder’s side have conceded more goals at home in the division than any other side (31 in 12 games). In Premier League history, only West Brom have shipped more goals in their first 12 home games of the campaign (2020-21). Today, they will face a Brighton side who haven’t beaten the Blades in their last seven league fixtures, with their last victory coming back in 2005.
Brighton will be looking to turn their away form around after a tricky run of games on the road. Roberto De Zerbi’s side are winless in their last six away Premier League matches (D2 L4), their longest winless run away from the Amex Stadium since a seven-game streak under Graham Potter between September and December 2021. The Seagulls lost 2-1 against Tottenham in their previous fixture, conceding a last-minute goal with Brennan Johnson scoring the winner. Playing against the side who currently sit bottom of the Premier League could be a chance to gain some momentum, but the Blades showed plenty of fight last time out.
SHEFFIELD UNITED (5-4-1): Wes Foderingham; Yasser Larouci, Anel Ahmedhodzic, Mason Holgate, Jack Robinson, Jayden Bogle; James McAtee, Vinicius Souza, Gustavo Hamer, Ben Osborn; William Osula.
SHEFFIELD UNITED SUBS: Auston Trust, Rhian Brewster, Oliver McBurnie, Ivo Grbic, Oliver Norwood, Tom Davies, Oliver Arblaster, Andre Brooks, Billy Blacker.
BRIGHTON (3-4-2-1): Bart Verbruggen; Adam Webster, Lewis Dunk, Jan Paul van Hecke; Tariq Lamptey, Billy Gilmour, Facundo Buonanotte, Pascal Gross; Kaoru Mitoma, Simon Adingra; Danny Welbeck.
BRIGHTON SUBS: Igor Julio, Jakub Moder, Carlos Baleba, Jason Steele, Evan Ferguson, Pervis Estupinan, Ansu Fati, Joel Veltman, Benicio Baker-Boaitey.
Wilder has made two changes from Sheffield United’s 3-1 victory over Luton in their previous match. In defence, Larouci comes in for the injured Rhys Norrington-Davies and is likely to slot in at left-back. Up front, joint-top goalscorer Cameron Archer misses out, with Osula coming into the starting XI.
Meanwhile, De Zerbi has made three alterations from Brighton’s 2-1 defeat at Tottenham last time out. In goal, Steele drops out of the team and will be replaced by Verbruggen. At the back, Webster is named in the starting XI, with Estupinan dropping to the bench. Adam Lallana fails to make the squad, so Adingra will play from the beginning of the match.
The players are making their way out onto the pitch ahead of kick-off.
Gilmour gets the game under way for Brighton at Bramall Lane!
Early chance for Sheffield United! McAtee dances through the challenges of multiple Brighton defenders and creates space for himself outside the box. He turns and spots the run of Bogle inside the penalty area, before feeding the ball into his path. Bogle gets it out of his feet and takes aim towards the bottom corner, but Verbruggen gets down well to make the save.
Dunk sends a searching ball over the top looking for the run of Lamptey, but Ahmedhodzic does well to intercept. Brighton now have a throw-in in a dangerous position, but Welbeck handles the ball after play resumes. The Seagulls are dominating the possession in the early stages, as expected.
So close to a Brighton opener! Webster plays a ball into the channel which Adingra latches onto it. He shifts it onto his right and delivers low into the area towards Welbeck. Ahmedhodzic flings himself in front of the cross and it's heading towards goal, but Foderingham palms it away. The ball was inches away from creeping over the line!
Brighton keep the ball across the back line, patiently waiting for an opening. Van Hecke receives it and spots the run of Gross beyond the Sheffield United defence. Gross has burst away unmarked, but he can't quite get it under control and the ball falls to Foderingham between the sticks.
Holgate gets his marching orders! Mitoma twists and turns and drives towards the Sheffield United defence. Holgate steps out and makes a reckless challenge on the Brighton winger at knee height. The referee originally gave a yellow card, but after a quick review from VAR, he's been sent off!
There's a problem for Sheffield United now as goalkeeper Foderingham has gone down. The medical team are on the pitch and giving him treatment at the moment and there will be a short delay as he receives attention. He's now back on his feet, and it looks as though he will be able to continue.
It was always going to be a tricky game for the Blades as they fight to pick up points in their battle to climb out of the relegation zone, but an early red card for Holgate has made things a lot more difficult. Wilder has changed the shape slightly and it's certainly not ideal to have to alter their game plan in the first half.
What a chance! Mitoma and Lamptey link up on the left-hand side before the ball comes back to Dunk. He whips a dangerous cross towards Welbeck who can't quite get there, and Robinson gets an important touch at the back post with Buonanotte flying in. He was unmarked at the back, but the Sheffield United defender has put it behind for a corner.
GOOOOOOAAAAAL!! 1-0 BRIGHTON!! The corner comes into the box and is delivered to the back post. Dunk heads it back across and Buonanotte helps it towards goal. The Sheffield United defence attempts to clear it, but the ball creeps over the line. The referee checks his watch, and he's given it! The Blades will have a mountain to climb now with 10 men.
Dunk unselfishly helped the corner back across goal and Buonanotte was there to nod it home.
GOOOOAAAAALLLL!! 2-0 BRIGHTON! The Seagulls are running riot! Gross and Webster exchange passes before the former delivers towards the back post. Mitoma comes flying in and takes a shot towards goal, but Foderingham palms it out. It falls straight into the path of Welbeck, and the English striker slams the ball home to double Brighton's lead!
Brighton are continuing to push and Sheffield United are struggling to deal with wave after wave of attacks. The ball comes into the box and the Blades can't quite clear it, and it falls to Adingra who sends a volley towards goal, but it flies over the bar and out for a goal-kick. Wilder's side need to settle down and try and remain resolute at the back.
Almost a third from Brighton! Mitoma twists and turns and gets to the byline, leaving Bogle in his shadow. He strikes towards goal but his shot is blocked, before Gross and Welbeck both attempt to find a third as there's a scramble inside the box, but Sheffield United manage to clear the danger.
Wilder has decided to make a change in order to shore up his defence. Osula comes off and Sheffield United bring on a central defender, with Trusty entering the fray.
The Blades are struggling to get out of their own half at the moment, and the substitution from Wilder hints that they could be going for damage limitation in this game. They need to tighten up at the back with Brighton dominating proceedings, or it could get messy for Sheffield United.
Since the game got under way, Brighton have made 160 passes inside the opposition half, touching the ball in Sheffield United's box 17 times. The Seagulls have had 78.4 per cent of the possession and are looking comfortable, helped by Holgate's sending-off earlier in the match.
Sheffield United have looked tighter at the back since the change and are attempting to hit Brighton on the counter-attack. Osborn wins it back and looks to spot the run of McAtee who has burst forward from midfield, but his touch is a little heavy and the ball rolls through to Verbruggen.
Adingra stands up his marker and looks to float a cross towards the back post with Mitoma waiting. It's headed away but Webster chests the ball back into the feet of Adingra, who shifts it onto his right foot and strikes towards goal, but it sails over the bar and behind for a goal-kick.
Another opportunity for Brighton. Lamptey receives the ball on the left-hand side of the box and works it onto his right foot, before delivering into the penalty area. Welbeck rises highest and attempts to head towards goal, but he gets it all wrong and it flies into the stands behind the goal.
Sheffield United have an opportunity from a corner. McAtee bursts down the line and gets in a foot race with Van Hecke, before the Brighton defender puts it behind. It's delivered towards the back post and then headed back across goal, and Osborn puts it into the back of the net! But wait... the referee has blown his whistle, and it won't count! VAR is checking it. The referee is taking a look at the monitor... he sticks with his decision, NO GOAL!
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of seven minutes of added time at the end of the first half.
Brighton are looking to keep possession in the final few minutes of the half as they try and prevent Sheffield United getting a goal before half-time. The Seagulls are remaining patient and waiting for an opening, but the Blades are camped inside their own box hoping to remain tight and maintain the current scoreline.
A corner comes into the box from Gross towards Dunk, and the Brighton defender manages to head it toward goal. It's flying towards the top corner, but Foderingham makes a superb stop to tip it over the bar and behind for another corner to the Seagulls. Gross delivers again, but Sheffield United are able to clear.
Lamptey goes into the book for a strong challenge as Sheffield United looked to break.
HALF-TIME: SHEFFIELD UNITED 0-2 BRIGHTON
Brighton go into the break with a 2-0 lead over Sheffield United at Bramall Lane. The Blades started brightly and were applying pressure on the Seagulls, but Holgate made a reckless challenge on Mitoma early in the first half, and after a VAR review, the referee sent the defender off. From that moment on, Wilder's side were up against it. Shortly after, Brighton took the lead as Buonanotte headed home from a few yards out. It didn't take long for De Zerbi's men to grab a second, with Welbeck pouncing inside the box to fire the ball into the back of the net. Sheffield United did have the ball in the back of the net through Osborn, but the goal was disallowed due to offside. The home team have a mountain to climb in the second half.
After his side had conceded twice and were down to 10 men, Wilder opted to bring on a defender for his only striker on the pitch. Brighton created 2.18 expected goals (xG) in the first half, so the Sheffield United boss had to tighten up his defence. The Blades became more resolute and prevented another goal after Trusty was brought on, but the supporters at Bramall Lane might want to see a little more in the final third. Although it's an uphill task to get back into the game, Wilder's men need all the points they can get. Could we see Brewster or McBurnie introduced early in the second half as they push to find the back of the net?
De Zerbi makes a change at the break. In defence, Igor is introduced for Webster.
Lamptey is also substituted for Brighton, and Moder will come on in his place.
McAtee gets the second half under way for Sheffield United at Bramall Lane!
Brighton are keeping the ball well in the early stages of the second half, relaxing in possession and remaining patient. Gilmour now finds Mitoma out wide and the Japanese winger cuts inside onto his right foot, but his shot is blocked and Sheffield United are able to clear.
McAtee finds Larouci on the left-hand side in plenty of space and Sheffield United look to break. He attempts to take on Van Hecke, but Adingra works hard to get back and dispossess the full-back. The Blades need to make the most of these opportunities whenever they win back possession, as Brighton aren't allowing them to have a lot of the ball.
Brighton work the ball well as Van Hecke finds himself in space just outside the penalty area. He fakes to shoot and then fires a pass into the feet of Adingra. The Brighton winger turns and gets away from his marker, before striking towards goal. However, it's a tame effort and Foderingham makes a comfortable stop.
The Blades enjoy a spell of possession inside the Brighton half. They take a quick throw-in and the ball reaches Souza in space outside the box. He gets it out of his feet and attempts an ambitious long-range effort, but he drags it wide of the post and it goes behind for a goal-kick to Brighton.
Buonanotte is the latest player to go into the referee's book for a late challenge in the middle of the pitch.
Sheffield United attempt to hit Brighton on the counter-attack again. A corner comes into the box and Foderingham comes out to collect it. He quickly fires a long ball beyond De Zerbi's defence and McAtee latches onto it. He delays as he waits for support from his team-mates, but the Brighton defence outnumber him and win the ball back.
Mitoma contiunes to cause issues for Sheffield United down the left-hand side. He receives the ball and instantly looks to take on Bogle, drifting past the defender and getting to the byline with ease. He fires a shot towards goal, but it's deflected behind for a corner. Gross delivers into the box, but Bogle can head it clear.
Wilder makes another alteration as Sheffield United look to get back into the game. Larouci makes his way to the bench, and Brooks will enter the fray.
Buonanotte, who opened the scoring for Brighton in today's game, is substituted. Ferguson will come on to replace him.
Another chance for Brighton! The Seagulls have a corner and Gross is standing over it. He delivers towards the six-yard box and Ferguson makes a run away from goal, twisting and getting his head to it. Unfortunately for him, it's straight at Foderingham who makes a comfortable save.
Brighton have continued to dominate the possession in the second half, making 111 passes in the final third while having 86.9 per cent of the possession. Sheffield United are camped inside their own half and attempting to hit the Seagulls in transition. Credit to the Blades' defence, they've looked a lot more compact since the break.
As it stands, Brighton will climb into seventh place in the Premier League table if they secure the three points in today's game. Sheffield United will remain at the bottom of the table, seven points adrift of Luton Town who sit in 17th place, if they fail get back into the match.
GOOOAAAAALLLL!! 3-0 BRIGHTON! Could that be game over? Mitoma receives the ball on the left-hand side and looks to take on Bogle. He works the ball onto his left foot and delivers a dangerous cross into the penalty area. Robinson darts across the front post and attempts to clear it, but he fires it into the back of his own net. Nothing is going right for the Blades in today's game.
Mitoma, who recently came back from injury, is taken off by De Zerbi. Fati is the player to replace him.
GOOOOAAAAAALLL!! 4-0 BRIGHTON!! Dunk finds Gross out wide and the Brighton man looks to whip a delivery into the box. Adingra gets across his marker and volleys the ball towards goal, and it flies into the corner of the net. The Ivory Coast international recently won the African Cup of Nations with his country, and he's back with the Seagulls and scoring goals!
It was a perfect cross from Gross onto the foot of Adingra, who only had to help the ball on its way into the back of the net.
McAtee has found it difficult to get into the game in the second half, and he's been replaced by Brewster in attack.
Sheffield United make another change and this time in midfield, with Davies replacing Hamer.
Norwood will come on for the Blades in the latter stages of the game, with Osborn making his way to the bench.
Brighton make an alteration, with Estupinan entering the fray. Welbeck is replaced for the Seagulls.
Norwood plays in Brooks down the left-hand side and he sends a first-time cross into the box, but Igor is there to clear it away. Sheffield United have a throw-in and Robinson will launch it into the penalty area. Dunk heads it away but straight back to Robinson. He floats in a cross and Ahmedhodzic nods it towards goal, but it goes wide of the post.
GOOOAAAAALLLL!! 5-0 BRIGHTON! The Seagulls are running riot! De Zerbi’s side keep possession just outside the penalty area before Fati attempts a strike towards goal. His shot is blocked but it finds Adingra. The Brighton winger hits it, and it deflects into the far corner of the goal, leaving Foderingham rooted to his spot! Wilder will be hoping to hear the full-time whistle as soon as possible.
All the noise is coming from the away end at Bramall Lane, with a large section of the Sheffield United support heading for the exits. They've seen enough as Wilder's side struggle to get back into the game. The Seagulls have been relentless in front of goal and are showing no mercy!
Gilmour goes into the book for dragging Brooks to the ground as Sheffield United attempted to break away.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of five minutes of added time at the end of the game.
Verbruggen tussles with Davies after Sheffield United win a corner, and the Brighton goalkeeper is given a yellow card.
Davies goes into the book for his involvement in an altercation with Verbruggen.
FULL-TIME: SHEFFIELD UNITED 0-5 BRIGHTON
Brighton secure the three points at Bramall Lane with an emphatic 5-0 victory over struggling Sheffield United. The Blades had a mountain to climb from the early stages of the game after Holgate was sent off for a reckless challenge on Mitoma. Shortly after, Brighton struck twice through Buonanotte and Welbeck and the Seagulls went into the break with a 2-0 lead against 10 men. De Zerbi's side came out in the second half with plenty of attacking intent despite their comfortable position in the game, and an own goal from Robinson made it three for Brighton. The Blades were a lot more compact in the second half, but the Seagulls continued to be relentless in front of goal, and a double from Adingra later in the game secured the victory at Bramall Lane. Up next for Sheffield United is a difficult trip to Wolverhampton Wanderers, while Brighton will host Everton at the Amex Stadium next Saturday. That's all for today, goodbye!
summary:
Aston Villa recovered from a Luton Town fightback to snatch a late winner at Kenilworth Road that consolidated their hold on fourth place. 
Having seen Tottenham Hotspur close to two points off their position with a turnaround victory at home to Crystal Palace earlier in the day, Villa seemed in control as they went 2-0 up through a first-half double from in-form Ollie Watkins. But the home side fought back through goals from Tahith Chong and Carlton Morris. However, two of Unai Emery’s substitutes combined as Moussa Diaby crossed to Lucas Digne to head in the winner in the 89th minute. 
How the match unfolded
Rob Edwards made one change to his Luton side as Andros Townsend replaced Cauley Woodrow, while Emery also made one change as Ezri Konsa came in for Pau Torres.
Villa made a quick start and Jacob Ramsey went close with a chested effort from a Leon Bailey cross, before Luton lost a defender after only six minutes as Amari’i Bell limped off.
Bailey then fed Watkins, whose shot towards the near post was saved by Thomas Kaminski. And from the ensuing 24th-minute corner delivered by Bailey, Watkins had time to head in.
Villa almost instantly got a second through Bailey and Watkins combining again, with the Jamaican releasing his team-mate, who shot across goal and hit the far post.
Watkins continued to torment Luton with his second goal in the 38th minute, latching on to Douglas Luiz’s quick free-kick over the top before whipping the ball clinically into the far Aston right corner. The goal was initially ruled out for offside but a VAR check showed he had timed his run perfectly.
It took Watkins’ tally to 16 Premier League goals, only one behind top scorer Erling Haaland in the race for the Castrol Golden Boot. He also has scored nine away goals, a feat only Dwight Yorke has managed for Villa in a season, in 1997/98.
A heavy home defeat looked on the cards at half-time, but Luton were transformed after the break, getting on top in midfield and testing Villa’s defence with a steady stream of balls into the box.
The hosts got their reward in the 66th minute as Villa failed to clear from a corner and Matty Cash was forced into a goalline block, with Tahith Chong following up to score.
Six minutes later it was 2-2 as Alfie Doughty delivered another splendid set-piece, whipping in a free-kick from the left which Carlton Morris at the far post volleyed low past Emiliano Martinez.
Luton looked the likelier side to score a late winner but in the final two minutes of normal time Diaby delivered a moment of brilliance, whipping in a left-footed cross for left-back Digne to head in powerfully and send the visiting fans in rapture.
Villa maintain their five-point gap over Spurs, with 55 points. Luton remain in 18th spot, four points adrift of safety with a match in hand on Nottingham Forest. 
Club reports
Luton Town report | Aston Villa report
Match officials
Referee: Michael Oliver. Assistants: Stuart Burt, Dan Cook. Fourth official: Matthew Donohue. VAR: Peter Bankes. Mark Scholes.
text:
["Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the Premier League fixture between Team_17 and Team_5 at Bramall Lane.
Team_17 currently sit in 20th place in the Premier League table, but they will be hoping to continue their momentum after picking up an impressive result last time out. The Blades defeated Team_12 3-1 at Kenilworth Road, ending a seven-match winless streak (D2 L5). Chris Wilder’s side have conceded more goals at home in the division than any other side (31 in 12 games). In Premier League history, only West Brom have shipped more goals in their first 12 home games of the campaign (2020-21).
