De Bruyne scored a fantastic equaliser to cancel out Mateta's opener, with Palace and City level at 1-1 heading into half-time. The Eagles took the lead inside three minutes through Mateta, who raced onto the end of Wharton's brilliant throughball and drove his low strike against the left post and into the net. City levelled less than four minutes later through De Bruyne. The Belgium international collected the ball on the left and whipped a brilliant strike into the top-right corner. Haaland was then denied by a sharp stop from Henderson, with Ayew crashing the bar from the hosts.
Palace struggled to create anything against Team_3 in their last outing, but they have shown signs of promise against Premier League champions City. The Eagles have registered an xG of 0.75 from their three shots, with their only effort on target coming from Mateta's goal. Henderson has also been brilliant, making four saves. As for City, they created an xG of 0.99 from their nine efforts. Guardiola's men have had 75.9 per cent of the possession. However, they have struggled at times to find a way through Palace's rigid defensive structure and have been vulnerable on the counter. Haaland might be getting frustrated up front after having just seven touches, but with De Bruyne in the side, he could be found at any moment.
City make a change to their defence before the restart. Gvardiol struggled at times before the break and is being replaced by Akanji.
City get the ball rolling again. The visitors must win to keep the pressure on title rivals Team_1 and Team_11, who will be delighted with the score so far.
GOALLLL! LEWIS SCORES! 2-1 CITY! The visitors take the lead for the first time! Grealish has possession on the left, getting to the byline before lifting a cross into the box. Andersen gets there but flicks a header straight to Lewis, who crashes his strike into the bottom-left corner.
City have scored 11 goals in the first 15 minutes of the second half, only Team_18 (15) have scored more in the Premier League this season. It’s also the second time Lewis has scored this season, with both coming against the Eagles!
There is a small penalty shout for City, with De Bruyne's cross from the left getting blocked by Andersen's arm. However, when the ball struck the arm of the Palace defender, it was close to his body and in a natural position.
Palace now need to stay in the contest and not concede again. Glasner will be furious with conceding just after half-time, especially as Lewis was free inside the box!
Wharton lofts a pass down the right for Munoz, who breaks down the wing and waits for support. He has plenty of time to pick the right option, but his cutback goes straight to Alvarez. The Eagles won’t get many chances, meaning they must do better when they get forward.

De Bruyne is over a corner on the right and drives a low pass to Grealish on the edge of the box. He has time and space, taking one touch before lashing his effort over the top of the bar.

They have stopped the Eagles from having a shot whilst keeping 70.3 per cent of the possession and eight touches in the opposition box. If City score again, it would be difficult to see Palace from getting any points.

Mateta is shown his fifth yellow card of the season after a heavy tackle on Bobb.
Eze has netted five goals in eight home games for Palace but hasn’t been able to make an impact today and is coming off for\xa0Schlupp.

De Bruyne adds an assist to his goal. He beats the offside trap to get onto Grealish's pass and instinctively finds Haaland in the middle with a fantastic ball into the forward.
Palace came from two goals behind to draw with City earlier in the season, but have struggled to put City under any pressure.
GOALLL! DE BRUYNE SCORES AGAIN! 4-1 CITY! De Bruyne and Grealish play a clever one-two on the left, allowing the England International to get to the byline before cutting the ball back to Rodri. He taps it to De Bruyne, who thunders his low strike into the bottom-left corner.
Rodri spots the run of De Bruyne and plays a simple pass into his feet, allowing the captain to thunder his effort past Henderson. One more goal would see City move to the top of the Premier League.

label: Exciting

events:
Welcome to live text commentary of Burnley v West Ham United in the Premier League.
Vincent Kompany’s Burnley side come into this match on the back of the worst home start in the history of the English top-flight, having lost six out of six matches at Turf Moor so far this campaign. West Ham have a tricky run coming up, so David Moyes will want to take advantage of the Hammers' positive form before the international break and head back to East London with nothing but all three points in the bag.
BURNLEY (4-4-2): James Trafford; Vitinho, Dara O'Shea, Jordan Beyer, Charlie Taylor; Sander Berge, Josh Brownhill, Johann Berg Gudmundsson, Luca Koleosho; Zeki Amdouni, Jay Rodriguez
Subs: Lawrence Vigouroux, Connor Roberts, Hjalmar Ekdal, Josh Cullen, Jacob Bruun Larsen, Michael Obafemi, Nathan Redmond, Anass Zaroury, Aaron Ramsey
WEST HAM (4-2-3-1): Alphonse Areola; Emerson, Nayef Aguerd, Kurt Zouma, Vladimir Coufal; James Ward-Prowse, Edson Alvarez; Lucas Paqueta, Tomas Soucek, Mohammed Kudus; Danny Ings
Subs: Lukas Fabianski, Aaron Cresswell, Konstantinos Mavropanos, Angelo Ogbonna, Thilo Kehrer, Pablo Fornals, Maxwel Cornet, Said Benrahma, Divin Mubama
We’ll start with the big team news… No Bowen for West Ham. He misses out through injury after pulling out of the England squad with a knee issue last week. It comes as a blow for Moyes as the forward has scored in all six of West Ham’s away games in the league this season. Ings makes his first league start of the campaign - which comes against his old club - and is West Ham’s only change from their previous win at Nottingham Forest.
As for Burnley, they’re unchanged from the defeat to Arsenal last time out. It looks as though Kompany has set his side up in two banks of four, with Gudmundsson and Koleosho deployed on either flank. Berge starts alongside Brownhill in central midfield, with the latter on the scoresheet last time out at Emirates Stadium.
The Hammers need to pick up as many points as possible before trying to navigate their way through a tricky Christmas period if they’re going to sustain their push for a European finish. They face Tottenham and Arsenal on the road and host Man United in December, before kickstarting their new year with a test against Brighton. As for Burnley, they’re in desperate need of a result. Rooted to the bottom of the table with just four points after 12 games, they’ve lost their last five in the league.
Both sets of players have emerged from the tunnel at Turf Moor and we're almost ready for kick-off.
Here we go! Amdouni gets the ball rolling for Burnley and the first half is underway.
Paqueta dinks a cross towards an unmarked Soucek in the box but the midfielder doesn't really know what to do with the ball and softly guides it towards goal with his head. Trafford comes off his line to claim it comfortably.
Gudmundsson takes on a shot on the edge of the box following a Burnley corner but it's straight at Areola.
West Ham fly forward but Vitinho crucially cuts out Soucek's pass out wide to Paqueta making a run down the left.
The West Ham fans behind Areola's goal are in fine voice as they enjoy their positive start to the season. Turf Moor is generally quite flat apart from the noisy section of travelling fans.
Paqueta can't find the onrushing Ings. Gudmundsson gives the ball away initially and works hard to block the Brazilian's attempted pass towards Ings on the right.
Berge makes a driving run towards the West Ham box but he runs into a cluster of white shirts. Vitinho picks up the ball and looks for Amdouni in the box, but he's quickly dispossessed.
CHANCE FOR BURNLEY! Rodriguez fizzes a ball across the six-yard box towards Amdouni at the back post but the ball is ever so slightly ahead of the Swiss striker's path. Rodriguez was unselfish, he could have taken the shot on himself.
West Ham have failed to score in three of their last four Premier League away games against Burnley. Their 0-0 draw last time out in December 2021 is their only clean sheet in eight visits to Turf Moor in the competition.
Koleosho makes a couple of positive runs towards Coufal down Burnley's left flank. The West Ham defender does enough to keep him at bay for now, but there are some positive signs for Burnley in the opening stages.
It's been a really open start to the game. It's been end-to-end in the early exchanges and both teams have had a sniff at goal. Burney have probably had the best chance of the game so far.
Kudus runs onto an overhit Coufal through ball and kicks it out for a throw-in rather than a goal kick to keep Burnley in their own half.
In possession, Burnley are playing patient football. They're waiting for an opening and not rushing themselves going forward. As I say that, Berge plays a long ball over the top which Koleosho brings down exceptionally before running into a group of defenders on the edge of the box and losing the ball.
Both teams have had a sniff at goal, but neither have created any real chances yet with nearly 25 minutes gone.
Burnley are enjoying a good spell, popping the ball around as the game settles. Amdouni chases down Areola, who gets the ball clear just in the nick of time.
BIG SAVE FROM AREOLA! Amdouni slips the ball to Koleosho arriving into the box on the left, he opens his body up for a shot on his right foot but Areola makes a strong save to his right at the near post.
West Ham have won their last seven Premier League games against promoted sides – their longest such run in the competition – while they’ve also won their last 10 against sides starting the day bottom of the table.
Paqueta drives through the Burnley midfield and Beyer trips him to earn the first booking of the match.
O'Shea miscontrols the ball and Paqueta is on him straight away. As the last defender, O'Shea dives in to get the ball clear as quickly as possible, which he does, but catches the winger in the meantime. Paqueta wants a foul but he won't get one, play on.
ANOTHER CHANCE FOR BURNLEY! Berge whips in an inviting cross to Amdouni at the back post, who steers the ball wide with a header.
The ball drops to Vitinho around 25 yards from goal. He takes a first-time strike but skews it well over the bar.
POSSIBLE BURNLEY PENALTY! Koleosho drives into the box and Coufal sticks his leg out to stop him. He seems to catch the winger's foot as Koleosho falls to the floor. VAR initially sends Samuel Barrott to the monitor, but then the decision changes to no penalty.
Alvarez talked his way into the book before the Burnley penalty was overturned.
Aguerd was also booked for dissent.
Burnley didn't get the penalty, but one thing it has done is give the home crowd a much-needed boost. It's the loudest it's been all game as we close in on half-time.
Kudus brings down Koleosho on the left and Burnley have a free-kick in a good position.
Beyer heads the free-kick wide. There will be one minute of added time at the end of the first half.
HALF-TIME: BURNLEY 0-0 WEST HAM
It's goalless at the break between Burnley and West Ham. As Burnley try to end their barren run of six consecutive defeats, the Clarets have looked the better side. They had a great chance to open the scoring when Koleosho thumped an effort straight at Areola but the big talking point was the possible penalty for Burnley. Koleosho, who caused a lot of problems for Coufal in the first half, skipped past the right-back before his legs were clipped which sent him to the floor. VAR had a quick check but deemed no pitchside review was necessary. It was harsh because they’ve certainly been given, but nonetheless, Kompany will be pleased with that first 45 minutes.
Both teams have enjoyed positive spells of possession during the first half but only Burnley have really made the opposition goalkeeper work. West Ham need to find a way of breaking down this stubborn Burnley defence, but first, they have to work the ball through the lines and get it to Ings' feet. He’s making a return to his former club and would surely love to score, so it’s up to Moyes to get him more involved. As for Burnley, more of the same is needed from Kompany's side. They could be more clinical, but with the way they're playing, they're bound to get another chance. A big second half for both teams coming up!
West Ham get the ball rolling for the second half.
Risky from Burnley! Trafford passes the ball to Taylor right on the edge of the Burnley box and the first wave of the West Ham attack is quickly onto him, but they play their way out of danger.
PENALTY FOR BURNLEY! Koleosho makes a tricky run into the box and Kudus is clumsy as he treads on his foot. The referee points straight to the spot!
There is a quick VAR check, but this isn't going to be overturned. It will be a penalty.
GOOOOOOOOOOOOALLL!!! What a huge moment this could be for Burnley! Rodriguez drills the ball down the middle from the spot and Burnley are ahead!
A big goal for Burnley and Rodriguez. He's now scored 19 of his last 20 penalty kicks - a brilliant record from the spot!
West Ham are looking to attack straight away and Coufal delivers a ball to the front post but Beyer stabs it away.
Ward-Prowse produces a fierce shot from 10 yards out but Berge blocks it from close range. West Ham have a corner.
The ball drops to Paqueta on the half-volley from a corner but he sends it well over the bar.
HUGE SAVE FROM AREOLA! Amdouni does really well to snatch the ball from Aguerd and drive at goal but Areola is down quickly to deny him at the front post. Burnley have a spring in their step!
Paqueta goes down with an injury, clutching his rib cage after a tussle with Berge. Burnley fans aren't happy with the Brazilian who is escorted off the pitch by the physio.
West Ham are preparing to make a couple of changes.
Paqueta is back on the pitch and is getting a chorus of boos from the home fans. He then plays a delicious ball out wide to Emerson as West Ham try and force an attack.
Mubama comes on in place of Ings, who has not enjoyed a happy return to Turf Moor eight years after leaving the club.
It will be a double change for West Ham as Alvarez is replaced by Benrahma. That might have something to do with the fact that he's on a yellow card.
West Ham have lost seven of their last 10 Premier League away games (W2 D1), conceding at least twice in each defeat. Indeed, since the start of last season only Nottingham Forest (18) have lost more Premier League away games than the Hammers (16).
Coufal searches for Mubama with a curling cross from deep but his delivery is headed clear.
Amdouni is hauled down on the halfway line as Coufal and Zouma chase him. The former is booked but it looked as though it was the latter that made the contact.
Benrahma is nearly through on goal as Mubama sends a direct ball over the top of the Burnley defence but Berge - the only player back - is excellently positioned to mop up on the halfway line.
Berge splits the West Ham defence with a pass through the middle, but Rodriguez is offside. Everyone inside Turf Moor is urging Burnley to move the ball around quicker!
Burnley make their first change as Ramsey replaces Amdouni. The Burnley striker put himself about today and played well.
Nearly an instant impact from Ramsey! He drives into the box and shoots from the right but his effort is just off target.
Burnley are winless in their last four Premier League meetings with West Ham (D2 L2), with the last two games in 2021-22 both ending in draws.
Ward-Prowse has more assists than any other Premier League player in all competitions this season and now West ham have a corner. They really need him to produce.
Trafford punches the set-piece away, much to Turf Moor's delight. Just over 10 more minutes for Burnley to hang on!
Coufal whips in a delivery and Zouma heads towards goal but he doesn't get enough purchase on the ball as Trafford comfortably catches the centre-back's tame effort.
Koleosho departs to a chorus of cheers from the Burnley faithful. He's been their best player in this match and is replaced by Zaroury.
BENRAHMA COMES SO CLOSE! Kudus plays the ball out wide to him and the Burnley fans are up in arms because they think he's handled it. Nevertheless, play continues and Benrahma cuts inside before sending a shot across the face of goal which flashes agonisingly wide of the post.
Gudmunds­son is subbed off and Cullen takes his place. The Icelandic winger had created the most chances in the match in an impressive display.
GOOOOOOOOOALLL!!! WEST HAM ARE LEVEL! Kudus does superbly to beat a cluster of maroon shirts on the right before producing a dangerous cross towards the front post from the byline, which Mubama stabs towards goal as the ball goes in off O'Shea!
The West Ham fans are in full voice now. They'll believe they can go on and win this.
There will be at least seven additional minutes added on. West Ham want to finish this match strongly and are on top in the closing stages.
GOOOOOOOOOOOOAAAAAAALLLL!!!! WEST HAM ARE IN FRONT! It's another sensational ball in from Kudus for Soucek at the back post, who volleys the Hammers ahead in the 91st minute!
Ward-Prowse slips the ball to Kudus on the right, who hesitates in front of Taylor before shifting the ball onto his left and curling in a pinpoint cross for Soucek to slam home. What a signing the Ghanaian is turning out to be - he has single-handedly turned this game on its head!
West Ham are now sitting back a bit. They've done their job up front and Moyes will be desperate to hold on for three points here.
West Ham have won their last seven Premier League games against promoted sides – their longest such run in the competition – while they’ve also won their last 10 against sides starting the day bottom of the table. They look set to continue those streaks here! Burnley are stunned.
Brownhill sends in a hopeful, lofted cross for Taylor who is completely unmarked at the back of the penalty area, but it looks as though he's lost the ball in the air as his touch takes it out of play.
FULL-TIME: BURNLEY 1-2 WEST HAM
And breathe! Another late Premier League comeback means West Ham come away from Turf Moor with all three points. It was all about Kudus in the second half, as he produced two excellent crosses which ended up in the back of the net, courtesy of an O'Shea own goal to cancel out Rodriguez's opener and a brilliant volley from Soucek to complete the comeback. You can't help but feel sorry for Burnley, who looked to have done enough for their first points at home this season, but it wasn't to be. It's now seven consecutive home defeats for Kompany’s side, who remain rooted to the foot of the table, while West Ham end their league run of three away matches without victory. Burnley will have the chance to quickly put their home form right when they welcome Sheffield United to Turf Moor next weekend, while West Ham turn their attention to Europe and travel to Serbia to face TSC Backa Topola on Thursday. Thank you for following our live coverage. Until next time, goodbye!
summary:
Declan Rice’s header in the seventh minute of stoppage time secured a dramatic victory as Arsenal beat Luton Town 4-3 to go five points clear at the top.
In a pulsating encounter at Kenilworth Road, both sides went in front only to be pegged back, but it was the Gunners who provided the decisive blow to extend their winning run in the league to four matches.
Arsenal controlled the early proceedings, but Luton aimed to assert their presence in the match with a number of strong challenges.
However, the Gunners would punish poor play from Luton to take the lead on 20 minutes.
A heavy backpass from Amari'i Bell forced goalkeeper Thomas Kaminski to kick out for a throw. Gabriel Jesus took it quickly and found Bukayo Saka, who on his 200th appearance in all competitions for Arsenal, cut the ball back from the byline for Gabriel Martinelli to sweep into the bottom corner.
Five minutes later, Luton equalised when Gabriel Osho got on the end of an Alfie Doughty corner to power his header beyond David Raya for his first Premier League goal.
With half-time approaching, Arsenal restored their advantage once more when Ben White’s first-time cross was nodded in by Gabriel Jesus.
The Brazilian’s first goal in eight Premier League matches and only second of the season made him the 11th different player to have scored Arsenal's last 11 goals in the competition.
Four minutes after the break, Luton were back level for the second time and this goal was almost a carbon-copy of their first.
Another corner from Doughty was not dealt with by Raya and he was out-jumped by Elijah Adebayo, who headed in.
With Kenilworth Road already rocking, Ross Barkley then put the hosts ahead on 57 minutes with a low left-footed shot that squirmed beneath Raya.
But Luton’s lead would last just three minutes as Kai Havertz continued his fine form in front of goal when he dinked the ball over the advancing Kaminski from a clever Gabriel Jesus pass for his third goal in his last four matches in all competitions.
Substitute Leandro Trossard twice went close twice to putting Arsenal back in front, with one shot being deflected over while he fired his second narrowly wide.
The match looked to be heading towards a draw but Rice headed Martin Odegaard’s cross into the bottom corner to spark joyous scenes in the away end.
It was the fifth time in 15 Premier League matches this season that Arsenal have scored a game-changing goal after the 84th minute, and the third in stoppage time.
Meanwhile, it's the first time since a 5-3 win over Chelsea in October 2011 that the Gunners have won a Premier League away match in which they've conceded three or more goals.
Arsenal now have 36 points, with rivals Liverpool and Manchester City both in action on Wednesday, when they will hope to close the gap on the Gunners.
Luton remain 17th on nine points, two clear of the bottom three.

Subs: Lawrence Vigouroux, Connor Roberts, Hjalmar Ekdal, Josh Cullen, Jacob Bruun Larsen, Michael Obafemi, Nathan Redmond, Anass Zaroury, Aaron Ramsey
Team_19 (4-2-3-1): Alphonse Areola; Emerson, Nayef Aguerd, Kurt Zouma, Vladimir Coufal; James Ward-Prowse, Edson Alvarez; Lucas Paqueta, Tomas Soucek, Mohammed Kudus; Danny Ings
Subs: Lukas Fabianski, Aaron Cresswell, Konstantinos Mavropanos, Angelo Ogbonna, Thilo Kehrer, Pablo Fornals, Maxwel Cornet, Said Benrahma, Divin Mubama

Ings makes his first league start of the campaign - which comes against his old club - and is Team_19’s only change from their previous win at Team_16.
As for Team_6, they’re unchanged from the defeat to Team_1 last time out. It looks as though Kompany has set his side up in two banks of four, with Gudmundsson and Koleosho deployed on either flank. Berge starts alongside Brownhill in central midfield, with the latter on the scoresheet last time out at Emirates Stadium.
The Hammers need to pick up as many points as possible before trying to navigate their way through a tricky Christmas period if they’re going to sustain their push for a European finish. events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Liverpool and Luton Town at Anfield!
This game was supposed to take place at the weekend, but due to Liverpool's involvement in the EFL Cup final on Sunday, it's been moved forward. The Reds have the chance to extend their lead at the top of the league ahead of the rest of the fixtures and can go four points clear of Manchester City with another win here. They've only lost one of their last 14 games in all competitions (W10 D3), but they've won back-to-back matches since their defeat to Arsenal. Their form at home is a force to be reckoned with, though, as they haven't lost at Anfield in any of their last 24 outings there (W19 D5).
As for Luton, they've slipped back into the relegation zone after Everton's draw with Crystal Palace on Monday, but if they avoid defeat here, they'll leapfrog the Toffees once more. After going on a six-game unbeaten run in all competitions at the start of the year (W3 D3), they've since lost their last two against Sheffield United and Manchester United, though they were unlucky to come out of the latter empty-handed.
LIVERPOOL STARTING XI (4-3-3): Caoimhin Kelleher; Conor Bradley, Jarell Quansah, Virgil van Dijk, Joe Gomez; Alexis Mac Allister, Wataru Endo, Ryan Gravenberch; Harvey Elliott, Cody Gakpo, Luis Diaz.
LIVERPOOL SUBS: Bobby Clark, Adrian, Kaide Gordon, Andy Robertson, Jayden Danns, Trey Nyoni, Ibrahima Konate, Kostas Tsimikas, James McConnel.
LUTON TOWN STARTING XI (3-4-2-1): Thomas Kaminski; Teden Mengi, Gabriel Osho, Amari'i Bell; Chiedozie Ogbene, Albert Sambi Lokonga, Ross Barkley, Alfie Doughty; Carlton Morris, Tahith Chong; Cauley Woodrow.
LUTON TOWN SUBS: Andros Townsend, Reece Burke, Issa Kabore, Dan Potts, Zack Nelson, Jordan Clark, Tim Krul, Luke Berry, Pelly-Rudock Mpanzu.
Jurgen Klopp makes five changes from Liverpool's win over Brentford on Saturday, as Quansah, Gomez, Gravenberch, Elliott and Gakpo are all brought in. Robertson and Konate drop to a young bench. Diogo Jota is out with a knee injury, while Curtis Jones and Darwin Nunez aren't risked after also going off in that game. Mohamed Salah also isn't in the squad.
Despite losing to United last time out, Rob Edwards was clearly pleased with what he saw from his team as he names an unchanged line-up here. Woodrow continues to lead the line after Elijah Adebayo picked up a hamstring injury in the warm-up of that game.
The teams are out on the pitch now, with kick-off just moments away!
Lokonga gets the game under way for Luton!
Liverpool win an early corner and it's worked to Mac Allister on the edge of the box. He curls an inviting cross to the far post, but Doughty heads it out for another corner. This one comes to nothing.
Kelleher sends it long over the top and Luton switch off, allowing Diaz to run onto it on the edge of the box. He can't get it out of his feet in time to get an early shot away though, and Mengi gets across to knock it away.
WIDE! Diaz has made a really bright start to this game, and Elliott plays it inside to him, and he just spins away from Osho to get a sight of goal. He does get a shot away this time, but fires it wide of the far post.
After a slow start to the game, Luton are advancing forward for the first time and Ogbene gets away from two Liverpool players to hook in a cross from the right. He's looking for Morris, but the captain can't get on the end of it.
Elliott goes out to take another corner, but it's cleared just in front of Quansah. It only goes as far as Mac Allister, who works it back out to Elliott, but the defender is caught on his heels this time.
Chong has acres of space in the middle of the field, and he spots Doughty to his left. He gets in front of Bradley to fizz a dangerous ball across the face of goal, but none of his team-mates are there to meet it.
GOOOAAALLL!!! OGBENE SCORES! Luton have the lead at Anfield! It comes from a throw-in on the left, and Doughty holds off Quansah to cushion it into Chong's path. The angle is tight, but he still goes for goal. It goes through Kelleher's legs, but the keeper gets enough on it to stop it from crossing the line. It loops up though, and Ogbene nods it in from the far post. 1-0 Luton!
Lokonga isn't strong enough as he tries to bring down Gakpo, and he's left on the floor by the Dutchman, who drives forward. He has options either side, but goes for goal himself, earning a corner as his shot deflects over the bar.
Luton are getting everybody back inside their own penalty area whenever Liverpool win a corner, and there's no space for the Reds. Bradley sees a cross blocked, and Van Dijk can't pick out a team-mate when he recycles it on the opposite flank.
Doughty steps across Gravenberch to try and stop him, but when the Dutchman gets away, he also pulls him back by the arm. The winger is shown the first yellow card of the game.
Bell's clearance is charged down by Gomez, which takes it straight to Gakpo, and he deftly flicks it into Elliott's path on the left of the box. He can't bring it under control quickly enough though, and Lokonga takes no risks by putting his laces through the clearance.
It's a lovely throughball from Chong into the box for Woodrow, but Kelleher is alert and rushes out to intercept it. He then throws it out to Mac Allister to set him on the counter, but he can't escape Barkley.
Luton have made a good start to this game, and Edwards will be delighted with what he's seen so far. However, history doesn't favour them in this exact fixture, as they've never beaten Liverpool in a league game at Anfield (P14 - W8 D6).
Luton have started to get a little sloppy in the last couple of minutes, and have given it away in their own half a couple of times. Mac Allister makes the latest interception, but his throughball to Gakpo is too close to Kaminski.
CHANCE! Gomez is allowed to advance and the Luton players just drop back, allowing him to keep going. When he gets to the edge of the box, he tries his luck, curling his shot towards the far-top corner, but it flies wide.
SAVE! Bell carries it out from the back, only to run into Van Dijk high up the pitch, and the Liverpool captain nicks it off him before picking out Diaz's run. He cuts inside from the left and drills his shot through Mengi's legs, but it's held by Kaminski.
Luton win a free-kick on the right, but they waste a good chance to put it into the box. It comes back to Barkley twice after he initially takes it short, but when he switches out to the opposite flank, Dought just drifts offside.
WHAT A CHANCE! Diaz starts the move, but he has to wait a while to get it back until Endo scoops a good pass into the box. The Colombian peels off the back of Mengi to reach it, but pokes it wide of the near post on the stretch.
Barkley's pass out to Ogbene is a bit too heavy, but the winger is able to keep it alive before returning it to the midfielder. Barkley does swing a cross in this time, but it's a tame one that is easily caught by Kelleher.
OVER! Diaz has had all of Liverpool's best chances here, and he sees another one go begging. Luton give it away in their own half again, with the forward driving to the edge of the box before letting fly, but his shot sails over the bar.
It's getting a bit stuck in midfield at the moment, with both sides struggling to keep hold of it for more than a couple of seconds. Gravenberch eventually trips Chong when his frustration gets the better of him, and Luton win a free-kick.
BLOCK! It's well won back by Bradley before Mac Allister's hopeful clearance sets Gravenberch away through the middle. He helps it out to Diaz once more, but Bell recovers brilliantly to slide in and block his latest attempt.
Another corner for the Reds is comfortably cleared by Luton, but Mac Allister manages to latch onto the second ball. He touches it back to Elliott, who is the latest Liverpool player to have a go from range, but this one flies over the bar too.
There's a collision between Woodrow and Quansah as they go up for an aerial challenge, with the defender getting caught on the side of his head. Woodrow is booked for the challenge.
Mac Allister nicks it off Osho on the halfway line and quickly gets it out to Diaz. He helps it onto Elliott, who has every intention of returning the one-two, but Luton swarm around him to stop the pass from getting through.
Into the first of two added minutes here, with Liverpool still attempting to get an equaliser before the break. Kelleher sends it long to Bradley, who flicks it onto Gakpo, but his cross is too close to Kaminski.
CHANCE! Ogbene has space to burst into down the right after knocking it past Gomez, and he curls an early cross into the box to Woodrow. He meets it awkwardly on the volley as he jumps, but it loops over the crossbar.
HALF-TIME: LIVERPOOL 0-1 LUTON TOWN.
Ogbene's early goal gives Luton a 1-0 lead over Liverpool at half-time. The Hatters scored just 12 minutes into the game after breezing through the Reds' defence, and Chong's tight-angled shot was saved by Kelleher, but it looped off the goalkeeper for Ogbene to head in at the far post. Liverpool have certainly had their chances, mainly from long range, but Diaz has come closest to getting them on the scoresheet, sending two great efforts wide of Kaminski's right post.
Edwards will be thrilled with what he's seen from his side so far - despite having few chances, they've looked a threat on the break, but more importantly, they've defended as a unit to frustrate Liverpool. Klopp didn't look too happy on the sideline, though his team did react well to going behind so early. He'll be looking for a more clinical performance after the break, especially since he has no senior attacking options to hand on the bench.
There is a change at the break for Luton. Lokonga is the player making way after picking up a knock in the first half, with Mpanzu on in his place.
Liverpool get us back under way for the second half!
Mengi thinks he's done enough to hold off Diaz, but a foul is actually given against the Luton man. The Liverpool fans want a booking for the defender, but it's a member of their coaching staff who's booked for dissent for his reaction on the sidelines.
There's so much space for Elliott on the edge of the box when Endo slides it into him, but he chooses to take on another shot from range. He drags at it, sending it well wide of the far post.
PENALTY SHOUT! Mengi makes a brilliant block to deny Diaz from a tight angle, but Liverpool quickly work it back into the box. The Colombian looks to square it into the middle this time when it hits Osho's arm, which is just behind him, but the referee awards a corner.
Liverpool's corner causes a scramble in the box, with nobody sure where it's going to fall next. Gakpo reacts quickest in the end to poke it towards goal, but Mpanzu clears before the offside flag goes up.
Mac Allister picks out Elliott's overlapping run down the right, and he floats a good cross into a still-crowded penalty area. Gakpo gets a flick on, but he can't direct it towards goal.
GOOD SAVE! Chong steps in to shield it from Elliott in the box, but Gakpo is on hand to nick it off him. He takes it around the winger before drilling a low shot at the near post, but Kaminski gets down smartly to push it wide.
GOOOAAALLL!!! VAN DIJK EQUALISES! It's been coming from Liverpool, and their captain steps up! They finally manage to make something of one of their many corners as Mac Allister whips it into the middle, and Van Dijk darts in front of his marker to meet it. He gets power on the header, and Kaminski can't keep it out. 1-1!
It's a brilliant delivery from Mac Allister as he puts it straight onto Van Dijk's head.
GOOD SAVE! Liverpool aren't letting up the pressure here, and Bradley finds a pocket of space just inside the box. He keeps his shot low as he hits it down the middle, and Kaminski keeps it out with his feet.
Luton are making their second change in answer to that Liverpool equaliser as Woodrow is replaced by Townsend.
GOOOAAALLL!!! GAKPO SCORES! And just like that, Liverpool lead! It comes down the right side once more as it's clipped into the near post by Mac Allister, and Gakpo just peels away from his defender to meet it. It's another great header as he flicks it past Kaminski and into the back of the net. 2-1 Liverpool!
That's two assists in just over two minutes for Mac Allister, who picks out another good cross into the box.
GREAT SAVE! Luton just can't get out of their own box at the moment, and Gakpo is in on goal again. He surges past Bell down the right of the box, but his low shot is turned away by Kaminski for a corner.
KAMINSKI SAVES AGAIN! Mac Allister has found his range from the corner flag and he whips another wonderful cross into the box to pick out Van Dijk. He sends another powerful header on goal, and the goalkeeper scoops it away from his line.
After a frantic spell of the game, Edwards is making another change to try and settle things in midfield. Chong is taken off, with Jordan Clark on in his place.
Mengi has his arms around Gakpo to stop him from turning past him, and Liverpool win a free-kick. Elliott swings it into the box, and Osho just does enough to stop it from reaching Gakpo.
CHANCE! Bradley is dispossessed on the halfway line, and Barkley sets off on a rare Luton attack in this second half. He slides it forward for Doughty, who tries to catch out Kelleher by chipping it towards the far post from a tight angle, but it's deflected wide.
Liverpool are making their first change now, and Bradley goes off to a standing ovation from the home crowd. He's replaced by Robertson, which means that Gomez will switch to right-back.
Osho is caught on the ball, and Gakpo profits, but his low cross is half-cleared by Mengi. He only gets it as far as Elliott, but his pullback is too short for Diaz on the far side.
GOOOAAALLL!!! DIAZ SCORES! That should do it for Liverpool! After missing a couple of good chances in the first half, Diaz makes no mistake this time. Luton gives it away in their own half, with Robertson cutting out a switch to Ogbene, and his interception falls to the Colombian's feet. He drives into the box before rifling his shot past Kaminski at the near post. 3-1 Liverpool!
Robertson reads it well and was alert to dart in front of Ogbene, and cushion it into Diaz's path.
SAVE! Luton have a chance to get themselves back into this game as it's sent long to Doughty, but Kelleher rushes out to close him down. The winger manages to square it to Townsend, but the goalkeeper quickly gets back in position to block it.
Luton's final change of the game is an enforced one. Doughty was caught by Kelleher during that last attack when the goalkeeper closed him down, so he can't carry on. Kabore replaces him, which will see Ogbene switch out to the left for the end of the game.
GREAT SAVE! Diaz finds space in the box once more, but with two Luton players bearing down on him, he has to take this chance quickly. He pokes it towards the near post, and Kaminski gets down smartly to tip it away.
Barkley drags at Elliott's shoulder before sliding in from behind to nick the ball off him. He did catch the youngster with the follow-through, and it earns him a yellow card, much to his frustration.
There's another change for Liverpool now, as Bobby Clark is brought on in place of Gravenberch.
Liverpool are just slowing the pace of the game down at the moment, and although Luton are attempting to press, it's half-hearted. Kelleher does misplace a pass to Robertson, but Mpanzu can't make anything of it.
CHANCE! Barkley is caught on the ball in the centre circle, and Endo is quick to slide it forward to Gakpo. He has time to take it into the box, but tries his luck from range instead, and curls it wide of the near post.
Gomez gets a handful of Ogbene's shirt, and the winger decides to pull up to show it to the referee. It works, with Luton getting a free-kick, and Gomez getting a booking.
In Salah (19), Jota (14), Nunez (13), Gakpo (11), and Diaz (10), Liverpool are the first club in Europe's big-five leagues to have five players reach 10+ goals in all competitions this season.
Luton are enjoying a good spell of possession here, but it's all in their own half as they try to slow things down a little bit. They're in no hurry to push forward, though Liverpool are pressing them high.
Quansah clips the back of Barkley's heel, taking his boot off, and Luton have a free-kick in a good position. Barkley steps up to take it but curls his effort straight into the wall.
The home crowd are on their feet to give a standing ovation to the players making way. Diaz, who scored the final goal, which looks like it will seal the three points, is replaced by Danns, who makes his debut.
And Mac Allister, who set up the first two goals, goes off for McConnell.
Kabore catches McConnell with a late tackle and becomes the fourth player to go into the referee's book.
GOOOAAALLL!!! ELLIOTT SCORES! Osho intercepts Robertson's pass, only to give it away to Danns. He slides it into the box for Gakpo, but Mengi takes it off his toe. Elliott races onto the loose ball and whips a shot past Kaminski and into the back of the net. 4-1 Liverpool!
We're into eight minutes of added time here as Luton attempt to pull another goal back. Mpanzu slides it down the right for Kabore to chase, but he's caught on his heels and can't keep it in play.
Quansah is allowed to carry the ball a long way before he tries to set McConnell away down the right. Ogbene does enough to stop that from happening but puts it straight out of play to gift possession back to Liverpool.
Luton are pushing forward again to try and give their fans something to cheer late on. Townsend swings in a corner, but Kelleher rushes off his line to punch it away.
FULL-TIME: LIVERPOOL 4-1 LUTON TOWN.
Liverpool's brilliant second-half display sees them come from behind to beat Luton 4-1. The visitors had a wonderful first half and took the lead just 12 minutes in as Ogbene headed in the rebound of Chong's saved effort. The Reds pushed to equalise but couldn't find a way through a compact Luton side. That changed after the break though, and two goals in just over two minutes flipped the game on its head. Van Dijk levelled things up with a thumping header before Gakpo flicked in their second. Diaz then punished Luton for giving the ball away inside their own half by rifling it into the back of the net, with Elliott rounding things off late on with a lovely curling effort in the 90th minute. It's a win that lifts Liverpool four points clear at the top of the table, though they have played a game more than the teams below them. Next up for them is the EFL Cup final against Chelsea on Sunday. That loss means that Luton stay in the bottom three, and they don't play again until their FA Cup fifth-round tie against Manchester City on Tuesday. That's all for today, goodbye!
summary:
Chelsea’s hopes of European football took another hit as they failed to beat Brentford for a fifth successive match as the two West London clubs battled to a 2-2 draw.
Thomas Frank’s team had led until the 83rd minute but Axel Disasi headed home his first goal since the opening weekend against Liverpool to earn a point.
How the match unfolded
There was no Neal Maupay for Brentford as Yoanne Wissa took the Frenchman’s place in attack for the Bees. Keane Lewis-Potter and Ben Mee were also out as Mads Roerslev and Nathan Collins returned.
Mauricio Pochettino made one change, with Trevoh Chalobah replacing Raheem Sterling.  
Chelsea assumed early control of the match, holding 72 per cent possession in the first half but struggled to create clear-cut opportunities. 
Nicolas Jackson came close to opening the scoring after receiving a through-ball from Enzo Fernandez and rounding Mark Flekken, but his weak shot was cleared by Zanka.
However five minutes later the striker redeemed himself with a leaping headed goal between the two Brentford centre-backs from a well-placed Malo Gusto cross.
Thomas Frank’s side were much more combative in the second half and it soon paid off as Roerslev scored his first goal in over two years, smashing home a loose ball after Sergio Reguilion’s effort had been blocked.
Brentford went close soon after as Vitaly Janelt’s low driven effort from the edge of the box sliced through the legs of Chalobah to hit a post.
The home team continued to attack and were rewarded by Wissa’s spectacular goal. Frank Onyeka’s reflex flick-up in the area was converted by Congolese’s bicycle kick.
But with seven minutes remaining, Disasi earned Chelsea a point as he headed in a good curling cross by Cole Palmer who received the ball from a corner.
The point takes Brentford above Everton into 15th on 26 points, six clear of the bottom three. Chelsea remain 11th with 36 points. 
Club reports
Brentford report | Chelsea report
Match Officials
Referee: Jarred Gillett. Assistants: Darren Cann, Akil Howson. Fourth official: Oliver Langford. VAR: Michael Salisbury. Assistant VAR: Natalie Aspinall.

["Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Team_11 and Team_12 at Anfield!
This game was supposed to take place at the weekend, but due to Team_11 involvement in the EFL Cup final on Sunday, it's been moved forward. The Reds have the chance to extend their lead at the top of the league ahead of the rest of the fixtures and can go four points clear of Team_13 with another win here. They've only lost one of their last 14 games in all competitions (W10 D3), but they've won back-to-back matches since their defeat to Team_1. Their form at home is a force to be reckoned with, though, as they haven't lost at Anfield in any of their last 24 outings there (W19 D5).
As for Luton, they've slipped back into the relegation zone after Team_9 draw with Team_8 on Monday, but if they avoid defeat here, they'll leapfrog the Toffees once more. Team_11 get us back under way for the second half!

There's so much space for Elliott on the edge of the box when Endo slides it into him, but he chooses to take on another shot from range. He drags at it, sending it well wide of the far post.
PENALTY SHOUT! Mengi makes a brilliant block to deny Diaz from a tight angle, but Team_11 quickly work it back into the box. The Colombian looks to square it into the middle this time when it hits Osho's arm, which is just behind him, but the referee awards a corner.
Team_11 corner causes a scramble in the box, with nobody sure where it's going to fall next. Gakpo reacts quickest in the end to poke it towards goal, but Mpanzu clears before the offside flag goes up.
Mac Allister picks out Elliott's overlapping run down the right, and he floats a good cross into a still-crowded penalty area. Gakpo gets a flick on, but he can't direct it towards goal.
GOOD SAVE! Chong steps in to shield it from Elliott in the box, but Gakpo is on hand to nick it off him. He takes it around the winger before drilling a low shot at the near post, but Kaminski gets down smartly to push it wide.
GOOOAAALLL!!! VAN DIJK EQUALISES! It's been coming from Team_11, and their captain steps up! They finally manage to make something of one of their many corners as Mac Allister whips it into the middle, and Van Dijk darts in front of his marker to meet it. He gets power on the header, and Kaminski can't keep it out. 1-1!
It's a brilliant delivery from Mac Allister as he puts it straight onto Van Dijk's head.
GOOD SAVE! Team_11 aren't letting up the pressure here, and Bradley finds a pocket of space just inside the box. He keeps his shot low as he hits it down the middle, and Kaminski keeps it out with his feet.
Luton are making their second change in answer to that Team_11 equaliser as Woodrow is replaced by Townsend.
GOOOAAALLL!!! GAKPO SCORES! And just like that, Team_11 lead! It comes down the right side once more as it's clipped into the near post by Mac Allister, and Gakpo just peels away from his defender to meet it. It's another great header as he flicks it past Kaminski and into the back of the net. 2-1 Team_11!
That's two assists in just over two minutes for Mac Allister, who picks out another good cross into the box.
GREAT SAVE! Luton just can't get out of their own box at the moment, and Gakpo is in on goal again. He surges past Bell down the right of the box, but his low shot is turned away by Kaminski for a corner.
KAMINSKI SAVES AGAIN! Mac Allister has found his range from the corner flag and he whips another wonderful cross into the box to pick out Van Dijk. He sends another powerful header on goal, and the goalkeeper scoops it away from his line.
After a frantic spell of the game, Edwards is making another change to try and settle things in midfield. Chong is taken off, with Jordan Clark on in his place.
Mengi has his arms around Gakpo to stop him from turning past him, and Team_11 win a free-kick. Elliott swings it into the box, and Osho just does enough to stop it from reaching Gakpo.
CHANCE! Bradley is dispossessed on the halfway line, and Barkley sets off on a rare Luton attack in this second half. He slides it forward for Doughty, who tries to catch out Kelleher by chipping it towards the far post from a tight angle, but it's deflected wide.
Team_11 are making their first change now, and Bradley goes off to a standing ovation from the home crowd. He's replaced by Robertson, which means that Gomez will switch to right-back.
Osho is caught on the ball, and Gakpo profits, but his low cross is half-cleared by Mengi. He only gets it as far as Elliott, but his pullback is too short for Diaz on the far side.
GOOOAAALLL!!! DIAZ SCORES! That should do it for Team_11! After missing a couple of good chances in the first half, Diaz makes no mistake this time. Luton gives it away in their own half, with Robertson cutting out a switch to Ogbene, and his interception falls to the Colombian's feet. He drives into the box before rifling his shot past Kaminski at the near post. 3-1 Team_11!
Robertson reads it well and was alert to dart in front of Ogbene, and cushion it into Diaz's path.
SAVE! Luton have a chance to get themselves back into this game as it's sent long to Doughty, but Kelleher rushes out to close him down. The winger manages to square it to Townsend, but the goalkeeper quickly gets back in position to block it.
Luton's final change of the game is an enforced one. Doughty was caught by Kelleher during that last attack when the goalkeeper closed him down, so he can't carry on. Kabore replaces him, which will see Ogbene switch out to the left for the end of the game.
GREAT SAVE! Diaz finds space in the box once more, but with two Luton players bearing down on him, he has to take this chance quickly. He pokes it towards the near post, and Kaminski gets down smartly to tip it away.
Barkley drags at Elliott's shoulder before sliding in from behind to nick the ball off him. He did catch the youngster with the follow-through, and it earns him a yellow card, much to his frustration.
There's another change for Team_11 now, as Bobby Clark is brought on in place of Gravenberch.
Team_11 are just slowing the pace of the game down at the moment, and although Luton are attempting to press, it's half-hearted. Kelleher does misplace a pass to Robertson, but Mpanzu can't make anything of it.
CHANCE! Barkley is caught on the ball in the centre circle, and Endo is quick to slide it forward to Gakpo. He has time to take it into the box, but tries his luck from range instead, and curls it wide of the near post.
Gomez gets a handful of Ogbene's shirt, and the winger decides to pull up to show it to the referee. It works, with Luton getting a free-kick, and Gomez getting a booking.
In Salah (19), Jota (14), Nunez (13), Gakpo (11), and Diaz (10), Team_11 are the first club in Europe's big-five leagues to have five players reach 10+ goals in all competitions this season.
Luton are enjoying a good spell of possession here, but it's all in their own half as they try to slow things down a little bit. They're in no hurry to push forward, though Team_11 are pressing them high.
Quansah clips the back of Barkley's heel, taking his boot off, and Luton have a free-kick in a good position. Barkley steps up to take it but curls his effort straight into the wall.
The home crowd are on their feet to give a standing ovation to the players making way. Diaz, who scored the final goal, which looks like it will seal the three points, is replaced by Danns, who makes his debut.
And Mac Allister, who set up the first two goals, goes off for McConnell.
Kabore catches McConnell with a late tackle and becomes the fourth player to go into the referee's book.
GOOOAAALLL!!! ELLIOTT SCORES! Osho intercepts Robertson's pass, only to give it away to Danns. He slides it into the box for Gakpo, but Mengi takes it off his toe. Elliott races onto the loose ball and whips a shot past Kaminski and into the back of the net. 4-1 Team_11!
We're into eight minutes of added time here as Luton attempt to pull another goal back. Mpanzu slides it down the right for Kabore to chase, but he's caught on his heels and can't keep it in play.
Quansah is allowed to carry the ball a long way before he tries to set McConnell away down the right. Ogbene does enough to stop that from happening but puts it straight out of play to gift possession back to Team_11.
Luton are pushing forward again to try and give their fans something to cheer late on. Townsend swings in a corner, but Kelleher rushes off his line to punch it away.
FULL-TIME: Team_11 4-1 Team_12.
Team_11 brilliant second-half display sees them come from behind to beat Luton 4-1. The visitors had a wonderful first half and took the lead just 12 minutes in as Ogbene headed in the rebound of Chong's saved effort. The Reds pushed to equalise but couldn't find a way through a compact Luton side. That changed after the break though, and two goals in just over two minutes flipped the game on its head. Van Dijk levelled things up with a thumping header before Gakpo flicked in their second. Diaz then punished Luton for giving the ball away inside their own half by rifling it into the back of the net, with Elliott rounding things off late on with a lovely curling effort in the 90th minute. It's a win that lifts Team_11 four points clear at the top of the table, though they have played a game more than the teams below them. Next up for them is the EFL Cup final against Team_7 on Sunday. That loss means that Luton stay in the bottom three, and they don't play again until their FA Cup fifth-round tie against Team_13 on Tuesday. That's all for today, goodbye!"]
label: Normal

events:
Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the Premier League fixture between Aston Villa and Sheffield United at Villa Park.
Villa host Sheffield United in a game where they will be hoping to continue their sensational run of form at home. The Midlands club have won each of their last 15 Premier League home games, which is the longest run in their league history. Unai Emery’s side have also had plenty of joy against today’s opponents and are unbeaten in their last 14 home league games against the newly-promoted outfit (W8 D6). A win would see Villa climb to the top of the Premier League table, even if temporarily, with Liverpool and Arsenal set to face each other this weekend.
Sheffield United head to Villa Park in search of their first victory away from home in the Premier League this season. The Blades have endured a difficult start to life back in England’s top flight, and have won just once in their last six matches (D1 L4). Chris Wilder was recently appointed as manager and the Yorkshire side will be desperate to see the experienced boss turn things around, and a victory away to Emery’s men could see them climb off the bottom of the table and into 18th.
ASTON VILLA (4-4-1-1): Emiliano Martinez; Lucas Digne, Clement Lenglet, Ezri Konsa, Matty Cash; John McGinn, Douglas Luiz, Jacob Ramsey, Leon Bailey; Moussa Diaby; Ollie Watkins.
ASTON VILLA SUBS: Diego Carlos, Alex Moreno, Calum Chambers, Nicolo Zaniolo, Jhon Duran, Leander Dendoncker, Filip Marschall, Tim Iroegbunam, Tommi O’Reilly.
SHEFFIELD UNITED (5-3-2): Wes Foderingham; Yasser Larouci, Jack Robinson, Auston Trusty, George Baldock, Jayden Bogle; Oliver Norwood, Anis Ben Slimane, Vinicius Souza; Andre Brooks, Cameron Archer.
SHEFFIELD UNITED SUBS: Adam Davies, John Fleck, Gustavo Hamer, Max Lowe, James McAtee, Oliver McBurnie, Ben Osborn, Luke Thomas, Benie Traore.
Emery has made four changes from Villa’s victory over Brentford last time out. In defence, Digne and Lenglet come into the side, with Diego Carlos and Pau Torres dropping out. Boubacar Kamara also misses out due to suspension, while Moreno drops to the bench, with Luiz and Bailey earning a place in the starting XI.
Meanwhile, Wilder has made five alterations from the Blades’ 2-0 defeat away to Chelsea in the Premier League. Anel Ahmedhodzic has failed to make the matchday squad after starting in their last fixture. Robinson comes in to replace him at the back. On the left-hand side of defence, Larouci is named in the XI with Lowe dropping to the bench. Elsewhere, Hamer, McBurnie, and McAtee all among the substitutes, with Baldock, Norwood, and Slimane coming in.
The players are making their way out onto the pitch ahead of kick-off.
Archer gets the game under way for Sheffield United at Villa Park!
Diaby produces a neat turn just outside the penalty area, and Trusty brings him down. The referee awards a free-kick, and it's a matter of inches outside of the box. Luiz and Digne are standing over it and the former lays it off for the latter, but his whipped shot goes high and wide and out for a goal-kick. A wasted opportunity there.
McGinn receives a pass in the middle of the pitch and wastes no time trying to find Watkins in behind the defensive line. The Scottish midfielder slightly overhits it and Foderingham rushes off his line to collect. It's unlikely to be the only time the Villa striker looks to make that run, using his pace to his benefit.
A switched ball finds Bailey and he looks to take on Trusty. The Jamaican winger cuts in on his left and drives into the box, before spotting Diaby on the overlap. He takes a touch and sends a low cross into the penalty area, but the assistant referee has his flag up for offside and Wilder's men have a free-kick.
Villa work the ball well on the left and Ramsey finds the run of Digne who drives into the penalty area. He clips it towards the back post and Watkins falls to the ground after colliding with Souza. The Villa supporters want a penalty, and VAR is now checking it!
After a short delay, the referee has waved play on and there will be no penalty. Instead, the Villans have a corner. It's delivered into the box and once again, a Villa player goes to the ground. This time it's Konsa at the back post, and VAR is checking for yet another potential penalty! However, the officials have decided it won't be a penalty this time either.
Villa have dominated the early proceedings, attempting 102 passes to Sheffield United's 19. The Villans have had 84.1 per cent of the possession with two shots and might consider themselves slightly unfortunate not to have had a penalty. Wilder's side appear happy to sit back and try and absorb the pressure.
Chance! Villa look to break down the right-hand side with Bailey, who spots the run of Diaby inside the box, laying the ball into his path. The French international shoots immediately, looking to catch Foderingham out, but the Sheffield United goalkeeper makes a smart stop to deny him. Wilder's side allowed Bailey far too much room to create on the right.
This time Villa look to attack down the left as Digne and Watkins link up well, but the latter loses possession and the Blades are able to clear. Emery's side have predominantly looked to get at their opponents on the right-hand side with Bailey and Cash, while Diaby has also drifted wide to create an overload.
Bailey receives out wide and Cash bursts down the right-hand side on the overlap. The Villa right-back is found and looks to deliver into the box, but it's deflected behind for a corner. McGinn is there to take and sends a deep cross towards the back post. Konsa comes flying out of nowhere, but he can't guide his header on target and it flies behind.
Brooks dispossesses Cash deep inside the Aston Villa half and the hosts are in trouble. The Sheffield United attacker tries to find a team-mate in the box, but his cross is poor and Villa regain possession. The Blades will need to make the most of these little opportunities if they want to get something out of this game.
Norwood makes a heavy, unnecessary challenge on Luiz in the middle of the pitch and the referee awards a free-kick. He'll certainly consider himself fortunate not to have had his name taken for a booking. The Brazilian midfielder looks in a bit of discomfort, but shortly after, he's back on his feet.
The Blades have managed to complete just 50 per cent of their passes in the first half so far. Wilder will need to get his side to look after the ball better, with Sheffield United surrendering possession regularly, giving Villa plenty of chances to attack.
Villa have a corner after some good work by McGinn, who is standing over it ready to deliver. He whips it towards the back post and Lenglet is there to nod it down into the path of Watkins. The English striker takes a wild swing at it in and around the penalty spot, but he sends his strike flying over the bar. He was slightly off balance, so it wasn't a simple chance.
Ramsey finds Watkins who slows the play down and waits for his team-mates. He lays it into the path of Luiz who strikes it and it deflects out wide to McGinn. The Villa midfielder tries to deliver into the box, but it cannons off a defender and out for a corner. McGinn will take... but it comes to nothing.
Diaby has drifted out wide and looks to get one-on-one with Trusty on the right-hand side. He dances past his marker and makes his way into the penalty area, before cutting back onto his left and clipping a cross towards the back post, but the Blades are able to head it away from danger.
Emery's men are appealing for a penalty once again! McGinn receives the ball in midfield and fires a pass into the path of Watkins inside the penalty area. The Villa striker takes a touch and falls to the ground, with Baldock challenging behind him. However, the referee waves play on. The Villa Park faithful aren't happy!
Villa have managed to touch the ball inside their opponent's box 18 times since the game got underway. However, Emery's side have tested Foderingham between the sticks just once, so the Villans need to show a little more creativity in the final third if they want to open the scoring.
Once again, Villa try and create an overload on the right-hand side, with Diaby hugging the touchline before finding the overlapping run of Cash. The Polish right-back carries the ball into the box and looks to cut it back for a team-mate, but Sheffield United are able to clear the danger. Emery's side are lacking that cutting edge at the moment.
McGinn tries to find the run of Watkins in behind the Blades' defence, but Robinson is there to snuff out the danger. Wilder's side now look to break, but Cash makes a foul and United now have a chance to throw some bodies forward from a free-kick. Foderingham goes long, but nothing comes of it and Villa regain possession.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of two minutes of added time at the end of the first half.
HALF-TIME: ASTON VILLA 0-0 SHEFFIELD UNITED
Aston Villa and Sheffield United go into the break at 0-0. It's been a game with very few talking points so far as Emery's side have grown increasingly frustrated as the game has gone on. The Blades are sitting deep and absorbing the pressure, looking to hit Villa on the break. The hosts might feel they should have had a penalty in the opening 45 minutes, with VAR called into action on multiple occasions, but the referee is yet to point to the spot. The Midlands outfit will need to show a little more creativity in the second half if they want to break the deadlock.
Villa have enjoyed plenty of the ball so far, managing to have 78.2 per cent of the possession. However, they have been unable to turn their dominance into creating any clear-cut chances, producing just 0.44 expected goals (xG) since the game got under way. Wilder's side are yet to attempt a shot on goal, so they will have to show a little more attacking intent if they want to snatch a winner in the second half. Emery might be considering switching things up in the final third shortly after the break - could Zaniolo be the man to help them open the scoring?
Diaby gets the second half under way for Aston Villa at Villa Park!
Villa have a throw-in deep inside the opposition half, which is worked into the middle to McGinn. He shifts it to his right to Cash who finds Diaby, and Emery's side remain patient keeping possession. It eventually comes to Lenglet who clips the ball over the top after spotting the run of Digne, but his cross deflects behind for a corner.
The Blades look to counter with Larouci, but Bailey brings him down inside the Villa half. The referee awards him the first booking of the game.
Larouci now goes into the book for a foul on Bailey, with Villa having a chance from a free-kick inside the United half.
Luiz carries the ball through midfield and feeds it out wide to Cash on the right-hand side. The Villa right-back tries to find the run of Bailey who has burst beyond the opposition defence, but it dribbles straight into the arms of Foderingham and United are able to clear the danger. Emery's side are lacking ideas at the moment.
Villa are enjoying plenty of possession in the second half but are finding it incredibly difficult to break the Blades down. Emery's side need to show a little more creativity in the final third, and they're growing increasingly frustrated with their lack of chances since the break.
Wilder opts to take off Larouci after his earlier yellow, with Lowe coming on in his place.
It's an alteration in attack from Wilder, with Hamer entering the fray with Brooks making his way to the bench.
GOOOOOAAAALLL!! 1-0 ASTON VILLA!! The Midlands outfit finally making their dominance pay! Baldock fails to clear from a corner and Watkins pounces, playing a one-two with Ramsey. Watkins then fires a cross towards the back post where Bailey is waiting, and he slams the ball into the back of the net! But wait... VAR is checking it!
NO GOAL! Bailey's finish has been disallowed. Ramsey was adjudged to have held onto the arm of Foderingham in the build-up to the goal. After a short delay, the referee headed to his monitor after guidance from VAR, and it won't count! Still 0-0.
Bailey finds the run of Watkins who cuts inside and waits for a team-mate. He plays the ball into the path of Diaby who looks to dance through the opposition defenders, but it deflects behind for a corner. McGinn is there to take and he delivers towards the back post, but Konsa can't quite get there.
Bogle goes into the book for a strong challenge on Ramsey near the halfway line.
Villa have an opportunity from a free-kick as Luiz sends a cross into the box. It's headed away and the Blades clear the danger. Emery's side are trying everything to find a goal in the second half, but Wilder's men are defending superbly and frustrating the Midlands outfit.
Villa are now appealing for a penalty once again. The ball bounces in the box and Baldock swings his arm towards it. VAR is now checking whether a penalty should be awarded! Check complete... NOT GIVEN! The referee waves play on. It appeared to come off his shoulder.
Emery makes a change in attack, with Diaby coming off, to be replaced by Colombian striker Duran.
Villa make an alteration at left-back. Moreno comes on in a straight swap for Digne.
Wilder looks to mix things up in attack, with McAtee coming off the bench. Slimane is the player to make way.
Duran gives the ball away and Lowe carries it into the Villa half. It's switched out wide to Hamer who stays patient, waiting for his team-mates to arrive. He lays it into the path of Norwood on the edge of the box and he strikes it first time towards the top corner, but Martinez dives across his goal and holds. That was Sheffield United's first shot of the game.
So close! The ball comes to Lowe on the left-hand side after some good work from McAtee. He fires a delivery low and hard into the penalty area, and Konsa swings a leg at it. It looks as though it's flying towards the top corner, but it whistles past the post and out for a corner. The Villa fans breathe a sigh of relief!
Emery makes another change in attack. Zaniolo enters the fray, with Bailey taking his place on the bench.
Sheffield United have started to grow into the game in the second half and are beginning to show a little more attacking intent, causing Villa some problems. Emery will be incredibly disappointed with the lack of chances his team have created. The Villans have managed just two shots since the break.
VAR is now called into action once again. The are checking whether Duran should be sent off after an altercation with Robinson. After a short delay, the referee waves play on.
GOOOOOAAAAALLLL!! 1-0 SHEFFIELD UNITED!! A clever pass finds Hamer who has burst forward from midfield into the box. He turns inside the penalty area, sending McGinn to the ground, before firing a cross into the danger zone. It falls to Archer, who takes aim and smashes it home! He's scored against his former club! Wilder's side have a shock lead!
Hamer came off the bench to produce a superb assist. After an excellent turn into the penalty area, his delivery to Archer's feet was inch-perfect.
Villa are heavily pushing for an equaliser after the goal from United has sparked them into life. A delivery is deep towards the back post from Zaniolo and Moreno finds himself unmarked before powering a header towards goal, but Foderingham makes a superb stop to deny him.
Wilder brings on some fresh legs in attack, with the goalscorer Archer replaced by McBurnie.
The fourth official indicated just a few moments ago that there would be a minimum of nine minutes of added time at the end of the game. There has been a host of VAR checks, so it's certainly not surprising.
Villa are struggling to find a breakthrough in the final few minutes of the game. Emery's side are passing it back and forth inside the Sheffield United half, but the lack of creativity will be a major concern for the Midlands outfit. To their credit, Wilder's men have defended superbly.
Zaniolo goes into the book for dissent after the referee opted against awarding him a free-kick.
GOOOAAAALLLL!! 1-1 ASTON VILLA EQUALISE LATE ON! Ramsey carries the ball through the middle and shifts it out wide to Luiz. The Brazilian gets it out of his feet and delivers into the penalty area, and Zaniolo rises above Foderingham who has come off his line, powering a header into the back of the net! Emery’s side finally turn their dominance into a goal!
Luiz's delivery tempted Foderingham to come off his line while also landing perfectly on the head of Zaniolo.
Trusty receives a yellow for an altercation in the back of the net after the goal was scored.
The Blades look to counter-attack, and Cash makes a tactical foul to prevent them going through on goal.
FULL-TIME: ASTON VILLA 1-1 SHEFFIELD UNITED
Aston Villa and Sheffield United share the spoils with the game ending 1-1. The first half produced little action with the Midlands outfit dominating the possession but struggling to break the away team down. There were minimal talking points in the opening 45 minutes, but the game sparked into life after the break. Emery thought his side had opened the scoring after Bailey fired in Watkins' cross, but the goal was disallowed after a VAR check. The Villans kept pushing, but it was the Blades who broke the deadlock, with Archer pouncing in the box to score against his former club. It looked as though Wilder's men had won it late on, but a Zaniolo header deep into stoppage time levelled the scoring. Villa will travel to Manchester United on Boxing Day as they look to go top of the Premier League table. Up next for Sheffield United, they will host fellow strugglers Luton Town at Bramall Lane. That's all for today, goodbye!
summary:
Wolverhampton Wanderers produced a rampant display spearheaded by a Hwang Hee-chan brace as they secured an emphatic 4-1 victory against Brentford at the Gtech Community Stadium. 
The South Korean scored twice in the first half, before going off injured, and goals from Mario Lemina and Jean-Ricner Bellegarde gave Wolves their biggest away win in the Premier League.
Yoane Wissa scored the hosts’ solitary goal as they slumped to a fourth straight defeat.
How the match unfolded
Thomas Frank made three changes from Brentford’s defeat against Aston Villa 10 days ago, with Nathan Collins replacing Mathias Jorgensen at the back, Yehor Yarmoliuk coming in for the suspended Ben Mee and Neal Maupay returning, with Mikkel Damsgaard dropping to the bench.
Wolves made one change from Sunday’s 2-1 win against Chelsea, with Santiago Bueno coming in for Craig Dawson. Gary O’Neil’s side were also boosted by the return of Pedro Neto, who was among the substitutes.
Despite a bright start from Brentford, it was Wolves who struck first as Lemina met a deep Pablo Sarabia cross to power in a header at the back post in the 13th minute.
The visitors’ one-goal advantage quickly became two 12 seconds from kick-off when Hwang beat Mark Flekken to an underhit backpass from ex-Wolves player Collins to roll the ball into an empty net.  
In an incredible opening to the match Brentford responded instantly as a clever flick from Maupay found Wissa, who stabbed a first-time shot past Jose Sa for his first league goal since October. 
The Bees came close to grabbing an equaliser just moments later when Keane Lewis-Potter whipped in a superb cross to the back post, but Vitaly Janelt’s header from close range was straight into the arms of Sa.
Just as the match was starting to settle, Wolves found a third. The visitors capitalised on a disorganised Brentford defence and picked out Hwang, who flicked the ball over Ethan Pinnock before firing a low shot past Flekken. This was to be Hwang’s final act of the evening, as he limped off soon after.
After the match, O'Neil allayed fears over Hwang's injury, saying the South Korean should be fit to play at the Asian Cup.
With seconds remaining of an enthralling first half, Maupay and Wissa combined again but the latter could only slice his shot wide.
Brentford started the second half with intent and came close to halvingthe deficit when Maupay slid a pass in behind the Wolves defence to Wissa, whose cutback found Lewis-Potter, but the young Englishman’s effort was tame.
The hosts had two chances to score again, with Lewis-Potter at the centre of both attacks, first clipping a cute cross to the back post that narrowly evaded Mads Roerslev, before darting to the byline and pulling a low cross back into a dangerous area.
Then Wolves came close, with Matheus Cunha latching on to a through-ball from Rayan Ait-Nouri, before sliding a low shot across goal that bounced off the far post.
Their fourth goal eventually came a few minutes later, Collins again ant fault as another loose pass put Wolves through on goal. It was Cunha again leading the charge, but this time the Brazilian laid off a pass to his left to allow Bellegarde to finish.
text:
["Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the Premier League fixture between Team_2 and Team_17 at Villa Park.
Villa host Team_17 in a game where they will be hoping to continue their sensational run of form at home. The Midlands club have won each of their last 15 Premier League home games, which is the longest run in their league history. Unai Emery’s side have also had plenty of joy against today’s opponents and are unbeaten in their last 14 home league games against the newly-promoted outfit (W8 D6). A win would see Villa climb to the top of the Premier League table, even if temporarily,\xa0with Team_11 and Team_1 set to face each other this weekend.
Team_17 head to Villa Park in search of their first victory away from home in the Premier League this season. The Blades have endured a difficult start to life back in England’s top flight, and have won just once in their last six matches (D1 L4). Chris Wilder was recently appointed as manager and the Yorkshire side will be desperate to see the experienced boss turn things around, and a victory away to Emery’s men could see them climb off the bottom of the table and into 18th.
Team_2 (4-4-1-1): Emiliano Martinez; Lucas Digne, Clement Lenglet, Ezri Konsa, Matty Cash; John McGinn, Douglas Luiz, Jacob Ramsey, Leon Bailey; Moussa Diaby; Ollie Watkins.
Team_2 SUBS: Diego Carlos, Alex Moreno, Calum Chambers, Nicolo Zaniolo, Jhon Duran, Leander Dendoncker, Filip Marschall, Tim Iroegbunam, Tommi O’Reilly.
Team_17 (5-3-2): Wes Foderingham; Yasser Larouci, Jack Robinson, Auston Trusty, George Baldock, Jayden Bogle; Oliver Norwood, Anis Ben Slimane, Vinicius Souza; Andre Brooks, Cameron Archer.
Team_17 SUBS: Adam Davies, John Fleck, Gustavo Hamer, Max Lowe, James McAtee, Oliver McBurnie, Ben Osborn, Luke Thomas, Benie Traore.
Emery has made four changes from Villa’s victory over Team_4 last time out. In defence, Digne and Lenglet come into the side, with Diego Carlos and Pau Torres dropping out. Boubacar Kamara also misses out due to suspension, while Moreno drops to the bench, with Luiz and Bailey earning a place in the starting XI.
Meanwhile, Wilder has made five alterations from the Blades’ 2-0 defeat away to Team_7 in the Premier League. Anel Ahmedhodzic has failed to make the matchday squad after starting in their last fixture. Robinson comes in to replace him at the back. On the left-hand side of defence, Larouci is named in the XI with Lowe dropping to the bench. Elsewhere, Hamer, McBurnie, and McAtee all among the substitutes, with Baldock, Norwood, and Slimane coming in.
The players are making their way out onto the pitch ahead of kick-off.
Archer gets the game under way for Team_17 at Villa Park!
Diaby produces a neat turn just outside the penalty area, and Trusty brings him down. The referee awards a free-kick, and it's a matter of inches outside of the box. Luiz and Digne are standing over it and the former lays it off for the latter, but his whipped shot goes high and wide and out for a goal-kick. A wasted opportunity there.
McGinn receives a pass in the middle of the pitch and wastes no time trying to find Watkins in behind the defensive line. The Scottish midfielder slightly overhits it and Foderingham rushes off his line to collect. It's unlikely to be the only time the Villa striker looks to make that run, using his pace to his benefit.
A switched ball finds Bailey and he looks to take on Trusty. The Jamaican winger cuts in on his left and drives into the box, before spotting Diaby on the overlap. He takes a touch and sends a low cross into the penalty area, but the assistant referee has his flag up for offside and Wilder's men have a free-kick.
Villa work the ball well on the left and Ramsey finds the run of Digne who drives into the penalty area. He clips it towards the back post and Watkins falls to the ground after colliding with Souza. The Villa supporters want a penalty, and VAR is now checking it!
After a short delay, the referee has waved play on and there will be no penalty. Instead, the Villans have a corner. It's delivered into the box and once again, a Villa player goes to the ground. This time it's Konsa at the back post, and VAR is checking for yet another potential penalty! However, the officials have decided it won't be a penalty this time either.
Villa have dominated the early proceedings, attempting 102 passes to Team_17 19. The Villans have had 84.1 per cent of the possession with two shots and might consider themselves slightly unfortunate not to have had a penalty. Wilder's side appear happy to sit back and try and absorb the pressure.
Chance! Villa look to break down the right-hand side with Bailey, who spots the run of Diaby inside the box, laying the ball into his path. The French international shoots immediately, looking to catch Foderingham out, but the Team_17 goalkeeper makes a smart stop to deny him. Wilder's side allowed Bailey far too much room to create on the right.
