This time Villa look to attack down the left as Digne and Watkins link up well, but the latter loses possession and the Blades are able to clear. Emery's side have predominantly looked to get at their opponents on the right-hand side with Bailey and Cash, while Diaby has also drifted wide to create an overload.
Bailey receives out wide and Cash bursts down the right-hand side on the overlap. The Villa right-back is found and looks to deliver into the box, but it's deflected behind for a corner. McGinn is there to take and sends a deep cross towards the back post. Konsa comes flying out of nowhere, but he can't guide his header on target and it flies behind.
Brooks dispossesses Cash deep inside the Team_2 half and the hosts are in trouble. The Team_17 attacker tries to find a team-mate in the box, but his cross is poor and Villa regain possession. The Blades will need to make the most of these little opportunities if they want to get something out of this game.
Norwood makes a heavy, unnecessary challenge on Luiz in the middle of the pitch and the referee awards a free-kick. He'll certainly consider himself fortunate not to have had his name taken for a booking. The Brazilian midfielder looks in a bit of discomfort, but shortly after, he's back on his feet.
The Blades have managed to complete just 50 per cent of their passes in the first half so far. Wilder will need to get his side to look after the ball better, with Team_17 surrendering possession regularly, giving Villa plenty of chances to attack.
Villa have a corner after some good work by McGinn, who is standing over it ready to deliver. He whips it towards the back post and Lenglet is there to nod it down into the path of Watkins. The English striker takes a wild swing at it in and around the penalty spot, but he sends his strike flying over the bar. He was slightly off balance, so it wasn't a simple chance.
Ramsey finds Watkins who slows the play down and waits for his team-mates. He lays it into the path of Luiz who strikes it and it deflects out wide to McGinn. The Villa midfielder tries to deliver into the box, but it cannons off a defender and out for a corner. McGinn will take... but it comes to nothing.
Diaby has drifted out wide and looks to get one-on-one with Trusty on the right-hand side. He dances past his marker and makes his way into the penalty area, before cutting back onto his left and clipping a cross towards the back post, but the Blades are able to head it away from danger.
Emery's men are appealing for a penalty once again! McGinn receives the ball in midfield and fires a pass into the path of Watkins inside the penalty area. The Villa striker takes a touch and falls to the ground, with Baldock challenging behind him. However, the referee waves play on. The Villa Park faithful aren't happy!
Villa have managed to touch the ball inside their opponent's box 18 times since the game got underway. However, Emery's side have tested Foderingham between the sticks just once, so the Villans need to show a little more creativity in the final third if they want to open the scoring.
Once again, Villa try and create an overload on the right-hand side, with Diaby hugging the touchline before finding the overlapping run of Cash. The Polish right-back carries the ball into the box and looks to cut it back for a team-mate, but Team_17 are able to clear the danger. Emery's side are lacking that cutting edge at the moment.
McGinn tries to find the run of Watkins in behind the Blades' defence, but Robinson is there to snuff out the danger. Wilder's side now look to break, but Cash makes a foul and United now have a chance to throw some bodies forward from a free-kick. Foderingham goes long, but nothing comes of it and Villa regain possession.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of two minutes of added time at the end of the first half.
HALF-TIME: Team_2 0-0 Team_17
Team_2 and Team_17 go into the break at 0-0. It's been a game with very few talking points so far as Emery's side have grown increasingly frustrated as the game has gone on. The Blades are sitting deep and absorbing the pressure, looking to hit Villa on the break. The hosts might feel they should have had a penalty in the opening 45 minutes, with VAR called into action on multiple occasions, but the referee is yet to point to the spot. The Midlands outfit will need to show a little more creativity in the second half if they want to break the deadlock.
Villa have enjoyed plenty of the ball so far, managing to have 78.2 per cent of the possession. However, they have been unable to turn their dominance into creating any clear-cut chances, producing just 0.44 expected goals (xG) since the game got under way. Wilder's side are yet to attempt a shot on goal, so they will have to show a little more attacking intent if they want to snatch a winner in the second half. Emery might be considering switching things up in the final third shortly after the break - could Zaniolo be the man to help them open the scoring?
Diaby gets the second half under way for Team_2 at Villa Park!
Villa have a throw-in deep inside the opposition half, which is worked into the middle to McGinn. He shifts it to his right to Cash who finds Diaby, and Emery's side remain patient keeping possession. It eventually comes to Lenglet who clips the ball over the top after spotting the run of Digne, but his cross deflects behind for a corner.
The Blades look to counter with Larouci, but Bailey brings him down inside the Villa half. The referee awards him the first booking of the game.
Larouci now goes into the book for a foul on Bailey, with Villa having a chance from a free-kick inside the United half.
Luiz carries the ball through midfield and feeds it out wide to Cash on the right-hand side. The Villa right-back tries to find the run of Bailey who has burst beyond the opposition defence, but it dribbles straight into the arms of Foderingham and United are able to clear the danger. Emery's side are lacking ideas at the moment.
Villa are enjoying plenty of possession in the second half but are finding it incredibly difficult to break the Blades down. Emery's side need to show a little more creativity in the final third, and they're growing increasingly frustrated with their lack of chances since the break.
Wilder opts to take off Larouci after his earlier yellow, with Lowe coming on in his place.
It's an alteration in attack from Wilder, with Hamer entering the fray with Brooks making his way to the bench.
GOOOOOAAAALLL!! 1-0 Team_2!! The Midlands outfit finally making their dominance pay! Baldock fails to clear from a corner and Watkins pounces, playing a one-two with Ramsey. Watkins then fires a cross towards the back post where Bailey is waiting, and he slams the ball into the back of the net! But wait... VAR is checking it!
NO GOAL! Bailey's finish has been disallowed. Ramsey was adjudged to have held onto the arm of Foderingham in the build-up to the goal. After a short delay, the referee headed to his monitor after guidance from VAR, and it won't count! Still 0-0.
Bailey finds the run of Watkins who cuts inside and waits for a team-mate. He plays the ball into the path of Diaby who looks to dance through the opposition defenders, but it deflects behind for a corner. McGinn is there to take and he delivers towards the back post, but Konsa can't quite get there.
Bogle goes into the book for a strong challenge on Ramsey near the halfway line.
Villa have an opportunity from a free-kick as Luiz sends a cross into the box. It's headed away and the Blades clear the danger. Emery's side are trying everything to find a goal in the second half, but Wilder's men are defending superbly and frustrating the Midlands outfit.
Villa are now appealing for a penalty once again. The ball bounces in the box and Baldock swings his arm towards it. VAR is now checking whether a penalty should be awarded! Check complete... NOT GIVEN! The referee waves play on. It appeared to come off his shoulder.
Emery makes a change in attack, with Diaby coming off, to be replaced by Colombian striker Duran.
Villa make an alteration at left-back. Moreno comes on in a straight swap for Digne.
Wilder looks to mix things up in attack, with McAtee coming off the bench. Slimane is the player to make way.
Duran gives the ball away and Lowe carries it into the Villa half. It's switched out wide to Hamer who stays patient, waiting for his team-mates to arrive. He lays it into the path of Norwood on the edge of the box and he strikes it first time towards the top corner, but Martinez dives across his goal and holds. That was Team_17 first shot of the game.
So close! The ball comes to Lowe on the left-hand side after some good work from McAtee. He fires a delivery low and hard into the penalty area, and Konsa swings a leg at it. It looks as though it's flying towards the top corner, but it whistles past the post and out for a corner. The Villa fans breathe a sigh of relief!
Emery makes another change in attack. Zaniolo enters the fray, with Bailey taking his place on the bench.
Team_17 have started to grow into the game in the second half and are beginning to show a little more attacking intent, causing Villa some problems. Emery will be incredibly disappointed with the lack of chances his team have created. The Villans have managed just two shots since the break.
VAR is now called into action once again. The are checking whether Duran should be sent off after an altercation with Robinson. After a short delay, the referee waves play on.
GOOOOOAAAAALLLL!! 1-0 Team_17!! A clever pass finds Hamer who has burst forward from midfield into the box. He turns inside the penalty area, sending McGinn to the ground, before firing a cross into the danger zone. It falls to Archer, who takes aim and smashes it home! He's scored against his former club! Wilder's side have a shock lead!
Hamer came off the bench to produce a superb assist. After an excellent turn into the penalty area, his delivery to Archer's feet was inch-perfect.
Villa are heavily pushing for an equaliser after the goal from United has sparked them into life. A delivery is deep towards the back post from Zaniolo and Moreno finds himself unmarked before powering a header towards goal, but Foderingham makes a superb stop to deny him.
Wilder brings on some fresh legs in attack, with the goalscorer Archer replaced by McBurnie.
The fourth official indicated just a few moments ago that there would be a minimum of nine minutes of added time at the end of the game. There has been a host of VAR checks, so it's certainly not surprising.
Villa are struggling to find a breakthrough in the final few minutes of the game. Emery's side are passing it back and forth inside the Team_17 half, but the lack of creativity will be a major concern for the Midlands outfit. To their credit, Wilder's men have defended superbly.
Zaniolo goes into the book for dissent after the referee opted against awarding him a free-kick.
GOOOAAAALLLL!! 1-1 Team_2 EQUALISE LATE ON! Ramsey carries the ball through the middle and shifts it out wide to Luiz. The Brazilian gets it out of his feet and delivers into the penalty area, and Zaniolo rises above Foderingham who has come off his line, powering a header into the back of the net! Emery’s side finally turn their dominance into a goal!
Luiz's delivery tempted Foderingham to come off his line while also landing perfectly on the head of Zaniolo.
Trusty receives a yellow for an altercation in the back of the net after the goal was scored.
The Blades look to counter-attack, and Cash makes a tactical foul to prevent them going through on goal.
FULL-TIME: Team_2 1-1 Team_17
Team_2 and Team_17 share the spoils with the game ending 1-1. The first half produced little action with the Midlands outfit dominating the possession but struggling to break the away team down. There were minimal talking points in the opening 45 minutes, but the game sparked into life after the break. Emery thought his side had opened the scoring after Bailey fired in Watkins' cross, but the goal was disallowed after a VAR check. The Villans kept pushing, but it was the Blades who broke the deadlock, with Archer pouncing in the box to score against his former club. It looked as though Wilder's men had won it late on, but a Zaniolo header deep into stoppage time levelled the scoring. Villa will travel to Team_14 on Boxing Day as they look to go top of the Premier League table. Up next for Team_17, they will host fellow strugglers Team_12 at Bramall Lane. That's all for today, goodbye!"]
label: Normal

summary:
Nuno Espirito Santo guided Nottingham Forest to a second win in a row, claiming a first home Premier League win over Manchester United, winning 2-1 to climb to 15th in the table thanks to Morgan Gibbs-White brilliant curling shot.
Man Utd’s hopes that their incredible comeback win over Aston Villa a week ago would mark a change in their fortunes were hit by a ninth league defeat of the season that leave them nine points off the top four.
How the match unfolded
Nuno made two changes from the side who won 3-1 at Newcastle United, with Ryan Yates and Nicolas Dominguez returning for Callum Hudson-Odoi and Ibrahim Sangare.
Erik ten Hag was forced into one change, with Antony coming in for the ill Rasmus Hojlund, meaning Marcus Rashford played down the middle.
It was a spirited start by Forest with Chris Wood, whose confidence was high after his Boxing Day hat-trick on Tyneside, having an early sight at goal but firing narrowly over.
Forest almost opened the scoring soon after when Raphael Varane miscued his clearance and watched the ball bounce across the face of the United goal and just wide. 
The hosts continued to search for the opener, former United winger Anthony Elanga cutting inside and laying a ball into Yates whose first-time shot flew over.
In a first half of few chances, United had just one shot on target, a deflected effort from Aaron Wan-Bissaka that Matt Turner saved easily in the 33rd minute.
Despite Forest having the brighter opening to the second half, United came closest to breaking the deadlock when Diogo Dalot struck a post with a well-hit shot from distance.
That sparked the match into life, with Morgan Gibbs-White earning a yellow card for a set of rash challenges, before Varane was also booked for tripping Elanga. 
In the 64th minute Forest got a deserved breakthrough. A patient passing move found Gonzalo Montiel on the right, who turned neatly before crossing for Dominguez to score with a first-time shot.
United came close to an immediate reply, Turner blocking an effort behind for a corner before then skewing a clearance and scrambling to amend his error.
Turner erred again but was punished this time as his poor pass out was intercepted by Garnacho, who squared to Rashford to whip a low finish into the bottom corner.
But with less than 10 minutes of normal time remaining Turner was able to redeem himself. From his save of Christian Eriksen, Forest countered. Elanga played in Gibbs-White, who wrapped a first-time shot beyond Andre Onana to restore their lead.
Deep into the 10 additional minutes of stoppage time Man Utd almost equalised, Eriksen spraying a corner out to Bruno Fernandes on the edge of the box but the captain’s sweetly struck effort deflected off Murillo before Turner tipped the ball over.
A first Forest win over Man Utd since November 1994 moves them up into 15th on 20 points, five above the bottom three. Man Utd remain seventh, nine points off the top four.
label: Normal

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Nottingham Forest and Arsenal at The City Ground!
Forest were on a run of seven without a win (D1 L6) before Nuno Espirito Santo took over, with the Portuguese since overseeing just one loss in his six games at the helm (W3 D2), though that did come in their last Premier League outing when they were beaten 3-2 by Brentford. After seeing a flurry of goals in the first five games under Nuno, Forest played out a 0-0 draw away at Bristol City in their last match in the FA Cup, forcing them to another replay.
It was a 1-0 defeat in this exact fixture last season that ended Arsenal's title hopes, and the Gunners will be looking to avoid a similar scoreline here as they look to close the gap to Liverpool at the top of the table. They had a slight wobble before their mid-season break, winning just one of their seven games in all competitions (D3 L3), but came back revitalised with a thumping 5-0 win over Crystal Palace last time out. However, they're winless in their last three Premier League away games (D1 L2) and haven't won any of their last three trips to The City Ground in all competitions.
NOTTINGHAM FOREST STARTING XI (4-2-3-1): Matt Turner; Gonzalo Montiel, Andrew Omabamidele, Murillo, Harry Toffolo; Orel Mangala, Danilo; Nicolas Dominguez, Morgan Gibbs-White, Neco Williams; Chris Wood.
NOTTINGHAM FOREST SUBS: Odisseas Vlachodimos, Felipe, Ryan Yates, Joe Worrall, Callum Hudson-Odoi, Taiwo Awoniyi, Anthony Elanga, Wayne Hennessey, Brandon Aguilera.
ARSENAL STARTING XI (4-3-3): David Raya; Ben White, William Saliba, Gabriel Magalhaes, Oleksandr Zinchenko; Martin Odegaard, Declan Rice, Emile Smith Rowe; Bukayo Saka, Gabriel Jesus, Gabriel Martinelli.
ARSENAL SUBS: Reiss Nelson, Eddie Nketiah, Kai Havertz, Aaron Ramsdale, Cedric Soares, Jakub Kiwior, Jorginho, Leandro Trossard, Reuell Walters.
Nuno makes three changes from the side that drew with Bristol on Friday, as Toffolo, Gibbs-White and Williams are all brought in. Mangala retains his place, despite reports linking him with a possible move to Lyon today. Yates and Hudson-Odoi drop to the bench, where they are boosted by the returns of Felipe, Elanga and Awoniyi from injury. Nuno Tavares is ineligible to face his parent club.
Mikel Arteta makes just two changes to the side that beat Palace last time out. Smith Rowe and Martinelli, who scored twice after coming off the bench in that game, both come in. Gabriel and Rice are also fit to start after passing late fitness checks following respective ankle and thigh problems. Havertz and Trossard start on the bench.
The teams are out on the pitch now, with kick-off just moments away!
Odegaard gets the game under way for Arsenal!
Forest crowd bodies down their left side, forcing Arsenal to switch it out to the opposite flank. Jesus plays a one-two with Martinelli to try and open up space on the edge of the box, but he can't get a sight of goal.
Jesus has started the game out on the left for the Gunners and he floats a cross into the box. It's just too high for Smith Rowe to get his head on, and Turner plucks it out of the air.
Forest are starting to press higher upfield now, and they're forcing Arsenal deeper into their own half. Gabriel just squeezes his pass past a stretching Williams, but Martinelli doesn't get too far with Dominguez tight to him.
Arsenal have won five of their last six Premier League games against Forest (L1), and are looking to do the double over them in the competition for just the second time (also in 1998-99).
Saka darts in behind down the right, but there's barely any space in the Forest penalty area. He tries to pull it back to the byline, but there are three red shirts between him and his closest team-mate.
Forest are struggling to get a foothold in the game so far, with Arsenal quickly winning it back whenever possession is turned over. The hosts are defending in numbers though, making things difficult for the Gunners.
BLOCK! Odegaard sees a low shot blocked from the right, and Arsenal quickly switch it out to the opposite flank, with Martinelli sliding it through for Smith Rowe. He squares it into the middle for Jesus, but his first-time shot deflects over off Omobamidele.
The offside flag goes up to end an Arsenal attack, and now there's a break in play, Turner goes down holding his right hand. He needs treatment, but he's quickly back on his feet to continue.
Forest's first push into the final third is quickly smothered, and Arsenal break quickly on the counter. Zinchenko tries to slide in Jesus on the left of the box, but the offside flag is up once more.
Raya goes long with a free-kick, and White gets in front of Toffolo down the right. A heavy touch at the wrong moment gets away from him though, and he runs it out of play before he can put a cross in.
Arsenal have had 71 per cent possession so far in this game, and they don't look like letting up the pressure any time soon. Martinelli drops a shoulder to lose Montiel down the right, but there are no Arsenal players in the box to get on the end of his cross.
Jesus drops deep in his own half to cut out a Forest attack before setting Martinelli on the break. He drives down the left and sees a cross blocked by Williams, who goes to ground. He's holding his wrist, but he gets back up without needing treatment.
Williams is penalised for a handball in midfield and Arsenal win a free-kick. After some debate, it's Odegaard that whips it into the box, but Turner rushes off his line to collect it.
Martinelli is getting a lot of joy down the left, and after Rice stops Gibbs-White's cross, he sets the Brazilian on his way. He fizzes a low cross into the box this time, but Murillo slides in to stop it from reaching Saka.
Saka gets a yard on Toffolo and lays it off to Odegaard, who touches it straight to Jesus. Instead of turning to have a shot, he tries to return it to the Arsenal captain, but it's one pass too many, and Forest clear their lines.
CHANCE! It's better from Arsenal here as Jesus slips away from Williams to burst along the edge of the box before touching it into Smith Rowe's feet. He spins to get a shot away, but he scoops it just wide of the near post.
Forest have barely managed a touch of the ball in the last five minutes as Arsenal continue to up the pressure. Jesus is in the middle of every attack as he lifts it over the top towards Martinelli, but Omabamidele stretches to nod it out of his path.
The Forest fans aren't happy with the referee at the moment, as they feel they should've had a free-kick. Dominguez looks to play a one-two with Williams, but he's blocked off from getting to the return pass. The referee waves him back to his feet.
BLOCK! There's a collision between Omabamidele and Montiel that sees the latter stay down in the box, but the referee doesn't stop play as it isn't a head injury. Martinelli carries on, curling a shot on goal, but it's blocked by Murillo.
Now that the danger has gone for Forest, Montiel goes down once more. He was caught on his shoulder by Omabamidele's studs and needs treatment. He's okay to carry on.
Again, Arsenal overwork it in the final third, and another chance goes begging. It's more good work by Jesus down the left as he fizzes it into the box, but Odegaard chooses to knock it onto Rice. There isn't enough on it though, and Danilo pokes it away.
Jesus picks up the first yellow card of the game. He's complaining about a decision not going his way and gets booked for dissent.
CHANCE! Danilo wins it back in midfield and the space just opens up in front of him to drive into. He takes it to the edge of the D before taking aim, but his shot sails just over Raya's crossbar.
SO CLOSE! Zinchenko's sliced cross isn't dealt with by Forest, and Smith Rowe keeps the move alive for Arsenal. His touch is heavy, but it ends up being a good pass to Saka, whose first-time shot trickles just wide of the near post after taking a deflection off Murillo.
Into the first of three added minutes, and Arsenal are trying to get a goal just before the break. They're still finding a lot of space down their left, with Zinchenko clipping it in this time, but Jesus' header loops high over the bar.
GOOD SAVE! In the final action of the first half, Saka checks back to lose Montiel before curling a deep cross into the far post. Jesus gets above Omabamidele to head it towards the top corner, but Turner stretches to tip it over.
HALF-TIME: NOTTINGHAM FOREST 0-0 ARSENAL.
Despite Arsenal's dominance over Forest in the first half, it's goalless at the break. The Gunners had 81 per cent possession but struggled to break down a compact Forest side in front of them. Their best chance came on the stroke of half-time as Jesus' header had to be scrambled over by Turner, with Smith Rowe also sending an attempt over on the half-hour mark. Forest barely got out of their own half, but Danilo had a good chance, only to send it over the bar when one-on-one with Raya.
As soon as the half-time whistle blew, Arteta set off on a jog down the tunnel, clearly eager to get his team inside. Everything has worked for them until they got it into the final third, and they need to come up with a plan on how to open up their opponents. Forest have defended as a unit, which Nuno will have been pleased to see. They'll likely keep biding their time, looking for the golden chance that could snatch something from this game.
There's a change at the break for Forest, and it's a straight swap up front. Wood struggled to get into the game, and he's replaced by Awoniyi.
Forest get us back under way for the second half!
Arsenal have picked up where they left off in the first half, with Saka linking up well with Jesus down the right. The Brazilian fizzes a low cross towards Smith Rowe, but Murillo hooks it away.
Zinchenko chips it forward for Martinelli, and it looks like the chance is gone when he trips, but he does well to still get a cross away. He can't pick out a team-mate either though, and Forest clear their lines once more.
Gibbs-White tries to pick out Awoniyi with an early pass, but Gabriel blocks it, only to gift possession back to the midfielder. He switches it out to Williams on the right instead, but Saliba gets in the way of that cross. That's much better by Forest!
SAVE! Awoniyi is wrestled down by Saliba to win a free-kick, and Gibbs-White curls a good delivery into the box. Williams rises highest to nod it towards goal, but it's straight down the middle at Raya.
GREAT SAVE! The game has opened up in the last couple of minutes, and Arsenal surge forward on the counter. It's not the cleanest strike by Saka as it bobbles in front of him and takes a slight nick off Montiel, but Turner still needs to get a strong arm behind it.
Jesus has his hands up at the far post, asking for Martinelli to pick him out as he's completely unmarked. His fellow Brazilian tries to do just that, but Murillo thumps it away for a corner in front of Turner, who had it covered.
OFF THE POST! It's great play from Arsenal, as Saka rolls it back to Odegaard, who dummies a shot before laying it off to Jesus on the right of the box. He's one-on-one with Turner and rifles a powerful shot past him, but it ricochets off the near post.
Forest have only won one of their last six Premier League games when drawing 0-0 at half-time (D3 L2), although that win did come in their most recent such match (2-1 v Manchester United in December).
Danilo spins away from two Arsenal defenders with clever turns, hooking the ball over his shoulder each time. There are half-hearted shouts from the stands for a penalty after he goes down under pressure from Gabriel in the box, but nothing's given.
Omabamidele darts in front of Smith Rowe to cut out Martinelli's cross, only to gift it straight back to the winger. He tries to pick out Jesus with his second attempt, but Danilo intercepts that one.
Forest are making another change here, and it's another adjustment to their frontline. Dominguez goes off, with Hudson-Odoi brought on in his place.
JESUS SCORES! Arsenal finally break the deadlock! After all of their hard work, Forest are opened up by a long throw-in from Zinchenko to Jesus, who has time to turn before driving into the box. The angle is tight, and he has no right to score from there, but his low shot goes through Turner's legs and rolls over the line. 1-0 Arsenal!
Zinchenko is assessing his options when the space just opens up for him to throw it straight to Jesus, though the forward still has a lot of work to do.
Nuno gives a shake of his head on the touchline as Forest get the game back under way. Williams pushes forward down the right, but can't get away from Zinchenko to pick out a cross.
Saliba cuts out Williams' cross, and the Gunners mount another dangerous counter. Saka has acres of space down the right and cuts inside to curl a shot on goal. It's blocked by Mangala, and Arsenal win their eighth corner of the game.
Arsenal's first change of the game sees Smith Rowe taken off for Havertz.
And there's another roll of the dice for Forest too, as Mangala makes way for Yates.
SAKA SCORES! It's a really poor attempt to get Forest upfield by Montiel as he gifts it straight to Odegaard on the edge of the centre circle. He wastes no time sweeping it out to Jesus on the left, and he gets his head up to spot Saka in space on the edge of the box. He hits a low shot across goal, and though Turner gets fingertips to it, he can't stop it from hitting the back of the net. 2-0 Arsenal!
Jesus has had a really bright game for Arsenal, and now he has an assist to go with his earlier goal.
Jesus has switched out to the right now, and he whips a pacy cross into Havertz on the far side. He can't get it under control for a shot but manages to poke it to Saka. Murillo desperately swings out a leg to clear it just in time.
That second Arsenal goal just seems to have knocked Forest's confidence slightly, and they're not pressing as high as before. The visitors aren't in a hurry to push forward, content to hold onto the ball in their own half.
Forest's final change of the game sees Elanga make his return from a thigh injury as he comes on for Williams.
Arsenal are making a double change as well. Martinelli goes off for Trossard.
And Jesus goes off to a warm reception from the away fans as he's replaced by Nketiah.
Jesus has now scored against 29 of the 31 sides he has played against in the Premier League (94 per cent), failing to do so only against Cardiff City (one app) and Manchester City (two apps).
WIDE! Arsenal break quickly on the counter once more, and Odegaard slides it into Trossard's path on the edge of the box. He puts his laces through the shot, but it swerves away from goal and wide of the post.
Nketiah is slightly off balance, but he still manages to volley a cross into the box, looking for Trossard on the penalty spot. Omabamidele is alert to send it out for another Arsenal corner, which comes to nothing.
Forest are still trying to play out from the back, but they can't find a way through Arsenal. Awoniyi plays a blind pass out to the right, not realising that none of his team-mates are there, and the Gunners are quickly back in possession.
It's a risky backpass from Danilo to Turner, and he doesn't get enough on it. Saka gambles by chasing it down, but he catches Toffolo as the defender tries to hook it away.
AWONIYI PULLS ONE BACK! Danilo goes for a more direct route this time, making a big switch to Montiel on the right, and he picks out a good cross into the middle. Awoniyi has two Arsenal defenders around him, but an awkward bounce favours him and wrongfoots Saliba. The forward reacts quickest to latch onto it and pokes it under Raya. VAR checks for an offside against Montiel, but he was onside. 2-1!
Montiel times his run perfectly to get in behind Zinchenko before picking out a good cross that causes confusion in the Arsenal penalty area.
Into the first of five added minutes here, and the Forest fans now believe they can snatch something late on. They're urging their team upfield and another loud cheer goes up as Elanga wins a corner.
Arteta is making a double change before Forest can take their corner because he wants to get two more defensive players on. Jorginho replaces Odegaard.
And Kiwior comes on in place of Zinchenko.
BLOCK! Raya's punched clearance isn't overly convincing, and it loops to Gibbs-White, who puts his laces through the half-volley. Kiwior is at full stretch to block it and it loops up for Awoniyi, but his effort is straight at the goalkeeper.
Murillo jumps to clear a long ball over the top, but as he does, Nketiah crashes head-first into his hip. The defender can't believe that a free-kick has gone against him, but it's giving Arsenal a chance to run the clock down.
Forest have one last chance to get the ball into the box, and Toffolo goes for a long throw-in. It's headed straight back to him by Rice, but his follow-up cross skims the top of Elanga's head.
FULL-TIME: NOTTINGHAM FOREST 1-2 ARSENAL.
Arsenal hold on to get a 2-1 win over Forest and close the gap to league leaders Liverpool. The Gunners dominated the first half but struggled in the final third to break down a compact Forest defence, though Jesus forced Turner into a good save right on the stroke of half-time. Things opened up after the break, and Jesus rifled a shot against the post before finally breaking the deadlock with a clever finish from a very tight angle. Shortly after, Arsenal got their second following a quick counter as Saka drilled his low shot across goal into the bottom corner. In the 89th minute, Awoniyi gave the hosts some hope, poking it past Raya to half the deficit, but they couldn't find another to get something from the game. It's three points that lift Arsenal into second place, now just two points behind Liverpool, who don't play until tomorrow, and it's the Reds that they face at the weekend. As for Forest, they stay in 16th, but the gap to the relegation zone is significantly smaller now due to results elsewhere. They travel to Bournemouth on Sunday. That's all for today, goodbye!
summary:
Callum Hudson-Odoi earned Nottingham Forest a point as they drew 1-1 at AFC Bournemouth to move two points clear of the bottom three.
Justin Kluivert opened the scoring for the Cherries, but Hudson-Odoi levelled with a sweetly-struck shot on the stroke of half-time.
Bournemouth substitute Philip Billing was sent off for a dangerous challenge on Hudson-Odoi with six minutes remaining, but Andoni Iraola’s side held on for a second consecutive 1-1 draw.
How the match unfolded
Iraola made two changes from the side that drew at West Ham United, with Luis Sinisterra and Kluivert coming in for Marcus Tavernier and Alex Scott.
As for Forest, new signing Matz Sels started in goal, while fellow January arrivals Gio Reyna and Rodrigo Ribeiro were named among the substitutes. Taiwo Awoniyi returned in attack after scoring off the bench in the 2-1 defeat to Arsenal as one of six changes.
It only took Bournemouth five minutes to open the scoring, with Sinisterra’s corner taking a touch off Forest’s Neco Williams before falling to Kluivert, who finished at the far post.
Forest responded well to the early setback, with Awoniyi forcing two saves from Neto before Ryan Yates missed a glorious chance to equalise, poking tamely at the Bournemouth 'keeper.
But the visitors did score a deserved equaliser on 45 minutes through Hudson-Odoi.
Bournemouth were unable to clear a free-kick, and after picking up the ball just outside the penalty area, Hudson-Odoi drove forward before whipping a superb shot into the bottom-right corner for his first Premier League goal since September.
Both sides struggled to create clear-cut openings in the second half, with Awoniyi hesitating when presented with a sight of goal.
Billing was shown a red card late on, but Forest were unable to take advantage, with Morgan Gibbs-White scuffing a shot straight at Neto, as both sides had to settle for a point.
Nuno Espirito Santo’s team stay 16th on 21 points, six fewer than Bournemouth, who remain 12th.
Club reports
Bournemouth report | Nott'm Forest report
Referee: Rebecca Welch. Assistants: Simon Bennett, Dan Robathan. Fourth official: Tony Harrington. VAR: Peter Bankes. Assistant VAR: Simon Long.
text:
["Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Team_16 and Team_1 at The City Ground!
Forest were on a run of seven without a win (D1 L6) before Nuno Espirito Santo took over, with the Portuguese since overseeing just one loss in his six games at the helm (W3 D2), though that did come in their last Premier League outing when they were beaten 3-2 by Team_4. After seeing a flurry of goals in the first five games under Nuno, Forest played out a 0-0 draw away at Bristol City in their last match in the FA Cup, forcing them to another replay.
It was a 1-0 defeat in this exact fixture last season that ended Team_1 title hopes, and the Gunners will be looking to avoid a similar scoreline here as they look to close the gap to Team_11 at the top of the table. They had a slight wobble before their mid-season break, winning just one of their seven games in all competitions (D3 L3), but came back revitalised with a thumping 5-0 win over Team_8 last time out. However, they're winless in their last three Premier League away games (D1 L2) and haven't won any of their last three trips to The City Ground in all competitions.
Team_16 STARTING XI (4-2-3-1): Matt Turner; Gonzalo Montiel, Andrew Omabamidele, Murillo, Harry Toffolo; Orel Mangala, Danilo; Nicolas Dominguez, Morgan Gibbs-White, Neco Williams; Chris Wood.
Team_16 SUBS: Odisseas Vlachodimos, Felipe, Ryan Yates, Joe Worrall, Callum Hudson-Odoi, Taiwo Awoniyi, Anthony Elanga, Wayne Hennessey, Brandon Aguilera.
Team_1 STARTING XI (4-3-3): David Raya; Ben White, William Saliba, Gabriel Magalhaes, Oleksandr Zinchenko; Martin Odegaard, Declan Rice, Emile Smith Rowe; Bukayo Saka, Gabriel Jesus, Gabriel Martinelli.
Team_1 SUBS: Reiss Nelson, Eddie Nketiah, Kai Havertz, Aaron Ramsdale, Cedric Soares, Jakub Kiwior, Jorginho, Leandro Trossard, Reuell Walters.
Nuno makes three changes from the side that drew with Bristol on Friday, as Toffolo, Gibbs-White and Williams are all brought in. Mangala retains his place, despite reports linking him with a possible move to Lyon today. Yates and Hudson-Odoi drop to the bench, where they are boosted by the returns of Felipe, Elanga and Awoniyi from injury. Nuno Tavares is ineligible to face his parent club.
Mikel Arteta makes just two changes to the side that beat Palace last time out. Smith Rowe and Martinelli, who scored twice after coming off the bench in that game, both come in. Gabriel and Rice are also fit to start after passing late fitness checks following respective ankle and thigh problems. Havertz and Trossard start on the bench.
The teams are out on the pitch now, with kick-off just moments away!
Odegaard gets the game under way for Team_1!
Forest crowd bodies down their left side, forcing Team_1 to switch it out to the opposite flank. Jesus plays a one-two with Martinelli to try and open up space on the edge of the box, but he can't get a sight of goal.
Jesus has started the game out on the left for the Gunners and he floats a cross into the box. It's just too high for Smith Rowe to get his head on, and Turner plucks it out of the air.
Forest are starting to press higher upfield now, and they're forcing Team_1 deeper into their own half. Gabriel just squeezes his pass past a stretching Williams, but Martinelli doesn't get too far with Dominguez tight to him.
Team_1 have won five of their last six Premier League games against Forest (L1), and are looking to do the double over them in the competition for just the second time (also in 1998-99).
Saka darts in behind down the right, but there's barely any space in the Forest penalty area. He tries to pull it back to the byline, but there are three red shirts between him and his closest team-mate.
Forest are struggling to get a foothold in the game so far, with Team_1 quickly winning it back whenever possession is turned over. The hosts are defending in numbers though, making things difficult for the Gunners.
BLOCK! Odegaard sees a low shot blocked from the right, and Team_1 quickly switch it out to the opposite flank, with Martinelli sliding it through for Smith Rowe. He squares it into the middle for Jesus, but his first-time shot deflects over off Omobamidele.
The offside flag goes up to end an Team_1 attack, and now there's a break in play, Turner goes down holding his right hand. He needs treatment, but he's quickly back on his feet to continue.
Forest's first push into the final third is quickly smothered, and Team_1 break quickly on the counter. Zinchenko tries to slide in Jesus on the left of the box, but the offside flag is up once more.
Raya goes long with a free-kick, and White gets in front of Toffolo down the right. A heavy touch at the wrong moment gets away from him though, and he runs it out of play before he can put a cross in.
Team_1 have had 71 per cent possession so far in this game, and they don't look like letting up the pressure any time soon. Martinelli drops a shoulder to lose Montiel down the right, but there are no Team_1 players in the box to get on the end of his cross.
Jesus drops deep in his own half to cut out a Forest attack before setting Martinelli on the break. He drives down the left and sees a cross blocked by Williams, who goes to ground. He's holding his wrist, but he gets back up without needing treatment.
Williams is penalised for a handball in midfield and Team_1 win a free-kick. After some debate, it's Odegaard that whips it into the box, but Turner rushes off his line to collect it.
Martinelli is getting a lot of joy down the left, and after Rice stops Gibbs-White's cross, he sets the Brazilian on his way. He fizzes a low cross into the box this time, but Murillo slides in to stop it from reaching Saka.
Saka gets a yard on Toffolo and lays it off to Odegaard, who touches it straight to Jesus. Instead of turning to have a shot, he tries to return it to the Team_1 captain, but it's one pass too many, and Forest clear their lines.
CHANCE! It's better from Team_1 here as Jesus slips away from Williams to burst along the edge of the box before touching it into Smith Rowe's feet. He spins to get a shot away, but he scoops it just wide of the near post.
Forest have barely managed a touch of the ball in the last five minutes as Team_1 continue to up the pressure. Jesus is in the middle of every attack as he lifts it over the top towards Martinelli, but Omabamidele stretches to nod it out of his path.
The Forest fans aren't happy with the referee at the moment, as they feel they should've had a free-kick. Dominguez looks to play a one-two with Williams, but he's blocked off from getting to the return pass. The referee waves him back to his feet.
BLOCK! There's a collision between Omabamidele and Montiel that sees the latter stay down in the box, but the referee doesn't stop play as it isn't a head injury. Martinelli carries on, curling a shot on goal, but it's blocked by Murillo.
Now that the danger has gone for Forest, Montiel goes down once more. He was caught on his shoulder by Omabamidele's studs and needs treatment. He's okay to carry on.
Again, Team_1 overwork it in the final third, and another chance goes begging. It's more good work by Jesus down the left as he fizzes it into the box, but Odegaard chooses to knock it onto Rice. There isn't enough on it though, and Danilo pokes it away.
Jesus picks up the first yellow card of the game. He's complaining about a decision not going his way and gets booked for dissent.
CHANCE! Danilo wins it back in midfield and the space just opens up in front of him to drive into. He takes it to the edge of the D before taking aim, but his shot sails just over Raya's crossbar.
SO CLOSE! Zinchenko's sliced cross isn't dealt with by Forest, and Smith Rowe keeps the move alive for Team_1. His touch is heavy, but it ends up being a good pass to Saka, whose first-time shot trickles just wide of the near post after taking a deflection off Murillo.
Into the first of three added minutes, and Team_1 are trying to get a goal just before the break. They're still finding a lot of space down their left, with Zinchenko clipping it in this time, but Jesus' header loops high over the bar.
GOOD SAVE! In the final action of the first half, Saka checks back to lose Montiel before curling a deep cross into the far post. Jesus gets above Omabamidele to head it towards the top corner, but Turner stretches to tip it over.
HALF-TIME: Team_16 0-0 Team_1.
Despite Team_1 dominance over Forest in the first half, it's goalless at the break. The Gunners had 81 per cent possession but struggled to break down a compact Forest side in front of them. Their best chance came on the stroke of half-time as Jesus' header had to be scrambled over by Turner, with Smith Rowe also sending an attempt over on the half-hour mark. Forest barely got out of their own half, but Danilo had a good chance, only to send it over the bar when one-on-one with Raya.
As soon as the half-time whistle blew, Arteta set off on a jog down the tunnel, clearly eager to get his team inside. Everything has worked for them until they got it into the final third, and they need to come up with a plan on how to open up their opponents. Forest have defended as a unit, which Nuno will have been pleased to see. They'll likely keep biding their time, looking for the golden chance that could snatch something from this game.
There's a change at the break for Forest, and it's a straight swap up front. Wood struggled to get into the game, and he's replaced by Awoniyi.
Forest get us back under way for the second half!
Team_1 have picked up where they left off in the first half, with Saka linking up well with Jesus down the right. The Brazilian fizzes a low cross towards Smith Rowe, but Murillo hooks it away.
Zinchenko chips it forward for Martinelli, and it looks like the chance is gone when he trips, but he does well to still get a cross away. He can't pick out a team-mate either though, and Forest clear their lines once more.
Gibbs-White tries to pick out Awoniyi with an early pass, but Gabriel blocks it, only to gift possession back to the midfielder. He switches it out to Williams on the right instead, but Saliba gets in the way of that cross. That's much better by Forest!
SAVE! Awoniyi is wrestled down by Saliba to win a free-kick, and Gibbs-White curls a good delivery into the box. Williams rises highest to nod it towards goal, but it's straight down the middle at Raya.
GREAT SAVE! The game has opened up in the last couple of minutes, and Team_1 surge forward on the counter. It's not the cleanest strike by Saka as it bobbles in front of him and takes a slight nick off Montiel, but Turner still needs to get a strong arm behind it.
Jesus has his hands up at the far post, asking for Martinelli to pick him out as he's completely unmarked. His fellow Brazilian tries to do just that, but Murillo thumps it away for a corner in front of Turner, who had it covered.
OFF THE POST! It's great play from Team_1, as Saka rolls it back to Odegaard, who dummies a shot before laying it off to Jesus on the right of the box. He's one-on-one with Turner and rifles a powerful shot past him, but it ricochets off the near post.
Forest have only won one of their last six Premier League games when drawing 0-0 at half-time (D3 L2), although that win did come in their most recent such match (2-1 v Team_14 in December).
Danilo spins away from two Team_1 defenders with clever turns, hooking the ball over his shoulder each time. There are half-hearted shouts from the stands for a penalty after he goes down under pressure from Gabriel in the box, but nothing's given.
Omabamidele darts in front of Smith Rowe to cut out Martinelli's cross, only to gift it straight back to the winger. He tries to pick out Jesus with his second attempt, but Danilo intercepts that one.
Forest are making another change here, and it's another adjustment to their frontline. Dominguez goes off, with Hudson-Odoi brought on in his place.
JESUS SCORES! Team_1 finally break the deadlock! After all of their hard work, Forest are opened up by a long throw-in from Zinchenko to Jesus, who has time to turn before driving into the box. The angle is tight, and he has no right to score from there, but his low shot goes through Turner's legs and rolls over the line. 1-0 Team_1!
Zinchenko is assessing his options when the space just opens up for him to throw it straight to Jesus, though the forward still has a lot of work to do.
Nuno gives a shake of his head on the touchline as Forest get the game back under way. Williams pushes forward down the right, but can't get away from Zinchenko to pick out a cross.
Saliba cuts out Williams' cross, and the Gunners mount another dangerous counter. Saka has acres of space down the right and cuts inside to curl a shot on goal. It's blocked by Mangala, and Team_1 win their eighth corner of the game.
Team_1 first change of the game sees Smith Rowe taken off for Havertz.
And there's another roll of the dice for Forest too, as Mangala makes way for Yates.
SAKA SCORES! It's a really poor attempt to get Forest upfield by Montiel as he gifts it straight to Odegaard on the edge of the centre circle. He wastes no time sweeping it out to Jesus on the left, and he gets his head up to spot Saka in space on the edge of the box. He hits a low shot across goal, and though Turner gets fingertips to it, he can't stop it from hitting the back of the net. 2-0 Team_1!
Jesus has had a really bright game for Team_1, and now he has an assist to go with his earlier goal.
Jesus has switched out to the right now, and he whips a pacy cross into Havertz on the far side. He can't get it under control for a shot but manages to poke it to Saka. Murillo desperately swings out a leg to clear it just in time.
That second Team_1 goal just seems to have knocked Forest's confidence slightly, and they're not pressing as high as before. The visitors aren't in a hurry to push forward, content to hold onto the ball in their own half.
Forest's final change of the game sees Elanga make his return from a thigh injury as he comes on for Williams.
Team_1 are making a double change as well. Martinelli goes off for Trossard.
And Jesus goes off to a warm reception from the away fans as he's replaced by Nketiah.
Jesus has now scored against 29 of the 31 sides he has played against in the Premier League (94 per cent), failing to do so only against Cardiff City (one app) and Team_13 (two apps).
WIDE! Team_1 break quickly on the counter once more, and Odegaard slides it into Trossard's path on the edge of the box. He puts his laces through the shot, but it swerves away from goal and wide of the post.
Nketiah is slightly off balance, but he still manages to volley a cross into the box, looking for Trossard on the penalty spot. Omabamidele is alert to send it out for another Team_1 corner, which comes to nothing.
Forest are still trying to play out from the back, but they can't find a way through Team_1. Awoniyi plays a blind pass out to the right, not realising that none of his team-mates are there, and the Gunners are quickly back in possession.
It's a risky backpass from Danilo to Turner, and he doesn't get enough on it. Saka gambles by chasing it down, but he catches Toffolo as the defender tries to hook it away.
AWONIYI PULLS ONE BACK! Danilo goes for a more direct route this time, making a big switch to Montiel on the right, and he picks out a good cross into the middle. Awoniyi has two Team_1 defenders around him, but an awkward bounce favours him and wrongfoots Saliba. The forward reacts quickest to latch onto it and pokes it under Raya. VAR checks for an offside against Montiel, but he was onside. 2-1!
Montiel times his run perfectly to get in behind Zinchenko before picking out a good cross that causes confusion in the Team_1 penalty area.
Into the first of five added minutes here, and the Forest fans now believe they can snatch something late on. They're urging their team upfield and another loud cheer goes up as Elanga wins a corner.
Arteta is making a double change before Forest can take their corner because he wants to get two more defensive players on. Jorginho replaces Odegaard.
And Kiwior comes on in place of Zinchenko.
BLOCK! Raya's punched clearance isn't overly convincing, and it loops to Gibbs-White, who puts his laces through the half-volley. Kiwior is at full stretch to block it and it loops up for Awoniyi, but his effort is straight at the goalkeeper.
Murillo jumps to clear a long ball over the top, but as he does, Nketiah crashes head-first into his hip. The defender can't believe that a free-kick has gone against him, but it's giving Team_1 a chance to run the clock down.
Forest have one last chance to get the ball into the box, and Toffolo goes for a long throw-in. It's headed straight back to him by Rice, but his follow-up cross skims the top of Elanga's head.
FULL-TIME: Team_16 1-2 Team_1.
Team_1 hold on to get a 2-1 win over Forest and close the gap to league leaders Team_11. The Gunners dominated the first half but struggled in the final third to break down a compact Forest defence, though Jesus forced Turner into a good save right on the stroke of half-time. Things opened up after the break, and Jesus rifled a shot against the post before finally breaking the deadlock with a clever finish from a very tight angle. Shortly after, Team_1 got their second following a quick counter as Saka drilled his low shot across goal into the bottom corner. In the 89th minute, Awoniyi gave the hosts some hope, poking it past Raya to half the deficit, but they couldn't find another to get something from the game. It's three points that lift Team_1 into second place, now just two points behind Team_11, who don't play until tomorrow, and it's the Reds that they face at the weekend. As for Forest, they stay in 16th, but the gap to the relegation zone is significantly smaller now due to results elsewhere. They travel to Team_3 on Sunday. That's all for today, goodbye!"]
label: Normal

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Everton and Luton Town at Goodison Park!
It's been a good week for Everton - they picked up their first Premier League win of the season last time out, beating Brentford 3-1 on Saturday before following it up with an EFL Cup third-round win over Aston Villa in midweek to progress to the next round. They're looking to keep building on this momentum and turn around their fortunes at home after failing to win and score in all three of their games at Goodison Park so far.
Luton, on the other hand, are still looking for their first win in the league this season, but did get their first point on the board in a 1-1 draw with 10-man Wolves last weekend. They've lost their other four games in the competition, and come into this game after being knocked out of the EFL Cup by League One side, Exeter City, in their midweek match.
EVERTON STARTING XI (4-4-1-1): Jordan Pickford; Ashley Young, James Tarkowski, Jarrad Branthwaite, Vitalii Mykolenko; James Garner, Amadou Onana, Idrissa Gueye, Dwight McNeil; Abdoulaye Doucoure; Dominic Calvert-Lewin.
EVERTON SUBS: Lewis Dobbin, Beto, Youssef Chermiti, Michael Keane, Ben Godfrey, Arnaut Danjuma, Jack Harrison, Joao Virginia, Nathan Patterson.
LUTON TOWN STARTING XI (3-4-2-1): Thomas Kaminski; Reece Burke, Tom Lockyer, Amari'i Bell; Issa Kabore, Pelly-Ruddock Mpanzu, Marvelous Nakamba, Alfie Doughty; Jacob Brown, Chiedozie Ogbene; Carlton Morris.
LUTON TOWN SUBS: Ryan Giles, Cauley Woodrow, Luke Berry, Joseph Johnson, Teden Mengi, Tahith Chong, Elijah Adebayo, Mads Andersen, Tim Krul.
Sean Dyche makes four changes from the side that knocked Villa out of the EFL Cup on Wednesday. Young, Gueye, McNeil and Doucoure are all brought in, while Mykolenko has passed a late fitness test to retain his place. Keane, Patterson, Harrison and Danjuma drop to the bench.
After ringing in the changes for their midweek loss to Exeter, Rob Edwards goes back to the side that drew with Wolves in their last Premier League game, with one enforced alteration. Albert Sambi Lokonga picked up a hamstring injury in that match, so he's out. Mpanzu comes in to replace him.
The teams are out on the pitch now, with kick-off just moments away!
Ogbene gets the game under way for Luton!
It's Everton trying to pile on some early pressure and it's knocked back to Tarkowski who sends it long over the top. Doucoure has made a good run through the middle, but Lockyer gets across to cut it out.
CLOSE! Doucoure's pass out to McNeil on the left is short, but a lazy touch by Kabore helps it into the winger's feet anyway. It bounces up in front of him and he strikes it on the volley, but it flashes wide of the far post.
SAVE! It's lovely work from Everton down the left, but Mykolenko's cross is put out from a throw-in. The left-back gets it straight back from Doucoure and this time picks out a good ball, but Calvert-Lewin's header is straight at Kaminski.
It's a good, darting run from Ogbene down the left, and he pulls it back to Nakamba when he spots him in space on the edge of the box. He leans back as he takes the shot though, and it's always rising over the bar.
Luton are winless in their six league games against Everton (D3 L3), with this the first such meeting between the sides since a 1-1 draw at Goodison Park in March 1992.
WIDE! Luton are wide open at the back and Doucoure switches play wonderfully out to Garner in acres of space down the right. He cuts onto his left foot and then tries to place it, but instead curls it wide of the far post.
CHANCE! It's more good play from Everton as Onana threads it through to Doucoure. He can't get a sight of goal so knocks it back for Gueye on the edge of the box, but he fires his first-time shot wide of the near post.
Onana finds another pocket of space in midfield and he floats a lovely pass out to Garner on the right. He plays a dangerous low ball across the six-yard box, but nobody's there for Everton.
WIDE! Everton miss another good chance! They knock it neatly down the left, and Mykolenko flicks it to Onana. He tries to whip a shot towards the far bottom corner, but just can't get it on target.
Down the other end, Morris holds the ball up before teeing up Ogbene for another driving run down the left. He pulls it back to the penalty spot towards Brown, but Onana gets back in time to hook it away.
Luton are starting to grow into this game, and Bell plays a good reverse pass into Doughty on the left. He holds the ball up instead of putting it into the box, but does manage to win a corner.
OVER! The resulting corner is swung in by Doughty, and his out-swinging cross picks out Lockyer in the middle. He rises high to thump a header towards goal, but it flies over the bar.
Onana is screaming for the ball in midfield and Garner eventually picks him out. He tries to slide it into the box for Calvert-Lewin, but they're not on the same wavelength, so it's a comfortable take for Kaminski.
LOCKYER SCORES! Everton just haven't been able to cope with Luton on corners, and the visitors have punished them! Doughty swings another dangerous cross in and Morris thumps a header on goal. It hits the bottom of the crossbar and bounces in front of Young, who tries to clear it. He hits the ball straight against Lockyer, who throws himself in front of it, and it hits the back of the net. 1-0 Luton!
Everton are looking to regain some of their earlier dominance and it's hooked upfield to Calvert-Lewin again. This time, he fouls his man trying to nod it down, and Luton have a free-kick.
Mpanzu went down after being shrugged off the ball in midfield, and he's holding his side. He slowly gets back up to his feet, and he can carry on without treatment.
CHANCE! Everton's threat comes from their left again, and McNeil jinks past Morris before whipping a dangerous cross into Calvert-Lewin. He can't get enough contact on the ball though, and ends up glancing it wide.
Onana has nicked the ball off Morris, but Tarkowski bundles into the forward, giving away a needless free-kick, which Doughty is standing over.
MORRIS SCORES! The forward peels away from the line of Everton defenders on the edge of the box, and he's completely free at the far post. Doughty picks him out, and Morris meets the ball on the half-volley, sending it across goal and out of Pickford's reach. 2-0 Luton!
It's another delightful delivery from Doughty, who is causing Everton all sorts of problems with the set-pieces that he's taking.
The rain is coming down even heavier now, and the slick surface is causing a few problems. Morris nods it forward for Ogbene, and Young's pass almost plays in the winger, but he manages to get it back to Pickford.
Gueye finds himself in a pocket of space just outside the box and shapes to shoot before deciding against it. Instead, he touches it out to Mykolenko, but nobody is in the middle for the hosts to meet his cross.
OFF THE BAR! Everton work it well down their left once more, and McNeil floats a great cross towards the far post. Garner darts forward to meet it and thumps a header on goal. Kaminski is beaten, but it smacks off the crossbar.
Everton are still seeing a lot of the ball, but they're finding it difficult to break down Luton. Tarkowski lifts another long ball over the top that forces Calvert-Lewin wide, which means that nobody is in the box for the hosts again.
CALVERT-LEWIN PULLS ONE BACK! Pickford's long ball is only half-cleared by Luton and Garner swings a follow-up cross into the middle. Onana is onside as he pokes it on goal, but Kaminski denies him. The keeper then scrambles across to deny Doucoure from close range but he can't get to Calvert-Lewin's prod. VAR is having a long look, but it'll count!
VAR is checking two things on this goal. The first is whether or not there was a foul on Burke in the build-up, and that's cleared up pretty quickly. The second is whether or not Calvert-Lewin is offside. It's a tight call, and it's taking some time to figure out.
THE GOAL STANDS! Everton have their first home goal of the season! Burke was leaning slightly to the left, and it's his shoulder that was playing Calvert-Lewin onside. It's 2-1!
BLOCK! We're into six minutes of added time after that VAR check, and Everton win a free-kick on the left. Kaminski doesn't get any distance on his punched clearance and Garner hits it on the volley as it drops. Burke blocks it in front of the line.
There are big shouts for a handball from the home fans and players as it strikes Bell. He was stood very close to Garner with his arm low by his side, and the referee gives a shake of his head.
Everton are searching for a goal that would take them into the break level. They're switching it from side to side, and Mykolenko finally finds some space, but Kaminski plucks his cross straight out of the air.
HALF-TIME: EVERTON 1-2 LUTON TOWN.
Luton take a 2-1 lead over Everton into half-time. It was the hosts with all of the early chances, but they struggled to test Kaminski. Luton took the lead through Lockyer - Doughty's corner was thumped against the underside of the bar by Morris, and the Hatters captain threw himself in front of Young's clearance to send it into the goal. Morris then doubled their lead from another set-piece, peeling away to send an unmarked volley past Pickford. At the other end, Garner smacked the bar with a header before Calvert-Lewin prodded home Everton's first home goal of the season to pull one back.
Edwards will be fairly pleased with what he's seen from his side - they soaked up a lot of pressure before exploiting Everton's weaknesses on set-pieces to get their two goals. He'll want to restore that two-goal cushion though. Half-time came at the wrong time for the hosts as they were starting to assert some dominance again. Calvert-Lewin netted an important goal, and Dyche will want to build on that after the break.
There's a change apiece at the break, starting with Everton. Gueye is taken off, with Harrison on in his place.
And for Luton, it's Burke that's making way, with Andersen replacing him.
Everton get us back under way for the second half!
Luton are looking to make a strong start to the second half, and they're keeping Everton penned back in their own half. Ogbene tries to cut inside from the left, but Young stands his ground to stop him from getting into the box.
Everton haven't really got going so far in the second half. They're struggling to string passes together, and Luton look comfortable at the moment.
The space opens up for Brown in the box and as he shapes to shoot, Tarkowski slides in with a perfectly-timed tackle to take it off him. Doughty takes the resulting corner, but this one sails over everyone.
Everton work it quickly upfield, but they're struggling to get the ball into the box. They're still looking to their left side to make something happen, but it's not coming off.
Lockyer went down in need of treatment, and Luton aren't going to risk him. He makes his way off the pitch with the medical team, and Mengi comes on to make his Premier League debut.
Ogbene goes down, asking for a free-kick that doesn't come. From that, Pickford plays out from the back, looking to get his side upfield. Onana tries to slide it down the right for Harrison, but Doughty shields it out of play.
Everton are making their second change as they continue their search for an equaliser. Doucoure is taken off, with Beto on in his place.
CHANCE! It's better from Everton here as Tarkowski loops another long ball over the top. Calvert-Lewin watches it drop over his shoulder and hits it on the volley, but his effort dribbles just wide of the far post.
OFFSIDE! Luton go straight down the other end and put the ball in the net, but it won't count! Doughty clips a good cross into the far post and Brown nods it over Pickford. Morris is on the line to help it over the line, but a belated flag goes up against Brown.
Branthwaite and Morris collide during an aerial challenge and the referee waves on the medical teams due to both players holding their heads.
Morris and Branthwaite are both back on their feet now and they'll be able to carry on after finishing their treatment.
Luton win a throw-in, and Kabore looks like he's going to take it before handing it over to Andersen instead. The referee doesn't like that, and Kabore is booked for time-wasting.
Doughty's latest corner hits Garner as it's swung in, and VAR is just having a quick look at it. It did strike the midfielder on the arm, but he was moving it down to his side, and there won't be a penalty awarded to Luton.
Harrison gets a yard on Bell as he drives down the right and he clips a deep cross into the six-yard box. Kaminski chooses to leave it, and Beto reaches it on the far side, but can only put it into the side netting.
Harrison switches play out to Mykolenko on the left, and he lays it off into Beto's path. He has space for a shot, but chooses to leave it for McNeil instead, which allows Luton to get back and block it.
There are more big shouts for a penalty, this time from the home fans. McNeil plays a good reverse pass into Calvert-Lewin, who goes shoulder-to-shoulder with Mengi, and when the forward goes down, the referee waves the claim away.
GREAT CHANCE! McNeil has people to aim for in the box this time, and he curls it into the far post, where Garner nods it down. Beto has a free header and flicks it towards the near top corner from close range, but it sails over the bar.
Garner cuts open Luton's backline with a great pass into the box, and Beto races onto it. He stumbles over the ball and manages to scuff a shot just wide from a tight angle.
Luton are making their second change here. Morris, whose goal is the difference at the moment, is replaced by Adebayo.
And Everton's latest change sees Patterson coming on for Young.
Luton are sitting deep and trying to make life difficult for Everton in the final third. Harrison plays a hopeful ball into the box from the right, but it's an easy one for Kabore to deal with at the far post.
Luton have a problem here as Kaminski is down in his box with a groin problem. The physio is on to give him some treatment, but he's okay to carry on.
Luton are making another change as they get ready to defend this Everton corner. Doughty goes off, with Woodrow on in his place.
Final roll of the dice for Everton now as Danjuma is brought on for McNeil.
OVER! Everton are upping the pressure here and after the first cross is cleared, the hosts recycle it. Garner lifts it into the far post and Beto thumps a header across goal which sails over the bar.
Luton are still standing their ground at the back, and Everton are desperately trying to get it forward. At the moment, they're struggling to string together enough passes to do that.
Mpanzu makes another good interception and drives down the right. His only aim is to keep Everton out of Luton's half by dragging the hosts back towards their own goal.
WIDE! Tarkowski has played some wonderful long balls over the top today, and this one is no different as he drops it into Calvert-Lewin. He lets it bounce before firing on goal, but he hits the side netting.
Everton are very much going for the direct route as Tarkowski sends it long once more. This time, he picks out Onana on the right of the box and he nods it towards Beto, but Bell is there for Luton.
Luton have everyone back in their own half as they continue to protect what would be a precious first-ever Premier League win. Brown does well as he drags Mykolenko out to him and wins a goal-kick off the left-back.
FULL-TIME: EVERTON 1-2 LUTON TOWN.
Luton win their first-ever Premier League game, beating Everton 2-1. All of the work was done in the first half from two set-pieces. The first was a corner, which Morris thumped against the crossbar, and Lockyer threw himself in front of Young's clearance to deflect it into the net. Then a free-kick, where Doughty picked out the unmarked Morris, and he volleyed past Pickford. Everton responded well, with Garner rattling the bar with a header before Calvert-Lewin poked a goal back from close range. The Toffees desperately pushed in the second half, but couldn't manage to test Kaminski.
It's a win that lifts Luton out of the relegation zone and up to 17th, only behind Everton now on goal difference. They'll play their game in hand against Burnley in midweek. That's four home defeats on the bounce for the Toffees, who go off to boos. They'll be hoping to change that against Bournemouth next weekend.
That's all for today, goodbye!
summary:
In-form Newcastle United earned a fourth win in five Premier League matches as eased past Crystal Palace 4-0 at St James’ Park. 
The home team got off to a dream start as Jacob Murphy opened the scoring in the fourth minute. Kieran Trippier’s sumptuous cushioned pass set up Murphy down the right channel to send a brilliant lob over Sam Johnstone and into the far corner. 
Anthony Gordon, back from suspension, missed a glorious chance to double the lead but could only hit the bar from close range. He made amends just before half-time, converting first-time Murphy’s brilliant cross at the far post. 
There was still time for a third Newcastle goal before the break, Sean Longstaff profiting from a slip by Marc Guehi to advance into the area and score. 
Murphy was also involved in the fourth with his cross-pass finding Callum Wilson to finish midway through the second half. 
The win lifts Newcastle to fifth, with 16 points. 
Palace are 11th with 12 points.
Referee: Tim Robinson. Assistants: Adrian Holmes, Simon Long. Fourth official: Keith Stroud. VAR: Simon Hooper. Assistant VAR: James Mainwaring.
