label: Exciting

events:
Hello and welcome to our live coverage of this Premier League clash as Luton Town face Wolves at Kenilworth Road!
We've got an early-season six-pointer for you here as Luton face Wolves. The hosts are the only Premier League side still seeking their first point of the season ahead of matchday six, after Burnley claimed a draw at Nottingham Forest on Monday. Rob Edwards' Hatters could become the sixth team in Premier League history to start a season with five straight defeats – three of the previous five finished bottom of the table.
There have been plenty of positives for Gary O'Neil to take from Wolves' early-season showings, but last week's 3-1 defeat to Liverpool left them with three points from their first five matches of the Premier League season. The likes of Pedro Neto, Jean-Ricner Bellegarde and Joao Gomes impressed against the Reds, but Wolves ran out of steam in the second half after taking an early lead. O'Neil will be aware of the need to turn encouraging performances into results, particularly against their fellow strugglers.
LUTON TOWN (5-2-3): Thomas Kaminski; Issa Kabore, Reece Burke, Tom Lockyer, Amari'i Bell, Alfie Doughty; Marvelous Nakamba, Albert Sambi Lokonga; Jacob Brown, Carlton Morris, Chiedozie Ogbene.
LUTON TOWN SUBS: Tim Krul, Mads Andersen, Luke Berry, Cauley Woodrow, Elijah Adebayo, Tahith Chong, Teden Mengi, Pelly Ruddock Mpanzu, Ryan Giles.
WOLVES (4-2-3-1): Jose Sa; Nelson Semedo, Maximilian Kilman, Craig Dawson, Rayan Ait-Nouri; Joao Gomes, Mario Lemina; Hwang Hee-chan, Jean-Ricner Bellegarde, Pedro Neto; Matheus Cunha.
WOLVES SUBS: Dan Bentley, Matt Doherty, Boubacar Traore, Fabio Silva, Hugo Bueno, Sasa Kalajdzic, Tommy Doyle, Pablo Sarabia, Toti Gomes.
Edwards makes two changes to the team that started last week's defeat at Fulham. Ross Barkley is still absent due to a hamstring injury, while Andersen and Chong drop to the bench. Ogbene and Doughty come in, with former Wolves wing-back Giles among the substitutes again.
Wolves, meanwhile, are unchanged from last week's 3-1 loss to Liverpool. O'Neil's men started that game at breakneck speed and it will be interesting to see whether they can maintain that intensity against less-fancied opponents. Neto leads the Premier League charts for assists (four) and chances created (17) this campaign and should offer a direct outlet on the visitors' left flank.
Luton are just the second team to lose their first four games as a Premier League club, along with Swindon Town in 1993, who drew 0-0 at Norwich City in their fifth game. Can the Hatters get their campaign up and running here? Kick-off is approaching and we're about to find out!
We're under way for just the second Premier League game to be played at Kenilworth Road! The hosts get us going and go long straight away, but the ball is quickly with Sa.
As you would expect, there's a fantastic atmosphere here. Luton win a free-kick out wide on the right as Ait-Nouri brings Ogbene down. They'll look to lift this into the Wolves area.
It's played short to Doughty, but his left-footed strike is straight into the wall before Brown sees a cross blocked by Semedo.
Gomes goes down after being caught in midfield, but the Brazilian is swiftly back to his feet. It's been a scrappy, high-octane start, which Luton won't mind one bit! They'll be keen to turn this contest into a physical battle.
Chance! Ogbene gets down the left to swing a cross into Wolves' area. His delivery is over Morris and Brown is attacking it at the far post, but Ait-Nouri does brilliantly to nod it behind his own goal.
Luton fail to make anything of the game's first corner before Bell sees his second delivery blocked. They've done a good job of penning Wolves back early on, however.
Wolves are struggling here! Sa flaps at Bell's deep cross, but there is no orange shirt there to attack the loose ball. Hwang then looks to break, but he runs it straight out of play on the visitors' left!
Wolves – donning their sky blue third kit – come forward for the first time, but Hwang is caught offside from Ait-Nouri's ball in behind.
OFF THE POST! Luton go so close to the opener! Morris latches onto a loose ball 20 yards from goal before shifting it onto his right foot. His curling, long-range effort has Sa beaten, but it bounces off the upright and the visitors can clear!
Luton are the Premier League's joint-lowest scorers with two goals (alongside Everton), while only Burnley (12) and Wolves (11) have conceded more than their 10 goals against, even though the Hatters have only played four matches. They have made an impressive start to this game, however.
This is a concerning moment for Wolves. Sa has gone down in the goalmouth, holding his left foot and appearing to be in some discomfort. He needs to receive treatment, though the home fans are not particularly sympathetic.
Sa is back on his feet and looks set to continue for now.
Luton are quick to drop into a 5-2-3 shape whenever they lose the ball. Wolves are struggling to get the likes of Cunha, Bellegarde and Neto involved on a regular basis – Neto has only had one touch.
Luton threaten down the left once again as Doughty finds space for a cross. He hangs it up towards Brown at the far post, but his header is straight at Sa. It's been one-way traffic so far!
Blocked by his own team-mate! Brown finds space for a shot just inside the area, but Morris gets in the way of his effort! Doughty then wins – and takes – a free-kick on the left, which Brown glances comfortably over the crossbar.
Luton have managed seven shots to Wolves' zero so far, though the Hatters have only hit the target once. They need to make this spell of sustained pressure count. Lemina concedes a corner on the Luton left.
The corner is cleared by the first defender, and a scrappy passage of play ends with Wolves receiving a goal-kick. The visitors have appeared rattled by Luton's physicality early on.
Hwang goes down following a tussle with Bell on halfway, claiming he was caught in the face. There was contact, but it was certainly accidental.
Neto finally gets a chance to run at Kabore. He beats the right wing-back with ease before flashing a cross across the face of goal, but there are no blue shirts attacking it.
This is the first top-flight meeting between Luton and Wolves since the 1983-84 campaign, with the Hatters winning home (4-0) and away (2-1) games against Wolves that season, when the Molineux men went on to finish bottom.
Cunha finds Neto out wide to start a Wolves break, and the winger plays it left to Ait-Nouri. The left-back sees his cutback turned behind for a corner, from which Brown stands firm to clear.
Bellegarde swings a right-footed delivery towards the far post, where Morris decides to let it run. He hadn't seen Kilman lurking behind him, but the Wolves captain is unable to keep it alive.
Wolves have settled down and are enjoying more time on the ball as we pass the half-hour mark, but they are yet to trouble Kaminski in the Luton goal.
Wolves are enjoying a sustained spell of possession inside Luton's half now, but that Hatters block continues to stand firm and deny the visitors space.
The referee halts play as both Kabore and Brown are left in a heap. Brown looks to have been caught on the top of the head by Kilman, while Kabore is holding his leg. Both men require treatment.
Both teams take the opportunity to receive instructions from the managers, before Wolves restart the game with a drop-ball. Brown and Kabore are both able to continue.
Wolves are still yet to record a shot of any kind in this match, though they are beginning to exercise some control in midfield as Gomes is fouled by Lokonga.
RED CARD FOR BELLEGARDE! WOLVES ARE DOWN TO 10 MEN! Lockyer and Bellegarde tussle for the ball and both men go down. Caught between the Luton man's legs, Bellegarde looks to escape and kicks out at the Hatters' defender. The referee calls the play back and issues a red card!
There's a VAR review to check whether Bellegarde's kick warranted a straight red card, but the on-field decision is swiftly confirmed! The Wolves man might feel hard done by as he was looking to escape a tangle of legs, but you can't lash out like that!
O'Neil will be absolutely furious. Just as Wolves were beginning to take control of the contest, they pick up a straight red card. It's going to be a long 50 minutes or so for the visitors now!
WHAT A LET-OFF FOR WOLVES! Dawson plays a no-look pass back towards his own goal, not realising Sa had moved off his line! Brown is looking to turn the ball into an unguarded net, but Kilman gets back to clear!
Lemina's quick free-kick almost gets Neto in behind, but Lockyer gets back with a huge tackle to deny the Portugal winger a clear sight of goal.
We're into five minutes of additional time before the break, with Luton still on the attack. Gomes' foul on Kabore gives the Hatters a set-piece chance from the right flank.
Gomes clearly won the ball with that challenge, but the referee opts to show the midfielder a yellow card.
The Wolves defence stands firm to clear from the free-kick. Luton keep the attack alive as Doughty delivers from the left, but Ait-Nouri clears with a fine defensive header.
Neto fouls Bell in the Luton left-back position. This has been such a frustrating 45 minutes for the visitors, and they need to keep cool heads.
Luton win another corner, which Lokonga swings straight out of play. Wolves look to have done enough to reach half-time still level.
HALF-TIME: LUTON TOWN 0-0 WOLVES.
It's still goalless as we reach the interval at Kenilworth Road, and what a chance this could be for Luton to get off the mark! The Hatters pushed Wolves back from the off and went close to a spectacular opener when Morris struck the post from range. Just as the visitors looked to be taking control of the match, Bellegarde was shown a straight red card for a mindless kick on Lockyer! Wolves have it all to do from here, and Luton will surely smell blood!
Wolves are yet to manage a shot at goal here, with Luton trying their luck nine times but only hitting the target twice. This could be a long second half for O'Neil's men, who need a rethink after struggling to contain their physically imposing hosts.
With Wolves a man down and struggling, O'Neil turns to his bench at the break. Doherty is on for Ait-Nouri.
Hwang, meanwhile, is replaced by Toti. Those changes will surely mean a change of shape for the visitors, perhaps to a back three.
We're back under way for the second half as Cunha gets the ball rolling for Wolves. Can the 10-man visitors find a way to pose a threat?
Luton come forward through Burke, who cuts inside and sees his shot smothered by Kilman's block. There's a half-hearted handball appeal from the hosts, but the referee shakes his head.
GOOD SAVE! Semedo gifts possession to Morris with a dreadful pass, and the striker waits for Ogbene to arrive with an overlapping run before picking him out. Ogbene returns the favour with a chipped cross, and Morris' header is parried and eventually held by Sa.
GOOOOOOOOOAAAAAAAAALLLLL! NETO PUTS WOLVES AHEAD! The 10 men have the lead, and what a brilliant solo goal it is from Neto! The in-form winger beats Lockyer to Gomes' pass before cutting inside from the right and blasting his finish beyond Kaminski! 1-0 Wolves!
That is a hammer blow for Luton, who have been well on top and were looking to press their numerical advantage home. Wolves score from their first shot of the game!
Luton win a free-kick on the right and work it infield for Nakamba. The midfielder looks to stand up a cross to the far post, but it drifts harmlessly out of play.
Brown battles with Toti and sends his opponent tumbling inside the Wolves box before winning a corner off him.
Doughty's corner is headed away by Semedo. Morris picks it up on the opposite flank and throws himself to ground under pressure from Toti. He wants a free-kick, but the referee says no.
Wolves only managed three touches in Luton's area before the break, but their fourth of the match resulted in Neto's opening goal. Can they hold on?
Neto is enjoying himself now. He turns Bell inside-out, beating him three times before the Luton man grows impatient and hauls him down. Wolves have a free-kick out wide on the right.
Mpanzu replaces Lokonga as Luton make their first substitution of the match.
DOUBLE SAVE! Neto swings the free-kick towards the back post, where Lemina stretches to meet it with a diving header. Kaminski is only able to parry his bouncing effort, then the Luton goalkeeper reacts well to smother Kilman's shot on the rebound. Wolves could have been 2-0 up!
Wolves are unbeaten in their last seven league games against Luton (W4 D3), winning the last three in a row. This is their first such meeting since a 3-2 win at Kenilworth Road in March 2007. Current Luton boss Edwards started at right-back for Wolves on that day.
Over! Luton threaten as Mpanzu threads a neat pass into Morris' feet, only for Kilman to step in with a crucial intervention. The ball drops kindly for Doughty, who flashes his effort just over the bar!
Wolves have been playing with a back three since making their half-time changes, with Toti joining Dawson and Kilman in the backline. Semedo is at right wing-back, with Doherty taking up an unfamiliar left wing-back role.
PENALTY LUTON! Brown picks out Kabore on the overlap, and the Luton right wing-back checks inside before shooting. The ball strikes Gomes on his outstretched arm, and the referee immediately points to the spot! There will be a VAR check, however, as the ball struck Gomes' foot first!
CHECK COMPLETE, THE PENALTY STANDS! The ball hit Gomes' foot before bouncing onto his hand, but with his arm in an unnatural position, the spot-kick stands! Morris has a huge chance to level this match…
GOOOOAAAAAAAAAL! MORRIS SCORES! The Luton striker shows great composure to send Sa the wrong way, rolling the spot-kick into the bottom-left corner! It's 1-1, and now Luton will be looking to win it!
The Kenilworth Road crowd are up for this now! Ogbene gets away from Dawson on the left before seeing his cross deflect behind for a corner!
Big chance! The corner is delivered through the crowd and finds Nakamba peeling away to the penalty spot, but the midfielder completely mishits his volley and it drops wide.
The momentum is with Luton now, with Wolves unable to keep hold of the ball. Neto sees an appeal for a free-kick turned down before Ogbene leads a Luton break, eventually seeing a shot deflect wide off Dawson.
Luton fail to make anything of their latest corner, but they retain possession inside the Wolves half through Mpanzu. Kilman gets under his left-wing cross to head it clear.
Well, this is a surprising change from O'Neil. Traore replaces Cunha in a switch that leaves Wolves without a recognised forward. He clearly sees a need for more legs in midfield.
Edwards responds with two substitutions of his own. Giles is on for Doughty on the left.
Woodrow, meanwhile, takes Brown's place in attack.
Heading into matchday six, only Aston Villa's Lucas Digne (32) and Wolves star Neto (25) had attempted more open-play crosses than Giles (19) in the Premier League.
Lemina stays down following a coming together with Morris, who caught the Wolves man with a flailing arm. There's a swift VAR check, but the contact from Morris was unintentional. Giles then delivers a left-wing free-kick, but Sa is able to claim the second ball.
Wolves haven't had an attack of any kind since Neto opened the scoring. Doherty attempts to get something going down the left, but his shove on Kabore grants Luton a free-kick.
Traore does brilliantly to get Wolves moving forward with little support. Semedo then tries to link up with Neto, but the attack breaks down.
Wolves are effectively playing 5-3-1 now, with Neto the only recognised attacking player left on the pitch for the visitors.
Luton's players are incandescent with rage as Nakamba is penalised for a challenge on Lemina. The Wolves man had overdone it inside his own half, and had the foul not been awarded, the Hatters were away.
We're into the final 10 minutes of the 90 here with the Kenilworth Road crowd urging Luton forwards. Will there be another twist?
Luton win a corner, which Giles swings towards the near post. Dawson is there to clear before Neto attempts to break, but he's all alone and is swiftly crowded out inside the Luton half.
Gomes does well to dispossess Kabore before winning a free-kick inside his own half. Wolves are about to turn to their bench again.
Hugo Bueno replaces Semedo and heads over to the left. Doherty will end the game at right wing-back.
Bueno is tested immediately as Kabore beats him for pace down the Luton right. The young Spaniard has to block the cross behind for another Hatters corner.
Kabore is withdrawn ahead of the corner being taken, with Adebayo on in an attacking change from Edwards.
Danger! Giles' delivery causes a scramble in the area as Burke puts Sa under pressure. His punch is weak, and Traore has to clear in acrobatic fashion. Luton then come again through Mpanzu, but his awkward effort flies well over the crossbar.
Woodrow pulls wide to cross into the area, but Lockyer sends his header well over Sa's crossbar. We're into the final two minutes of the 90, with Luton the only team offering anything as an attacking force.
GOOOAAAAAALLL, BUT WAIT, THE FLAG IS UP! Luton think they have a winner as Mpanzu's shot deflects off a blue shirt and lands kindly for Ogbene, who tucks his left-footed finish past Sa. The flag is quickly raised, however, and a VAR check confirms the Luton man went too early!
O'Neil makes another change as Doyle replaces Gomes in the Wolves midfield.
We're into SIX added minutes at the end of this game! There could be more than that, however, with Neto currently down after being caught in the face.
Neto is still receiving treatment, lying down on the turf. Wolves will be happy to take the sting out of this game.
Neto is back up and Luton can get the game restarted. They're still looking for a late winner!
OVER! Sa comes for a cross and drops it under pressure from Adebayo. The ball falls for Woodrow, who looks to lift his effort over three Wolves defenders on the goal line, but it drops onto the roof of the net.
Ogbene cuts inside before swinging a cross towards the far post, but Doherty does well to shield the ball away from Giles and behind.
Lemina goes into the book for a heavy challenge on halfway.
Luton keep Wolves penned back, working the ball down the right. It's cut back towards Woodrow, who shoots first time… but Traore deflects it behind for a late corner!
Giles' corner is cleared at the near post, but Neto fails to make any headway on the counter-attack. Do Luton have time to create one last chance?
FULL-TIME: LUTON TOWN 1-1 WOLVES.
The full-time whistle sounds at Kenilworth Road, and while Luton have their first point as a Premier League club, they may well see this 1-1 draw as a missed opportunity! The Hatters played over 50 minutes with a numerical advantage after Bellegarde was dismissed for a petulant kick, but they failed to make the most of their dominance. Wolves threatened to take all three points when Neto scored a brilliant solo goal on the break, but Luton hit back through Morris' penalty. Wolves will feel aggrieved by the award of that spot-kick, with the ball striking Gomes' foot before deflecting onto his hand.
Luton remain bottom of the pile with a single point to their name, though they will go above Burnley if the Clarets lose to Manchester United in Saturday's late kick-off. Wolves, meanwhile, jump above Bournemouth into 15th place with four points from six matches. After their midweek EFL Cup exertions, Luton visit Everton and Wolves host champions Manchester City!
We hope you've enjoyed our coverage of this hard-fought Premier League fixture. Until next time, it's goodbye from us!
summary:
Lewis Dunk's second-half goal stopped Liverpool from going second in the table as they drew 2-2 at Brighton & Hove Albion. 
Mohamed Salah scored twice to turn the match around after Simon Adingra's wonderful Brighton opener, but Dunk's goal from Solly March's free-kick ensured a share of the points.
text:
["Hello and welcome to our live coverage of this Premier League clash as Team_12 face Team_20 at Kenilworth Road!
We've got an early-season six-pointer for you here as Luton face Team_20. The hosts are the only Premier League side still seeking their first point of the season ahead of matchday six, after Team_6 claimed a draw at Team_16 on Monday. Rob Edwards' Hatters could become the sixth team in Premier League history to start a season with five straight defeats – three of the previous five finished bottom of the table.
There have been plenty of positives for Gary O'Neil to take from Team_20' early-season showings, but last week's 3-1 defeat to Team_11 left them with three points from their first five matches of the Premier League season. The likes of Pedro Neto, Jean-Ricner Bellegarde and Joao Gomes impressed against the Reds, but Team_20 ran out of steam in the second half after taking an early lead. O'Neil will be aware of the need to turn encouraging performances into results, particularly against their fellow strugglers.
Team_12 (5-2-3): Thomas Kaminski; Issa Kabore, Reece Burke, Tom Lockyer, Amari'i Bell, Alfie Doughty; Marvelous Nakamba, Albert Sambi Lokonga; Jacob Brown, Carlton Morris, Chiedozie Ogbene.
Team_12 SUBS: Tim Krul, Mads Andersen, Luke Berry, Cauley Woodrow, Elijah Adebayo, Tahith Chong, Teden Mengi, Pelly Ruddock Mpanzu, Ryan Giles.
Team_20 (4-2-3-1): Jose Sa; Nelson Semedo, Maximilian Kilman, Craig Dawson, Rayan Ait-Nouri; Joao Gomes, Mario Lemina; Hwang Hee-chan, Jean-Ricner Bellegarde, Pedro Neto; Matheus Cunha.
Team_20 SUBS: Dan Bentley, Matt Doherty, Boubacar Traore, Fabio Silva, Hugo Bueno, Sasa Kalajdzic, Tommy Doyle, Pablo Sarabia, Toti Gomes.

Team_20, meanwhile, are unchanged from last week's 3-1 loss to Team_11. Mpanzu replaces Lokonga as Luton make their first substitution of the match.
DOUBLE SAVE! Neto swings the free-kick towards the back post, where Lemina stretches to meet it with a diving header. Kaminski is only able to parry his bouncing effort, then\xa0the Luton goalkeeper reacts well to smother Kilman's shot on the rebound. Team_20 could have been 2-0 up!
Team_20 are unbeaten in their last seven league games against Luton (W4 D3), winning the last three in a row. This is their first such meeting since a 3-2 win at Kenilworth Road in March 2007. Current Luton boss Edwards started at right-back for Team_20 on that day.
Over! Luton threaten as Mpanzu threads a neat pass into Morris' feet, only for Kilman to step in with a crucial intervention. The ball drops kindly for Doughty, who flashes his effort just over the bar!
Team_20 have been playing with a back three since making their half-time changes, with Toti joining Dawson and Kilman in the backline. Semedo is at right wing-back, with Doherty taking up an unfamiliar left wing-back role.
PENALTY LUTON! Brown picks out Kabore on the overlap, and the Luton right wing-back checks inside before shooting. The ball strikes Gomes on his outstretched arm, and the referee immediately points to the spot! There will be a VAR check, however, as the ball struck Gomes' foot first!
CHECK COMPLETE, THE PENALTY STANDS! The ball hit Gomes' foot before bouncing onto his hand, but with his arm in an unnatural position, the spot-kick stands! Morris has a huge chance to level this match…
GOOOOAAAAAAAAAL! MORRIS SCORES! The Luton striker shows great composure to send Sa the wrong way, rolling the spot-kick into the bottom-left corner! It's 1-1, and now Luton will be looking to win it!
The Kenilworth Road crowd are up for this now! Ogbene gets away from Dawson on the left before seeing his cross deflect behind for a corner!
Big chance! The corner is delivered through the crowd and finds Nakamba peeling away to the penalty spot, but the midfielder completely mishits his volley and it drops wide.
The momentum is with Luton now, with Team_20 unable to keep hold of the ball. Neto sees\xa0an appeal for a free-kick turned down before Ogbene leads a Luton break, eventually seeing a shot deflect wide off Dawson.
Luton fail to make anything of their latest corner, but they retain possession inside the Team_20 half through Mpanzu. Kilman gets under his left-wing cross to head it clear.
Well, this is a surprising change from O'Neil. Traore replaces Cunha in a switch that leaves Team_20 without a recognised forward. He clearly sees a need for more legs in midfield.
Edwards responds with two substitutions of his own. Giles is on for Doughty on the left.
Woodrow, meanwhile, takes Brown's place in attack.
Heading into matchday six, only Team_2 Lucas Digne (32) and Team_20 star Neto (25) had attempted more open-play crosses than Giles (19) in the Premier League.
Lemina stays down following a coming together with Morris, who caught the Team_20 man with a flailing arm. There's a swift VAR check, but the contact from Morris was unintentional. Giles then delivers a left-wing free-kick, but Sa is able to claim the second ball.
Team_20 haven't had an attack of any kind since Neto opened the scoring. Doherty attempts to get something going down the left, but his shove on Kabore grants Luton a free-kick.
Traore does brilliantly to get Team_20 moving forward with little support. Semedo then tries to link up with Neto, but the attack breaks down.
Team_20 are effectively playing 5-3-1 now, with Neto the only recognised attacking player left on the pitch for the visitors.
Luton's players are incandescent with rage as Nakamba is penalised for a challenge on Lemina. The Team_20 man had overdone it inside his own half, and had the foul not been awarded, the Hatters were away.
We're into the final 10 minutes of the 90 here\xa0with the Kenilworth Road crowd urging Luton forwards. Will there be another twist?
Luton win a corner,\xa0which Giles swings towards the near post. Dawson is there to clear before Neto attempts to break, but he's all alone and is swiftly crowded out inside the Luton half.
Gomes does well to dispossess Kabore before winning a free-kick inside his own half. Team_20 are about to turn to their bench again.
Hugo Bueno replaces Semedo and heads over to the left. Doherty will end the game at right wing-back.
Bueno is tested immediately as Kabore beats him for pace down the Luton right. The young Spaniard has to block the cross behind for another Hatters corner.
Kabore is withdrawn ahead of the corner being taken, with Adebayo on in an attacking change from Edwards.
Danger! Giles' delivery causes a scramble in the area as Burke puts Sa under pressure. His punch is weak, and Traore has to clear in acrobatic fashion. Luton then come again through Mpanzu, but his awkward effort flies well over the crossbar.
Woodrow pulls wide to cross into the area, but Lockyer sends his header well over Sa's crossbar. We're into the final two minutes of the 90, with Luton the only team offering anything as an attacking force.
GOOOAAAAAALLL, BUT WAIT,\xa0THE FLAG IS UP! Luton think they have a winner as Mpanzu's shot deflects off a blue shirt and lands kindly for Ogbene, who tucks his left-footed finish past Sa. The flag is quickly raised, however, and a VAR check confirms the Luton man went too early!
O'Neil makes another change as Doyle replaces Gomes in the Team_20 midfield.
We're into SIX added minutes at the end of this game! There could be more than that, however, with Neto currently down after being caught in the face.
Neto is still receiving treatment, lying down on the turf. Team_20 will be happy to take the sting out of this game.
Neto is back up and Luton can get the game restarted. They're still looking for a late winner!
OVER! Sa comes for a cross and drops it under pressure from Adebayo. The ball falls\xa0for Woodrow, who looks to lift his effort over three Team_20 defenders on the goal line, but it drops onto the roof of the net.
Ogbene cuts inside before swinging a cross towards the far post, but Doherty does well to shield the ball away from Giles and behind.
Lemina goes into the book for a heavy challenge on halfway.
Luton keep Team_20 penned back, working the ball down the right. It's cut back towards Woodrow, who shoots first time… but Traore deflects it behind for a late corner!
Giles' corner is cleared at the near post, but Neto fails to make any headway on the counter-attack. Do Luton have time to create one last chance?
FULL-TIME: Team_12 1-1 Team_20.
The full-time whistle sounds at Kenilworth Road, and while Luton\xa0have their first point as a Premier League club, they may well see this 1-1 draw as a missed opportunity! The Hatters played over 50 minutes with a numerical advantage after Bellegarde was dismissed for a petulant kick, but they failed to make the most of their dominance. Team_20 threatened to take all three points when Neto scored a brilliant solo goal on the break, but Luton hit back through Morris' penalty. Team_20 will feel aggrieved by the award of that spot-kick, with the ball striking Gomes' foot before deflecting onto his hand.
Luton remain bottom of the pile with a single point to their name, though they will go above Team_6 if the Clarets lose to Team_14 in Saturday's late kick-off. Team_20, meanwhile, jump above Team_3 into 15th place with four points from six\xa0matches. After their midweek EFL Cup exertions, Luton visit Team_9 and Team_20 host champions Team_13!
We hope you've enjoyed our coverage of this hard-fought Premier League fixture. Until next time, it's goodbye from us!"]
label: Exciting

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Chelsea and Brighton at Stamford Bridge!
With an upturn in form, things had started to look up for Chelsea in recent weeks. Going into last weekend, they'd lost just one of eight games in competitions (W5 D2), with that run including a 1-0 win over Brighton in the EFL Cup in late September. They followed it up last weekend with a heavy 4-1 defeat at Newcastle United. Mauricio Pochettino will be hoping his team can bounce back today and turn around their home form as they've won just one of their last 14 Premier League games at Stamford Bridge which came against promoted Luton Town (3-0).
Brighton come into today on the back of a midweek high having secured their place in the knockout rounds of the Europa League with a 1-0 win over AEK Athens on Thursday. They also ended a run of six without a win in the Premier League last weekend after holding on for a 3-2 over Nottingham Forest. They've enjoyed success in the league against Chelsea in recent years, going unbeaten against them in their last five such meetings (W2 D3), including doing the double over them last season.
CHELSEA STARTING XI (4-2-3-1): Robert Sanchez; Axel Disasi, Beniot Badiashile, Thiago Silva, Levi Colwill; Enzo Fernandez, Moises Caicedo; Raheem Sterling, Conor Gallagher, Mykhailo Mudryk; Nicolas Jackson.
CHELSEA SUBS: Lucas Bergstrom, Alfie Gilchrist, Alex Matos, Deivid Washington, Cole Palmer, Noni Madueke, Armando Broja, Ian Maatsen, Dorde Petrovic.
BRIGHTON STARTING XI (4-2-3-1): Jason Steele; Joel Veltman, Jan-Paul van Hecke, Igor Julio, Jack Hinshelwood; Carlos Baleba, Billy Gilmour; Facundo Buonanotte, Adam Lallana, Simon Adingra; Evan Ferguson.
BRIGHTON SUBS: Mark O'Mahony, James Milner, Kaoru Mitoma, Benicio Baker-Boaitey, Bart Verbruggen, Joao Pedro, Jakub Moder, Leigh Kavanagh, Pascal Gross.
Pochettino makes four changes from the loss to Newcastle last Saturday, as Disasi, Colwill, Caicedo and Mudryk all come into the side. Reece James was sent off in that game, while Marc Cucurella picked up his fifth booking of the season, so they're both suspended. Palmer drops to the bench, while Lesley Ugochukwu isn't in the squad.
Roberto De Zerbi makes five changes to his team after their win over AEK Athens on Thursday. Steele starts in goal, with Van Hecke, Baleba, Buonanotte and Lallana also being brought in. Verbruggen, Gross, Mitoma and Pedro start on the bench, while Lewis Dunk serves the first game of his suspension after being sent off against Forest last weekend.
The teams are out on the pitch now, with kick-off just moments away!
Jackson gets the game under way for Chelsea!
Brighton do well to win it back in midfield and quickly counter, though Adingra can't get into the box. Ferguson is nudged off the ball by Badiashile, but it rolls towards Adingra again, who is wiped out by Sanchez. After a quick VAR check, there's no penalty.
Brighton have made a bright start to this game and they're putting Chelsea under some early pressure. Veltman links up well with Buonanotte down the right, but Silva reacts quickly to stop him from cutting inside.
It's better from Chelsea here as Sterling holds off Hinshelwood long enough to play a reverse pass down the left for Jackson. He isn't strong enough though, and Julio is able to clear the danger for Brighton.
Gallagher sweeps it out to Sterling, who plays a one-two with Jackson to lose his marker so he can square a low cross into the box. He's looking for Mudryk at the far post, but doesn't get enough on it, and Baleba intercepts.
Brighton have failed to score in eight of their 10 away games against Chelsea in all competitions, including a 1-0 defeat already this season in the EFL Cup.
Chelsea do well to pass it out from the back around Brighton's high press, but Sterling is tripped by Hinshelwood to win a free-kick. The Blues take it short, but it comes to nothing as Mudryk loses the ball when it gets to him.
Brighton are struggling to keep hold of the ball in the final third, with their attacks fizzling out and turning into Chelsea breaks. Sterling leads the latest charge and has options ahead of him, but can't pick any of them out.
Sterling makes another surging run down the right, and he has the beating of Hinshelwood once more. He loops a cross into the far post, but it's just behind Mudryk.
FERNANDEZ SCORES! Brighton are caught out from a corner, which is swung deep into Badiashile at the far post by Gallagher. He has Hinshelwood tight to him as well as his back to goal, but he improvises, volleying it over his shoulder. Fernandez is unmarked at the far post, and he nods in from close range. 1-0 Chelsea!
It's good work by Badiashile, who could've looked to Mudryk, who was making a supporting run down the left. Instead, he picks out a good cross himself.
BLOCK! Brighton just can't get out of their own half at the moment, and Jackson's darting run down the left has the visitors scrambling back into their box. He clips it in from the byline, but Van Hecke blocks it just ahead of Fernandez.
CHANCE! Chelsea have the feel for it now, and it's back with Sterling down the right side. He fizzes a low cross into the six-yard box, but Baleba slides in to deflect it just wide of the near post.
COLWILL SCORES! It's another corner that has Brighton scrambling, and again, it's swung deep to the far post. Jackson peels away from Julio to nod it back into the mix and Colwill rises highest to thump a header on goal. It originally looks like Gilmour manages to clear it off the line, but the referee's watch buzzes, and the Brighton midfielder didn't do it in time. 2-0 Chelsea!
Julio couldn't even get off the floor as the corner was hung into the far post, but Jackson was alert and backpedalled to head it back into the crowd in the six-yard box.
De Zerbi is pacing in his technical area, and he'll have concerns about how those two goals were conceded. Brighton are pushing upfield at the moment, but they don't seem to know what to do when they get into the final third.
Adingra wins a free-kick through the middle and Gilmour clips it into the box. Silva only half clears it, but Hinshelwood rushes in to try and keep it alive, only to lift it out of play under pressure from Caicedo.
There's a very nervy moment at the back for Chelsea as Sanchez is far too casual when Fernandez knocks it back to him. The ball skims off his foot and rolls towards his net, but the keeper reacts quickly to prevent the own goal.
Colwill makes a driving run through midfield and Van Hecke tries to block the path, getting a kick in the process. He stays down, but gets back to his feet after a little while without needing treatment.
Gallagher is late getting across to Buonanotte and crashes into the youngster with a clumsy challenge. He picks up the first booking of the game.
Gallagher gives away another free-kick in midfield, and Gilmour lifts it long into the box once more. It's another comfortable clearance for Chelsea though, who look very at ease in this game.
Chelsea look like they want it more in midfield, and their high press is causing Brighton all sorts of problems. Fernandez turns possession over once more, only to overhit the throughball into Jackson.
Lallana is a little sloppy with his first-time pass into Baleba, and Jackson is sniffing around him. The Chelsea forward threatens to break, but Baleba recovers well to stop him from getting over the halfway line.
Chelsea almost get over-confident playing out from the back, and Fernandez is caught on the ball inside his own box. He just about manages to poke it back to Sanchez, who gets lucky that his own pass out to Disasi isn't cut out by Lallana.
WIDE! Mudryk gets away from Veltman with a lovely turn before bursting forward to the edge of the box. He has a quick glance up before fizzing a pacy low shot just wide of the far post.
Brighton have won a lot of similarly positioned free-kicks in midfield, but they haven't been able to take advantage of them. Buonanotte takes this one, but just like Gilmour before him, he can't pick out a team-mate in the area.
BUONANOTTE PULLS ONE BACK! And what a way to do it! Adingra stretches to keep the ball for Brighton, and Lallana just as quickly helps it onto Buonanotte. He checks back, wrongfooting Colwill, before curling a delightful strike out of Sanchez's reach and into the far side of the net. 2-1!
Lallana has space and time, but he chooses to get it out of his feet quickly to give Buonanotte a better chance.
WHAT A SAVE! Straight from the restart, Chelsea want to restore their two-goal cushion and Mudryk surges down the left before sending his cross into the box. It deflects off Julio's trailing leg, and Steele is at full stretch to tip it away.
GALLAGHER IS OFF! After such a strong start to the game, things are going downhill for Chelsea! Gilmour was racing away through the middle and Gallagher made up a lot of ground to get to him. The ball is already out of his reach, and he clumsily brings down the Scotsman. It earns him his second yellow card, and for the second game in a row, Chelsea are down to 10 men!
Unsurprisingly, that red card has just tipped the momentum in Brighton's favour and they're putting Chelsea under pressure already. The Seagulls are pushing numbers forward and manage to win a corner out of it, but it comes to nothing.
Chelsea clear their lines after Brighton's latest attack, and Sterling has space to run down the right. He plays it into Fernandez, continuing down the wing, only to stray offside when it comes to him.
WIDE! Ferguson peels out to the left and drops a shoulder to wrongfoot Disasi before fizzing a low shot on goal from a long way out. A touch from one of his team-mates would've taken it past Sanchez, but instead, it rolls wide of the far post.
Hinshelwood has been struggling to cope with Sterling's threat down the right, and he just nudges the winger off the ball this time, picking up a yellow card.
HALF-TIME: CHELSEA 2-1 BRIGHTON.
Chelsea take a 2-1 lead over Brighton into half-time, but face a tough second half with only 10 men. It was a perfect start for the Blues, who dominated for most of the first half. It was two corners that caught out Brighton, with Fernandez heading in his first-ever Premier League goal from close range, before Colwill netted his first Chelsea goal with a thumping header. The Seagulls started to grow into the game, and Buonanotte pulled one back with a wonderful curling finish before Steele pulled off a marvellous save at the other end. The Chelsea captain, Gallagher, was then sent off for his second yellow card offence.
Pochettino won't be able to believe what's happened - his side looked to be in total control, but within two minutes at the end of the half, things flipped on their head. He knows it won't be easy to protect a lead against this Brighton side, especially with 10 men. De Zerbi won't be happy about the goals they conceded, but he can have no complaints about how they reacted. He'll know this game is there for the taking in the second half.
Brighton get us back under way for the second half!
Andingra weaves this way and that, only to overrun the ball out of play at the byline. Sanchez goes long from the resulting free-kick to pick out Sterling, but Van Hecke brilliantly cuts out his throughball into Jackson.
Brighton have started the second half on the front foot and are pushing Chelsea back into their own half. Baleba is allowed to carry the ball a long way, and decides to try his luck from range, but Sanchez gets down to hold it.
Caicedo steps across Ferguson to stop his run and immediately protests against the free-kick. His reaction gets him a booking for dissent.
Fernandez has scored his first Premier League goal in his 31st appearance and from his 43rd shot in the competition. Before today. he'd attempted more shots than any player without a goal in the competition this season (22).
CHANCE! Buonanotte's header is blocked for a corner, and Chelsea can't clear their lines from the resulting set-piece. Adingra hangs in a cross for Lallana, who spins and scuffs a volley on goal, but he sends it wide.
De Zerbi is making a quadruple change as his side continue to search for an equaliser. Buonanotte has had a good game, and he goes off for Mitoma.
Hinshelwood, on the other hand, has struggled at times up against Sterling, and he's replaced by Milner.
And Gross gets the captain's armband as he's brought on for Baleba.
Julio catches Mudryk with a late foul as he tries to stop him from breaking, and he goes into the book.
Lallana is also taken off, with Pedro on for him.
Fernandez isn't happy when a Brighton player isn't booked for a challenge on Caicedo. He picks up his own yellow card for dissent.
PENALTY? Jackson's layoff to Mudryk is perfectly-weighted, but his first touch shows too much of it to Milner. He nudges the Ukrainian out of the way to see it back to Steele, and Chelsea are claiming they should have a spot-kick.
After a long look at all of the angles, the referee is asked to go over to the monitor to have another look at the incident. At first, it looked like Milner just nudged Mudryk off the ball, but he was clumsy, clipping the Ukrainian's heels, and he could be in trouble.
PENALTY TO CHELSEA! After having another look at the incident, referee Craig Pawson comes back onto the pitch, and much to Chelsea's delight, points to the spot!
Gross is protesting Milner's innocence for him, and the Brighton captain talks his way into a booking.
Milner is also shown a yellow card for his challenge on Mudryk that led to the penalty.
FERNANDEZ SCORES AGAIN! After a long wait for a Premier League goal, the Argentinian now has two in one game! He had the ball in his hands before the penalty was awarded and coolly steps up now. He takes a long run-up before stroking it down the right side of the goal, leaving Steele no chance as he dives the wrong way. 3-1 Chelsea!
Pochettino is making his first change of the game now that the two-goal cushion is restored. Sterling is taken off, with Palmer on for him.
Brighton are still throwing bodies forward in an attempt to cut the scoreline down once more. Adingra is afforded so much space down the right, and sees Mitoma in a similar position on the left, but he overhits the cross.
Adingra's latest cross is blocked by Badiashile, and Pedro keeps it alive, though he fouls Fernandez in the process. The referee doesn't immediately award the foul, so Gilmour takes aim from range, but it's blocked by Silva.
Chelsea are making another change here. Jackson, who only managed one shot in this game, and he's replaced by Maatsen.
Brighton are dominating possession at the moment, but they're still struggling to get in behind Chelsea. The Seagulls are trying to use their wide players, with Gross threading it forward for Pedro, but he's caught on his heels.
Again, Brighton have numbers in the box, but they can't make them count. Adingra chooses to go short instead of curling a cross into the crowd, and his pull back to Gilmour is cleared by Fernandez.
After soaking up Brighton's pressure, Chelsea move it upfield quickly, with Palmer picking out Caicedo in space just outside the D. He takes aim from distance, but doesn't trouble Steele as he fires it over.
CHANCE! It looks like the chance is gone for Brighton when Gross lets it run, but Pedro just about manages to keep it alive. He spreads it out to Milner on the left, who picks out Adingra at the far post, but his header is so poor, he picks out the substitute once more.
Mudryk went down, and after a quick bit of treatment, Pochettino decides not to take a risk. He's taken off, with Broja on in his place.
Mitoma is starting to impose himself down the left a little more now, and he holds off Disasi as he makes another bursting run down the left. He picks out Pedro at the far post, but his thumping header is straight at Sanchez.
Brighton's final roll of the dice sees 19-year-old Baker-Boaitey come on in place of Julio.
SAVE! Fernandez just steps on Pedro's foot, and even though it's soft, Brighton have a free-kick in a good position. Gross curls his shot over the wall, but Sanchez has it covered as he holds onto it.
Ferguson gets the ball caught under his feet, but Silva can't get enough on his clearance. It bobbles out to Gross on the edge of the box, but his low shot is held by Sanchez again.
Sanchez is starting to dawdle on the ball, and the referee has had enough as he books him for time-wasting.
GREAT SAVE! Brighton are flooding forward into Chelsea's box, but Gross decides to have another go from range. He curls his shot through the crowd and it's sneaking into the far post until Sanchez tips it wide.
WIDE! Into the first of 10 added minutes here and the corner is whipped into the box. Chelsea have practically everyone back in their box, and Silva just manages to get in the way of Pedro's header to give away another corner.
PEDRO PULLS ANOTHER ONE BACK! Brighton's pressure finally pays off! It's a great delivery from Milner on the corner and he clips it into the near post, where Pedro rises highest. He flicks his header on, and Sanchez has no chance as it skims into the far side of his net. 3-2, but can Brighton get another one with eight minutes still to go?
It's the best delivery that Brighton have put into the box in this game, and it gets turned into the back of the net by Pedro's equally good header.
Broja goes over the top of Baker-Boaitey trying to win an aerial challenge, and he's come out of it with his nose bleeding. He needs patching up but initially refuses to go off until the referee forces the issue.
There are so many bodies in Chelsea's six-yard box as Milner swings another corner into the box. This one misses everyone in the middle, and though Adingra keeps it in play on the far side, it's caught by Sanchez.
SAVE! Still, Brighton push for an equaliser, and they look to their right again as Gross gets a yard on Badiashile. The German pulls it back to Ferguson, who improvises with a clever backheel flick, but there's no power on it and Sanchez holds on.
SAVE! There's still a couple of minutes to go in this tie, but Chelsea are standing firm for now. Pedro drops back to the edge of the box to get the ball before drilling a low shot on goal, but Sanchez gets down to hold this one too.
PENALTY TO BRIGHTON! In the dying seconds, Brighton have a major lifeline! Or do they? Adingra whips a cross in from the right, and Colwill's arm is level with his head. The penalty is given for a handball, but it looks like it actually hits him in the face. This might get overturned....
NO PENALTY! After watching the replays of the penalty and seeing that it clearly smacks Colwill in the side of the head, the referee decides to overturn his original decision, and it's actually a drop ball to Chelsea, much to Brighton's disbelief.
Brighton are adamant that they either should've had a free-kick for a foul on Gross earlier in the move, or a corner for his blocked cross. Neither is given, and Pedro is booked for dissent.
FULL-TIME: CHELSEA 3-2 BRIGHTON.
Ten-man Chelsea hold on to get a vital home win as they beat Brighton 3-2. The Blues made a perfect start to the game, with two corners causing Brighton all sorts of problems. Fernandez headed in his first Premier League goal from the first, while Colwill thumped in his first Chelsea goal to double their tally. That lead was halved just before the break, with Buonanotte curling in a wonderful strike before Gallagher received his second yellow card. Fernandez got his second of the game in the 65th minute from the spot after Milner fouled Mudryk, and it took Brighton until stoppage time to pull back another, with Pedro flicking it in at the near post. In the dying moments, the referee awarded a spot-kick to the Seagulls for handball, but it was overturned by VAR. It's a win that lifts Chelsea into 10th, and they'll be hoping to build some momentum off this as they travel to Manchester United on Wednesday. Brighton stay in eighth, with Brentford at home next up for them. That's all for today, goodbye!
summary:
Sheffield United picked up only their second win of the season as they beat Brentford 1-0 thanks to a fantastic goal from James McAtee.
The Manchester City loanee’s first Premier League goal was enough to secure all three points at Bramall Lane as manager Chris Wilder got his first win on his return to the club.
Yoane Wissa and Keane Lewis-Potter came into the Brentford side looking to step up in the absence of the injured Bryan Mbeumo, but the Bees were boosted by Christian Norgaard’s return from suspension.
Wilder made seven changes to the team who lost to Liverpool in midweek. 
After a quiet start, Brentford players appealed for a penalty in the 27th minute when Anel Ahmedhodzic brought down Ethan Pinnock, but referee Stuart Atwell was not interested.
Three minutes later, Brentford’s Frank Onyeka survived a VAR check for a red card after a foul on Vinicius Souza which left the midfielder needing treatment for five minutes.
Sheff Utd took the lead on the stroke of half-time as McAtee produced a stunning strike to beat Mark Flekken, curling the ball into the far corner from the right side of the box.
Substitute Anis Slimane missed a huge chance in the 56th minute to double Sheff Utd’s lead as he shot straight at Flekken from point-blank range after Cameron Archer had won the ball high up the pitch and teed up his team-mate.
Flekken was forced into another save with 10 minutes to go when Archer went through on goal. He overpowered Ben Mee to get to a loose ball but could not beat the goalkeeper with his shot.
Slimane burst into the box just a minute later as the Blades pushed hard for a second, but the Tunisian could only find the side-netting from a very tight angle.
The Bees threw everything at an equaliser but fell short in the end despite efforts from Wissa and Mee.
Sheff Utd are still bottom, now with eight points. Brentford remain 11th but are level on 19 points with three other teams.
Referee: Stuart Attwell. Assistants: Neil Davies, Wade Smith. Fourth official: Darren England. VAR: Rob Jones. Assistant VAR: Ian Hussin.
text:
["Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League meeting between Team_7 and Team_5 at Stamford Bridge!
With an upturn in form, things had started to look up for Team_7 in recent weeks. Going into last weekend, they'd lost just one of eight games in competitions (W5 D2), with that run including a 1-0 win over Team_5 in the EFL Cup in late September. They followed it up last weekend with a heavy 4-1 defeat at Team_15. Mauricio Pochettino will be hoping his team can bounce back today and turn around their home form as they've won just one of their last 14 Premier League games at Stamford Bridge which came against promoted Team_12 (3-0).
Team_5 come into today on the back of a midweek high having secured their place in the knockout rounds of the Europa League with a 1-0 win over AEK Athens on Thursday. They also ended a run of six without a win in the Premier League last weekend after holding on for a 3-2 over Team_16. They've enjoyed success in the league against Team_7 in recent years, going unbeaten against them in their last five such meetings (W2 D3), including doing the double over them last season.
Team_7 STARTING XI (4-2-3-1): Robert Sanchez; Axel Disasi, Beniot Badiashile, Thiago Silva, Levi Colwill; Enzo Fernandez, Moises Caicedo; Raheem Sterling, Conor Gallagher, Mykhailo Mudryk; Nicolas Jackson.
Team_7 SUBS: Lucas Bergstrom, Alfie Gilchrist, Alex Matos, Deivid Washington, Cole Palmer, Noni Madueke, Armando Broja, Ian Maatsen, Dorde Petrovic.
Team_5 STARTING XI (4-2-3-1): Jason Steele; Joel Veltman, Jan-Paul van Hecke, Igor Julio, Jack Hinshelwood; Carlos Baleba, Billy Gilmour; Facundo Buonanotte, Adam Lallana, Simon Adingra; Evan Ferguson.
Team_5 SUBS: Mark O'Mahony, James Milner, Kaoru Mitoma, Benicio Baker-Boaitey, Bart Verbruggen, Joao Pedro, Jakub Moder, Leigh Kavanagh, Pascal Gross.
Pochettino makes four changes from the loss to Team_15 last Saturday, as Disasi, Colwill, Caicedo and Mudryk all come into the side. Reece James was sent off in that game, while Marc Cucurella picked up his fifth booking of the season, so they're both suspended. Palmer drops to the bench, while Lesley Ugochukwu isn't in the squad.
Roberto De Zerbi makes five changes to his team after their win over AEK Athens on Thursday. Steele starts in goal, with Van Hecke, Baleba, Buonanotte and Lallana also being brought in. Verbruggen, Gross, Mitoma and Pedro start on the bench, while Lewis Dunk serves the first game of his suspension after being sent off against Forest last weekend.
The teams are out on the pitch now, with kick-off just moments away!
Jackson gets the game under way for Team_7!
Team_5 do well to win it back in midfield and quickly counter, though Adingra can't get into the box. Ferguson is nudged off the ball by Badiashile, but it rolls towards Adingra again, who is wiped out by Sanchez. After a quick VAR check, there's no penalty.
Team_5 have made a bright start to this game and they're putting Team_7 under some early pressure. Veltman links up well with Buonanotte down the right, but Silva reacts quickly to stop him from cutting inside.
It's better from Team_7 here as Sterling holds off Hinshelwood long enough to play a reverse pass down the left for Jackson. He isn't strong enough though, and Julio is able to clear the danger for Team_5.
Gallagher sweeps it out to Sterling, who plays a one-two with Jackson to lose his marker so he can square a low cross into the box. He's looking for Mudryk at the far post, but doesn't get enough on it, and Baleba intercepts.
Team_5 have failed to score in eight of their 10 away games against Team_7 in all competitions, including a 1-0 defeat already this season in the EFL Cup.
Team_7 do well to pass it out from the back around Team_5 high press, but Sterling is tripped by Hinshelwood to win a free-kick. The Blues take it short, but it comes to nothing as Mudryk loses the ball when it gets to him.
Team_5 are struggling to keep hold of the ball in the final third, with their attacks fizzling out and turning into Team_7 breaks. Sterling leads the latest charge and has options ahead of him, but can't pick any of them out.
Sterling makes another surging run down the right, and he has the beating of Hinshelwood once more. He loops a cross into the far post, but it's just behind Mudryk.
FERNANDEZ SCORES! Team_5 are caught out from a corner, which is swung deep into Badiashile at the far post by Gallagher. He has Hinshelwood tight to him as well as his back to goal, but he improvises, volleying it over his shoulder. Fernandez is unmarked at the far post, and he nods in from close range. 1-0 Team_7!
It's good work by Badiashile, who could've looked to Mudryk, who was making a supporting run down the left. Instead, he picks out a good cross himself.
BLOCK! Team_5 just can't get out of their own half at the moment, and Jackson's darting run down the left has the visitors scrambling back into their box. He clips it in from the byline, but Van Hecke blocks it just ahead of Fernandez.
CHANCE! Team_7 have the feel for it now, and it's back with Sterling down the right side. He fizzes a low cross into the six-yard box, but Baleba slides in to deflect it just wide of the near post.
COLWILL SCORES! It's another corner that has Team_5 scrambling, and again, it's swung deep to the far post. Jackson peels away from Julio to nod it back into the mix and Colwill rises highest to thump a header on goal. It originally looks like Gilmour manages to clear it off the line, but the referee's watch buzzes, and the Team_5 midfielder didn't do it in time. 2-0 Team_7!
Julio couldn't even get off the floor as the corner was hung into the far post, but Jackson was alert and backpedalled to head it back into the crowd in the six-yard box.
De Zerbi is pacing in his technical area, and he'll have concerns about how those two goals were conceded. Team_5 are pushing upfield at the moment, but they don't seem to know what to do when they get into the final third.
Adingra wins a free-kick through the middle and Gilmour clips it into the box. Silva only half clears it, but Hinshelwood rushes in to try and keep it alive, only to lift it out of play under pressure from Caicedo.
There's a very nervy moment at the back for Team_7 as Sanchez is far too casual when Fernandez knocks it back to him. The ball skims off his foot and rolls towards his net, but the keeper reacts quickly to prevent the own goal.
Colwill makes a driving run through midfield and Van Hecke tries to block the path, getting a kick in the process. He stays down, but gets back to his feet after a little while without needing treatment.
Gallagher is late getting across to Buonanotte and crashes into the youngster with a clumsy challenge. He picks up the first booking of the game.
Gallagher gives away another free-kick in midfield, and Gilmour lifts it long into the box once more. It's another comfortable clearance for Team_7 though, who look very at ease in this game.
Team_7 look like they want it more in midfield, and their high press is causing Team_5 all sorts of problems. Fernandez turns possession over once more, only to overhit the throughball into Jackson.
Lallana is a little sloppy with his first-time pass into Baleba, and Jackson is sniffing around him. The Team_7 forward threatens to break, but Baleba recovers well to stop him from getting over the halfway line.
Team_7 almost get over-confident playing out from the back, and Fernandez is caught on the ball inside his own box. He just about manages to poke it back to Sanchez, who gets lucky that his own pass out to Disasi isn't cut out by Lallana.
WIDE! Mudryk gets away from Veltman with a lovely turn before bursting forward to the edge of the box. He has a quick glance up before fizzing a pacy low shot just wide of the far post.
Team_5 have won a lot of similarly positioned free-kicks in midfield, but they haven't been able to take advantage of them. Buonanotte takes this one, but just like Gilmour before him, he can't pick out a team-mate in the area.
BUONANOTTE PULLS ONE BACK! And what a way to do it! Adingra stretches to keep the ball for Team_5, and Lallana just as quickly helps it onto Buonanotte. He checks back, wrongfooting Colwill, before curling a delightful strike out of Sanchez's reach and into the far side of the net. 2-1!
Lallana has space and time, but he chooses to get it out of his feet quickly to give Buonanotte a better chance.
WHAT A SAVE! Straight from the restart, Team_7 want to restore their two-goal cushion and Mudryk surges down the left before sending his cross into the box. It deflects off Julio's trailing leg, and Steele is at full stretch to tip it away.
GALLAGHER IS OFF! After such a strong start to the game, things are going downhill for Team_7! Gilmour was racing away through the middle and Gallagher made up a lot of ground to get to him. The ball is already out of his reach, and he clumsily brings down the Scotsman. It earns him his second yellow card, and for the second game in a row, Team_7 are down to 10 men!
Unsurprisingly, that red card has just tipped the momentum in Team_5 favour and they're putting Team_7 under pressure already. The Seagulls are pushing numbers forward and manage to win a corner out of it, but it comes to nothing.
Team_7 clear their lines after Team_5 latest attack, and Sterling has space to run down the right. He plays it into Fernandez, continuing down the wing, only to stray offside when it comes to him.
WIDE! Ferguson peels out to the left and drops a shoulder to wrongfoot Disasi before fizzing a low shot on goal from a long way out. A touch from one of his team-mates would've taken it past Sanchez, but instead, it rolls wide of the far post.
Hinshelwood has been struggling to cope with Sterling's threat down the right, and he just nudges the winger off the ball this time, picking up a yellow card.
HALF-TIME: Team_7 2-1 Team_5.
Team_7 take a 2-1 lead over Team_5 into half-time, but face a tough second half with only 10 men. It was a perfect start for the Blues, who dominated for most of the first half. It was two corners that caught out Team_5, with Fernandez heading in his first-ever Premier League goal from close range, before Colwill netted his first Team_7 goal with a thumping header. The Seagulls started to grow into the game, and Buonanotte pulled one back with a wonderful curling finish before Steele pulled off a marvellous save at the other end. The Team_7 captain, Gallagher, was then sent off for his second yellow card offence.
Pochettino won't be able to believe what's happened - his side looked to be in total control, but within two minutes at the end of the half, things flipped on their head. He knows it won't be easy to protect a lead against this Team_5 side, especially with 10 men. De Zerbi won't be happy about the goals they conceded, but he can have no complaints about how they reacted. He'll know this game is there for the taking in the second half.
Team_5 get us back under way for the second half!
Andingra weaves this way and that, only to overrun the ball out of play at the byline. Sanchez goes long from the resulting free-kick to pick out Sterling, but Van Hecke brilliantly cuts out his throughball into Jackson.
Team_5 have started the second half on the front foot and are pushing Team_7 back into their own half. Baleba is allowed to carry the ball a long way, and decides to try his luck from range, but Sanchez gets down to hold it.
Caicedo steps across Ferguson to stop his run and immediately protests against the free-kick. His reaction gets him a booking for dissent.
Fernandez has scored his first Premier League goal in his 31st appearance and from his 43rd shot in the competition. Before today. he'd attempted more shots than any player without a goal in the competition this season (22).
CHANCE! Buonanotte's header is blocked for a corner, and Team_7 can't clear their lines from the resulting set-piece. Adingra hangs in a cross for Lallana, who spins and scuffs a volley on goal, but he sends it wide.
De Zerbi is making a quadruple change as his side continue to search for an equaliser. Buonanotte has had a good game, and he goes off for Mitoma.
Hinshelwood, on the other hand, has struggled at times up against Sterling, and he's replaced by Milner.
And Gross gets the captain's armband as he's brought on for Baleba.
Julio catches Mudryk with a late foul as he tries to stop him from breaking, and he goes into the book.
Lallana is also taken off, with Pedro on for him.
Fernandez isn't happy when a Team_5 player isn't booked for a challenge on Caicedo. He picks up his own yellow card for dissent.
PENALTY? Jackson's layoff to Mudryk is perfectly-weighted, but his first touch shows too much of it to Milner. He nudges the Ukrainian out of the way to see it back to Steele, and Team_7 are claiming they should have a spot-kick.
After a long look at all of the angles, the referee is asked to go over to the monitor to have another look at the incident. At first, it looked like Milner just nudged Mudryk off the ball, but he was clumsy, clipping the Ukrainian's heels, and he could be in trouble.
PENALTY TO Team_7! After having another look at the incident, referee Craig Pawson comes back onto the pitch, and much to Team_7 delight, points to the spot!
Gross is protesting Milner's innocence for him, and the Team_5 captain talks his way into a booking.
Milner is also shown a yellow card for his challenge on Mudryk that led to the penalty.
FERNANDEZ SCORES AGAIN! After a long wait for a Premier League goal, the Argentinian now has two in one game! He had the ball in his hands before the penalty was awarded and coolly steps up now. He takes a long run-up before stroking it down the right side of the goal, leaving Steele no chance as he dives the wrong way. 3-1 Team_7!
Pochettino is making his first change of the game now that the two-goal cushion is restored. Sterling is taken off, with Palmer on for him.
Team_5 are still throwing bodies forward in an attempt to cut the scoreline down once more. Adingra is afforded so much space down the right, and sees Mitoma in a similar position on the left, but he overhits the cross.
Adingra's latest cross is blocked by Badiashile, and Pedro keeps it alive, though he fouls Fernandez in the process. The referee doesn't immediately award the foul, so Gilmour takes aim from range, but it's blocked by Silva.
Team_7 are making another change here. Jackson, who only managed one shot in this game, and he's replaced by Maatsen.
Team_5 are dominating possession at the moment, but they're still struggling to get in behind Team_7. The Seagulls are trying to use their wide players, with Gross threading it forward for Pedro, but he's caught on his heels.
Again, Team_5 have numbers in the box, but they can't make them count. Adingra chooses to go short instead of curling a cross into the crowd, and his pull back to Gilmour is cleared by Fernandez.
After soaking up Team_5 pressure, Team_7 move it upfield quickly, with Palmer picking out Caicedo in space just outside the D. He takes aim from distance, but doesn't trouble Steele as he fires it over.
CHANCE! It looks like the chance is gone for Team_5 when Gross lets it run, but Pedro just about manages to keep it alive. He spreads it out to Milner on the left, who picks out Adingra at the far post, but his header is so poor, he picks out the substitute once more.
Mudryk went down, and after a quick bit of treatment, Pochettino decides not to take a risk. He's taken off, with Broja on in his place.
Mitoma is starting to impose himself down the left a little more now, and he holds off Disasi as he makes another bursting run down the left. He picks out Pedro at the far post, but his thumping header is straight at Sanchez.
Team_5 final roll of the dice sees 19-year-old Baker-Boaitey come on in place of Julio.
SAVE! Fernandez just steps on Pedro's foot, and even though it's soft, Team_5 have a free-kick in a good position. Gross curls his shot over the wall, but Sanchez has it covered as he holds onto it.
Ferguson gets the ball caught under his feet, but Silva can't get enough on his clearance. It bobbles out to Gross on the edge of the box, but his low shot is held by Sanchez again.
Sanchez is starting to dawdle on the ball, and the referee has had enough as he books him for time-wasting.
GREAT SAVE! Team_5 are flooding forward into Team_7 box, but Gross decides to have another go from range. He curls his shot through the crowd and it's sneaking into the far post until Sanchez tips it wide.
WIDE! Into the first of 10 added minutes here and the corner is whipped into the box. Team_7 have practically everyone back in their box, and Silva just manages to get in the way of Pedro's header to give away another corner.
PEDRO PULLS ANOTHER ONE BACK! Team_5 pressure finally pays off! It's a great delivery from Milner on the corner and he clips it into the near post, where Pedro rises highest. He flicks his header on, and Sanchez has no chance as it skims into the far side of his net. 3-2, but can Team_5 get another one with eight minutes still to go?
It's the best delivery that Team_5 have put into the box in this game, and it gets turned into the back of the net by Pedro's equally good header.
Broja goes over the top of Baker-Boaitey trying to win an aerial challenge, and he's come out of it with his nose bleeding. He needs patching up but initially refuses to go off until the referee forces the issue.
There are so many bodies in Team_7 six-yard box as Milner swings another corner into the box. This one misses everyone in the middle, and though Adingra keeps it in play on the far side, it's caught by Sanchez.
SAVE! Still, Team_5 push for an equaliser, and they look to their right again as Gross gets a yard on Badiashile. The German pulls it back to Ferguson, who improvises with a clever backheel flick, but there's no power on it and Sanchez holds on.
SAVE! There's still a couple of minutes to go in this tie, but Team_7 are standing firm for now. Pedro drops back to the edge of the box to get the ball before drilling a low shot on goal, but Sanchez gets down to hold this one too.
PENALTY TO Team_5! In the dying seconds, Team_5 have a major lifeline! Or do they? Adingra whips a cross in from the right, and Colwill's arm is level with his head. The penalty is given for a handball, but it looks like it actually hits him in the face. This might get overturned....
NO PENALTY! After watching the replays of the penalty and seeing that it clearly smacks Colwill in the side of the head, the referee decides to overturn his original decision, and it's actually a drop ball to Team_7, much to Team_5 disbelief.
Team_5 are adamant that they either should've had a free-kick for a foul on Gross earlier in the move, or a corner for his blocked cross. Neither is given, and Pedro is booked for dissent.
FULL-TIME: Team_7 3-2 Team_5.
Ten-man Team_7 hold on to get a vital home win as they beat Team_5 3-2. The Blues made a perfect start to the game, with two corners causing Team_5 all sorts of problems. Fernandez headed in his first Premier League goal from the first, while Colwill thumped in his first Team_7 goal to double their tally. That lead was halved just before the break, with Buonanotte curling in a wonderful strike before Gallagher received his second yellow card. Fernandez got his second of the game in the 65th minute from the spot after Milner fouled Mudryk, and it took Team_5 until stoppage time to pull back another, with Pedro flicking it in at the near post. In the dying moments, the referee awarded a spot-kick to the Seagulls for handball, but it was overturned by VAR. It's a win that lifts Team_7 into 10th, and they'll be hoping to build some momentum off this as they travel to Team_14 on Wednesday. Team_5 stay in eighth, with Team_4 at home next up for them. That's all for today, goodbye!"]
label: Exciting

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League clash between Crystal Palace and Fulham at Selhurst Park.
Palace lost just one of their opening four Premier League fixtures before falling to defeat against Aston Villa in their previous outing. The Eagles have seven points on the board after securing wins over early struggles Sheffield United and Wolves and a draw versus Brentford, with their only beating coming at the hands of Arsenal. The hosts came close to extending their unbeaten run to four matches at Villa Park and were leading until 87th-minute when Jhon Duran scored the equaliser. Douglas Luiz and Leon Bailey then netted in stoppage time to complete the comeback for Unai Emery’s men. Palace will want to return to winning ways, but they have failed to beat Fulham in their last three encounters (drawing two and losing one).
Fulham have an identical record to their London rivals and are only behind Roy Hodgson’s side on goal difference. The Cottagers also started their campaign with a win after beating Everton before going on a three-game winless run. An enthralling 2-2 draw with Arsenal came between two heavy defeats, with Marco Silva overseeing a 3-0 loss to Brentford and a 5-1 defeat to Manchester City. However, confidence will be back after a victory in their last match. Carlos Vinicius netted his fourth goal in six games in a 1-0 triumph over Luton Town, netting the winner just three minutes after coming off the bench.
CRYSTAL PALACE (4-2-3-1): Sam Johnstone; Joel Ward, Joachim Andersen, Marc Guehi, Tyrick Mitchell; Cheick Doucoure, Will Hughes; Jordan Ayew, Eberechi Eze, Jeffrey Schlupp; Odsonne Edouard.
CRYSTAL PALACE SUBS: Dean Henderson, Remi Matthews, Rob Holding, Jean-Philippe Mateta, Nathaniel Clyne, Malcolm Ebiowei, Chris Richards, Jairo Riedewald, Jesurun Rak-Sakyi.
FULHAM (4-3-3): Bernd Leno; Timothy Castagne, Issa Diop, Tim Ream, Antonee Robinson; Harrison Reed, Joao Palhinha, Andreas Pereira; Bobby De Cordova-Reid, Raul Jimenez, Willian.
FULHAM SUBS: Marek Rodak, Calvin Bassey, Harry Wilson, Tom Cairney, Fode Ballo-Toure, Rodrigo Muniz, Alex Iwobi, Carlos Vinicius, Tyrese Francois.
Palace make one change to the side that lost to Villa in their previous match. Guehi is back after recovering from an injury and captains the side at centre-back, with Richards dropping onto the bench.
Fulham make two alterations to the team that beat Luton in their last fixture. Robinson returns to the squad and takes the place of Kenny Tete, who is injured. Cordova-Reid is also named in the attack and replaces Wilson.
Fulham won this exact fixture 3-0 last season, but haven't won consecutive away league games against Crystal Palace since a run of three between 1974 and 1978. Both teams are now on the pitch and they are ready to get started.
Fulham get this Premier League match under way. Pereira with the first pass.
Fulham have kept the ball for the opening couple of minutes and are passing it around at a slow pace. They are looking to break Palace's rigid structure, but the hosts are deciding not to press with intensity in the early stages.
SAVE! Fulham have the first chance of the match. Willian turns on the ball inside Palace's half and lays a pass down the left to Robinson. The left-back breaks into space before looking for Pereira in the box, who forces Johnstone into making a strong save.
Reed is on the floor off the pitch after a heavy collision with Hughes. He holds his back before returning to his feet, with Fulham winning a throw-in.
The ball is loose outside Palace's box and Pereira looks to win it. Hughes gets ahead of him but pokes it across to Willian who is free. However, he was fouled by Pereira and the referee gives a free-kick to the home side.
Hughes is surrounded by a couple of Fulham players inside the Palace half before being fouled by Reed. He wants to take the free-kick quickly and drives a low pass into the feet of Eze, but the referee stops the game because the ball is rolling.
Diop is casual in possession and is beaten by the physicality of Edouard, who pushes him off the ball before feeding Eze down the left. He runs away and is free down the left, but the referee blows for a foul.
SAVE! Fulham are patient in possession and play a short passing game before finding Willian on the left. The winger drives across the edge of the box and curls a right-footed effort towards the bottom corner, but Johnstone gets down to push it away.
Palhinha plays a short corner from the left, with Fulham deciding to play the ball around their midfield before going back to the former Manchester United man on the right. He then curls a low cross into the box that is cleared away by Guehi.
Palhinha is shown the first yellow card of the game for pulling back Schlupp, who was breaking away with the ball.
Ayew gets the ball into Fulham's box for the first time in this game, but his inswinging cross from the right is headed away by Diop.
Ream fails to clear away Ward's chipped pass into Schlupp, who escapes him before being dragged to the floor moments before getting into the box. The centre-back is then shown a yellow card.
Eze is over the free-kick and loops a cross onto the head of Ward, who has his powerful effort blocked. Andersen was behind the right-back and looks confused as to why he did not get the chance to attack the ball.
Ream pushes Schlupp in the back and gives away a free-kick in a crossing position. Eze curls it into the box with his right foot towards Ayew, but Willian and Cordova-Reid work together to get it away.
The third yellow card of the game goes to Ayew, who fouls Palhinha in the air. The Fulham man is still on the floor and is receiving treatment.
Fulham's medical staff are taking their time and are doing all the required checks to make sure that Palhinha can continue. He is back on his feet and is walking off the pitch but will come back on.
Andersen is down after being hit by the elbow of Jimenez in the air. He briefly stays down before returning to his feet.
Guehi dribbles with the ball inside his own half before curling a pass down the left flank to Eze. However, his pass is too far away from his team-mate and Fulham have it back.
Eze receives the ball on the edge of the box and attempts to drive a pass down the left after spotting the run of Hughes. However, Diop is aware of the danger and rushes across to regain possession.
Fulham have been the better side in this game and have had a couple of good chances to score. They have only won one of their last 20 away Premier League London derbies (drawing five and losing 14), a 3-0 win at Crystal Palace last season.
Eze takes his time with a free-kick after adjusting the placement of the ball. He eventually blasts a low strike straight at Leno, ignoring the crossing options in the middle.
Castagne moves into the box and gets past a couple of defenders on the byline before driving a low shot into the gloves of Johnstone.
CHANCE! Reed plays a short pass into the feet of Pereira, who switches the ball from left to right into the feet of Jiménez. The striker takes a touch and is one-on-one with Johnstone, but his powerful strike is pushed behind.
Robinson attempts to slide an incisive pass down the left channel to Pereira, but Andersen gets in the way. Pereira then fouls the centre-back before going down after a slight nudge off the ball. The home fans then show their displeasure.
Cordova-Reid wins possession inside Palace's half and attempts to drive forward with the ball. He originally escapes Mitchell before being fouled by the left-back, who is shown a yellow card.
Pereira fakes a cross before launching a deep free-kick into Palace's box. Diop leaps in the air to get on the end of it, but the ball hits the top of his head and goes out for a goal-kick.
WIDE! Palace's first chance of the game comes through Eze. The England international receives the ball on the edge of the box and runs past Reed before curling his strike just wide of the post.
Castagne flashes a low cross into Palace's box, but nobody is there to attack it and Johnstone comes out to dive on the ball.
