Schlupp wins a late corner off of Palhinha, who stops him from moving into the box. Andersen dives across to get onto the end of Eze's cross, but he cannot direct the ball towards the goal.
There will be four minutes of additional time.
There is a short stop to the game after a heavy challenge from Hughes on Willian. The former Chelsea man goes down holding his foot before getting back to his feet.
Ayew bursts down the right with the ball and evades Ream before chipping a cross into the box. However, it has too much height on it and is too close to Leno, allowing the goalkeeper to make a simple catch.
HALF-TIME: CRYSTAL PALACE 0-0 FULHAM
Fulham had the better chances before the break, but the game is goalless at half-time. Johnstone has been called into action a couple of times and denied Pereira inside the first three minutes. The former Manchester United man received the ball inside the box on the left and blasted his shot across the goal, with Johnstone making a smart stop. Willian then looked to break the deadlock with a curling effort angled towards the bottom corner, but the England international got across to push it wide. Palace were quiet for most of the half. However, Eze was always posing a threat. He arrived on the edge of the box and looked to whip a shot into the corner. However, it flashed just wide of the post.
Palace had just one shot on target before the break and must do more to support Edouard. The striker has had just 11 touches and has been kept quiet by Ream and Diop. Eze has shown fleeting moments of quality but has also not seen enough of the ball. As for Fulham, they started the game quickly before slowing down. Willian has shown his ability on the left, with the Cottagers looking much more effective in the attack due to the return of left-back Robinson. However, Palhinha must be careful in the midfield as he has already been shown a yellow card.
Palace get the ball rolling again. No changes at the break.
Hughes has the ball on his right foot but uses his quick feet to get past Palhinha and switch it over to his left. His curling effort from outside the box is then caught by Leno.
Diop has the ball inside Fulham's half and launches a long pass up the pitch. However, nobody makes the run and Palace have it back.
Ayew and Robinson get into a battle on the right just outside Fulham's box, with the Palace man moving his body one way and pushing the ball the other to get past the defender. He then blasts a low cross into the gloves of Leno.
Eze skips past Castagne and pokes a throughball down the left side of the box to Edouard, who has his blasted attempt pushed over by Leno. The flag then goes up for offside against the striker, who did not watch the line and was past the defence by a distance.
Pereira and Willian are over a free-kick on the right. The latter takes and curls a cross into the box that is headed away by Edouard.
Andersen displays his range of passing and switches the play from right to left towards Mitchell. He looks to volley a cross into the box, but it goes up in the air, allowing Diop to beat Eze to the ball.
PENALTY SHOUT! Mitchell gets down the left flank again and drags a low cross into the middle of the box. Eze looks to get onto the end of it but goes down under a challenge from Reed. He wants a penalty, but the referee ignores his claims.
Robinson has possession on the left and floats a high cross into the box. Jimenez beats Guehi in the air but heads his attempt over the bar.
Mitchell is on the floor inside Palace's box and requires medical attention. He walks off the pitch and will be able to continue.
Palace have been better since the restart and are protecting Johnstone well. They have lost just two of their last 12 home Premier League matches (winning four and drawing six), defeats against Man City in March and Arsenal in August. Since Roy Hodgson returned in April, the Eagles have picked up 14 points in seven league games at Selhurst Park (winning four, drawing two and losing one).
Hughes plays a short pass across to Eze, who unleashes a curling effort from the edge of the box. The ball hits the elbow of Castagne, but his arms were by his side.
Robinson displays his pace and pushes the ball past Ward, running the other way around him to get onto the end of it on the other side. The USA international then whips a cross into the box towards Jimenez, but Guehi gets across to head it away.
CHANCE! Fulham should have broke the deadlock. Cordova-Reid drives down the middle of the pitch and has options to his left and right outside the box. He slots a pass into the feet of Jimenez, who decides against shooting from a tight angle. He looks for Pereira, who is free next to the goal, but it evades his outstretched foot.
Doucoure is shown a yellow card for a late tackle on Willian outside the box.
Pereira and Willian are over the free-kick. The former takes it, crashing the wall with his attempt.
Palace make the first change of the game. Schlupp has been fantastic in this game and put  Palhinha and Ream on yellow cards, but he is now coming off. Mateta takes his place.
Willian switches the ball from left to right and finds Castagne on the byline. He attempts to direct a cross into the middle but gets it all wrong.
Palace have had most of the ball for the last couple of minutes, but have not been able to do anything with it. They have moved into Fulham's defensive third on a couple of occasions. However, the away side have defended their box well.
Eze moves into the middle of the pitch and looks to unlock Edouard on the right. However, his touch is poor, allowing Robinson to come away with the ball.
Fulham make their first change of the game. Pereira is usually an influential figure but has been quiet since the restart. Iwobi made a big impact off the bench against Luton and is being tasked with doing the same today.
The tempo of the game has dropped in the last 10 minutes. There have been a lot of loose passes and both teams are giving away possession cheaply. The match is there for the taking if Palace of Fulham improve their ability to create chances in the final 13 minutes.
Eze's outswinging corner is met by Andersen, but he heads the ball well over the bar.
Fulham make a straight swap in the attack. Jimenez is replaced by Vinicius, who scored the winning goal in the game against Luton.
Wilson also makes his way onto the pitch. Cordova-Reid is the player to come off.
Wilson is straight into the action and looks to make space for a shot on the edge of the box. However, Ayew tracks him all the way and makes the block.
Guehi has been vital for Palace at the heart of the defence. He gets ahead of Vinicius to head away another cross from Robinson.
SAVE! What a stop from Johnstone. Castagne keeps the ball on the pitch on the right and plays a short pass into the box to Reed, who drives a cross into the feet of Willian. He is free on the left and blasts a low shot across the goal that is blocked by Johnstone.
Mitchell breaks free on the left and floats a cross to the back on the box. Ayew makes a darting run to get onto the end of it and looks to have a free header, but Robinson makes a vital intervention.
CHANCE! Eze spots the run of Mateta, who breaks free of Fuham's defence and rushes into the box. He collects the ball well and looks to drive a shot across the goal and into the bottom corner, but his attempt is tame. Leno gets down and makes a simple stop.
Eze's inswinging corner from the left is cleared away. Fulham almost get a chance to break away on the counter after a poor pass from Doucoure, but Hughes slides across to stop them from getting forward.
Eze delicately chips the ball over Fulham's defence and into the path of Mateta, who is forced down the left. He then flashes a cross into Edouard, but the flag goes up for offside.
Edouard started the game up front but failed to have a shot in the match. Rak-Sakyi is on for the final three minutes.
Fulham have a late chance to score a winner. Robinson breaks forward with the ball and has options ahead of him, but waits for too long to thread a throughball into Vinicius, with the striker running offside.
FULL-TIME: CRYSTAL PALACE 0-0 FULHAM
Fulham had the better chances against Palace but couldn't find a way through Johnstone, with the game ending goalless. The Eagles shot-stopper goalkeeper denied Pereira inside the first three minutes before getting across his line to push Willian's whipped effort around the post later in the half. Jimenez also had a one-on-one opportunity, but the goalkeeper made himself big to block his attempt. They then went close to opening the scoring but squandered an opportunity. Cordova-Reid found Jimenez in the box, but he looked for a pass rather than a shot, with the ball rolling out for a goal-kick. Johnstone saved another shot from Willian, with Mateta having Palace's best chance. He escaped the defence but struck his effort into the gloves of Leno.
The Eagles now have back-to-back trips to Old Trafford and will face Manchester United in the third round of the EFL Cup before playing them again in the Premier League. As for Fulham, they will host Norwich City in the EFL Cup. Marco Silva’s men will then welcome Chelsea to Craven Cottage in the league.
That's all for today, goodbye.
summary:
Roy Hodgson became only the eighth manager to take charge of 400 Premier League matches as he saw his depleted Crystal Palace side share a goalless draw with Nottingham Forest. 
Palace went into the match at Selhurst Park missing a number of key attacking players through injury and suffered another setback as Jeffery Schlupp limped off midway through the first half. 
With Forest’s leading scorer Taiwo Awoniyi also out for a month and Palace’s injury woes, scoring opportunities were always going to be at a premium. 
Forest had the better of the first-half chances, most notably when Morgan Gibbs-White went through on 21 minutes but saw his volleyed lob over Sam Johnstone hit the far post and rebound into the goalkeeper’s arms. 
Palace had a glorious opportunity to go ahead in the 63rd minute when Odsonne Edouard set up Jean-Philippe Mateta on the edge of the area but the French forward shot narrowly wide.  
The away side looked more like getting a late winner but Johnstone stood strong to deny Forest twice as Palace stay ninth with 12 points, while Forest are 13th with nine points.
Crystal Palace report | Forest report
Referee: Craig Pawson. Assistants: Richard West, Marc Perry. Fourth official: Chris Kavanagh. VAR: Michael Salisbury. Assistant VAR: Sian Massey-Ellis.
text:
["Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League clash between Team_8 and Team_10 at Selhurst Park.
Palace lost just one of their opening four Premier League fixtures before falling to defeat against Team_2 in their previous outing. The Eagles have seven points on the board after securing wins over early struggles Team_17 and Team_20 and a draw versus Team_4, with their only beating coming at the hands of Team_1. The hosts came close to extending their unbeaten run to four matches at Villa Park and were leading until 87th-minute when Jhon Duran scored the equaliser. Douglas Luiz and Leon Bailey then netted in stoppage time to complete the comeback for Unai Emery’s men. Palace will want to return to winning ways, but they have failed to beat Team_10 in their last three encounters (drawing two and losing one).
Team_10 have an identical record to their London rivals and are only behind Roy Hodgson’s side on goal difference. The Cottagers also started their campaign with a win after beating Team_9 before going on a three-game winless run. An enthralling 2-2 draw with Team_1 came between two heavy defeats, with Marco Silva overseeing a 3-0 loss to Team_4 and a 5-1 defeat to Team_13. However, confidence will be back after a victory in their last match. Carlos Vinicius netted his fourth goal in six games in a 1-0 triumph over Team_12, netting the winner just three minutes after coming off the bench.
Team_8 (4-2-3-1): Sam Johnstone; Joel Ward, Joachim Andersen, Marc Guehi, Tyrick Mitchell; Cheick Doucoure, Will Hughes; Jordan Ayew, Eberechi Eze, Jeffrey Schlupp; Odsonne Edouard.
Team_8 SUBS: Dean Henderson, Remi Matthews, Rob Holding, Jean-Philippe Mateta, Nathaniel Clyne, Malcolm Ebiowei, Chris Richards, Jairo Riedewald, Jesurun Rak-Sakyi.
Team_10 (4-3-3): Bernd Leno; Timothy Castagne, Issa Diop, Tim Ream, Antonee Robinson; Harrison Reed, Joao Palhinha, Andreas Pereira; Bobby De Cordova-Reid, Raul Jimenez, Willian.
Team_10 SUBS: Marek Rodak, Calvin Bassey, Harry Wilson, Tom Cairney, Fode\xa0Ballo-Toure, Rodrigo Muniz, Alex Iwobi, Carlos Vinicius, Tyrese Francois.
Palace make one change to the side that lost to Villa in their previous match. Guehi is back\xa0after recovering\xa0from an injury and captains the side at centre-back, with Richards dropping onto the bench.
Team_10 make two alterations to the team that beat Luton in their last fixture. Robinson returns to the squad and takes the place of Kenny Tete, who is injured. Cordova-Reid is also named in the attack and replaces Wilson.
Team_10 won this exact fixture 3-0 last season, but haven't won consecutive away league games against Team_8 since a run of three between 1974 and 1978. Both teams are now on the pitch and they are ready to get started.
Team_10 get this Premier League match under way.\xa0Pereira with the first pass.
Team_10 have kept the ball for the opening couple of minutes and are passing it around at a slow pace. They are looking to break Palace's rigid structure, but the hosts are deciding not to press with intensity in the early stages.
SAVE! Team_10 have the first chance of the match. Willian turns on the ball inside Palace's half and lays a pass down the left to\xa0Robinson. The left-back breaks into space before looking for\xa0Pereira in the box, who forces\xa0Johnstone into making a strong save.
Reed is on the floor off the pitch after a heavy collision with Hughes. He holds his back before returning to his feet, with Team_10 winning a throw-in.
The ball is loose outside Palace's box and\xa0Pereira looks to win it. Hughes gets ahead of him but pokes it across to Willian who is free. However, he was fouled by\xa0Pereira and the referee gives a free-kick to the home side.
Hughes is surrounded by a couple of Team_10 players inside the Palace half before being fouled by Reed. He wants to take the free-kick quickly and drives a low pass into the feet of Eze, but the referee stops the game because the ball is rolling.
Diop is casual in possession and is beaten by the physicality of\xa0Edouard, who pushes him off the ball before feeding Eze down the left. He runs away and is free down the left, but the referee blows for a foul.
SAVE! Team_10 are patient in possession and play a short passing game before finding\xa0Willian on the left. The winger drives across the edge of the box and curls a right-footed effort towards the bottom corner, but\xa0Johnstone gets down to push it away.
Palhinha plays a short corner from the left, with Team_10 deciding to play the ball around their midfield before going back to the former Team_14 man on the right. He then curls a low cross into the box that is cleared away by\xa0Guehi.
Palhinha is shown the first yellow card of the game for pulling back\xa0Schlupp, who was breaking away with the ball.
Ayew gets the ball into Team_10 box for the first time in this game, but his inswinging cross from the right is headed away by Diop.
Ream fails to clear away Ward's chipped pass into\xa0Schlupp, who escapes him before being dragged to the floor moments before getting into the box. The centre-back is then shown a yellow card.
Eze is over the free-kick and loops a cross onto the head of Ward, who has his powerful effort blocked.\xa0Andersen was behind the right-back and looks confused as to why he did not get the chance to attack the ball.
Ream pushes\xa0Schlupp in the back and gives away a free-kick in a crossing position. Eze curls it into the box with his right foot towards Ayew, but Willian and\xa0Cordova-Reid work together to get it away.
The third yellow card of the game goes to Ayew, who fouls\xa0Palhinha in the air. The Team_10 man is still on the floor and is receiving treatment.
Team_10 medical staff are taking their time and are doing all the required checks to make sure that\xa0Palhinha can continue. He is back on his feet and is walking off the pitch but will come back on.
Andersen is down after being hit by the elbow of\xa0Jimenez in the air. He briefly stays down before returning to his feet.
Guehi dribbles with the ball inside his own half before curling a pass down the left flank to Eze. However, his pass is too far away from his team-mate and Team_10 have it back.
Eze receives the ball on the edge of the box and attempts to drive a pass down the left after spotting the run of Hughes. However, Diop is aware of the danger and rushes across to regain possession.
Team_10 have been the better side in this game and have had a couple of good chances to score. They\xa0have only won one of their last 20 away Premier League London derbies (drawing five and losing 14), a 3-0 win at Team_8 last season.
Eze takes his time with a free-kick after adjusting the placement of the ball. He eventually blasts a low strike straight at Leno, ignoring the crossing options in the middle.
Castagne\xa0moves into the box and gets past a couple of defenders on the byline before driving a low shot into the gloves of\xa0Johnstone.
CHANCE! Reed plays a short pass into the feet of\xa0Pereira, who switches the ball from left to right into the feet of\xa0Jiménez. The striker takes a touch and is one-on-one with\xa0Johnstone, but his powerful strike is pushed behind.
Robinson attempts to slide an incisive pass down the left channel to\xa0Pereira, but\xa0Andersen gets in the way.\xa0Pereira then fouls the centre-back before going down after a slight nudge off the ball. The home fans then show their displeasure.
Cordova-Reid wins possession inside Palace's half and attempts to drive forward with the ball. He originally escapes\xa0Mitchell before being fouled by the left-back, who is shown a yellow card.
Pereira fakes a cross before launching a deep free-kick into Palace's box. Diop leaps in the air to get on the end of it, but the ball hits the top of his head and goes out for a goal-kick.
WIDE! Palace's first chance of the game comes through Eze. The England international receives the ball on the edge of the box and runs past Reed before curling his strike just wide of the post.
Castagne flashes a low cross into Palace's box, but nobody is there to attack it and\xa0Johnstone comes out to dive on the ball.
Schlupp wins a late corner off of Palhinha, who stops him from moving into the box.\xa0Andersen dives across to get onto the end of Eze's cross, but he cannot direct the ball towards the goal.
There will be four minutes of additional time.
There is a short stop to the game after a heavy challenge from Hughes on Willian. The former Team_7 man goes down holding his foot before getting back to his feet.
Ayew bursts down the right with the ball and evades Ream before chipping a cross into the box. However, it has too much height on it and is too close to Leno, allowing the goalkeeper to make a simple catch.
HALF-TIME: Team_8 0-0 Team_10
Team_10 had the better chances before the break, but the game is goalless at half-time. Johnstone has been called into action a couple of times and denied Pereira inside the first three minutes. The former Team_14 man received the ball inside the box on the left and blasted his shot across the goal, with Johnstone making a smart stop. Willian then looked to break the deadlock with a curling effort angled towards the bottom corner, but the England international got across to push it wide. Palace were quiet for most of the half. However, Eze was always posing a threat. He arrived on the edge of the box and looked to whip a shot into the corner. However, it flashed just wide of the post.
Palace had just one shot on target before the break and must do more to support Edouard. The striker has had just 11 touches and has been kept quiet by Ream and Diop. Eze has shown fleeting moments of quality but has also not seen enough of the ball. As for Team_10, they started the game quickly before slowing down. Willian has shown his ability on the left, with the Cottagers looking much more effective in the attack due to the return of left-back Robinson. However, Palhinha must be careful in the midfield as he has already been shown a yellow card.
Palace get the ball rolling again. No changes at the break.
Hughes has the ball on his right foot but uses his quick feet to get past\xa0Palhinha and switch it over to his left. His curling effort from outside the box is then caught by Leno.
Diop has the ball inside Team_10 half and launches a long pass up the pitch. However, nobody makes the run and Palace have it back.
Ayew and\xa0Robinson get into a battle on the right just outside Team_10 box, with the Palace man moving his body one way and pushing the ball the other to get past the defender. He then blasts a low cross into the gloves of Leno.
Eze skips past\xa0Castagne and pokes a throughball down the left side of the box to Edouard, who has his blasted attempt pushed over by Leno. The flag then goes up for offside against the striker, who did not watch the line and was past the defence by a distance.
Pereira\xa0and Willian are over a free-kick on the right. The latter takes and curls a cross into the box that is headed away by Edouard.
Andersen displays his range of passing and switches the play from right to left towards\xa0Mitchell. He looks to volley a cross into the box, but it goes up in the air, allowing Diop to beat Eze to the ball.
PENALTY SHOUT!\xa0Mitchell gets down the left flank again and drags a low cross into the middle of the box. Eze looks to get onto the end of it but goes down under a challenge from\xa0Reed. He wants a penalty, but the referee ignores his claims.
Robinson has possession on the left and floats a high cross into the box.\xa0Jimenez beats\xa0Guehi in the air but heads his attempt over the bar.
Mitchell is on the floor inside Palace's box and requires medical attention. He walks off the pitch and will be able to continue.
Palace have been better since the restart and are protecting\xa0Johnstone well.\xa0They have lost just two of their last 12 home Premier League matches (winning four and drawing six), defeats against Team_13 in March and Team_1 in August. Since Roy Hodgson returned in April, the Eagles have picked up 14 points in seven league games at Selhurst Park (winning four, drawing two and losing one).
Hughes plays a short pass across to Eze, who unleashes a curling effort from the edge of the box. The ball hits the elbow of\xa0Castagne, but his arms were by his side.
Robinson displays his pace and pushes the ball past Ward, running the other way around him to get onto the end of it on the other side. The USA international then whips a cross into the box towards\xa0Jimenez, but\xa0Guehi gets across to head it away.
CHANCE! Team_10 should have broke the deadlock.\xa0Cordova-Reid drives down the middle of the pitch and has options to his left and right outside the box. He slots a pass into the feet of\xa0Jimenez, who decides against shooting from a tight angle. He looks for\xa0Pereira, who is free next to the goal, but it evades his outstretched foot.
Doucoure is shown a yellow card for a late tackle on Willian outside the box.
Pereira and Willian are over the free-kick. The former takes it, crashing the wall with his attempt.
Palace make the first change of the game.\xa0Schlupp has been fantastic in this game and put\xa0\xa0Palhinha and\xa0Ream on yellow cards, but he is now coming off.\xa0Mateta takes his place.
Willian switches the ball from left to right and finds\xa0Castagne on the byline. He attempts to direct a cross into the middle but gets it all wrong.
Palace have had most of the ball for the last couple of minutes, but have not been able to do anything with it. They have moved into Team_10 defensive third on a couple of occasions. However, the away side have defended their box well.
Eze moves into the middle of the pitch and looks to unlock Edouard on the right. However, his touch is poor, allowing\xa0Robinson to come away with the ball.
Team_10 make their first change of the game.\xa0Pereira is usually an influential figure but has been quiet since the restart.\xa0Iwobi made a big impact off the bench against Luton and is being tasked with doing the same today.
The tempo of the game has dropped in the last 10 minutes. There have been a lot of loose passes and both teams are giving away possession cheaply. The match is there for the taking if Palace of Team_10 improve their ability to create chances in the final 13 minutes.
Eze's outswinging corner is met by\xa0Andersen, but he heads the ball well over the bar.
Team_10 make a straight swap in the attack.\xa0Jimenez is replaced by\xa0Vinicius, who scored the winning goal in the game against Luton.
Wilson also makes his way onto the pitch.\xa0Cordova-Reid is the player to come off.
Wilson is straight into the action and looks to make space for a shot on the edge of the box. However, Ayew tracks him all the way and makes the block.
Guehi has been vital for Palace at the heart of the defence. He gets ahead of\xa0Vinicius to head away another cross from\xa0Robinson.
SAVE! What a stop from\xa0Johnstone.\xa0Castagne keeps the ball on the pitch on the right and plays a short pass into the box to Reed, who drives a cross into the feet of Willian. He is free on the left and blasts a low shot across the goal that is blocked by\xa0Johnstone.
Mitchell breaks free on the left and floats a cross to the back on the box. Ayew makes a darting run to get onto the end of it and looks to have a free header, but\xa0Robinson makes a vital intervention.
CHANCE! Eze spots the run of\xa0Mateta, who breaks free of Fuham's defence and rushes into the box. He collects the ball well and looks to drive a shot across the goal and into the bottom corner, but his attempt is tame. Leno gets down and makes a simple stop.
Eze's inswinging corner from the left is cleared away. Team_10 almost get a chance to break away on the counter after a poor pass from Doucoure, but Hughes slides across to stop them from getting forward.
Eze delicately chips the ball over Team_10 defence and into the path of\xa0Mateta, who is forced down the left. He then flashes a cross into Edouard, but the flag goes up for offside.
Edouard started the game up front but failed to have a shot in the match.\xa0Rak-Sakyi is on for the final three minutes.
Team_10 have a late chance to score a winner. Robinson breaks forward with the ball and has options ahead of him, but waits for too long to thread a throughball into Vinicius, with the striker running offside.
FULL-TIME: Team_8 0-0 Team_10
Team_10 had the better chances against Palace but couldn't find a way through Johnstone, with the game ending goalless. The Eagles shot-stopper goalkeeper denied Pereira inside the first three minutes before getting across his line to push Willian's whipped effort around the post later in the half. Jimenez also had a one-on-one opportunity, but the goalkeeper made himself big to block his attempt. They then went close to opening the scoring but squandered an opportunity. Cordova-Reid found Jimenez in the box, but he looked for a pass rather than a shot, with the ball rolling out for a goal-kick. Johnstone saved another shot from Willian, with Mateta having Palace's best chance. He escaped the defence but struck his effort into the gloves of Leno.
The Eagles now have back-to-back trips to Old Trafford and will face Team_14 in the third round of the EFL Cup before playing them again in the Premier League. As for Team_10, they will host Norwich City in the EFL Cup. Marco Silva’s men will then welcome Team_7 to Craven Cottage in the league.
That's all for today, goodbye."]
label: Normal

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of Newcastle United v Everton.
Newcastle are on a four-match unbeaten run and looking to build on their late season momentum, having come from 3-1 down to beat West Ham 4-3 at the weekend. The hosts are in eighth place on 43 points, trailing fifth-placed Aston Villa by 13 points for a Europa League spot. They’ve only lost three times at home this season, while their record against Everton will give them further confidence: the Magpies have won five of their last seven meetings. A win today would see them leapfrog West Ham into sixth place.
Everton are desperate to bring a halt to a grim run of results, and will likely take inspiration from the fact that their only win in eight midweek Premier League matches was a 3-0 victory over Newcastle in the reverse fixture. The Toffees sit 16th in the Premier League, just three points above the drop zone, and are winless in their last 12 Premier League games – their longest league run without a victory since 1957 – including their last seven on the road. A win today would see them complete the league double over the Magpies for the first time since 2017-18, and take them above Brentford into 15th.
NEWCASTLE UNITED (4-3-3): Martin Dubravka; Emil Krafth, Fabian Schar, Dan Burn, Lewis Hall; Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes; Elliot Anderson, Jacob Murphy, Alexander Isak, Harvey Barnes.
NEWCASTLE UNITED SUBS: Paul Dummett, Matt Ritchie, Lorius Karius, Joe Willock, Mark Gillespie, Joe White, Amadou Diallo, Alex Murphy, Ben Parkinson.
EVERTON (4-4-1-1): Jordan Pickford; Ben Godfrey, James Tarkowski, Jarrad Branthwaite, Vitalii Mykolenko; Ashley Young, Idrissa Gueye, Amadou Onana, Dwight McNeil; Abdoulaye Doucoure; Beto.
EVERTON SUBS: Nathan Patterson, Michael Keane, Dominic Calvert-Lewin, Jack Harrison, Joao Virginia, Andre Gomes, Seamus Coleman, Youssef Chermiti, James Garner.
Substitute Harvey Barnes’ brace at the weekend is rewarded with a start for Newcastle tonight, while Emil Krafth, Lewis Hall and Elliot Anderson also come into the starting XI. Anthony Gordon won’t be able to face his former club as he serves a one-match ban. In another blow to the Magpies’ injury-stricken season, captain Jamaal Lascelles tore his ACL in that same match and will be out for up to nine months, while Miguel Almiron and Tino Livramento, also injured on Saturday, miss out on the squad too.
Everton boss Sean Dyche makes four changes from their midweek loss to Bournemouth, as Beto, Ashley Young, Vitalii Mykolenko – who has recovered from an illness - and Idrissa Gueye come in for Seamus Coleman, James Garner, Jack Harrison and Dominic Calvert-Lewin. Forwards Arnaut Danjuma and Lewis Dobbin are again set to miss out due to injuries.
The teams are out on the pitch and we’re about to get underway!
KICK-OFF: NEWCASTLE UNITED V EVERTON. Everton get us going - to an immediate chorus of boos from St James' Park.
Everton already under pressure! Newcastle with an early press up the pitch, but Barnes - replacing the suspended Gordon - can't quite get a touch on it. Isak then tries to tee up Barnes again but Pickford gets the block.
Branthwaite makes an interception at the back and Everton break. Young chips the ball over the Magpies defence but there's no one in the box to take advantage. Newcastle are enjoying most of the possession at the moment.
Barnes and Anderson link up well in the box but Everton - tripping up Barnes in the process - get it under control and break. A long ball from Pickford falls to Doucoure but his first strike from the edge of the box soars over the bar!
Every touch by an Everton player is greeted with deafening boos from the fortress that is St James' Park. Krafth just clips Beto before he can get the ball. Free-kick to Everton about 20 yards out...
Huge missed chance for Everton! McNeil's free-kick falls to Tarkowski, who nods it over the top from five yards out! That was a great chance squandered by the visitors...
Everton on the break! McNeil makes an excellent run through acres of space, Godfrey delivers it to Young in the box, but Newcastle defend it well. No corner for the visitors.
Krafth crosses to Isak in the box but Branthwaite is there to make the clearance. It goes out for a Newcastle corner - Hall swings it in to Guimaraes, who takes a touch, but it's too far over and Everton clear it safely.
This has been fairly even so far, with both sides fancying their chances on the break but yet to find a way through. Murphy sends a brilliant cross in Barnes' direction a few yards off the far post, but Godfrey wins their aerial duel and it's out for a Newcastle corner.
Pickford's long ball was expertly taken apart by Newcastle and Barnes already has an assist to his name, his through-ball soaring past the Everton defence and finding Isak.
GOOOAAAALLLL! Newcastle are 1-0 ahead and it's Alexander Isak once again, his 19th this season! The through-ball soars over Tarkowski and Isak weaves his way expertly past Branthwaite to slot it in the bottom corner, way out of Pickford's reach. The Toon goes wild!
Newcastle pressing again, Hall ducking and diving through the defence but Onana clears it. Beto goes sprawling on the turf after a challenge by Burn.
All Newcastle now! Onana slides in on Anderson driving down the left, and the Newcastle man goes down and wins a free-kick.
There's a brief pause in play for the players to break their Ramadan fast.
Everton have been a lot more subdued since going behind. The hosts are controlling the game, with 66% of the possession, and looking much more dangerous.
Anderson and Guimaraes get in each other's way a little in midfield. Anderson tries to get into space and wins a free kick after getting shoved over, near the Newcastle box.
Anderson drives down the centre and squares it to Barnes, but there's a sea of blue shirts in the box to block and after a bit of pinball Everton head it clear.
Massive chance for Murphy! Everton are camped out in their box and Murphy takes his chance to sprint through and have a shot from range - but it fizzes over the bar! Newcastle have had six attempts now to Everton's two and are bringing all the intensity.
Now Beto has a go for the visitors! He gets into a good position but his shot from the edge of the box is miles off target. Sean Dyche does not look impressed.
Guimaraes and Gueye get in an elaborate tangle and the Brazilian hauls him over, giving away a free kick in the centre. Nothing comes of it and Barnes attempts to break, but Everton regain possession - Beto tries to cut it back, possibly for Doucoure, but his accuracy is way off again and Newcastle recover it easily.
Isak's attempt to pass to Barnes down the left, frustrated by the Everton midfield, is greeted with appreciation by the crowd. Their star man has now scored in each of his last five Premier League home games, the first player to do so since Yoan Gouffran in 2013.
Everton once again are asleep at the back as Isak and Anderson again combine dangerously in the box, but Godfrey makes a great clearance to save their blushes. The resulting corner is flicked over by Burn for an Everton goal-kick.
Barnes makes another electric run down the left but Tarkowski arrests it and concedes a throw-in. In another worrying sight for Eddie Howe, Hall is down on the pitch, holding onto his ribs. Medical staff are on the pitch - is this yet another injury setback for the Magpies?
Play resumes. Guimaraes and Anderson wrestle with Everton over a corner and the latter goes down courtesy of Doucoure. Everton have possession now, but McNeil's ball goes nowhere.
Beto gets a talking to for a lunge on Krafth. Still no yellow cards in this game despite some feisty challenges. Hall is back up and appears to be moving well.
Chance for Everton! Doucoure finds some space in the box and has a good attempt, but Dubravka jumps and gets his gloves to it. That's the most positive Everton have looked all game!
Huge stop by Pickford! After a calmer period of Newcastle possession the ball falls to Barnes at the far left - he gets it around Pickford, who's off his line, but no one can get a decent touch on it. Murphy then has a go himself and the Everton goalkeeper sticks out a leg to keep it out!
Four added minutes here at St James' Park.
Huge chance for Newcastle and Isak almost has a second! He glides through the defence and has a glorious chance to put the hosts 2-0 up, but it floats just over the bar.
Murphy swings in a cross and Pickford does well to collect just a couple of yards out from goal!
HALF-TIME: NEWCASTLE UNITED 1-0 EVERTON.
Newcastle are 1-0 up at the break! Both sides have had chances, but the hosts - roared on by the crowd - have looked much the brighter, led by star player Isak, who showed his worth with a brilliant strike in the opening 15 minutes. The Magpies have controlled the game well, with 62 per cent of possession compared to Everton's 38, and an xG of 1.37 to the Toffees' 0.47.
Everton need to turn this around quickly, and while they've threatened on the break, Newcastle haven't looked too troubled by their efforts so far. Worryingly for the visitors, they haven't won any of their last 25 Premier League games when trailing at half-time. They also failed to have a shot on target in that entire half - let's see if Dyche's half-time pep talk has any effect...
KICK-OFF: NEWCASTLE UNITED 1-0 EVERTON. Second half underway!
No changes at the break. Everton nick possession early on and Young hoofs a cross in towards Beto, but it doesn't quite find the target. A minute later Beto goes down in the box thanks to a shirt-pull by Schar but the ref is stone-faced to his appeals.
Almost a very embarrassing moment for Everton! Newcastle have a corner and the box is rammed. Tarkowski tries to clear but kicks it backwards onto his own post! It bounces away but wow, that could have been a disastrous start to this half!
Branthwaite chucks a long ball in the vague direction of Doucoure, approaching a near-empty Newcastle box, but Everton don't have the pace at the moment to make anything of it.
Guimaraes opts to leave a ball in his own penalty area and Beto launches towards it, sliding it on an approaching Dubravka. The keeper gets to it without much hassle but seems to clip his gloves on the Everton man in the process. Further up the pitch, Burn shoves McNeil over and concedes a free-kick.
Pickford takes the free-kick and sends it flying down towards the Newcastle box but the danger is cleared easily. Everton have a corner...
McNeil chips in the corner but it's rather flat and is cleared away. Everton have come out more strongly in this half, offering more in the opposition box. Tarkowski fires in a long ball but Onana, surrounded by Newcastle defenders, can't get his head to it and it sails behind.
Newcastle take a free kick, Isak squares the pass cutely to Dan Burn and the 6'7" centre-back fires it home! But wait... It's gone to VAR... They're checking for an offside on Isak.
Decision made: Burn's goal is chalked off. Isak was leaning just a fraction too far forward beyond the Everton defence.
Dyche decides now is the time to make some changes. Doucoure is replaced by Gomes.
Onana comes off for James Garner.
And a final change for Everton: the misfiring Beto is replaced by Dominic Calvert-Lewin. The latter hasn't scored in 23 games: can he break that streak here and get his side back in it?
Everton enjoy a spell of possession but Newcastle break! Pickford comes out to see to a long ball.
Calvert-Lewin jumps for a cross but Dubravka gets there first and catches!
Almost an equaliser for Everton! Garner - who has come on full of energy - spins on the ball and fires a brilliant first-time shot, but it bounces off the inside of the post! Huge, huge chance for Everton.
Chance after chance for Newcastle! It's absolute madness in the Everton box, Pickford is nowhere to be seen but Everton defend with their lives and Mykolenko clears Isak's shot just off the line - how is this still 1-0?! Barnes now fires another shot clear over the bar from a Krafth cross!
End-to-end stuff at the moment, Everton really energised by their substitutions. Mykolenko attempts to pass to McNeil in the box but Krafth knocks it out for an corner. It's floated to the back post, out to a central position where Young is waiting - but his fierce attempt is blocked by a defender.
Eddie Howe decides now is the time to make a change. Anderson is replaced by Joe Willock.
Schar slides in on Mykolenko to stop him advancing on goal. Everton are really ramping up the pressure now, Newcastle know their lead is slim and they can't sit this one out.
Longstaff does well to rob Garner of the ball and set up Willock on the break. Isak dances through the defence and passes to Barnes, but his effort is well saved by Pickford.
Godfrey knocks the ball behind and Newcastle have a corner. It's getting a bit feisty - Burn and Branthwaite are pushing and shoving each other in the box. Murphy's ball in is booted clear by Gomes.
Calvert-Lewin sprints forward in acres of space but with no-one to pass to in the box, he takes too much time and Burn gets to him and takes out the danger. Dummett looks to be readying himself - Hall is down on the turf again so may be about to be replaced.
Hall is indeed coming off, replaced by Paul Dummett, making a rare appearance.
Into the last 11 minutes. In the reverse fixture Everton scored three goals in that time - is this game going to have an equally dramatic end?
The first yellow of the game goes to Tarkowski for stepping on the back of Murphy's heel.
Another change for Everton: Portuguese youngster Youssef Chermiti replaces Gueye.
Chermiti's first action of the game is to trip up Krafth. Murphy is limping around, testing his heel - that looked like it hurt. Burn makes an excellent challenge to halt Chermiti's run on goal in its tracks.
Guimaraes boots a shot way over the bar. Late drama: VAR are checking for a possible penalty for Everton down the other end... Dummett hauled down Young by the neck in the box with the ball nowhere in sight. Could the visitors get a lifeline here?
Tony Harrington is being called to the screen...
PENALTY GIVEN! Everton DO get a lifeline! The ball is going nowhere near Young and Dummett, with his arm round his neck, hauls him down regardless. Calvert-Lewin to take - can he end his goal drought here and revitalise his season?
GOOOOAAAALLLL! Calvert-Lewin scores a penalty to make it 1-1! His powerful spot-kick clatters off Dubvraka's hand and into the back of the net - it's a huge, huge moment for Everton, is the comeback? Huge for Calvert-Lewin as well, his first goal in 23 games.
Another change from Everton, looking to capitalise on that equaliser. Godfrey is replaced by Seamus Coleman.
There will be NINE MINUTES of added time. Newcastle pushing...
Schar takes down Calvert-Lewin near the sideline, who goes flying straight into the Toffees manager. Seconds later Everton have a corner.
Tarkowski and Calvert-Lewin were both well-positioned to receive that but the whistle blew for some argy-bargy in the box.
Longstaff and Isak both in the Everton box trying to get a decent touch but Garner is there to marshal the defence. Both sides are pushing for a winner here with the St James' crowd roaring their players on. It deflects out for a Newcastle corner...
Murphy takes but the whistle blows - possibly before the corner was taken - as Burn shoves over Branthwaite. It's getting scrappy in the box and Tarkowski is remonstrating with the ref, annoyed at having to set up again.
Murphy takes it again, Burn and Branthwaite are - again - grappling in the box, but it's cleared out. Someone looked to have gone down in the box but the ref isn't interested.
Chermiti receives a yellow for a challenge on Schar.
Guimaraes takes the free kick and floats it towards Burn; Chermiti wins it back, Guimaraes is there once again and McNeil sees yellow for taking him down.
Guimaraes takes the free-kick, Branthwaite knocks it clear, and after a bit of pinball it comes into the hands of Pickford.
And that's the last action of the game!
FULL-TIME: NEWCASTLE UNITED 1-1 EVERTON.
What a breathless end to that half! It ends 1-1, but Newcastle will be ruing that as a missed opportunity when they should have put the game to bed in a dominant first half. A glorious solo strike by Isak put the hosts in front after just 15 minutes, and he should have had a second shortly before the half-time whistle. But Everton, who had been flat since going behind, regrouped at the break and some inspired substitutions made the second half altogether more competitive. This was a game largely decided by two substitutes: Dummett, making a rare appearance for Newcastle, hacked down Young in the box and conceded a penalty, and Everton sub Calvert-Lewin - who has scored more goals against Newcastle, six, than any other side - levelled from the spot with his first goal since October. Newcastle had 60 per cent possession and an xG of 1.42 compared to the Toffees' 0.44, but couldn't capitalise, and Everton come away with a crucial point in their battle to avoid the drop. Thanks for reading!
summary:
How the match unfolded
Arsenal went back to the top of the Premier League table with a 3-0 victory over Brighton at the Amex Stadium.
Bukayo Saka’s penalty and Kai Havertz’s close-range finish put the Gunners, who had seen Manchester City join Liverpool at the top of the standings with a 4-2 victory over Crystal Palace earlier on Saturday, in control on the south coast.
An emphatic victory was secured when, on his first return to the Amex, former Brighton favourite Leandro Trossard dinked home late on.
While Arsenal will hope Manchester United do them a favour by beating Liverpool at Old Trafford on Sunday, Brighton are now in 10th, with their hopes of European qualification hanging by a thread.
Arsenal made a quick start and should have gone ahead inside 63 seconds, only for Gabriel Magalhaes to head wide of a gaping goal after being found by Martin Odegaard's free-kick.
Saka shot wide of the far corner and Gabriel Jesus was denied by a firm stop from Bart Verbruggen as Arsenal continued to probe, and the Gunners made the breakthrough shortly after the half-hour mark.
Lamptey clumsily felled Jesus as the Brazilian bustled into the penalty area, and John Brooks did not hesitate in pointing to the spot. Saka made no mistake from 12 yards, firing into the bottom-left corner for his 14th league goal of the season.
Julio Enciso went close to levelling in spectacular fashion shortly before half-time, but David Raya was able to claw his dipping strike away from the top-left corner.
Arsenal made Raya’s good work count in the 62nd minute – Jorginho getting to the byline and squaring for Havertz, who duly tucked in.
Having replaced Saka, Trossard tried his luck from distance soon after, but Bart Verbruggen was equal to the Belgium international’s low strike.
Brighton’s goalkeeper could do little to prevent Trossard from making it 3-0 in the 86th minute, though, with the winger keeping his cool in a one-v-one and lifting home a delicate finish to further compound his old club’s misery.
Verbruggen stopped Declan Rice and then Gabriel from making it a rout, as Mikel Arteta’s team continued their exceptional form.
Saka on the spot
Saka has now scored as many Premier League goals this season (14 in 29 matches) as he did in 2022-23 (14 in 38 encounters).
His successfully converted penalty here means he has now scored nine of his last 10 spot-kicks in the Premier League, including his last five in a row.
With Euros 2024 on the horizon, it is indeed timely to brush up on goalscoring output – especially from the spot. 
Brighton bereft as fine home record falls
Disappointingly for Brighton, this defeat at the hands of Arsenal ends a fine run of form on home turf.
Before this, the last defeat at the Amex came 3-1 to West Ham United in August. The clipping of the Seagulls’ wings now means that a 12-game unbeaten run, their longest unbeaten run at the Amex in the Premier League, draws to a close (W6 D6).
text:
['Hello and welcome to live coverage of Team_15 v Team_9.
Team_15 are on a four-match unbeaten run and looking to build on their late season momentum, having come from 3-1 down to beat Team_19 4-3 at the weekend. The hosts are in eighth place on 43 points, trailing fifth-placed Team_2 by 13 points for a Europa League spot. They’ve only lost three times at home this season, while their record against Team_9 will give them further confidence: the Magpies have won five of their last seven meetings. A win today would see them leapfrog Team_19 into sixth place.
Team_9 are desperate to bring a halt to a grim run of results, and will likely take inspiration from the fact that their only win in eight midweek Premier League matches was a 3-0 victory over Team_15 in the reverse fixture. The Toffees sit 16th in the Premier League, just three points above the drop zone, and are winless in their last 12 Premier League games – their longest league run without a victory since 1957 – including their last seven on the road. A win today would see them complete the league double over the Magpies for the first time since 2017-18, and take them above Team_4 into 15th.
Team_15 (4-3-3): Martin Dubravka; Emil Krafth, Fabian Schar, Dan Burn, Lewis Hall; Sean Longstaff, Bruno Guimaraes; Elliot Anderson, Jacob Murphy, Alexander Isak, Harvey Barnes.
Team_15 SUBS: Paul Dummett, Matt Ritchie, Lorius Karius, Joe Willock, Mark Gillespie, Joe White, Amadou Diallo, Alex Murphy, Ben Parkinson.
Team_9 (4-4-1-1): Jordan Pickford; Ben Godfrey, James Tarkowski, Jarrad Branthwaite, Vitalii Mykolenko; Ashley Young, Idrissa Gueye, Amadou Onana, Dwight McNeil; Abdoulaye Doucoure; Beto.
Team_9 SUBS: Nathan Patterson, Michael Keane, Dominic Calvert-Lewin, Jack Harrison, Joao Virginia, Andre Gomes, Seamus Coleman, Youssef Chermiti, James Garner.
Substitute Harvey Barnes’ brace at the weekend is rewarded with a start for Team_15 tonight, while Emil Krafth, Lewis Hall and Elliot Anderson also come into the starting XI. Anthony Gordon won’t be able to face his former club as he serves a one-match ban. In another blow to the Magpies’ injury-stricken season, captain Jamaal Lascelles tore his ACL in that same match and will be out for up to nine months, while Miguel Almiron and Tino Livramento, also injured on Saturday, miss out on the squad too.
Team_9 boss Sean Dyche makes four changes from their midweek loss to Team_3, as Beto, Ashley Young, Vitalii Mykolenko – who has recovered from an illness - and Idrissa Gueye come in for Seamus Coleman, James Garner, Jack Harrison and Dominic Calvert-Lewin. Forwards Arnaut Danjuma and Lewis Dobbin are again set to miss out due to injuries.
The teams are out on the pitch and we’re about to get underway!
KICK-OFF: Team_15 V Team_9. Team_9 get us going - to an immediate chorus of boos from St James' Park.
Team_9 already under pressure! Team_15 with an early press up the pitch, but Barnes - replacing the suspended Gordon - can't quite get a touch on it. Isak then tries to tee up Barnes again but Pickford gets the block.
Branthwaite makes an interception at the back and Team_9 break. Young chips the ball over the Magpies defence but there's no one in the box to take advantage. Team_15 are enjoying most of the possession at the moment.
Barnes and Anderson link up well in the box but Team_9 - tripping up Barnes in the process - get it under control and break. A long ball from Pickford falls to Doucoure but his first strike from the edge of the box soars over the bar!
Every touch by an Team_9 player is greeted with deafening boos from the fortress that is St James' Park. Krafth just clips Beto before he can get the ball. Free-kick to Team_9 about 20 yards out...
Huge missed chance for Team_9! McNeil's free-kick falls to Tarkowski, who nods it over the top from five yards out! That was a great chance squandered by the visitors...
Team_9 on the break! McNeil makes an excellent run through acres of space, Godfrey delivers it to Young in the box, but Team_15 defend it well. No corner for the visitors.
Krafth crosses to Isak in the box but Branthwaite is there to make the clearance. It goes out for a Team_15 corner - Hall swings it in to Guimaraes, who takes a touch, but it's too far over and Team_9 clear it safely.
This has been fairly even so far, with both sides fancying their chances on the break but yet to find a way through. Murphy sends a brilliant cross in Barnes' direction a few yards off the far post, but Godfrey wins their aerial duel and it's out for a Team_15 corner.
Pickford's long ball was expertly taken apart by Team_15 and Barnes already has an assist to his name, his through-ball soaring past the Team_9 defence and finding Isak.
GOOOAAAALLLL! Team_15 are 1-0 ahead and it's Alexander Isak once again, his 19th this season! The through-ball soars over Tarkowski and Isak weaves his way expertly past Branthwaite to slot it in the bottom corner, way out of Pickford's reach. The Toon goes wild!
Team_15 pressing again, Hall ducking and diving through the defence but Onana clears it. Beto goes sprawling on the turf after a challenge by Burn.
All Team_15 now! Onana slides in on Anderson driving down the left, and the Team_15 man goes down and wins a free-kick.
There's a brief pause in play for the players to break their Ramadan fast.
Team_9 have been a lot more subdued since going behind. The hosts are controlling the game, with 66% of the possession, and looking much more dangerous.
Anderson and Guimaraes get in each other's way a little in midfield. Anderson tries to get into space and wins a free kick after getting shoved over, near the Team_15 box.
Anderson drives down the centre and squares it to Barnes, but there's a sea of blue shirts in the box to block and after a bit of pinball Team_9 head it clear.
Massive chance for Murphy! Team_9 are camped out in their box and Murphy takes his chance to sprint through and have a shot from range - but it fizzes over the bar! Team_15 have had six attempts now to Team_9 two and are bringing all the intensity.
Now Beto has a go for the visitors! He gets into a good position but his shot from the edge of the box is miles off target. Sean Dyche does not look impressed.
Guimaraes and Gueye get in an elaborate tangle and the Brazilian hauls him over, giving away a free kick in the centre. Nothing comes of it and Barnes attempts to break, but Team_9 regain possession - Beto tries to cut it back, possibly for Doucoure, but his accuracy is way off again and Team_15 recover it easily.
Isak's attempt to pass to Barnes down the left, frustrated by the Team_9 midfield, is greeted with appreciation by the crowd. Their star man has now scored in each of his last five Premier League home games, the first player to do so since Yoan Gouffran in 2013.
Team_9 once again are asleep at the back as Isak and Anderson again combine dangerously in the box, but Godfrey makes a great clearance to save their blushes. The resulting corner is flicked over by Burn for an Team_9 goal-kick.
Barnes makes another electric run down the left but Tarkowski arrests it and concedes a throw-in. In another worrying sight for Eddie Howe, Hall is down on the pitch, holding onto his ribs. Medical staff are on the pitch - is this yet another injury setback for the Magpies?
Play resumes. Guimaraes and Anderson wrestle with Team_9 over a corner and the latter goes down courtesy of Doucoure. Team_9 have possession now, but McNeil's ball goes nowhere.
Beto gets a talking to for a lunge on Krafth. Still no yellow cards in this game despite some feisty challenges. Hall is back up and appears to be moving well.
Chance for Team_9! Doucoure finds some space in the box and has a good attempt, but Dubravka jumps and gets his gloves to it. That's the most positive Team_9 have looked all game!
Huge stop by Pickford! After a calmer period of Team_15 possession the ball falls to Barnes at the far left - he gets it around Pickford, who's off his line, but no one can get a decent touch on it. Murphy then has a go himself and the Team_9 goalkeeper sticks out a leg to keep it out!
Four added minutes here at St James' Park.
Huge chance for Team_15 and Isak almost has a second! He glides through the defence and has a glorious chance to put the hosts 2-0 up, but it floats just over the bar.
Murphy swings in a cross and Pickford does well to collect just a couple of yards out from goal!
HALF-TIME: Team_15 1-0 Team_9.
Team_15 are 1-0 up at the break! Both sides have had chances, but the hosts - roared on by the crowd - have looked much the brighter, led by star player Isak, who showed his worth with a brilliant strike in the opening 15 minutes. The Magpies have controlled the game well, with 62 per cent of possession compared to Team_9 38, and an xG of 1.37 to the Toffees' 0.47.
Team_9 need to turn this around quickly, and while they've threatened on the break, Team_15 haven't looked too troubled by their efforts so far. Worryingly for the visitors, they haven't won any of their last 25 Premier League games when trailing at half-time. They also failed to have a shot on target in that entire half - let's see if Dyche's half-time pep talk has any effect...
KICK-OFF: Team_15 1-0 Team_9. Second half underway!
No changes at the break. Team_9 nick possession early on and Young hoofs a cross in towards Beto, but it doesn't quite find the target. A minute later Beto goes down in the box thanks to a shirt-pull by Schar but the ref is stone-faced to his appeals.
Almost a very embarrassing moment for Team_9! Team_15 have a corner and the box is rammed. Tarkowski tries to clear but kicks it backwards onto his own post! It bounces away but wow, that could have been a disastrous start to this half!
Branthwaite chucks a long ball in the vague direction of Doucoure, approaching a near-empty Team_15 box, but Team_9 don't have the pace at the moment to make anything of it.
Guimaraes opts to leave a ball in his own penalty area and Beto launches towards it, sliding it on an approaching Dubravka. The keeper gets to it without much hassle but seems to clip his gloves on the Team_9 man in the process. Further up the pitch, Burn shoves McNeil over and concedes a free-kick.
Pickford takes the free-kick and sends it flying down towards the Team_15 box but the danger is cleared easily. Team_9 have a corner...
McNeil chips in the corner but it's rather flat and is cleared away. Team_9 have come out more strongly in this half, offering more in the opposition box. Tarkowski fires in a long ball but Onana, surrounded by Team_15 defenders, can't get his head to it and it sails behind.
Team_15 take a free kick, Isak squares the pass cutely to Dan Burn and the 6'7" centre-back fires it home! But wait... It's gone to VAR... They're checking for an offside on Isak.
Decision made: Burn's goal is chalked off. Isak was leaning just a fraction too far forward beyond the Team_9 defence.
Dyche decides now is the time to make some changes. Doucoure is replaced by Gomes.
Onana comes off for James Garner.
And a final change for Team_9: the misfiring Beto is replaced by Dominic Calvert-Lewin. The latter hasn't scored in 23 games: can he break that streak here and get his side back in it?
Team_9 enjoy a spell of possession but Team_15 break! Pickford comes out to see to a long ball.
Calvert-Lewin jumps for a cross but Dubravka gets there first and catches!
Almost an equaliser for Team_9! Garner - who has come on full of energy - spins on the ball and fires a brilliant first-time shot, but it bounces off the inside of the post! Huge, huge chance for Team_9.
Chance after chance for Team_15! It's absolute madness in the Team_9 box, Pickford is nowhere to be seen but Team_9 defend with their lives and Mykolenko clears Isak's shot just off the line - how is this still 1-0?! Barnes now fires another shot clear over the bar from a Krafth cross!
End-to-end stuff at the moment, Team_9 really energised by their substitutions. Mykolenko attempts to pass to McNeil in the box but Krafth knocks it out for an corner. It's floated to the back post, out to a central position where Young is waiting - but his fierce attempt is blocked by a defender.

Hall is indeed coming off, replaced by Paul Dummett, making a rare appearance.

The first yellow of the game goes to Tarkowski for stepping on the back of Murphy's heel.

Chermiti's first action of the game is to trip up Krafth. Murphy is limping around, testing his heel - that looked like it hurt. Burn makes an excellent challenge to halt Chermiti's run on goal in its tracks.

summary:
Everton were denied a first win in nine Premier League matches as Lewis Dunk scored a stoppage-time equaliser for 10-man Brighton & Hove Albion to claim.
Sean Dyche’s team had led by a well-hit Jarrad Branthwaite shot at the Amex Stadium but despite the Seagulls going down to 10 men, Dunk, on his 400th appearance for the club, guided a fine header past Jordan Pickford in the fifth minute of stoppage time.
How the match unfolded
Robert De Zerbi made two changes from the side that thrashed Sheffield United 5-0, with Igor Julio and Evan Ferguson coming in for Adam Webster and Kaoru Mitoma. As for Everton, Dyche recalled Jack Harrison, with Ashley Young dropping to the bench.
Brighton assumed control of the match, dominating possession and playing out from the back to evade Everton’s press. The Seagulls came close from a through-ball by Pascal Gross to Danny Welbeck, who could not poke the ball past an onrushing Jordan Pickford.

Welbeck had another opportunity after a midfield turnover but a brilliant sliding challenge by Ben Godfrey deflected his shot for a corner.
Everton in the first half  seemed content to soak up the pressure in the hope of catching the home team on a counter but their opportunities were few. The best came from Dominic Calvert-Lewin, whose glancing header went narrowly wide.
But in the second half Everton started as the brighter team, Abdoulaye Doucoure’s sidefoot volley beating goalkeeper Bart Verbruggen but not a fine headed goalline clearance from Tariq Lamptey, the shortest player in the league at 5ft 4in.
What had been a steady match of possession became an end-to-end affair and Everton took the lead from a set-piece. Pickford launched a ball into the box that fell to Branthwaite, who arrowed it into the top corner.
Matters went from bad to worse for Brighton as Billy Gilmour received his first career red card for a high tackle on Amadou Onana. 
Everton substitute Beto had a chance to double the lead but could not convert a through-ball.
Despite their man disadvantage Brighton pressed for an equaliser and Pascal Gross delivered a perfect cross from the right to allow Dunk loop a header past the outstretched hands of Pickford.
Brighton now have 39 points, five behind Manchester United in sixth. The point lifts Everton above Luton and out of the bottom three. 
Club reports
Brighton report | Everton report
Match officials
Referee: Tony Harrington. Assistants: Richard West, Scott Ledger. Fourth official: Dean Whitestone. VAR: David Coote. Assistant VAR: Natalie Aspinall.
