Koleosho looks to make things happen again down the left flank. He tries to send the ball into the box, but Ward is well-placed to deflect it behind for a corner.
WHAT A TACKLE! Taylor picks out Koleosho with a lovely lofted ball to the left wing. The latter takes it in his stride and advances into the penalty area, but Andersen produces a perfectly timed sliding challenge to deny him a shot on goal.
Team_6 continue to ask questions as Brownhill sends a ball in from the left flank. The ball comes back to the midfielder, but he is ruled offside.
Gudmundsson whips a free-kick into the box from the right. Amdouni meets the delivery, but his header is lacking the required pace and direction and drifts behind for a goal-kick.
Palace go in search of the second goal with Ayew and Schlupp sending balls into the box, but Team_6 survive as the fourth official indicates there will be an additional two minutes at the end of this first half.
Good try! Team_6 look to equalise before the break and take a quick free-kick on the edge of the penalty area. Koleosho lets fly and Johnstone is forced to push his effort to safety.
Guehi goes into the book for dissent after taking his protests with the referee too far. The England defender was far from happy with the official, but needs to calm down.
Ayew also goes into the book for Palace. Like Guehi, he appeared to be questioning the referee's decision to allow Team_6 to take the quick free-kick just now.
HALF-TIME: Team_6 0-1 Team_8
Palace are in front at the halfway mark at Turf Moor. Team_6 dominated the opening 20 minutes, but were caught out soon after as a defensive lapse culminated in Ayew squaring the ball for Schlupp to apply the finishing touch at the far post. The hosts have responded well, but trail at the break.
Despite their positive display, Kompany will be urging his Team_6 players to demonstrate a stronger clinical edge. Despite registering eight shots, just one was on target during the opening 45 minutes. They must address that upon the resumption of this contest.
The referee blows his whistle and Palace get the ball rolling again in the second half.
Palace are without a win in each of their last five league meetings with Team_6. But as things stand, the Eagles are on course to end that streak today.
Team_6 look to launch an early threat in the second half as Rodriguez flicks on a long ball towards Koleosho, but Andersen gets across well to make a neatly timed sliding intervention.
Palace continue to maintain their defensive discipline. Gudmundsson looks to switch the play towards Koleosho, but Ward is alert and intercepts for the visitors.
A patient build-up from Team_6 culminates in O'Shea crossing from the right flank. Rodriguez meets it on the turn, but cannot direct his header towards the target.
As things stand, Palace will climb into the top half of the Premier League table with victory here. But they must maintain their concentration levels and discipline throughout the remainder of this contest.
Palace make their first change as Eze returns to action after missing the Eagles' last three matches. He replaces Doucoure, who gained possession three times for the visitors - a tally only bettered by Ayew and Andersen.
CHANCE! Team_6 threaten with Koleosho leading their charge from the left once more. He cuts the ball back for Gudmundsson, who looks to help it towards goal, but it drifts just wide of the right post.
There is a concern for the hosts with Berge moving a little gingerly. The midfielder and his team-mates will be hoping he can shake it off.
OFFSIDE, NO GOAL! Team_6 have the ball in the net as Koleosho cuts inside and lets fly. His tame effort is latched onto by Rodriguez, who clinically sweeps the ball into the roof of the net. However, his joy is cut short by the offside flag and it was definitely the right call by the linesman.
Team_6 have scored just eight goals in the Premier League this season, with only bottom side Team_17 netting fewer times (seven). The Clarets must address that if they are going to take anything from this game.
We are into the final quarter of the game at Turf Moor. Palace are still leading by a goal to nil and looking fairly comfortable at the moment.
Schlupp, whose goal separates the two sides, is given a breather by Hodgson after he was involved in a joint-high nine duels for the visitors today. He is replaced by Ahamada.
Ward, who made a game-high four tackles today, also makes way with Clyne coming on in his place.
It will be interesting to see whether Team_6 follow suit and turn to the bench. The hosts are looking for inspiration in their quest to turn this deficit around.
Palace are looking comfortable as we approach the final quarter of an hour at Turf Moor. The visitors are neatly knocking the ball around and maintaining possession.
Gudmundsson whips a long ball forward that Amdouni and Rodriguez help towards Keleosho on the left. The winger tries his luck from a tight angle, but his effort is always rising.
Team_6 make a double-substitution. The first sees Amdouni, who had two shots on goal, replaced by Redmond.
The lively Koleosho, who had a game-high four shots on goal and was involved in 13 duels, is given a breather by the hosts. Odobert takes his place.
Worth a go! After Team_6 attack down the left flank, Brownhill has time and space to let fly from 25 yards. His fierce effort is on target and Johnstone is forced to turn it over.
GOOD SAVE! Rodriguez loses his marker to meet Gudmunsson's corner at the near post. He heads the ball towards well, but Johnstone produces a smart reflex save to keep it out.
The hosts continue to threaten and Odobert embarks on a strong run down the left before drilling the ball towards goal. It is threatening to sneak in at the far post and Johnstone is forced to push it away.
There is a concern for Palace as Edouard stays down and is in need of attention. The visitors will hope he is fine to continue, but will surely ready a substitute for if not.
Edouard, who has been involved in a game-high eight aerial duels, is unable to continue and is replaced by Richards in a defensive change by Palace.
After successfully completing a game-high 80 passes for Team_6, Beyer makes way for the final few minutes. Tresor comes on in his place.
CHANCE! Team_6 seek the equaliser and O'Shea meets a cross into the box from the right wing. His downward header is creeping into the bottom corner, but Johnstone gets down well to keep it out.
Lerma brings down Brownhill as we approach stoppage time at Turf Moor. The Palace midfielder goes into the book.
We are into the first of five additional minutes of stoppage time at the end of this game. Can Palace hold on or can Team_6 snatch a dramatic equaliser?
Gudmunds\xadson has enjoyed a productive day, completing a game-high 94.1 per cent of his passes for Team_6. He is replaced by Bruun Larsen.
Andersen has his name taken by the referee. Team_6 have a free-kick and time is rapidly running out for the hosts.
MITCHELL!!! 2-0 PALACE! GAME OVER! The visitors secure all three points in the dying moments. Team_6 try to clear the ball down the other end of the field, but get it all wrong. The ball ends up with Eze on the edge of the box. The substitute then produces a perfectly timed lay-off for the onrushing Mitchell, who slots past Trafford to make it 2-0.
Eze showed great composure on the edge of the box as he waited before laying the ball off for Mitchell to put the game beyond Team_6.
FULL-TIME: Team_6 0-2 Team_8
Team_8 move into the top half of the Premier League table after a 2-0 victory at Team_6. Although on the back foot for most of the first 22 minutes, the Eagles took the lead against the run of play through Jeffrey Schlupp. Roy Hodgson's side then wrapped up the points in stoppage time when Eberechi Eze set up Tyrick Mitchell to put the game beyond the hosts. Team_6 become the first side in English top-flight history to lose each of their opening six home games in a season. The Clarets will desperately seek a response away at Team_1 next Saturday, with Palace hosting Team_9 on the same day. That's all for today. Thank you for joining us. Until next time, goodbye!"]
label: Normal

events:
Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the Premier League fixture between Crystal Palace and Luton Town at Selhurst Park.
The Eagles will be playing their third game under the guidance of new manager Oliver Glasner, who has overseen a 3-0 victory over Burnley and a 3-1 loss away at Tottenham so far. Palace have won three of their last four Premier League games at Selhurst Park (L1), as many as in their previous 13 beforehand (D5 L5). The Eagles have scored exactly three goals in each of those three wins, after having only scored three or more goals in three of their previous 31 home league matches prior to this. Crystal Palace are in 14th place on 28 points, having scored 32 goals and conceded 47. A victory could see them climb above Bournemouth into 13th position if results go their way.
Luton travel to Selhurst Park hoping to do the double over the capital club, having won the previous meeting 2-1 at Kenilworth Road, with Teden Mengi and Jacob Brown scoring their goals. However, Rob Edwards’ side are on a disappointing run of form, losing each of their last four games in the Premier League. The Hatters suffered a 3-2 defeat against Aston Villa at Kenilworth Road in their last Premier League match, extending their winless streak to five (D1 L4), putting them in 18th place on 20 points, four points from safety with 12 matches to play.
CRYSTAL PALACE (3-4-2-1): Sam Johnstone; Chris Richards, Joachim Andersen, Joel Ward; Tyrick Mitchell, Adam Wharton, Jefferson Lerma, Daniel Munoz; Eberechi Eze, Jordan Ayew; Jean-Philippe Mateta.
CRYSTAL PALACE SUBS: James Tomkins, Nathaniel Clyne, Will Hughes, Odsonne Edouard, Naouirou Ahamada, Dean Henderson, Luke Plange, Kaden Rodney, David Ozoh.
LUTON TOWN (3-4-2-1): Thomas Kaminski; Teden Mengi, Gabriel Osho, Reece Burke; Alfie Doughty, Ross Barkley, Jordan Clark, Issa Kabore; Tahith Chong, Chiedozie Ogbene; Carlton Morris.
LUTON TOWN SUBS: James Shea, Luke Berry, Cauley Woodrow, Pelly Ruddock Mpanzu, Tim Krul, Daiki Hashioka, Andros Townsend, Zack Nelson, Axel Piesold.
Glasner has named an unchanged side from Palace’s 3-1 defeat away to Tottenham in the Premier League last time out. The Austrian manager is still working out his best team after a few weeks in charge, and he’s given the previous starting XI another chance to impress.
Meanwhile, Edwards has made two alterations from Luton’s 3-2 defeat at home to Aston Villa in their previous game. In defence, Amari'i Bell misses out due to injury, and Osho comes into the starting XI. Ogbene will also come into the side, with Townsend dropping to the bench.
The players are making their way out onto the pitch ahead of kick-off.
Morris gets the game under way for Luton at Selhurst Park!
Clark looks to find Kabore down the right-hand side and he battles with Mitchell, winning a throw-in deep inside the Palace half. Play resumes and Kabore manages to win a corner, and Doughty will take. He delivers towards the back post and Morris heads towards goal, but Mateta is there to clear.
Barkley has gone down inside the Palace penalty area after a clash of heads, and the medical team are on the pitch giving him treatment. There's going to be a delay as the physios treat the English midfielder. The Luton star attempted to head towards goal, but collided with Ward.
Barkley is still receiving treatment and appears to be bleeding from the nose. It's a nasty injury for the former Everton man. After a lengthy delay, he's back on his feet. It looks as though he's going to be able to continue after the Luton medical team patch him up.
Ward sends a ball down the line and Mateta will chase it in beyond the Luton defence. The towering striker gets there and looks to deliver into the penalty area, but Kaminski darts off his line and is able to collect. It's been a cagey affair so far with neither side showing much of a threat in the final third.
GOOOOOAAAAAALLLL!!! 1-0 PALACE!! Doughty looks to pass the ball back to his goalkeeper, but he doesn't get enough on it and Munoz races through on goal. He gets there before Kaminski and rounds the goalkeeper. He's forced out wide but he finds Mateta in the middle, and the French striker flicks the ball into the back of the net! It's a wonderful finish!
Munoz did superbly to round the goalkeeper and stay composed, finding Mateta in the middle.
Eze dances through the Luton midfield and feeds the ball out wide to Ayew. The Palace forward takes a touch and delivers into the penalty area towards Mateta, but Kabore gets back well to fire it behind for a corner. Wharton will take and he delivers into the box, but it's headed away from danger.
Ayew twists and turns on the right-hand side of the box and looks to deliver into the danger zone, but his cross is deflected behind for a corner. Wharton is standing over it and he plays it short to Lerma. The Palace midfielder takes a touch before whipping it towards the front post, but Ward sends his header over the bar.
Glasner's side have enjoyed a positive start to the game, producing three shots with one of those being on target. The Eagles are getting into some dangerous areas, but the Palace boss will be hoping to see some better end product in the final third. Edwards' men will have to tighten up at the back.
Chong sends Doughty down the left-hand side and Luton have an opportunity to break. The wing-back delivers into the box, but it's cleared away from danger. Morris is eventually found inside the box unmarked, but his cross is poor and Johnstone comes off his line to collect comfortably.
Clark drives through the middle and looks to find Morris inside the penalty area, but his pass cannons back into his path. He attempts to deliver a cross into the box, but it's deflected behind for a corner. Doughty is there to take and he sends a searching ball towards the back post, but Richards rises highest to head it away.
Palace have a throw-in inside the Luton half and they look to remain patient and keep possession. Richards carries it out of defence and finds Eze. He sends a searching pass beyond the Luton backline to Mitchell, but he can't quite control it and the Hatters win it back.
Kabore goes into the book for a strong challenge on Lerma just outside the Luton penalty area.
From the resulting free-kick, Eze delivers a powerful cross towards the front post. It's headed on by Andersen, but it cannons off Mengi and goes behind for a corner. Palace take it short and it comes to Lerma who unleashes an ambitious effort from range, but it strikes a defender and flies into the stands behind the goal.
Wharton finds Eze inside the Luton penalty area and he tussles with Mengi with his back to goal. The English midfielder turns and looks to strike it, but it's a tame effort and it flies into the air, with Kaminski coming off his line to gather comfortably.
Doughty is found on the left-hand side and he gets the ball out of his feet before looking to deliver it into the box, but it cannons off Munoz and goes behind for another corner. It's whipped towards the back post and Osho wins the initial header, but the Eagles are able to clear away from danger.
Mateta tussles with Mengi and drives with the ball down the right-hand side, but the Luton defender brings him down with a strong challenge. The Palace forward looks in a bit of discomfort, but he should be fine to continue. Wharton and Eze are standing over the free-kick and the former delivers it, but it evades everyone and goes behind for a goal-kick.
Eze receives a yellow card for bringing down Burke as Luton looked to break away.
Eze fires the ball into the feet of Mateta, who holds off the Luton defenders before laying it into the path of Ayew. The Palace forward drives towards the penalty area and gets it out of his feet before unleashing from range, but Kaminski gets down to his right to make the stop and holds onto the ball.
What a chance! Clark receives the ball in the middle and looks to pass it back to his goalkeeper. It's almost a carbon copy of the earlier goal as Mateta rushes in to get there first. He takes it past Kaminski and looks to chip it back towards goal, but he fails to hit the target! He has to be scoring from there!
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of four minutes of added time at the end of the first half.
Luton win a free-kick deep inside the Palace half as Andersen drags Morris to the ground. The Hatters have a chance to fill the box in the final few minutes of the half. Barkley delivers into the box and Osho flicks it towards goal, but his header loops over the bar and lands on the roof of the net.
HALF-TIME: CRYSTAL PALACE 1-0 LUTON TOWN
Crystal Palace go into the break with a 1-0 lead over Luton Town at Selhurst Park. Glasner will be the happier of the two managers at half-time with his side showing plenty of attacking threat in the final third. The home team have limited their opposition for the most part, with the Eagles enjoying the better chances. Palace opened the scoring in the first half after Doughty's pass back towards his own goalkeeper was intercepted by Muniz, and the wing-back did superbly to find Mateta in the penalty area, and his clever flick rolled into the back of the net. Glasner's men kept on pushing and should have found a second after Mateta pounced on another mistake at the back, but his dink over Kaminski trickled wide of the post. Edwards will be desperate to see his side tighten up at the back, while they need to provide more of a threat going forward.
Luton have created just 0.09 expected goals (xG) in the game so far from two shots. Palace have produced 1.1 expected goals and look the more likely to grab the second goal of the game. The Eagles have managed six shots inside the opposition box, forcing Kaminiski into one save. It wouldn't be a surprise to see Edwards make an early change after the break, with Townsend, who started in their previous fixture, waiting in the wings. Glasner might not want to alter his side too much with his game plan working so far. The home team will be desperate to find a second goal early on after half-time, with the Hatters capable of producing goals out of nothing.
Ayew gets the second half under way for Palace at Selhurst Park!
What a chance! Wharton finds Eze on the left-hand side and he delivers into the penalty area. Munoz has burst forward from defence and he tussles with Burke. He looks to head towards goal from just a few yards out, but he doesn't connect with the header and the opportunity goes begging.
Lerma chips the ball to Ayew who has found space inside the penalty area. He spots the run of Munoz on the overlap and finds him. The Palace wing-back looks to pull it to the edge of the box where Ayew is waiting, but the Luton defenders rush back in numbers to intercept and clear the danger.
Palace have a throw-in deep inside the opposition half and Munoz finds Ward. The ball is pumped into the box towards Eze who controls superbly. He gets it out of his feet and strikes it, but his effort flies into the stands behind the goal and Luton will have a goal-kick.
Glasner's side are asserting their dominance in the second half and Luton have struggled to create too many chances. Edwards' men are yet to touch the ball inside the opposition box since the break, and Palace have barely looked troubled from a defensive standpoint.
Burke goes into the book for a strong challenge as Palace look to counter-attack.
Wharton drives through the middle of the park and finds Lerma, and he shifts the ball to Eze on the edge of the Luton penalty area. He twists and turns before working it into his left foot and he strikes from outside of the box, but it's a tame effort and Kaminski can gather comfortably.
Edwards makes a change as Hashioka enters the fray. Mengi is the player to head to the bench.
Andersen finds himself in space between the Luton midfield and defence and he picks out Mateta on the edge of the area. Ayew has made a run outside of him and the French forward lays it into his path. He strikes towards goal with his right, but the Hatters get plenty of bodies in the way and block the shot.
Chance for Luton! Doughty receives a pass out wide and looks to take on Munoz. He shifts it out of his feet before delivering into the penalty area. Morris gets there first and heads towards goal, but it's straight at Johnstone and the Palace goalkeeper makes a comfortable save.
Morris drives down the left-hand side of the pitch and bursts past Anderson before attempting to find a team-mate in the box, but his cross deflects off the Palace centre-back and goes behind for a corner. Doughty will deliver, but it's headed behind by Andersen. The Luton wing-back will take again, but Richards is able to clear the danger.
Glasner makes an alteration in attack as Ahamada comes off the bench. Ayew will make way for Palace.
Luton are enjoying more of the possession in the second half, managing to have 55.6 per cent of the ball. However, Edwards' side have struggled to turn that into clear-cut opportunities and have attempted just one shot since the break.
Huge chance for Palace! Eze feeds the ball to Mitchell inside the penalty area and he stands up his marker before creating space for a cross. He whips a dangerous delivery into the box and Mateta is there to meet it from just a few yards out, but his volley is somehow saved by Kaminski! What a stop!
The ball comes to Ahamada outside of the box and he strikes from range, but his effort is blocked. Luton are able to clear and Palace regain possession. The Eagles can't quite find a breakthrough in the final third and it's a slender lead for Glasner's side, so they will have to be wary at the back.
There's a bit of delay as Osho goes down and he requires treatment from the Palace physios. He's eventually back to his feet and he heads towards the side of the pitch, and there's some activity on the Luton bench. He could be heading off.
Glasner makes a change in attack and it's a straight swap, with Edouard coming on for Mateta.
Osho's game is over after his injury, and Woodrow comes on to replace him.
Palace make an alteration in the middle of the park. Hughes comes off the bench in place of Wharton.
So close! Eze receives the ball just inside the Luton half and he spots Kaminski off his line. He attempts an ambitious strike from near the halfway line and his strike is heading towards goal, but it doesn't quite dip in time and it bounces off the roof of the net! What an effort!
Luton hit the bar! Doughty's cross into the penalty area looks as though it's heading out for a goal-kick, but Ogbene does superbly to help it back into the danger zone. His looping delivery is heading towards goal, but it bounces off the top of the bar and goes behind.
Munoz is the latest player to receive a yellow for a late challenge on Chong.
Luton make an attacking alteration, with Ogbene heading off and Townsend entering the fray.
Edwards rolls the dice once again with Nelson sent on in the final few minutes. Chong is the player to be replaced.
Edwards makes a change in midfield, with Berry coming on to replace Clark.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of six minutes of added time at the end of the game.
Berry receives a yellow for a reckless challenge as Palace attempted to counter-attack.
Palace are continuing to push for a second goal as Mitchell feeds Eze on the edge of the penalty area. The English midfielder turns well before poking an effort towards goal, but it's deflected behind for a corner. Eze will take and it's delivered into the box, but Morris is there to head away from danger.
Off the bar! Luton appeal for a free-kick but the referee is having none of it and Mitchell finds Edouard in space. He drives towards the penalty area and produces a powerful effort from the edge of the box, and it flies towards goal before slamming against the bar! The Eagles are searching for a second.
GOOOAAAAALLLL!! 1-1!! LUTON EQUALISE! The Hatters throw everything forward and Townsend gets the ball out of his feet on the right-hand side before delivering a dangerous ball into the penalty area. Woodrow gets there first and flicks it towards goal, and it bounces into the far corner of the net with Johnstone scrambling! Edwards' side find an equaliser in the last few seconds!
Townsend whipped a perfect cross onto the head of Woodrow, who flicked it home.
FULL-TIME: CRYSTAL PALACE 1-1 LUTON TOWN
Crystal Palace and Luton Town share the points with a 1-1 draw at Selhurst Park. The Eagles started the brighter and were looking a threat in the final third, and it didn't take them long to find the opening goal. Munoz pounced on a mistake at the back from Doughty before rounding the goalkeeper, and his pass into the box was flicked home by Mateta. Glasner's side kept pushing for a second, but Palace went into the break with a slender lead. In the second half, the home team had a host of chances to put the game to bed, with Mateta missing from just a few yards out. The 1-0 advantage was always going to be dangerous as the Hatters threw everything at it in the final few moments, and they found an equaliser late on. Townsend worked the ball onto his left and whipped a dangerous cross into the box, and Woodrow was there to head it home in the final seconds. Luton are on the road again on Wednesday, playing Bournemouth in the Premier League, while Palace will have to wait until 30th March for their next game, where they play Nottingham Forest. That's all for today, goodbye!
summary:
Nicolo Zaniolo came off the bench to earn Aston Villa a point as they came from behind to draw 1-1 at West Ham United.
Michail Antonio gave the Hammers a first-half lead, heading in to score for the first time since August, but Zaniolo poked in to level with 11 minutes remaining.
West Ham had the ball in the back of the net deep into stoppage time, but Tomas Soucek's effort was overturned following a VAR review for handball. 
A point moves Villa three clear of Tottenham Hotspur in fifth, with West Ham, who extended their unbeaten home run against Villa to nine matches, remaining in seventh.
How the match unfolded
West Ham made two changes from the side that beat Freiburg 5-0 in the UEFA Europa League on Thursday, with Alphonse Areola replacing Lukasz Fabianski in goal, while and Emerson Palmieri came in for Aaron Cresswell.
Unai Emery opted to make four changes from the midweek 4-0 UEFA Europa Conference victory over Ajax. 
Jhon Duran, Youri Tielemans, Ezri Konsa and Clement Lenglet replaced Matty Cash, Diego Carlos, Moussa Diaby and the suspended John McGinn. Ollie Watkins was fit to start after recovering from a cut to his knee that forced him off on Thursday night.
After an evenly contested start, the first clear chance fell to Watkins, but his low effort was pushed around a post by Areola.
West Ham took the lead just before the half-hour with Antonio's superb diving header from Vladimir Coufal's cross.
Coufal has now provided an assist in each of his last five league matches at London Stadium. 
The Hammers continued to look dangerous and Mohammed Kudus twice came close to doubling their advantage, first firing a shot narrowly wide, West Ham’s ninth of the half, before having a goal ruled out due to a foul in the build-up.
Antonio thought he had doubled West Ham's lead on 49 minutes but, but his effort overturned following a VAR review after he was adjudged to have handled the ball.
Villa stepped up the pressure in search of an equaliser and Areola was forced to keep out a trademark long-range shot from Tielemans.
At the other end, Emiliano Martinez was called into action as he dived to prevent Lucas Paqueta's deflected free-kick from creeping in.
Zaniolo brought Villa level, finishing first time from close range after Diaby had got the better of Emerson and cut the ball back to the Italian.
Both of Zaniolo’s Premier League goals for Villa this season have been second-half equalisers after coming off the bench.
West Ham almost snatched a late winner, but substitute James Ward-Prowse’s strike in the second minute of stoppage time was superbly blocked by Cash.
There was still time for a dramatic finale, as Ward-Prowse’s free-kick was poked towards goal by Konstantinos Mavropanos before being bundled in on the goalline by Soucek.
But after being checked by VAR, referee Jarred Gillett was sent to the Referee Review Area and ruled out the goal, deeming it to have been handled by Soucek.
text:
["Hello and welcome to our live coverage of the Premier League fixture between Team_8 and Team_12 at Selhurst Park.
The Eagles will be playing their third game under the guidance of new manager Oliver Glasner, who has overseen a 3-0 victory over Team_6 and a 3-1 loss away at Team_18 so far. Palace have won three of their last four Premier League games at Selhurst Park (L1), as many as in their previous 13 beforehand (D5 L5). The Eagles have scored exactly three goals in each of those three wins, after having only scored three or more goals in three of their previous 31 home league matches prior to this. Team_8 are in 14th place on 28 points, having scored 32 goals and conceded 47. A victory could see them climb above Team_3 into 13th position if results go their way.
Luton travel to Selhurst Park hoping to do the double over the capital club, having won the previous meeting 2-1 at Kenilworth Road, with Teden Mengi and Jacob Brown scoring their goals. However, Rob Edwards’ side are on a disappointing run of form, losing each of their last four games in the Premier League. The Hatters suffered a 3-2 defeat against Team_2 at Kenilworth Road in their last Premier League match, extending their winless streak to five (D1 L4), putting them in 18th place on 20 points, four points from safety with 12 matches to play.
Team_8 (3-4-2-1): Sam Johnstone; Chris Richards, Joachim Andersen, Joel Ward; Tyrick Mitchell, Adam Wharton, Jefferson Lerma, Daniel Munoz; Eberechi Eze, Jordan Ayew; Jean-Philippe Mateta.
Team_8 SUBS: James Tomkins, Nathaniel Clyne, Will Hughes, Odsonne Edouard, Naouirou Ahamada, Dean Henderson, Luke Plange, Kaden Rodney, David Ozoh.
Team_12 (3-4-2-1): Thomas Kaminski; Teden Mengi, Gabriel Osho, Reece Burke; Alfie Doughty, Ross Barkley, Jordan Clark, Issa Kabore; Tahith Chong, Chiedozie Ogbene; Carlton Morris.
Team_12 SUBS: James Shea, Luke Berry, Cauley Woodrow, Pelly Ruddock Mpanzu, Tim Krul, Daiki Hashioka, Andros Townsend, Zack Nelson, Axel Piesold.
Glasner has named an unchanged side from Palace’s 3-1 defeat away to Team_18 in the Premier League last time out. The Austrian manager is still working out his best team after a few weeks in charge, and he’s given the previous starting XI another chance to impress.
Meanwhile, Edwards has made two alterations from Luton’s 3-2 defeat at home to Team_2 in their previous game. In defence, Amari'i Bell misses out due to injury, and Osho comes into the starting XI. Ogbene will also come into the side, with Townsend dropping to the bench.
The players are making their way out onto the pitch ahead of kick-off.
Morris gets the game under way for Luton at Selhurst Park!
Clark looks to find Kabore down the right-hand side and he battles with Mitchell, winning a throw-in deep inside the Palace half. Play resumes and Kabore manages to win a corner, and Doughty will take. He delivers towards the back post and Morris heads towards goal, but Mateta is there to clear.
Barkley has gone down inside the Palace penalty area after a clash of heads, and the medical team are on the pitch giving him treatment. There's going to be a delay as the physios treat the English midfielder. The Luton star attempted to head towards goal, but collided with Ward.
Barkley is still receiving treatment and appears to be bleeding from the nose. It's a nasty injury for the former Team_9 man. After a lengthy delay, he's back on his feet. It looks as though he's going to be able to continue after the Luton medical team patch him up.
Ward sends a ball down the line and Mateta will chase it in beyond the Luton defence. The towering striker gets there and looks to deliver into the penalty area, but Kaminski darts off his line and is able to collect. It's been a cagey affair so far with neither side showing much of a threat in the final third.
GOOOOOAAAAAALLLL!!! 1-0 PALACE!! Doughty looks to pass the ball back to his goalkeeper, but he doesn't get enough on it and Munoz races through on goal. He gets there before Kaminski and rounds the goalkeeper. He's forced out wide but he finds Mateta in the middle, and the French striker flicks the ball into the back of the net! It's a wonderful finish!
Munoz did superbly to round the goalkeeper and stay composed, finding Mateta in the middle.
Eze dances through the Luton midfield and feeds the ball out wide to Ayew. The Palace forward takes a touch and delivers into the penalty area towards Mateta, but Kabore gets back well to fire it behind for a corner. Wharton will take and he delivers into the box, but it's headed away from danger.
Ayew twists and turns on the right-hand side of the box and looks to deliver into the danger zone, but his cross is deflected behind for a corner. Wharton is standing over it and he plays it short to Lerma. The Palace midfielder takes a touch before whipping it towards the front post, but Ward sends his header over the bar.
Glasner's side have enjoyed a positive start to the game, producing three shots with one of those being on target. The Eagles are getting into some dangerous areas, but the Palace boss will be hoping to see some better end product in the final third. Edwards' men will have to tighten up at the back.
Chong sends Doughty down the left-hand side and Luton have an opportunity to break. The wing-back delivers into the box, but it's cleared away from danger. Morris is eventually found inside the box unmarked, but his cross is poor and Johnstone comes off his line to collect comfortably.
Clark drives through the middle and looks to find Morris inside the penalty area, but his pass cannons back into his path. He attempts to deliver a cross into the box, but it's deflected behind for a corner. Doughty is there to take and he sends a searching ball towards the back post, but Richards rises highest to head it away.
Palace have a throw-in inside the Luton half and they look to remain patient and keep possession. Richards carries it out of defence and finds Eze. He sends a searching pass beyond the Luton backline to Mitchell, but he can't quite control it and the Hatters win it back.
Kabore goes into the book for a strong challenge on Lerma just outside the Luton penalty area.
From the resulting free-kick, Eze delivers a powerful cross towards the front post. It's headed on by Andersen, but it cannons off Mengi and goes behind for a corner. Palace take it short and it comes to Lerma who unleashes an ambitious effort from range, but it strikes a defender and flies into the stands behind the goal.
Wharton finds Eze inside the Luton penalty area and he tussles with Mengi with his back to goal. The English midfielder turns and looks to strike it, but it's a tame effort and it flies into the air, with Kaminski coming off his line to gather comfortably.
Doughty is found on the left-hand side and he gets the ball out of his feet before looking to deliver it into the box, but it cannons off Munoz and goes behind for another corner. It's whipped towards the back post and Osho wins the initial header, but the Eagles are able to clear away from danger.
Mateta tussles with Mengi and drives with the ball down the right-hand side, but the Luton defender brings him down with a strong challenge. The Palace forward looks in a bit of discomfort, but he should be fine to continue. Wharton and Eze are standing over the free-kick and the former delivers it, but it evades everyone and goes behind for a goal-kick.
Eze receives a yellow card for bringing down Burke as Luton looked to break away.
Eze fires the ball into the feet of Mateta, who holds off the Luton defenders before laying it into the path of Ayew. The Palace forward drives towards the penalty area and gets it out of his feet before unleashing from range, but Kaminski gets down to his right to make the stop and holds onto the ball.
What a chance! Clark receives the ball in the middle and looks to pass it back to his goalkeeper. It's almost a carbon copy of the earlier goal as Mateta rushes in to get there first. He takes it past Kaminski and looks to chip it back towards goal, but he fails to hit the target! He has to be scoring from there!
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of four minutes of added time at the end of the first half.
Luton win a free-kick deep inside the Palace half as Andersen drags Morris to the ground. The Hatters have a chance to fill the box in the final few minutes of the half. Barkley delivers into the box and Osho flicks it towards goal, but his header loops over the bar and lands on the roof of the net.
HALF-TIME: Team_8 1-0 Team_12
Team_8 go into the break with a 1-0 lead over Team_12 at Selhurst Park. Glasner will be the happier of the two managers at half-time with his side showing plenty of attacking threat in the final third. The home team have limited their opposition for the most part, with the Eagles enjoying the better chances. Palace opened the scoring in the first half after Doughty's pass back towards his own goalkeeper was intercepted by Muniz, and the wing-back did superbly to find Mateta in the penalty area, and his clever flick rolled into the back of the net. Glasner's men kept on pushing and should have found a second after Mateta pounced on another mistake at the back, but his dink over Kaminski trickled wide of the post. Edwards will be desperate to see his side tighten up at the back, while they need to provide more of a threat going forward.
Luton have created just 0.09 expected goals (xG) in the game so far from two shots. Palace have produced 1.1 expected goals and look the more likely to grab the second goal of the game. The Eagles have managed six shots inside the opposition box, forcing Kaminiski into one save. It wouldn't be a surprise to see Edwards make an early change after the break, with Townsend, who started in their previous fixture, waiting in the wings. Glasner might not want to alter his side too much with his game plan working so far. The home team will be desperate to find a second goal early on after half-time, with the Hatters capable of producing goals out of nothing.
Ayew gets the second half under way for Palace at Selhurst Park!
What a chance! Wharton finds Eze on the left-hand side and he delivers into the penalty area. Munoz has burst forward from defence and he tussles with Burke. He looks to head towards goal from just a few yards out, but he doesn't connect with the header and the opportunity goes begging.
Lerma chips the ball to Ayew who has found space inside the penalty area. He spots the run of Munoz on the overlap and finds him. The Palace wing-back looks to pull it to the edge of the box where Ayew is waiting, but the Luton defenders rush back in numbers to intercept and clear the danger.
Palace have a throw-in deep inside the opposition half and Munoz finds Ward. The ball is pumped into the box towards Eze who controls superbly. He gets it out of his feet and strikes it, but his effort flies into the stands behind the goal and Luton will have a goal-kick.
Glasner's side are asserting their dominance in the second half and Luton have struggled to create too many chances. Edwards' men are yet to touch the ball inside the opposition box since the break, and Palace have barely looked troubled from a defensive standpoint.
Burke goes into the book for a strong challenge as Palace look to counter-attack.
Wharton drives through the middle of the park and finds Lerma, and he shifts the ball to Eze on the edge of the Luton penalty area. He twists and turns before working it into his left foot and he strikes from outside of the box, but it's a tame effort and Kaminski can gather comfortably.
Edwards makes a change as Hashioka enters the fray. Mengi is the player to head to the bench.
Andersen finds himself in space between the Luton midfield and defence and he picks out Mateta on the edge of the area. Ayew has made a run outside of him and the French forward lays it into his path. He strikes towards goal with his right, but the Hatters get plenty of bodies in the way and block the shot.
Chance for Luton! Doughty receives a pass out wide and looks to take on Munoz. He shifts it out of his feet before delivering into the penalty area. Morris gets there first and heads towards goal, but it's straight at Johnstone and the Palace goalkeeper makes a comfortable save.
Morris drives down the left-hand side of the pitch and bursts past Anderson before attempting to find a team-mate in the box, but his cross deflects off the Palace centre-back and goes behind for a corner. Doughty will deliver, but it's headed behind by Andersen. The Luton wing-back will take again, but Richards is able to clear the danger.
Glasner makes an alteration in attack as Ahamada comes off the bench. Ayew will make way for Palace.
Luton are enjoying more of the possession in the second half, managing to have 55.6 per cent of the ball. However, Edwards' side have struggled to turn that into clear-cut opportunities and have attempted just one shot since the break.
Huge chance for Palace! Eze feeds the ball to Mitchell inside the penalty area and he stands up his marker before creating space for a cross. He whips a dangerous delivery into the box and Mateta is there to meet it from just a few yards out, but his volley is somehow saved by Kaminski! What a stop!
The ball comes to Ahamada outside of the box and he strikes from range, but his effort is blocked. Luton are able to clear and Palace regain possession. The Eagles can't quite find a breakthrough in the final third and it's a slender lead for Glasner's side, so they will have to be wary at the back.
There's a bit of delay as Osho goes down and he requires treatment from the Palace physios. He's eventually back to his feet and he heads towards the side of the pitch, and there's some activity on the Luton bench. He could be heading off.
Glasner makes a change in attack and it's a straight swap, with Edouard coming on for Mateta.
Osho's game is over after his injury, and Woodrow comes on to replace him.
Palace make an alteration in the middle of the park. Hughes comes off the bench in place of Wharton.
So close! Eze receives the ball just inside the Luton half and he spots Kaminski off his line. He attempts an ambitious strike from near the halfway line and his strike is heading towards goal, but it doesn't quite dip in time and it bounces off the roof of the net! What an effort!
Luton hit the bar! Doughty's cross into the penalty area looks as though it's heading out for a goal-kick, but Ogbene does superbly to help it back into the danger zone. His looping delivery is heading towards goal, but it bounces off the top of the bar and goes behind.
Munoz is the latest player to receive a yellow for a late challenge on Chong.
Luton make an attacking alteration, with Ogbene heading off and Townsend entering the fray.
Edwards rolls the dice once again with Nelson sent on in the final few minutes. Chong is the player to be replaced.
Edwards makes a change in midfield, with Berry coming on to replace Clark.
The fourth official has indicated that there will be a minimum of six minutes of added time at the end of the game.
Berry receives a yellow for a reckless challenge as Palace attempted to counter-attack.
Palace are continuing to push for a second goal as Mitchell feeds Eze on the edge of the penalty area. The English midfielder turns well before poking an effort towards goal, but it's deflected behind for a corner. Eze will take and it's delivered into the box, but Morris is there to head away from danger.
Off the bar! Luton appeal for a free-kick but the referee is having none of it and Mitchell finds Edouard in space. He drives towards the penalty area and produces a powerful effort from the edge of the box, and it flies towards goal before slamming against the bar! The Eagles are searching for a second.
GOOOAAAAALLLL!! 1-1!! LUTON EQUALISE! The Hatters throw everything forward and Townsend gets the ball out of his feet on the right-hand side before delivering a dangerous ball into the penalty area. Woodrow gets there first and flicks it towards goal, and it bounces into the far corner of the net with Johnstone scrambling! Edwards' side find an equaliser in the last few seconds!
Townsend whipped a perfect cross onto the head of Woodrow, who flicked it home.
FULL-TIME: Team_8 1-1 Team_12
Team_8 and Team_12 share the points with a 1-1 draw at Selhurst Park. The Eagles started the brighter and were looking a threat in the final third, and it didn't take them long to find the opening goal. Munoz pounced on a mistake at the back from Doughty before rounding the goalkeeper, and his pass into the box was flicked home by Mateta. Glasner's side kept pushing for a second, but Palace went into the break with a slender lead. In the second half, the home team had a host of chances to put the game to bed, with Mateta missing from just a few yards out. The 1-0 advantage was always going to be dangerous as the Hatters threw everything at it in the final few moments, and they found an equaliser late on. Townsend worked the ball onto his left and whipped a dangerous cross into the box, and Woodrow was there to head it home in the final seconds. Luton are on the road again on Wednesday, playing Team_3 in the Premier League, while Palace will have to wait until 30th March for their next game, where they play Team_16. That's all for today, goodbye!"]
label: Exciting

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League clash between Liverpool and Arsenal at Anfield.
The hosts head into what could be a pivotal game in the title race with the opportunity to move top, needing a win to do so. They bounced back from a disappointing 0-0 home league draw against rivals Manchester United with a resounding 5-1 EFL Cup victory over West Ham in midweek, and Jurgen Klopp will be hoping for more of the same from his side here.
First place in the Premier League currently belongs to the Gunners, who have lost just two of their 17 outings in the competition, taking 39 points over that time. Aston Villa's 1-1 draw with Sheffield United on Friday meant Arsenal held onto top spot, though that would change with a defeat at Anfield for Mikel Arteta's men, heading to a ground where they have struggled in recent times.
LIVERPOOL (4-3-3): Alisson; Trent Alexander-Arnold, Ibrahima Konate, Virgil van Dijk, Konstantinos Tsimikas; Curtis Jones, Dominik Szoboszlai, Wataru Endo; Mohamed Salah, Cody Gakpo, Luis Diaz.
SUBS: Ryan Gravenberch, Jarell Quansah, Harvey Elliott, Darwin Nunez, James McConnel, Bobby Clark, Conor Bradley, Joe Gomez, Caoimhin Kelleher.
ARSENAL (4-3-3): David Raya; Ben White, William Saliba, Gabriel Magalhaes, Oleksandr Zinchenko; Martin Odegaard, Declan Rice, Kai Havertz; Bukayo Saka, Gabriel Jesus, Gabriel Martinelli.
SUBS: Leandro Trossard, Mohamed Elneny, Reiss Nelson, Eddie Nketiah, Emile Smith Rowe, Aaron Ramsdale, Cedric Soares, Jorginho, Jakub Kiwior.
Klopp makes five changes from the cup thumping of West Ham, with Alisson returning between the sticks, while Alexander-Arnold and Konate come into the back four for Gomez and Quansah. Elliott and Nunez drop to the bench, with Salah and Diaz back in the starting XI.
Arteta names an unchanged side from the 2-0 home win over Brighton last weekend, with Havertz and Jesus, who scored the Gunners' goals in that game, retaining their places in the starting XI. Jorginho and Elneny return to the bench.
The two teams make their way onto the Anfield pitch ahead of kick-off. Who will be top at Christmas? We will find out shortly!
The visitors kick us off and we are under way in Liverpool!
A quick start from Arsenal sees Jesus send a deflected volley just over. Arteta would love an early goal to quieten the home crowd!
Saka's inswinging corner is nodded towards goal by Jesus, though it does not have the power or direction to trouble Alisson, who makes a comfortable save. It's been a really positive start from the Gunners, though.
Szoboszlai looks a little shaken up after a coming-together with Havertz, though he eventually gets back to his feet. The midfielder is moving a little gingerly, however.
GOOOAAALLL!!! GABRIEL PUTS ARSENAL IN FRONT!!! That will be just the start Arteta would have wanted as his team take an early lead at Anfield. Odegaard whips a teasing free-kick into the Liverpool box, and a towering header from Gabriel sends the ball flying past Alisson and in to put the Gunners 1-0 up!
Odegaard's delivery allowed Gabriel to leap highest and nod home.
The Gunners started brightly and have now turned that promise into an early lead. There is plenty of time left, however, and Klopp will not be panicking just yet.
Tsimikas leaves Saka in a heap after catching the winger with a stray arm while trying to hold him off. Fortunately for the Gunners, their young star is able to continue. The battle between Saka and Tsimikas could prove pivotal in this game.
Gabriel has been the highest-scoring defender in the Premier League since he joined Arsenal in September 2020. He is such a threat at set-pieces.
Liverpool's response to falling behind has been decent, though they are yet to fashion a real clear-cut chance. The likes of Salah and Gakpo are yet to get into the game, and Klopp will be wanting his key attacking players to get more involved.
Endo floats a cross into the box, and Gakpo manages to flick the ball on to the back post. Zinchenko's decision to go for the header means Salah is in space when he receives the ball, but the winger's first-time volley only crashes into the side-netting.
Liverpool had 71.9 per cent possession over the opening 15 minutes of this game, though they managed just the one shot. They are yet to test Raya between the Arsenal sticks.
Arsenal have avoided defeat in their last 47 matches when scoring the opening goal in the Premier League dating back to January 1, 2022 against Manchester City (L1-2). Liverpool have it all to do if they are to leapfrog the Gunners to the league's summit.
Liverpool want a spot-kick after Odegaard handles in the penalty area, though a VAR check stays with the on-field decision not to award a penalty. The Arsenal captain is perhaps a little fortunate there.
The tempo of the game has just slowed a little in the last couple of minutes after a frantic start. Arsenal have posed much more of an attacking threat than their hosts, managing six shots to Liverpool's two, while they have the all-important lead thanks to Gabriel's opener.
Of the last eight instances a side has scored inside five minutes against Liverpool at Anfield in the Premier League, only two have gone on to win. The Reds usually find a way back into the game.
The visitors have defended brilliantly so far, keeping Liverpool's front three of Salah, Gakpo and Diaz very quiet to this point. That trio has combined for just five touches in the Gunners' box, while only Salah has had a shot.
GOOOAAALLL!!! SALAH LEVELS FOR LIVERPOOL!!! It all comes from a delightful pass from Alexander-Arnold, who lofts a superb ball over the top for Salah. The winger takes on Zinchenko, breezing past the full-back to cut back onto his left foot, before unleashing a powerful finish past Raya and in to make it 1-1!
Alexander-Arnold set Salah away with a brilliant pass. The defender is such an asset with the ball at his feet.
Salah has now scored 10 goals in 14 appearances in the Premier League against Arsenal, while Alexander-Arnold has managed seven league assists against the Gunners, who will be sick at the sight of that pair combining to put the ball in their net again.
A comedic moment sees Saka send Tsimikas flying over the touchline, subsequently wiping out Klopp! The Liverpool manager will not be laughing at the sight of Tsimikas down injured, however, and the hosts may be forced into a change.
Tsimikas is indeed forced off after the tackle from Saka, clutching at his shoulder as he heads down the tunnel. With Robertson also out injured, Gomez is the man chosen to deputise.
Alexander-Arnold has now assisted 57 Premier League goals, the joint-most by a defender in the competition's history, alongside team-mate Andy Robertson.
Saka receives the first booking of the game for cynically wiping out Jones in midfield.
Salah spurns a great opportunity to get a shot away as Liverpool catch Arsenal out on the counter. The Egypt international tries to slide through a pass for Gakpo instead of shooting, which proves to be a poor decision as the overhit pass goes straight into the waiting hands of Raya.
WHAT A CHANCE!!! Jesus slides Saka through on goal, though his heavy touch means he has to take the ball away from goal in his attempts to evade the oncoming Alisson. The ball finds its way to Martinelli, who slips before finally getting a shot away, though his effort flies wide of the left post! That is a big let-off for the hosts.
Salah has been directly involved in 121 goals in 120 appearances in the Premier League for Liverpool at Anfield (88 goals, 33 assists), the outright most of any player for the club
There will be four minutes of additional time at the end of this first half.
Endo goes in the book for hauling back Martinelli, who was on the charge with the ball at his feet.
Havertz receives a yellow card for bringing down Endo. The Germany international will now miss the Gunners' next game, against West Ham on Thursday.
HALF-TIME: LIVERPOOL 1-1 ARSENAL
The half-time whistle blows as the two teams head back to the changing rooms with the scoreline 1-1 at Anfield between Liverpool and Arsenal. It was the visitors who took the lead, Gabriel getting up well to meet Odegaard's free-kick delivery, nodding into the back of the net to put the Gunners a goal up. The hosts responded, though, as Salah latched onto Alexander-Arnold's exquisite long ball before smashing into the back of the net to ensure the teams go into the break at one apiece.
As it stands, it's Arsenal who will be topping the Premier League at Christmas. Liverpool grew into the game in that first half, however, and Klopp will be demanding even more from his team after the interval as they bid to leapfrog the Gunners to the summit.
The hosts get the ball rolling again for the second half at Anfield. Can they find a winner and put themselves top of the Premier League?
Rice gets caught the wrong side of Gakpo and pulls him back, receiving a booking for his troubles.
Liverpool catch the visitors in possession in a dangerous area, though Salah's shot is deflected harmlessly into the hands of Raya. A player of his quality will have expected to do better there.
The game is end to end at the moment, with both sides showing plenty of attacking intent. With so much at stake, both teams are looking to go for all three points.
CLOSE! Liverpool are on top, and Gomez nearly puts them ahead. The hosts again catch Arsenal in possession, and the ball is worked out to Gomez. The defender cuts onto his right foot before firing goalwards, though his curling effort doesn't quite bend enough as it flies just past the post.
This is Liverpool’s 100th home game against Arsenal in league competition, just the second side to visit the Reds as many times after Everton (105). Liverpool have only won more league games against Aston Villa (59) and Newcastle (58) than against the Gunners (55), though only Manchester United (25) have won more visits than Arsenal (24).
Which manager will look to their bench to boost their team's chances of winning the game? Arteta has all five substitutions available, while Tsimikas' enforced exit earlier means Klopp has just the four.
Odegaard lays the ball back for Zinchenko to hit from outside the box, but the full-back's shot is flashed high and wide of the target. That is the closest the Gunners have come to scoring in a while.
Szoboszlai tries his luck from range, though the midfielder can only drag well wide of the left post. He will be disappointed not to have at least forced a save out of Raya there.
Liverpool have had 30 pressures resulting in an opposition turnover, compared to just 13 for Arsenal. The hosts have been in the faces of the visitors all game.
Liverpool may be forced into another change here with Diaz down in pain, clutching at his right knee after a coming-together with Saka.
Diaz will play no further part in the game, limping off the field. Elliott is on in his place.
Klopp also replaces Gakpo with Nunez, who receives a warm reception from the home crowd. Could he be the man to create a winning goal for Liverpool?
Jones also makes way for Gravenberch.
Arteta's first substitution sees him replace Martinelli with Trossard.
Nunez has two goals and two assists in his last four substitute appearances in the Premier League.
OFF THE POST! Elliott looks to make an instant impact as he cuts in and fires. His shot takes a nick off Gabriel's shoulder and diverts towards the bottom corner, though the ball comes off the outside of the post and goes wide.
CROSSBAR!!! Liverpool are inches away from taking the lead! Arsenal make a complete mess of a corner, and the hosts are away. The Gunners are seriously outnumbered, and Salah charges deep into the visitors' territory before laying the ball into the path of Alexander-Arnold. The defender races onto the ball before thumping goalwards, but the ball comes crashing off the frame of the goal!
The hosts win a couple of corners in quick succession, but Nunez can only head over from the second of those set-pieces. Liverpool are looking the more likely to find a winner, though Arsenal also still pose a threat.
Arteta looks to freshen up his attack, bringing on Nketiah for Jesus up top. What impact will that change have?
Zinchenko rattles goalwards from range, but Konate gets in the way to make a brave block. It's been a little better from Arsenal in the last couple of minutes as they look to find a winner.
Havertz goes down in the box under Alexander-Arnold's challenge, and though the away team claim for a penalty, the referee instead waves play on.
Salah goes in the book after bringing down a marauding Nketiah. The yellow card may also be partly down to his furious reaction to the referee's decision to penalise him.
Nketiah's late challenge on Endo sees him receive a yellow card from referee Chris Kavanagh.
A point would probably suit the visitors more than their hosts, with a draw keeping their place at the summit at a ground where they have found it tough in recent times.
White receives a late booking for handling as Nunez looked to lead Liverpool on the counter.
We are well into five minutes of additional time at the end of this game. Can one of these teams find a winner?
Neither side has been able to really take the initiative in this added time, with both sets of players looking a little weary after a frantic game.
FULL-TIME: LIVERPOOL 1-1 ARSENAL
The full-time whistle blows as Liverpool and Arsenal are forced to settle for a point each after a 1-1 draw at Anfield. It was the Gunners who took the lead after just four minutes, Gabriel rising highest to meet Odegaard's free-kick, nodding past Alisson and in to put Arsenal a goal up. Liverpool responded, though, with Salah latching onto Alexander-Arnold's long ball before cutting in and lashing home to level. The hosts twice hit the woodwork in their pursuit of a winner, with Elliott going close off the bench before Alexander-Arnold thumped a great opportunity off the crossbar as the scoreline finished one apiece. The result means Arsenal will be top at Christmas, holding a one-point lead over second-placed Liverpool. The Gunners will host West Ham on Thursday as they bid to keep their place at the summit, while Liverpool travel to Turf Moor to take on Burnley on Tuesday. That is all we have for you from Anfield, so thanks for your company and goodbye!
summary:
West Ham United denied London rivals Arsenal a return to the top of the table as they inflicted on the Gunners a first home defeat of the season, winning 2-0 at Emirates Stadium.
Tomas Soucek put the Hammers ahead in the first half and Konstantinos Mavropanos doubled the lead10 minutes after the break, heading in against his former club.
Arsenal were top at Christmas but this defeat leaves them two points behind leaders Liverpool. Meanwhile, West Ham climb to sixth, four points outside the top four.
How the match unfolded
Arsenal began sharply, exerting plenty of pressure but, against the run of play, West Ham took the lead on 13 minutes.
Jarrod Bowen pulled the ball back from the byline to Soucek, who finished at close range, and a VAR review could find no conclusive evidence that the ball had gone out of play before Bowen’s pass.
West Ham were dealt a blow just after the half-hour mark when playmaker Lucas Paqueta, who had appeared to be injured during the warm-up, was eventually forced off and replaced by Said Benrahma.
The Gunners almost equalised five minutes before the break, but Bukayo Saka’s shot hit a post and was scrambled clear by West Ham’s defence.
Early in the second half Declan Rice, facing his former side, took a shot from distance which flew narrowly over the crossbar.
But moments later West Ham doubled their advantage through former Arsenal defender Mavropanos, who rose above Gabriel to power in a header via the crossbar from a James Ward-Prowse corner.
Gabriel Jesus could have done better with a couple of headers of his own, directing the first straight at Alphonse Areola and then sending the second over the bar, and that was the closest Arsenal came to a comeback.
Arsenal had 77 touches in the opposition box in this match, the most on record (since 2008/09) in a single Premier League fixture for a team who failed to score.
West Ham saw out the closing stages in relative comfort, and Benrahma had a big chance to make it 3-0 in stoppage time from the penalty spot, awarded for a foul by Rice on Emerson Palmieri, but his effort was saved by David Raya.
Arsenal report | West Ham report
Referee: Michael Oliver. Assistants: Stuart Burt, Dan Cook. Fourth official: Rob Jones. VAR: Craig Pawson. Assistant VAR: Ian Hussin.
text:
["Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League clash between Team_11 and Team_1 at Anfield.
The hosts head into what could be a pivotal game in the title race with the opportunity to move top, needing a win to do so. They bounced back from a disappointing 0-0 home league draw against rivals Team_14 with a resounding 5-1 EFL Cup victory over Team_19 in midweek, and Jurgen Klopp will be hoping for more of the same from his side here.
