Team_2 1-1 draw with Team_17 on Friday meant Team_1 held onto top spot, though that would change with a defeat at Anfield for Mikel Arteta's men, heading to a ground where they have struggled in recent times.
Team_11 (4-3-3): Alisson; Trent Alexander-Arnold, Ibrahima Konate, Virgil van Dijk, Konstantinos Tsimikas; Curtis Jones, Dominik Szoboszlai, Wataru Endo; Mohamed Salah, Cody Gakpo, Luis Diaz.
SUBS: Ryan Gravenberch, Jarell Quansah, Harvey Elliott, Darwin Nunez, James McConnel, Bobby Clark, Conor Bradley, Joe Gomez, Caoimhin Kelleher.
Team_1 (4-3-3): David Raya; Ben White, William Saliba, Gabriel Magalhaes, Oleksandr Zinchenko; Martin Odegaard, Declan Rice, Kai Havertz; Bukayo Saka, Gabriel Jesus, Gabriel Martinelli.
SUBS: Leandro Trossard, Mohamed Elneny, Reiss Nelson, Eddie Nketiah, Emile Smith Rowe, Aaron Ramsdale, Cedric Soares, Jorginho, Jakub Kiwior.
Klopp makes five changes from the cup thumping of Team_19, with Alisson returning between the sticks, while Alexander-Arnold and Konate come into the back four for Gomez and Quansah. Elliott and Nunez drop to the bench, with Salah and Diaz back in the starting XI.
Arteta names an unchanged side from the 2-0 home win over Team_5 last weekend, with Havertz and Jesus, who scored the Gunners' goals in that game, retaining their places in the starting XI. Jorginho and Elneny return to the bench.
The two teams make their way onto the Anfield pitch ahead of kick-off. Who will be top at Christmas? We will find out shortly!
The visitors kick us off and we are under way in Team_11!
A quick start from Team_1 sees Jesus send a deflected volley just over. Arteta would love an early goal to quieten the home crowd!
Saka's inswinging corner is nodded towards goal by Jesus, though it does not have the power or direction to trouble Alisson, who makes a comfortable save. It's been a really positive start from the Gunners, though.
Szoboszlai looks a little shaken up after a coming-together with Havertz, though he eventually gets back to his feet. The midfielder is moving a little gingerly, however.
GOOOAAALLL!!! GABRIEL PUTS Team_1 IN FRONT!!! That will be just the start Arteta would have wanted as his team take an early lead at Anfield. Odegaard whips a teasing free-kick into the Team_11 box, and a towering header from Gabriel sends the ball flying past Alisson and in to put the Gunners 1-0 up!
Odegaard's delivery allowed Gabriel to leap highest and nod home.
The Gunners started brightly and have now turned that promise into an early lead. There is plenty of time left, however, and Klopp will not be panicking just yet.
Tsimikas leaves Saka in a heap after catching the winger with a stray arm while trying to hold him off. Fortunately for the Gunners, their young star is able to continue. The battle between Saka and Tsimikas could prove pivotal in this game.
Gabriel has been the highest-scoring defender in the Premier League since he joined Team_1 in September 2020. He is such a threat at set-pieces.
Team_11 response to falling behind has been decent, though they are yet to fashion a real clear-cut chance. The likes of Salah and Gakpo are yet to get into the game, and Klopp will be wanting his key attacking players to get more involved.
Endo floats a cross into the box, and Gakpo manages to flick the ball on to the back post. Zinchenko's decision to go for the header means Salah is in space when he receives the ball, but the winger's first-time volley only crashes into the side-netting.
Team_11 had 71.9 per cent possession over the opening 15 minutes of this game, though they managed just the one shot. They are yet to test Raya between the Team_1 sticks.
Team_1 have avoided defeat in their last 47 matches when scoring the opening goal in the Premier League dating back to January 1, 2022 against Team_13 (L1-2). Team_11 have it all to do if they are to leapfrog the Gunners to the league's summit.
Team_11 want a spot-kick after Odegaard handles in the penalty area, though a VAR check stays with the on-field decision not to award a penalty. The Team_1 captain is perhaps a little fortunate there.
The tempo of the game has just slowed a little in the last couple of minutes after a frantic start. Team_1 have posed much more of an attacking threat than their hosts, managing six shots to Team_11 two, while they have the all-important lead thanks to Gabriel's opener.
Of the last eight instances a side has scored inside five minutes against Team_11 at Anfield in the Premier League, only two have gone on to win. The Reds usually find a way back into the game.
The visitors have defended brilliantly so far, keeping Team_11 front three of Salah, Gakpo and Diaz very quiet to this point. That trio has combined for just five touches in the Gunners' box, while only Salah has had a shot.
GOOOAAALLL!!! SALAH LEVELS FOR Team_11!!! It all comes from a delightful pass from Alexander-Arnold, who lofts a superb ball over the top for Salah. The winger takes on Zinchenko, breezing past the full-back to cut back onto his left foot, before unleashing a powerful finish past Raya and in to make it 1-1!
Alexander-Arnold set Salah away with a brilliant pass. The defender is such an asset with the ball at his feet.
Salah has now scored 10 goals in 14 appearances in the Premier League against Team_1, while Alexander-Arnold has managed seven league assists against the Gunners, who will be sick at the sight of that pair combining to put the ball in their net again.
A comedic moment sees Saka send Tsimikas flying over the touchline, subsequently wiping out Klopp! The Team_11 manager will not be laughing at the sight of Tsimikas down injured, however, and the hosts may be forced into a change.
Tsimikas is indeed forced off after the tackle from Saka, clutching at his shoulder as he heads down the tunnel. With Robertson also out injured, Gomez is the man chosen to deputise.
Alexander-Arnold has now assisted 57 Premier League goals, the joint-most by a defender in the competition's history, alongside team-mate Andy Robertson.
Saka receives the first booking of the game for cynically wiping out Jones in midfield.
Salah spurns a great opportunity to get a shot away as Team_11 catch Team_1 out on the counter. The Egypt international tries to slide through a pass for Gakpo instead of shooting, which proves to be a poor decision as the overhit pass goes straight into the waiting hands of Raya.
WHAT A CHANCE!!! Jesus slides Saka through on goal, though his heavy touch means he has to take the ball away from goal in his attempts to evade the oncoming Alisson. The ball finds its way to Martinelli, who slips before finally getting a shot away, though his effort flies wide of the left post! That is a big let-off for the hosts.
Salah has been directly involved in 121 goals in 120 appearances in the Premier League for Team_11 at Anfield (88 goals, 33 assists), the outright most of any player for the club
There will be four minutes of additional time at the end of this first half.
Endo goes in the book for hauling back Martinelli, who was on the charge with the ball at his feet.
Havertz receives a yellow card for bringing down Endo. The Germany international will now miss the Gunners' next game, against Team_19 on Thursday.
HALF-TIME: Team_11 1-1 Team_1
The half-time whistle blows as the two teams head back to the changing rooms with the scoreline 1-1 at Anfield between Team_11 and Team_1. It was the visitors who took the lead, Gabriel getting up well to meet Odegaard's free-kick delivery, nodding into the back of the net to put the Gunners a goal up. The hosts responded, though, as Salah latched onto Alexander-Arnold's exquisite long ball before smashing into the back of the net to ensure the teams go into the break at one apiece.
As it stands, it's Team_1 who will be topping the Premier League at Christmas. Team_11 grew into the game in that first half, however, and Klopp will be demanding even more from his team after the interval as they bid to leapfrog the Gunners to the summit.
The hosts get the ball rolling again for the second half at Anfield. Can they find a winner and put themselves top of the Premier League?
Rice gets caught the wrong side of Gakpo and pulls him back, receiving a booking for his troubles.
Team_11 catch the visitors in possession in a dangerous area, though Salah's shot is deflected harmlessly into the hands of Raya. A player of his quality will have expected to do better there.
The game is end to end at the moment, with both sides showing plenty of attacking intent. With so much at stake, both teams are looking to go for all three points.
CLOSE! Team_11 are on top, and Gomez nearly puts them ahead. The hosts again catch Team_1 in possession, and the ball is worked out to Gomez. The defender cuts onto his right foot before firing goalwards, though his curling effort doesn't quite bend enough as it flies just past the post.
This is Team_11’s 100th home game against Team_1 in league competition, just the second side to visit the Reds as many times after Team_9 (105). Team_11 have only won more league games against Team_2 (59) and Team_15 (58) than against the Gunners (55), though only Team_14 (25) have won more visits than Team_1 (24).
Which manager will look to their bench to boost their team's chances of winning the game? Arteta has all five substitutions available, while Tsimikas' enforced exit earlier means Klopp has just the four.
Odegaard lays the ball back for Zinchenko to hit from outside the box, but the full-back's shot is flashed high and wide of the target. That is the closest the Gunners have come to scoring in a while.
Szoboszlai tries his luck from range, though the midfielder can only drag well wide of the left post. He will be disappointed not to have at least forced a save out of Raya there.
Team_11 have had 30 pressures resulting in an opposition turnover, compared to just 13 for Team_1. The hosts have been in the faces of the visitors all game.
Team_11 may be forced into another change here with Diaz down in pain, clutching at his right knee after a coming-together with Saka.
Diaz will play no further part in the game, limping off the field. Elliott is on in his place.
Klopp also replaces Gakpo with Nunez, who receives a warm reception from the home crowd. Could he be the man to create a winning goal for Team_11?
Jones also makes way for Gravenberch.
Arteta's first substitution sees him replace Martinelli with Trossard.
Nunez has two goals and two assists in his last four substitute appearances in the Premier League.
OFF THE POST! Elliott looks to make an instant impact as he cuts in and fires. His shot takes a nick off Gabriel's shoulder and diverts towards the bottom corner, though the ball comes off the outside of the post and goes wide.
CROSSBAR!!! Team_11 are inches away from taking the lead! Team_1 make a complete mess of a corner, and the hosts are away. The Gunners are seriously outnumbered, and Salah charges deep into the visitors' territory before laying the ball into the path of Alexander-Arnold. The defender races onto the ball before thumping goalwards, but the ball comes crashing off the frame of the goal!
The hosts win a couple of corners in quick succession, but Nunez can only head over from the second of those set-pieces. Team_11 are looking the more likely to find a winner, though Team_1 also still pose a threat.
Arteta looks to freshen up his attack, bringing on Nketiah for Jesus up top. What impact will that change have?
Zinchenko rattles goalwards from range, but Konate gets in the way to make a brave block. It's been a little better from Team_1 in the last couple of minutes as they look to find a winner.
Havertz goes down in the box under Alexander-Arnold's challenge, and though the away team claim for a penalty, the referee instead waves play on.
Salah goes in the book after bringing down a marauding Nketiah. The yellow card may also be partly down to his furious reaction to the referee's decision to penalise him.
Nketiah's late challenge on Endo sees him receive a yellow card from referee Chris Kavanagh.
A point would probably suit the visitors more than their hosts, with a draw keeping their place at the summit at a ground where they have found it tough in recent times.
White receives a late booking for handling as Nunez looked to lead Team_11 on the counter.
We are well into five minutes of additional time at the end of this game. Can one of these teams find a winner?
Neither side has been able to really take the initiative in this added time, with both sets of players looking a little weary after a frantic game.
FULL-TIME: Team_11 1-1 Team_1
The full-time whistle blows as Team_11 and Team_1 are forced to settle for a point each after a 1-1 draw at Anfield. It was the Gunners who took the lead after just four minutes, Gabriel rising highest to meet Odegaard's free-kick, nodding past Alisson and in to put Team_1 a goal up. Team_11 responded, though, with Salah latching onto Alexander-Arnold's long ball before cutting in and lashing home to level. The hosts twice hit the woodwork in their pursuit of a winner, with Elliott going close off the bench before Alexander-Arnold thumped a great opportunity off the crossbar as the scoreline finished one apiece. The result means Team_1 will be top at Christmas, holding a one-point lead over second-placed Team_11. The Gunners will host Team_19 on Thursday as they bid to keep their place at the summit, while Team_11 travel to Turf Moor to take on Team_6 on Tuesday. That is all we have for you from Anfield, so thanks for your company and goodbye!"]
label: Normal

events:
Hello and welcome to this live commentary for the Premier League fixture between West Ham and Bournemouth live from the London Stadium.
After falling to a disappointing late draw against Sheffield United, West Ham enjoyed a much-needed time to reset with the Hammers not in FA Cup fourth-round action last weekend. David Moyes' side will be looking for an immediate reaction, though, having failed to win any of their last four games prior to today. It's been a busy day of outgoings in the transfer market but those fans travelling to the London Stadium tonight will be keen to see three points from those still in the squad as their side look to put pressure on Aston Villa in fifth following their defeat to Newcastle on Tuesday.
Bournemouth, meanwhile, will be heading into this fixture full of confidence after their comprehensive 5-0 win against Swansea in the FA Cup fifth round last Thursday. The Cherries, however, have lost their last two Premier League games and are winless against the Hammers in their last five games (D2, L3). A win tonight would move Andoni Iraola's side above Fulham and into 12th after the Cottagers drew 0-0 with Everton on Tuesday.
WEST HAM (4-3-2-1): Alphonse Areola; Ben Johnson, Konstantinos Mavropanos, Kurt Zouma, Emerson; Kalvin Phillips, Tomas Soucek, Edson Alvarez; Mohammed Kudus, James Ward-Prowse; Jarrod Bowen.
WEST HAM SUBS: Lukasz Fabianski, Divin Mubama, Angelo Ogbonna, Kaelan Casey, Aaron Cresswell, Lewis Orford, Oliver Scarles, Danny Ings, Maxwel Cornet.
BOURNEMOUTH (4-2-3-1): Neto; Adam Smith, Illia Zabarnyi, Marcos Senesi, Lloyd Kelly; Lewis Cook, Ryan Christie; Antoine Semenyo, Adam Scott, Marcus Tavernier; Dominic Solanke.
BOURNEMOUTH SUBS: Mark Travers, Philip Billing, Max Kinsey-Wellings, Luis Sinisterra, Chris Mepham, Gavin Kilkenny, Milos Kerkez, Justin Kluivert, Romain Faivre.
David Moyes makes four changes to his West Ham side that drew 2-2 against Sheffield United last time out. Vladimir Coufal is suspended after picking up a red card and so Ben Johnson comes in at right-back. Further forward, both Cornet and Ings drop to the bench, while Pablo Fornals misses out altogether, with the Spaniard closing in on a deadline-day move to Real Betis. In their place, there is a first start for new signing Kalvin Phillips after joining on loan from Manchester City, while Alvarez and Kudus return from injury and the Africa Cup of Nations respectively.
Andoni Iraola, meanwhile, also names four changes from Bournemouth's 5-0 win FA Cup win against Swansea. Neto and Smith return in goal and defence to replace Travers and James Hill. Further forward, Tavernier is preferred to Sinisterra, while David Brooks is replaced by Semenyo, with the Welshman having recently completed a loan move to Championship side Southampton.
West Ham have kept a clean sheet in each of their last three Premier League home games. The last time they achieved four in a row came between December and January in 2009-10 under Gianfranco Zola.
KICK-OFF! West Ham get us underway here in London for the first half.
GOAAALLL!! BOURNEMOUTH LEAD! 1-0! What a nightmare start in a West Ham shirt for Phillips. The Englishman is caught in possession on the edge of his box and, under pressure from Christie, gifts the ball to Solanke who slots home past Areola. The goal was initially ruled out for offside but the final touch came off the West Ham midfielder so the goal stands.
OVER! West Ham still haven't woken up here as Bournemouth almost have a second. A free-kick is swung in from the left and Senesi fires just over the bar as he strikes the loose ball at the first time of asking.
That's just the third time that West Ham have conceded a first-half goal at home this season. Not the start that Moyes would have been after from his men.
Bournemouth continue to press high up the pitch and force Areola to go long with the kick. Bowen is leading the line tonight but he hasn't got the aerial presence to outmuscle the Bournemouth central defenders.
Moyes is cutting an animated figure on the sideline as he barks orders at his West Ham players. Smith deflects Bowen's corner behind as West Ham win their first corner of the game.
Ward-Prowse swings in the corner to the front post but the delivery is unusually poor from the Englishman and Bournemouth win a goal-kick.
Kudus does well to hassle Kelly off the ball down the left side but Bowen eventually loses the ball on the edge of the box. Bournemouth break before Cook's long-range effort has Areola worried for a moment but the effort sails well wide of the target.
Tavernier feeds Semenyo and it's a great little run from the winger to get himself into the box. His eventual left-footed effort takes a deflection off Mavropanos but goes out for a corner. The corner is whipped in by Scott but Areola clings on after it flicks off Solanke's arm.
West Ham have not clicked into gear so far this match, with the home side registering just one shot so far this game.
Another well-worked move from Bournemouth as Mavropanos heads Scott's fierce cross behind for another corner.
Scott delivers his ball to the near post but Christie's looping header goes comfortably over the bar.
Soucek pulls back Cook in the middle of the park to give away another foul. That's greeted by more groans from the home fans in attendance who are less than impressed with the start their side have made to this contest.
Dominic Solanke has now scored 13 Premier League goals this season – only Joshua King in 2016-17 (16) and Callum Wilson in 2018-19 (14) have scored more in a single top-flight campaign for Bournemouth.
Ward-Prowse is really struggling out on this left flank. The midfielder has had just ten touches of the ball so far this game, the joint-fewest of any West Ham player so far.
A lovely defence-splitting pass from Cook plays Tavernier down the right side of the box. The winger tries to cut the ball towards Solanke but West Ham clear the threat away.
West Ham line up a long throw-in but it's a poor delivery from the centre-back which gets nowhere near the penalty area. That sums up West Ham's first half so far. The home side do win a free-kick shortly after but Ward-Prowse's delivery is cleared away.
Bowen is having to drop deep to get on the ball which isn't an ideal position for the West Ham centre forward. The Englishman gives the ball away cheaply but Semenyo can't make anything stick with his surging run down the right flank.
SAVE! A huge save from Areola to keep the home side in it. Again, West Ham are dispossessed in the middle of the park and Solanke has the ball inside the box in an instant. He shifts it to Semenyo who should score but blasts his effort straight at Areola who makes the vital stop. That should be 2-0.
A superb delivery into the box from Ward-Prowse as he finally gets into an advanced position down the left side. Bowen throws himself at the cross but can't make contact with the header and Neto is able to push the ball away.
Better now from West Ham as Kudus makes a good run to the byline. His cross reaches the onrushing Soucek but the midfielder can't control his header and it's well over the bar from the Czech international.
A lovely turn from Kudus gives Johnson plenty of space on the right side to whip in a cross. His delivery, though, is poor and goes behind the three West Ham players queuing up in the box.
It's been a far better end to the half for the home side who have enjoyed 80 per cent of the ball in these last five minutes.
Tavernier forces a good save from Areola but the flag goes up on Solanke who was offside in the build-up.
Into the first of two minutes of first-half added time we go.
Another good chance for the Cherries on the stroke of half-time. A lovely pass from Christie opens up the pitch as Solankes surges forward. He slides through Semenyo but his left-footed effort is deflected over the bar for a corner.
HALF-TIME: WEST HAM 0-1 BOURNEMOUTH
West Ham trail 1-0 at the break against Bournemouth after Dominic Solanke notched up his 13th goal of the Premier League season. The Cherries striker has been in fine form this season and took just three minutes to add to his tally at the London Stadium, firing home after debutant Kalvin Phillips was caught in possession. The away side should really be two goals to the good but for Alphonse Areola's smart save to deny Antoine Semenyo's well-struck effort. West Ham grew into the game as the half wore on but they still have plenty of work to do after the break to pull this one back.
Moyes should be pleased with how his side ended the first half but they will need to keep that level up for the entirety of the second half. In particular, the Hammers were very sloppy in midfield and often found themselves caught out by Bournemouth's press.
KICK-OFF! Bournemouth get us back underway after the break.
A slight pause as Solanke goes down following a collision. The Bournemouth striker is back up on his feet, though and good to continue.
Scott whips in a good ball from the left side - looking for Tavernier - but Zouma makes the vital clearance.
West Ham appear to have moved to a narrow diamond in midfield since the break. They will surely be hoping to get Ward-Prowse more involved in open play after he struggled out on the left in the first half.
The home side win a free-kick on the left side in a promising position. There's a lovely arc on Ward-Prowse's cross into the box but Soucek struggles to direct his header on target as it flies wide.
Johnson's cross is cleared only as far as Alvarez but his strike from the edge of the box clatters its way through to Neto who makes a comfortable save.
The home fans are incensed as Kudus goes down inside the area. The winger had the beating of Kelly before going down inside the box but the referee waves the protests away. VAR is taking a look, however.
The referee Tim Robinson is told to head to the monitor. It did appear that Kelly clipped the heel of Kudus on replay.
PENALTY! The referee changes his decision and West Ham will have a penalty and a chance to level up this game.
GOOOAAAALLL!! WEST HAM EQUALISE! 1-1! Neto dives to his right but Ward-Prowse smashes it down the middle and the home side are level.
Kelly, who conceded the West Ham penalty, almost redeems himself as he makes a surging, overlapping run down the left. His cross is looking for Solanke in the middle but Areola does well to parry it out for a corner.
Scott's corner is aimed towards the far post but Zouma rises well to clear it away.
Christie is given too much space on the edge of the box but his clipped, left-footed effort just drifts past the right post.
Kudus is causing real problems down his West Ham right. He draws another foul and this time Christie is shown the game's first yellow card.
Ward-Prowse whips the cross towards the back post but Bowen is unable to direct his header on target through a crowd of players.
Bournemouth make a double change as Semenyo departs for Sinisterra.
Scott also makes way, with Kluivert replacing him.
West Ham also make a change as Phillips departs after a mixed debut. Former Cherries man Ings comes on in his place.
Bowen flies into a fifty-fifty challenge with Zabarnyi but catches the defender late. It will be a yellow card for the West Ham forward.
Cook gifts the ball away but does superbly well to track back and execute a perfect sliding tackle to dispossess Bowen.
Bowen makes a great surging run down the right but a slight deflection on the cross just takes it behind Ings. The Hammers striker recovers the ball, laying it back to Soucek but his effort is blocked by Senesi.
Kelly has hit the turf again and it looks like the defender's torrid luck with injury is set to continue.
Kerkez will replace Kelly as he hobbles off the pitch.
Tavernier whips a free-kick into the box from deep but Johnson does well to win the header before the offside flag goes up.
Kluivert sparks into life down the right but Christie can't figure out his feet as the ball drops to him inside the box and the half chance goes begging.
Cook commits a rather cynical foul on Ings down the right side as the Hammers striker looks to break away. The midfielder is shown a yellow card for his troubles.
Sinisterra is given too much space on the left edge of the box. He jinks inside but his fierce effort is blocked well by the head of Mavropanos.
The corner is whipped in but it's a poor delivery which is headed away easily at the front post.
Both sides are giving it a real go in the final few minutes in search of what would surely be a winning goal. Will either side make the breakthrough?
There will be eight minutes of added time to end this second half.
A late change for Bournemouth as Tavernier makes way for Faivre who makes his first start since returning from his loan spell at Lorient.
Bournemouth aren't hurrying in these final few moments as Smith and Solanke run down the clock in the right corner of the pitch. Perhaps the away side are more than happy with a point at this stage.
The away side work the ball patiently as they look for one final chance but Smith's eventual cross from the right is wildly overhit and flies out for a throw-in.
A late change for the home side as Kudus is replaced by Cornet for the final minutes.
Faivre is shown a late yellow for timewasting.
FULL-TIME: WEST HAM 1-1 BOURNEMOUTH
A sluggish West Ham were held to a 1-1 draw at home against Bournemouth as David Moyes' side missed out on the chance to put pressure on Aston Villa in fifth place. The home side got off to the worst possible start as Dominic Solanke fired home after just three minutes when debutant Kalvin Phillips was caught in possession. Antoine Semenyo missed a golden opportunity to double the Cherries' lead but saw his effort saved by Alphonse Areola. It was a game of few chances in the second half but the Hammers took their one clear chance when a VAR check afforded James Ward-Prowse the chance to slam home from the penalty spot after Lloyd Kelly brought down Mohammed Kudus in the area. The Hammers remain in sixth, while Bournemouth's winless run against West Ham extends to six games. Next up for Moyes' side is a tricky visit to face Manchester United, while Bournemouth host Nottingham Forest. That's all for today - thanks for tuning in!
summary:
Phil Foden produced an outstanding display as his hat-trick put Manchester City two points off league leaders Liverpool as the champions came from behind to win 3-1 at Brentford.
Neal Maupay gave Brentford a surprise lead but Foden equalised just before half-time and he then added his second and third in the second half to claim the match ball.
How the match unfolded
Brentford made one change from their defeat to Tottenham Hotspur last Wednesday with Sergio Reguilon coming in for Keane Lewis-Potter.
The big news for Man City was the return of Erling Haaland, who was making his first start since a 1-0 loss against Aston Villa on 6 December. Kyle Walker, Ruben Dias and Bernardo Silva also returned to the side.
City started the match in control, with Mark Flekken called into action early as he denied two long-range strikes from Julian Alvarez and another from Walker.
However, it was Brentford who took a surprise lead in the 21st minute through Maupay as the French striker raced through on goal before calmly slotting the ball into the bottom-left corner.
Ivan Toney played a large part in the goal, as he held off Nathan Ake, but the official assist went to Mark Flekken, who becomes the first goalkeeper to record an assist in the Premier League since April 2023, when Brighton’s Jason Steele provided a goal against Brentford.
It is also a goal in a fifth consecutive appearance for Maupay in all competitions, his longest-ever scoring run for an English side.
Haaland then had a brilliant chance to equalise moments later when a poor backpass from Vitaly Janelt put him through on goal, but Flekken made another great save to keep Man City out.
Flekken was in inspired form in the first half, making nine saves, the most by any goalkeeper in a opening period since records began, but the visitors scored just before the break through Foden following a mistake from Ethan Pinnock as his header fell kindly to the City player, who finished past the goalkeeper.
Foden followed up his late goal in the first half with an early one in the second period as he got on the end of Kevin De Bruyne's cross and headed it past Flekken.
Brentford pushed for an equaliser, with Maupay, Toney and Christian Norgaard all going close, but they were unable to find their second goal.
Foden then completed his hat-trick and secured the win for Man City with 20 minutes to go as he finished off a well-worked move, assisted by Haaland.
Foden's third strike also meant it was a record number for goals in a single Matchweek, with 45 being scored across the 10 Premier League fixtures over the weekend.
Pep Guardiola's side ended the contest in comfortable fashion as they secure a fifth win in a row to move on to 49 points, two behind Liverpool, who have played a match more. 
Brentford, who have lost seven of their last eight matches, remain in 15th on 22 points, three points above 18th-place Everton.
Club reports
Brentford report | Man City report
Match officials
text:

Further forward, both Cornet and Ings drop to the bench, while Pablo Fornals misses out altogether, with the Spaniard closing in on a deadline-day move to Real Betis. Team_19 have kept a clean sheet in each of their last three Premier League home games. The last time they achieved four in a row came\xa0between December and January in 2009-10 under Gianfranco Zola.
KICK-OFF! Team_19 get us underway here in London for the first half.
GOAAALLL!! Team_3 LEAD! 1-0! What a nightmare start in a Team_19 shirt for Phillips. The Englishman is caught in possession on the edge of his box and, under pressure from Christie, gifts the ball to Solanke who slots home past Areola. The goal was initially ruled out for offside but the final touch came off the Team_19 midfielder so the goal stands.
OVER! Team_19 still haven't woken up here as Team_3 almost have a second. A free-kick is swung in from the left and Senesi fires just over the bar as he strikes the loose ball at the first time of asking.
That's just the third time that Team_19 have conceded a first-half goal at home this season. Not the start that Moyes would have been after from his men.
Team_3 continue to press high up the pitch and force Areola to go long with the kick. Bowen is leading the line tonight but he hasn't got the aerial presence to outmuscle the Team_3 central defenders.
Moyes is cutting an animated figure on the sideline as he barks orders at his Team_19 players. Smith deflects Bowen's corner behind as Team_19 win their first corner of the game.
Ward-Prowse swings in the corner to the front post but the delivery is unusually poor from the Englishman and Team_3 win a goal-kick.
Kudus does well to hassle Kelly off the ball down the left side but Bowen eventually loses the ball on the edge of the box. Team_3 break before Cook's long-range effort has Areola worried for a moment but the effort sails well wide of the target.
Tavernier feeds Semenyo and it's a great little run from the winger to get himself into the box. His eventual left-footed effort takes a deflection off Mavropanos but goes out for a corner. The corner is whipped in by Scott but Areola clings on after it flicks off Solanke's arm.
Team_19 have not clicked into gear so far this match, with the home side registering just one shot so far this game.
Another well-worked move from Team_3 as Mavropanos heads Scott's fierce cross behind for another corner.
Scott delivers his ball to the near post but Christie's looping header goes comfortably over the bar.
Soucek pulls back Cook in the middle of the park to give away another foul. That's greeted by more groans from the home fans in attendance who are less than impressed with the start their side have made to this contest.
Dominic Solanke has now scored 13\xa0Premier League goals this season – only Joshua King in 2016-17 (16) and Callum Wilson in 2018-19 (14) have scored more in a single top-flight campaign for Team_3.
Ward-Prowse is really struggling out on this left flank. The midfielder has had just ten touches of the ball so far this game, the joint-fewest of any Team_19 player so far.
A lovely defence-splitting pass from Cook plays Tavernier down the right side of the box. The winger tries to cut the ball towards Solanke but Team_19 clear the threat away.
Team_19 line up a long throw-in but it's a poor delivery from the centre-back which gets nowhere near the penalty area. That sums up Team_19 first half so far. The home side do win a free-kick shortly after but Ward-Prowse's delivery is cleared away.
Bowen is having to drop deep to get on the ball which isn't an ideal position for the Team_19 centre forward. The Englishman gives the ball away cheaply but Semenyo can't make anything stick with his surging run down the right flank.
SAVE! A huge save from Areola to keep the home side in it. Again, Team_19 are dispossessed in the middle of the park and Solanke has the ball inside the box in an instant. He shifts it to Semenyo who should score but blasts his effort straight at Areola who makes the vital stop. That should be 2-0.
A superb delivery into the box from Ward-Prowse as he finally gets into an advanced position down the left side. Bowen throws himself at the cross but can't make contact with the header and Neto is able to push the ball away.
Better now from Team_19 as Kudus makes a good run to the byline. His cross reaches the onrushing Soucek but the midfielder can't control his header and it's well over the bar from the Czech international.
A lovely turn from Kudus gives Johnson plenty of space on the right side to whip in a cross. His delivery, though, is poor and goes behind the three Team_19 players queuing up in the box.
It's been a far better end to the half for the home side who have enjoyed 80 per cent of the ball in these last five minutes.
Tavernier forces a good save from Areola but the flag goes up on Solanke who was offside in the build-up.
Into the first of two minutes of first-half added time we go.
Another good chance for the Cherries on the stroke of half-time. A lovely pass from Christie opens up the pitch as Solankes surges forward. He slides through Semenyo but his left-footed effort is deflected over the bar for a corner.
HALF-TIME: Team_19 0-1 Team_3
Team_19 trail 1-0 at the break against Team_3 after Dominic Solanke notched up his 13th goal of the Premier League season. The Cherries striker has been in fine form this season and took just three minutes to add to his tally at the London Stadium, firing home after debutant Kalvin Phillips was caught in possession. The away side should really be two goals to the good but for Alphonse Areola's smart save to deny Antoine Semenyo's well-struck effort. Team_19 grew into the game as the half wore on but they still have plenty of work to do after the break to pull this one back.
Moyes should be pleased with how his side ended the first half but they will need to keep that level up for the entirety of the second half. In particular, the Hammers were very sloppy in midfield and often found themselves caught out by Team_3 press.
KICK-OFF! Team_3 get us back underway after the break.
A slight pause as Solanke goes down following a collision. The Team_3 striker is back up on his feet, though and good to continue.
Scott whips in a good ball from the left side - looking for Tavernier - but Zouma makes the vital clearance.
Team_19 appear to have moved to a narrow diamond in midfield since the break. They will surely be hoping to get Ward-Prowse more involved in open play after he struggled out on the left in the first half.
The home side win a free-kick on the left side in a promising position. There's a lovely arc on Ward-Prowse's cross into the box but Soucek struggles to direct his header on target as it flies wide.
Johnson's cross is cleared only as far as Alvarez but his strike from the edge of the box clatters its way through to Neto who makes a comfortable save.
The home fans are incensed as Kudus goes down inside the area. The winger had the beating of Kelly before going down inside the box but the referee waves the protests away. VAR is taking a look, however.
The referee Tim Robinson is told to head to the monitor. It did appear that Kelly clipped the heel of Kudus on replay.
PENALTY! The referee changes his decision and Team_19 will have a penalty and a chance to level up this game.
GOOOAAAALLL!! Team_19 EQUALISE! 1-1! Neto dives to his right but Ward-Prowse smashes it down the middle and the home side are level.
Kelly, who conceded the Team_19 penalty, almost redeems himself as he makes a surging, overlapping run down the left. His cross is looking for Solanke in the middle but Areola does well to parry it out for a corner.
Scott's corner is aimed towards the far post but Zouma rises well to clear it away.
Christie is given too much space on the edge of the box but his clipped, left-footed effort just drifts past the right post.
Kudus is causing real problems down his Team_19 right. He draws another foul and this time Christie is shown the game's first yellow card.
Ward-Prowse whips the cross towards the back post but Bowen is unable to direct his header on target through a crowd of players.
Team_3 make a double change as Semenyo departs for Sinisterra.
Scott also makes way, with Kluivert replacing him.
Team_19 also make a change as Phillips departs after a mixed debut. Former Cherries man Ings comes on in his place.
Bowen flies into a\xa0fifty-fifty challenge with\xa0Zabarnyi but catches the defender late. It will be a yellow card for the Team_19 forward.
Cook gifts the ball away but does superbly well to track back and execute a perfect sliding tackle to dispossess Bowen.
Bowen makes a great surging run down the right but a slight deflection on the cross just takes it behind Ings. The Hammers striker recovers the ball, laying it back to Soucek but his effort is blocked by Senesi.
Kelly has hit the turf again and it looks like the defender's torrid luck with injury is set to continue.
Kerkez will replace Kelly as he hobbles off the pitch.
Tavernier whips a free-kick into the box from deep but Johnson does well to win the header before the offside flag goes up.
Kluivert sparks into life down the right but Christie can't figure out his feet as the ball drops to him inside the box and the half chance goes begging.
Cook commits a rather cynical foul on Ings down the right side as the Hammers striker looks to break away. The midfielder is shown a yellow card for his troubles.
Sinisterra is given too much space on the left edge of the box. He jinks inside but his fierce effort is blocked well by the head of Mavropanos.
The corner is whipped in but it's a poor delivery which is headed away easily at the front post.
Both sides are giving it a real go in the final few minutes in search of what would surely be a winning goal. Will either side make the breakthrough?
There will be eight minutes of added time to end this second half.
A late change for Team_3 as Tavernier makes way for Faivre who makes his first start since returning from his loan spell at Lorient.
Team_3 aren't hurrying in these final few moments as Smith and Solanke run down the clock in the right corner of the pitch. Perhaps the away side are more than happy with a point at this stage.
The away side work the ball patiently as they look for one final chance but Smith's eventual cross from the right is wildly overhit and flies out for a throw-in.
A late change for the home side as Kudus is replaced by Cornet for the final minutes.
Faivre is shown a late yellow for timewasting.
FULL-TIME: Team_19 1-1 Team_3
A sluggish Team_19 were held to a 1-1 draw at home against Team_3 as David Moyes' side missed out on the chance to put pressure on Team_2 in fifth place. The home side got off to the worst possible start as Dominic Solanke fired home after just three minutes when debutant Kalvin Phillips was caught in possession. Antoine Semenyo missed a golden opportunity to double the Cherries' lead but saw his effort saved by Alphonse Areola. It was a game of few chances in the second half but the Hammers took their one clear chance when a VAR check afforded James Ward-Prowse the chance to slam home from the penalty spot after Lloyd Kelly brought down Mohammed Kudus in the area. The Hammers remain in sixth, while Team_3 winless run against Team_19 extends to six games. Next up for Moyes' side is a tricky visit to face Team_14, while Team_3 host Team_16. That's all for today - thanks for tuning in!"]
label: Exciting

events:
Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League clash between Liverpool and Brighton at Anfield.
This could be a pivotal weekend in the title race, with leaders Arsenal set to take on third-placed Manchester City later on Sunday. Ahead of that game, though, Liverpool will bid to keep their own title charge on course with victory at a ground where they are so strong, winning 11 of their 14 games at Anfield in this season's Premier League and yet to taste defeat on home soil, the best record in the division. Prior to the international break, however, Liverpool suffered late heartbreak away at rivals Manchester United in the FA Cup as Amad Diallo's extra-time winner condemned the Reds to a 4-3 defeat.
Brighton's European charge has been dented somewhat by recent struggles in the league, winning just three of their last nine Premier League outings to leave them in ninth heading into this one, six points behind sixth-placed United. However, a shock win here would see the Seagulls leapfrog West Ham into seventh, and that should provide the motivation needed to bounce back from crashing out of the Europa League after defeat over two legs against Roma before the international pause.
LIVERPOOL (4-3-3): Caoimhin Kelleher; Conor Bradley, Virgil van Dijk, Jarell Quansah, Joe Gomez; Dominik Szoboszlai, Wataru Endo, Alexis Mac Allister; Mohamed Salah, Darwin Nunez, Luis Diaz.
SUBS: Cody Gakpo, Ryan Gravenberch, Harvey Elliott, Adrian, James McConnell, Bobby Clark, Jayden Danns, Ibrahima Konate, Konstantinos Tsimikas.
BRIGHTON (3-4-3): Bart Verbruggen; Joel Veltman, Lewis Dunk, Jan-Paul van Hecke; Tariq Lamptey, Pascal Gross, Carlos Baleba, Pervis Estupinan; Simon Adingra, Danny Welbeck, Jakub Moder.
SUBS: Igor Julio, Adam Webster, Adam Lallana, Valentin Barco, Jason Steele, Evan Ferguson, Ansu Fati, Facundo Buonanotte, Samy Chouchane.
Jurgen Klopp makes one change from the cup defeat to United. It's an enforced one as Andrew Robertson misses out after picking up an ankle knock while on international duty with Scotland. Bradley comes in as Gomez slides across to left-back, while Curtis Jones is absent from the squad.
Roberto De Zerbi goes with three alterations from the second leg with Roma as Moder, Veltman and Baleba come in. Lallana drops to the bench, while Billy Gilmour and Julio Enciso are missing from the squad. Welbeck gets the nod up front for his 100th Premier League appearance for the Seagulls.
The two teams make their way onto the pitch ahead of a big game for their respective Premier League ambitions. Who will collect the three points? We will find out shortly!
The visitors kick us off and we are under way at Anfield!
GOOOAAALLL!!! WHAT A START FOR BRIGHTON!!! On his 100th Premier League appearance for the Seagulls, Welbeck has blasted De Zerbi's men in front at Anfield! Liverpool give possession away and Brighton pounce. Adingra brings it forward before the ball is worked into the box, where it sits up nicely for Welbeck to smash goalwards. His powerful effort gives Kelleher absolutely no chance, and Brighton lead 1-0!
Welbeck has marked his milestone game with a goal, becoming just the fourth English player to reach 100 Premier League appearances for Brighton after Dunk, Solly March and Adam Webster.
This is a day that could have major ramifications in the Premier League's title race, and the first goal of it certainly hasn't gone the way you'd have expected. It's crucial Liverpool find a response, though they have plenty of time to find one.
The hosts are getting the ball into dangerous areas but are yet to really threaten. Brighton have largely sat back since going ahead, a dangerous ploy against a side of Liverpool's caliber.
WIDE! As he has done so often for Liverpool, Salah looks to cut onto his left foot and bend a finish into the top corner. This time, however, his effort just doesn't quite curl enough, and the ball flies past the left post.
Welbeck's goal was the earliest a visiting side has gone 1-0 up at Anfield in the Premier League since Tottenham did so in October 2019 (Harry Kane after 47 seconds).
Mac Allister's eyes light up as the balls falls kindly for him to hit and try and score against his old club. However, his former team-mates breathe a sigh of relief as the midfielder's shot flies a couple of yards over the target.
Mac Allister receives the first booking of the game for sending Adingra tumbling to the turf on a Brighton counter. There didn't seem to be too much contact, and the referee certainly hesitated before eventually deciding to blow up and card Mac Allister.
Liverpool are dominating the ball, but Brighton are continuing to look threatening on the counter. The hosts will have to be wary of that, as going 2-0 down would be a huge problem.
CHANCE! Mac Allister picks out a brilliant lofted ball to pick out Salah in the box. Nunez is waiting in the middle, but Salah decides to go for goal himself, and his first-time left-footed volley flies over the crossbar. That was a big opportunity for a player of Salah's quality.
Gross catches his former team-mate Mac Allister with a late challenge in midfield, receiving a yellow card for his troubles. The Argentina international has been left in a heap and looks in a bit of pain.
Much to the majority of Anfield's relief, Mac Allister is up and okay to continue. He has impressed so far in Liverpool's engine room.
After a frenzied opening, the game has just hit its first lull with the tempo slowing. Klopp will be wanting his team to ramp it up again as they look to put the visitors' lead under threat.
Having won each of their first six Premier League games against Brighton, Liverpool have now won just one of their last seven against them (four draws, two defeats).
GOOOAAALLL!!! DIAZ LEVELS FOR LIVERPOOL!!! A corner comes in from the right, and Brighton fail to fully deal with it with a poor clearing header. Salah nods the ball back into the danger area, where Veltman inadvertently nudges it into the path of Diaz. The Colombia international takes it first time, poking into the back of the net at full stretch to make it 1-1! Game on!
The crowd is really up for it now, and it's imperative Brighton don't concede again quickly or this game could get away from them. The Seagulls need half-time, though there's still a good 16 or so minutes until they will receive the sweet relief of the referee's whistle.
Brighton's response to seeing their lead eradicated has been impressive. They threaten down the left again, and the clever move ends with Welbeck blasting into the side-netting. They have certainly given the hosts some real warning signs at the back.
Persistent work from Bradley sees him win the ball back and stride into the Brighton box. He then lays the ball back for Diaz, but the winger can't find the back of the net for a second time as his tame shot is saved comfortably by Verbruggen.
Welbeck manages to get to a ball over the top and cut it back for Moder, but the recipient's shot is deflected over the crossbar and out for a corner, which then comes to nothing.
CLOSE AGAIN! A bizarre moment nearly puts Liverpool ahead as Nunez, on the floor after just seeing a header blocked, manages to swing a leg and flick the loose ball goalwards. It's nearly brilliant, but Nunez's inventive effort takes a nick off the inside of Verbruggen's left leg and deflects wide of the target.
Liverpool have won 23 points from losing positions this season, the highest in the Premier League. That resilience could stand them in good stead again here as they look to add three points to that tally.
As we close in on the break, the frantic pace at Anfield is showing no sign of slowing down. It's been a brilliant first half, and there could yet be more drama before the half-time whistle.
Of Diaz's 15 Premier League goals, 12 have come at Anfield. He has scored in four of his last five home matches in the competition.
We are into four minutes of additional time at the end of this lively first half.
Brighton are unbeaten in their last three away league games against Liverpool (one win, two draws), having only avoided defeat in two of their previous 11 visits to Anfield.
HALF-TIME: LIVERPOOL 1-1 BRIGHTON
The whistle blows to bring an intriguing first half to an end with the scoreline 1-1 at Anfield between Liverpool and Brighton. It was the visitors who took a shock lead within 87 seconds, as former United man Welbeck blasted a powerful finish past the helpless Kelleher to put the Seagulls ahead. Klopp's men responded, though, and after Salah twice went close, he played a key role in Liverpool's equaliser. The Egypt international nodded a loose Brighton clearance into the box, and after Veltman's skewed clearance fell to Diaz, the winger poked into the back of the net to ensure the Reds are on level terms at the interval.
It was a first half that Liverpool certainly had the better of, accumulating 1.24 xG (expected goals) to Brighton's 0.17, but the Seagulls got into some really threatening positions too, and looked potent on the counter. You'd expect the hosts to be the side pressing after the break, but don't rule out De Zerbi's men snatching the three points themselves.
The hosts get the ball rolling again for the second half.
Welbeck receives a yellow card for asking the referee to book Mac Allister following a foul on Baleba.
Van Dijk goes in the book now for hauling Baleba to the turf as Brighton looked to counter.
Brighton have focused one one wing in particular, with 62 per cent of their attacks in the opening 45 minutes coming down the left-hand side, while Adingra recorded the most dribbles of any player in the first half (four). Quansah and Bradley have certainly faced some problems.
CHANCE! Gomez whips a delightful cross into the box for Mac Allister. The midfielder, not known for his heading abilities, tries to nod into the bottom-right corner, but the ball skims off his head somewhat and bounces a couple of yards wide of the target.
Liverpool fans want a penalty as Salah goes down in the box under a challenge from Dunk, but the referee waves away the protests.
Baleba tries his luck with an ambitious effort from range, and it proves to be a very poor decision as he smashes high into the stands, never close to troubling Kelleher.
Gomez receives a blatant yellow card for wiping out Lamptey, who was looking to set his team away on a counter.
Half an hour left to play at Anfield, and as it stands, the hosts are dropping valuable points in the title race. There's no doubt they've been the better team, but they haven't yet converted that dominance into a second and potentially winning goal.
The Seagulls are camped in their own box at the moment, daring their hosts to break them down. They've defended pretty resolutely here, but there's plenty of work still to be done if they are to come away with a shock result.
Nunez cuts onto his right foot and smashes goalwards, but it's straight at Verbruggen, who manages to beat away as Liverpool continue to threaten.
GOOOAAALLL!!! WHAT A GOAL!!! It's a brilliant move that allows Salah to stroke home and make it 2-1! Szoboszlai fizzes a pass from out wide into Mac Allister, who takes a touch before quickly laying into the path of Salah. The winger brings the ball under his spell, before coolly placing a superb left-footed finish past Verbruggen and into the bottom-left corner to put Liverpool into the lead at Anfield!
Mac Allister has impressed here, and he superbly controlled Szoboszlai's pass before teeing up Salah to finish.
Salah has been directly involved in 15 Premier League goals against Brighton (nine goals, six assists), his most against a single opponent. He absolutely loves playing the Seagulls.
The first change of the contest comes from De Zerbi, who brings on Buonanotte for Lamptey.
GOOOAAALLL!!! Or is it??? Diaz thinks he has put Liverpool 3-1 up as he gets onto the end of Salah's perfectly weighted throughball, before his shot goes straight through Verbruggen. He wheels off to celebrate, but the flag goes up for offside to curtail the jubilant scenes. There will be a VAR check, however...
As we await the outcome of the VAR check to see whether Liverpool are 3-1 up, Van Hecke is booked for a foul in the build-up to Diaz's finish.
NO GOAL!!! It remains 2-1 as the linesman's decision to award offside is confirmed to be correct, with Diaz's 'goal' ruled out. There really wasn't much in it, though!
Liverpool charge forward on the counter, with Diaz laying it to his left for Salah. The Egypt international gets into the box, but his effort doesn't seriously trouble Verbruggen, who gets down low to make the save.
Mac Allister has now registered five Premier League assists for Liverpool (24 appearances) - as many as he had in his Brighton career in the competition (98 appearances).
Most of Brighton's threat in this game has been on the counter-attack. Now they have to be the side pressing, it'll be interesting to see if they can conjure up the same problems for Liverpool.
SAVE! Dunk gets up brilliantly to meet Gross' free-kick delivery into the box, and his header looks to be sneaking into the bottom corner, until Kelleher gets down to his left to tip past the post.
It's not been Nunez's most active game, and he is replaced by Elliott for these closing exchanges.
Adingra has caused Liverpool real problems here but now makes way for Ferguson, who will hope to give Brighton a bit more physical presence up top.
Lallana enters the fray against his former side for Moder.
Five minutes left at Anfield, and the visitors aren't exactly hammering the door down in their pursuit of an equaliser. In fact, it's the hosts who look the more likely to grab the fourth goal of this game and secure the three points.
CHANCE! Lallana nearly finds a leveller against his old club after he is picked out in the box, though his low shot dribbles a couple of yards wide of the left post. That would've been some story if he was the man to break Liverpool hearts!
Endo is yellow-carded for cynically pulling the marauding Van Hecke to the turf.
Having scored his side's leveller earlier on, Diaz is replaced by Gakpo.
WHAT A SAVE!!! Verbruggen makes an extraordinary stop to keep his side in the game! After a neat Liverpool move down the right, Salah pounces upon a loose ball in the Brighton box. He fires towards the bottom corner with the help of a deflection, but somehow, Verbruggen gets down to his right to get a strong hand to the attempt and ensure his team still has a chance of a result.
We are well into six minutes of additional time at the end of this game. It's nervy at Anfield now!
Barco joins the action for the closing stages, on in place of Estupinan.
As Klopp looks to see the game out, he brings on Gravenberch for Szoboszlai.
Salah tries to kill the game off by catching Verbruggen out at his near post, but the winger drags his effort wide right of the target.
Gakpo now sees yellow for pulling back Veltman.
FULL-TIME: LIVERPOOL 2-1 BRIGHTON
The full-time whistle brings sighs of relief around Anfield as Liverpool run out 2-1 winners over Brighton to move top of the Premier League, at least until City take on Arsenal later on Sunday. The Reds found themselves behind after just 87 seconds, Welbeck firing past Kelleher and in to stun Anfield. The hosts would respond, though, levelling through Diaz, before a clever move unlocked the Brighton door again in the second half for Salah to finish. There were a few nervy moments late on for the home crowd, but their team held on to secure another huge three points that move them top and with a three-point lead, at least temporarily. For the Seagulls, they remain ninth having seen their European hopes take another blow. They will look to get back on track when they travel to Brentford on Wednesday, while Liverpool host struggling Sheffield United the following day. That is all we have for you from Anfield, so thanks for your company and goodbye!
summary:
Tottenham Hotspur missed the chance to move level with Aston Villa in the top-four race as they were held to a 1-1 draw at West Ham United in a London derby.
Brennan Johnson fired Spurs in front on five minutes, but Kurt Zouma’s equaliser soon after ultimately proved enough to earn the Hammers a point. 
Spurs remain fifth with 57 points. West Ham, who are winless in their last four matches, stay seventh on 45 points. 
Ange Postecoglou’s Spurs side, who had come from behind to beat Luton Town 2-1 on Saturday, were quick out of the blocks. 
They went in front after a swift exchange of neat passes down West Ham’s right culminated in Timo Werner crossing for Johnson to tuck home from close range. 
The Hammers have now conceded 55 league goals this season, the same amount as they let in throughout the entire 2022/23 campaign. 
Pedro Porro and Son Heung-min went close to doubling Spurs’ lead, but the visitors were pegged back in the 19th minute as Jarrod Bowen’s corner went in off Zouma's back as he attempted a header. 
Zouma has now scored 11 Premier League goals in the last four seasons, with Arsenal’s Gabriel the only defender to find the net more often during that time, scoring 14 times.
West Ham began the second half strongly as they looked to complete the turnaround, with Guglielmo Vicario producing reflex saves to deny Michail Antonio and Konstantinos Mavropanos. 
Antonio then squandered a marvellous opportunity on the hour. Having outmuscled Micky van de Ven to latch onto a long ball, the Jamaica international fired straight at Vicario. 
Lukasz Fabianski was grateful to see Destiny Udogie’s strike in the fourth minute of stoppage time sail into his grasp in an end-to-end finale, as both sides had to settle for a point.
Club reports
West Ham report | Spurs report
Match officials
Referee: John Brooks. Assistants: Simon Bennett, Dan Robathan. Fourth official: Tim Robinson. VAR: Andy Madley. Assistant VAR: Constantine Hatzidakis.
text:
["Hello and welcome to live coverage of the Premier League clash between Team_11 and Team_5 at Anfield.
This could be a pivotal weekend in the title race, with leaders Team_1 set to take on third-placed Team_13 later on Sunday. Ahead of that game, though, Team_11 will bid to keep their own title charge on course with victory at a ground where they are so strong, winning 11 of their 14 games at Anfield in this season's Premier League and yet to taste defeat on home soil, the best record in the division. SUBS: Igor Julio, Adam Webster, Adam Lallana, Valentin Barco, Jason Steele, Evan Ferguson, Ansu Fati, Facundo Buonanotte, Samy Chouchane.

Roberto De Zerbi goes with three alterations from the second leg with Roma as Moder, Veltman and Baleba come in. Lallana drops to the bench, while Billy Gilmour and Julio Enciso are missing from the squad. Welbeck gets the nod up front for his 100th Premier League appearance for the Seagulls.

The visitors kick us off and we are under way at Anfield!
